The intrigue and suspense of story increases the story’s momentum with car chases, attempted murders and a dead witness.  Zandr adds drama to his story when an influential businessman frames  Marconi for murder.THE GUILTY never slows down as Zandri takes his readers on a whirlwind adventure dealing with political corruption, kidnapping and murder.  All these  elements add surprises to Marconi’s investigation.  Readers will have a hard time putting THE GUILTY down.  The mystery is a must read and earn a 5 star ranking.

IT WILL ALWAYS BE YOU is fast moving story built around a young woman looking to find happiness.  While she pursues the challenges of building a career in the field she loves, she learns to deal with betrayal, manipulation, and trust issues.  Ness keeps her readers in suspense when her main female character Elizabeth Murphy finds the person she has admired from a distance might not be the person she thinks he is.  The author builds a world of intrigue around her main male character who has seems to have secrets he is not willing to share.Readers are given the backstory of each of the support characters as Ness introduces them to the storyline.  Murphy has a great supportive family who she wants to share with the person she would like to be with for the rest of her life.  As the author builds the intrigue and intensity of her story she create in her readers the need to keep reading to find out what happens next.Ness gives her readers a scare when an assailant attacks Elizabeth.  Readers see through Elizabeth’s eyes how she deals with nightmares shaking her confidence.  When Elizabeth learns her attacker has a connection to person she loves she is afraid to tell him.  The plot has twists and turns and direction changes.  IT WILL ALWAYS BE YOU  is a great example of how people deal with adversity.  Ness keeps her readers looking to find out what happens right up to the last paragraph of the last page.  This is a must read and earn a 5 star ranking.

FALSE TRUTH #9 story picks up with Jordan Fox recovering from her kidnapping and finding out the drug cartel is eliminating loose ends. The Tampa Police and FBI think they consider Jordan a loose end. Jordan is asked to house watch her bosses house while she is out of town.  Capri and Dexter involves her readers in Jordan’s efforts to land a permanent position at Channel 12 by giving them the backstory of what has taken place since she started interning at Channel 12.  Capri and Dexter continues to expand the storyline as well as add to the history of the support characters and their role in the story.When Jordan returns to work and finds herself in the doghouse for not being a team player, Capri and Dexter provides her readers details of why she needs the job at Channel 12 to help in her efforts to find her mother’s killer.  The assigned story with her colleague Theresa places her on track to a story relating to human trafficking.  Doors are opening for Jordan in her search of information relating to the death of her mother.The story gains momentum when Jordan, Keith, and Theresa track FBI Agent Ryser to the location of a missing woman.  In her effort to be a team player and stay out of investigating crime, Jordan ends up in the middle human trafficking ring.  Capri and Dexter continues to build the suspense of Jordan’s quest for a full time position at Channel 12 and the author builds on Jordan’s nose for news placing her readers next to Jordan as she broadcasts live for a crime scene. FALSE TRUTH #9 is a fast moving mystery filled with intriguing an unpredictable ending.  This story is a must read and earns a 5 star ranking.

John Kurtze Review of THE GANGSTER’S KISS By Ginger RingPages: 250Publisher: Beau Coup Publishing LLCTHE GANGSTER’S KISS transports readers back to the day of prohibition, Al Capone, and the backwoods of Wisconsin.  Readers meet Ginger Ring’s protagonists, Grace Sullivan and John O’Malley.  Ring gives readers backstory of Grace’s family and their role in the storyline. The author also gives her readers John O’Malley’s backstory and details on John’s family and friend’s role in THE GANGSTER’S KISS. Ring helps her readers understand the different worlds Grace and John come from and as THE GANGSTER’S KISS unfolds she shows how John and Grace find a common ground and goal.The author creates several key support characters explaining each character’s role as they enter the story.  Ring’s plot moves at a pace as fast as a light fuse.  Events happen so fast readers can’t turn the page fast enough to see which direction Ring has taken the story.  Grace’s life is in danger not just because her father isn’t alive to protect her from the gangsters and thugs moving into the area.  She knows one of the gangsters is looking to kill her.  Grace’s brother knows of the looming danger and hires John O’Malley to protect Grace.The plot comes to life as Ring descriptive prose tells her readers about all the illegal activity unfolding while Grace’s brother turns a blind eye as a sheriff on the take.  The author introduces romance, betrayal, murder, bribery, love, trust and danger making her story so realistic readers will check history books to learn what is real and what is fiction.  Ring delivers an unbelievable and exciting ending in THE GANGSTER’S KISS.  Ginger Ring’s first book of a trilogy on gangsters of the 1920’s is a spellbinder and is a must read and earns a 5 star ranking.  Ring will hook her readers and they will look for the upcoming launch of her second book about the gangsters of the era, THE GANGSTER’S WOMAN.

THE DYING ROOM FACE OF EVIL keys in on events soon after Police Chief Dan Burnett and Deputy Chief Jess Harris€™ wedding.  Deputy Chief Jess Harris and her team begin investigating murders of prominent citizens of Birmingham. Medical Examiner Sylvia Baron makes a chilling discovery affecting her family as she autopsyâ€™s the victims.  Sylvia is also distracted by secrets of her own personal past and is unhappy with past decisions she has made.Webbâ€™s THE DYING ROOM involves her readers in the stand alone storyline by seeking to solve the murders and at the same time creating intriguing subplots.  The great subplots give Webb an opportunity to expand all of the backstories of each key character.  As the storyline unfolds Webb keeps the readers off balance with each changes direction. The author does not disappoint her FACES OF EVIL fans as she takes them on a fast moving ride through the past and present lives of major players in Birmingham, Alabama.The author keeps transitioning back and forth between Jessâ€™ murder investigations, Sylviaâ€™s pursuit of information resulting from her autopsy discovery, and her decision to correct her mistakes. Readers are given insight to challenges Sylvia faces protecting her secrets and keeping Jess aware of things that related to the victims. THE DYING ROOM expands the trust between Jess and Sylvia, and their friendship becomes stronger when Sylvia shares her concerns with Jess.  Fans will learn interesting secrets of key support characters and enjoy seeing Jess Harris Burnett at her finest moments.  Webb is an expert of mystery and suspense and adds a new dimension in this intriguing story that readers will enjoy.  THE DYING ROOM is a must read and earns a 5 star ranking.Debra Webb launches the first stand alone Faces of Evil THE DYING ROOM.  This is the first of many new cases for Jess Harris and her team.  Congratulations Debra.

Webb and Black end their DANGEROUS PROTECTOR trilogy on strong note.  They give readers a fast moving mystery full of action and suspense.  Claudia, the voice on the end of the telephone who takes care of the Protectors, leaves suddenly for home after her sister calls and says she is in trouble.  The owner of the Guardian Agency knows Claudia is going to need help and sends Protector Nate Jennings to look out for her.Nate knows Claudia is the sexy voice of the Guardian Agency that is always there ready to assist with his assignments 24/7 with just a phone call; her skills on the computer and internet are invaluable.  Webb and Black place readers next to Nate and readers see how much he has wants to meet Claudia.  Now, tension builds between Nate and Claudia when he insists he is going to help her.NOTHING TO LOSE is the strongest adventure of the trilogy.  Debra Webb and Regan Black's Dangerous Protector series as usual have someone in need of help to solve and injustice.  Webb and Regan keep their readers guessing as who the bad guys are and how Nate and Claudia are going to find her sister.  While readers are looking at Nate and Claudia in action in their pursuit of the antagonist, Webb and Regan are creating an interesting chemistry between Nate and Claudia.  Webb and Black create strength and determination in each of their main characters, and show how Nate and Claudia work together overcome their own personal demons.  A must read and earn a 5 star ranking.

WRONGFUL DEATH is the 10th book in the Wade Jackson series.  Sellers involves her readers immediately as if they are inside the head of Detective Jackson as he proceeds in his investigation of a fellow cop’s murder.  There are several subplots set in motion involving Detective Jackson’s personal life and his work.  As the plot picks up momentum, Sellers introduces support characters, explaining each character’s role in the storyline.  As events unfold, Sellers addresses social issues as she shares the backstory of support characters.  The WRONGFUL DEATH plot describes how economics creates staff cutbacks at the Eugene Police Department as well affecting the staffing at the city’s newspaper.  The author continues to keep her readers aware of the history around issues Jackson’s personal life.Sellers keeps increasing the momentum of the story as Jackson and his team deal with their ongoing investigations.  Each of the detective’s cases seems to lead the plot in several different directions, making the reader curious about their connection to the murder case.  In addition to the team of detectives, Jackson makes use of the media to uncover clues and find information to help move his case closer to a resolve. The story’s subplots increase the pace of action and add interesting twists to the storyline.  The subplots cover situations from alcoholism to homeless families to teenage suicide.  Readers are on edge as to what will happen next regarding the investigations and the issues in Jackson’s personal life.All of the open cases increase the challenges facing Jackson, and Sellers keeps readers aware of the progress of each investigation.  Sellers shows how Jackson is dealing with his family issues and still is keeping up with his investigation  to solve the murder.  The author gives readers the backstory of the family issues and an understanding of Jackson’s plan of action to resolve them.  Sellers  demonstrates Jackson’s growth as he deals with juggling his family responsibilities and all of his team’s open cases.  Readers see Jackson motivating his team of detectives, helping them with their investigations while working on his murder case. WRONGFUL DEATH’s ending is so unpredictable, readers might have to go back and find the clues.  Sellers’ latest Detective Jackson is a must read and earns a 5-star ranking.

Jance writes a feel good story with something for all of her readers.  Ali Reynolds, Jance’s protagonist, is going marry B. Simpson.  Simpson and Reynolds decide to marry in Vegas on Christmas Eve.  Ali’s biggest headache was getting everyone to Vegas.  Once she put that issue to bed things came together.Everyone in the family has a role in Ali’s wedding.  Ali’s dad took her grandchildren Colleen and Colin, Christmas shopping and on the drive back to the hotel a car in front of him opens his car door and throws a puppy out.  Colin chases after the puppy to keep him from getting hurt.  Ali’s dad brings Colin and the dog back to Ali.  Simpson and Ali decide they need to look why someone dumped the dog.  Simpson and Ali with the aid of Simpson’s super computer sleuth to find the owner.  THE LAST GOODBYE is far from the normal investigation for Ali Reynolds.  The author gives readers the back story of Ali’s usual investigations. With the information Ali and Sampson uncover they know what needs to be done.Ali wasn’t going to let the issue of finding the dog’s owner interfere with her wedding. She hires a sitter and Simpson and Reynolds went on with their wedding.  Jance prepares her readers for what Ali intends to do with the answer she has found.  Ali is intends to seek justice for the dog and her owner.  Her investigation allows Ali to resolve a difficult situation and get justice for the dog.  THE LAST GOODBYE allows Reynolds and Sampson and extra wedding present.  Jance keeps her readers guessing through the entire story, not giving a hint of how everything ends.  A warm must read regardless of the time of year and earns a 5 star ranking.

Zoe Sharp’s DIE EASY delivers readers a well-developed plot full of action and well-defined characters readers can easily embrace.  She introduces her readers to DIE EASY‘s unknown antagonists who seem to have scores to settle with those attending the New Orleans hurricane Katrina fundraiser, as well as Fox’s past enemies.DIE EASY is a mystery thriller focusing on Charlie Fox’s continuing pursuit of maintaining her new life and career after leaving a career in special forces.  Zoe Sharp’s 10th Charlie Fox Thriller places her readers in the ruins left behind by Hurricane Katrina in New Orleans.  Fox and her estranged partner, Sean Meyer working as bodyguards for a wealthy businessman, travel to New Orleans for a fund raiser for victims of Katrina.  Sharp introduces strong support characters and their role in her intriguing story.  Her plot introduces corrupt politicians, drug dealers, murderers, kidnappers, and Fox’s past enemies all set on fulfilling their own agendas.  All these antagonists have no issue with killing Charlie Fox and Sean Meyer if it is necessary to accomplish their goals.  Charlie Fox is set on not allowing anyone interfere with her commitment to keep her client safe.Sharp takes her readers on a wild ride through historic French Quarter where they see attempted kidnapping, helicopters being shot out of the sky and attempts to kill Fox, Meyer, and her client.  She places Fox on river boat cruise filled with celebrities, thieves, hijackers and a Fox enemy set on ruining or killing her.  DIE EASY increases the adrenaline rush of readers as they experience the twists and turns in Sharp’s plot, well defined characters, and challenges to Charlie’s psyche.  Readers hold their breath wondering what is happening as bullets fly, bombs explode, and people die.  Zoe Sharp delivers a must read suspenseful mystery keeping readers on the edge of their seats until the last page.

Diane Capri with Beth Dexter are embarking on a novel method of delivering a great mystery filled with suspense and intrigue. They are writing the fast moving book as a serial mystery. The title of the series is THE HUNT FOR TRUTH. Each book has the title FALSE TRUTHS - A JORDAN FOX MYSTERY.The series began last October releasing FALSE TRUTH BOOK #1 – A JORDAN FOX MYSTERY. Since their first book release of mystery thriller series, Capri with Dexter have added six additional books to their serial mystery. Readers will find the stories intriguing and captivating. Capri has created a box set of the first 4 books in THE HUNT FOR TRUTH series of her serial mystery series. Set is a great value.

When Diane Capri with Beth Dexter began the HUNT FOR TRUTH SERIES they were planning on giving their readers six novels in the serial mystery FALSE TRUTH A JORDAN FOX SERIES.  Readers responding to the adventures of the stories’ protagonist, Jordan Fox gave the authors a challenge to keep the series moving forward.  The first seven books have taken readers from Jordan’s college graduation to her first day as a rookie at Channel 12.  Jordan needs to secure a permanent spot on Channel 12’s news team first to pursue her career goal and second, to investigate a 5 year old unsolved murder.FALSE TRUTH BOOK #8 places Jordan reviewing her assignment to investigate personal use of drones in Tampa, Florida.  Her personal life is in turmoil with her friends playing matchmaker.  While pursuing her role on the news team, she needs keep her nose out of police investigations.  The action and activity of the story picks up speed as Jordan discovers a possible connection to the crash of a Cessna aircraft, death of DEA agent, and a recording from the pilot describing the UAV coming towards his aircraft.  All these clues stimulate Jordan Fox’s nose for news.Jordan shares information with the police she thinks will help a police murder investigation. While working on her drone story, Jordan makes a connection with her drone video footage, hard clues, and interviews of experts.  She shares her theories with the FBI.  Capri with Dexter continue developing their storyline introducing subplots and several important support characters.  Jordan finds her sharing with law enforcement interferes with her story.  Events unfold very fast and readers standing close to Jordan’s investigations find themselves in the middle of her unfolding story.  Capri with Dexter involve their readers in the excitement of a kidnapping, hostage situation, attempt on Jordan’s life, interviews with Channel 12’s reporter leading the investigation of the 5 year old unsolved murder, and activities hooking readers to read future JORDAN FOX MYSTERY serial stories. Book is a must read earning a 5 star ranking.

FLIGHT 12 – PSI THRILLER is a creative supernatural spy story pursuing international enemy Orlenda Kobach whose goal is to take over the world.  A.K. Alexander and J.R. Rains bring their readers a fast moving story with suspense, thrills, espionage and intrigue.  Readers meet the Psychic Sensory Intelligence who are in Paris to stop chemist Jean-Claude Babineaux who is creating a poisonous virus.  Whoever buys the virus will use it against the free world.The PSI team Kylie Cain, Noah Kensington, and John Herrel work together, each with a special power of psychic ability.  Alexander and Rains quickly bring their readers the PSI team’s back story of their mission in Paris.  The authors share how Kylie Cain and John Herrel are lovers and discussing marriage.  They also give details of the antagonists Kobach and Babineaux and the evil both represent.  Readers are immediately aware this adventure is going to focus on John Herrel and his healing gift.Unknown to his team members Herrel is kidnapped by someone who has betrayed him and the team.  He wants to use Herrel as guinea pig to turn him into a killing machine.  Using manipulation of the facts allows Herrel’s team members to think he has betrayed them.  The authors develop the plot changing  direction several times to keep readers guessing as to what will happen next.  Alexander and Rains grab readers and take them behind the scenes allowing them see what Herrel does to recover. They describe how Herrel kept his team safe while working on his recovery.  Once he is sure of his recovery he needs to find a way to share what he has gone through with Kylie to regain her trust and then the team.  He returns to the United States to talk with Kylie only to find she is in Rome.  He decides to leave for Rome on the next available flight.  He hopes to get to the international terminal in time to catch Skyway’s Midnight Flight 12 to Rome.  Did he get his boarding pass for the flight to Rome?  Must read to see what Herrel ends up doing.  Flight 12 PSI thriller earns a  5 star ranking.

Segment seven of the serial mystery opens a look at what story Capri with Dexter are going to drop in the lap of their energetic Jordan Fox.  The authors continue to enhance the strengths of Jordan but are still making their protagonist work hard for the permanent position of a multimedia journalist in the Channel 12 newsroom.  Jordan keeps showing a willingness to struggle as she hasn’t had time to finish her investigation of a 5 year old unsolved murder.  She is focusing on her job while her friends are trying to get her to add a social life.er first weeks on the job have been very productive even though the assignment desk seems to continue to give Jordan a hard time every time she turns around.  Readers sitting on Jordan’s shoulder know Jordan is gaining confidence and her one friend in the newsroom is working to help Jordan stand up for herself.  Jordan knows she can write better copy and provide better video that anyone on the staff.FALSE TRUTH BOOK #7 introduces readers to the social scene of Tampa and Jordan is out with her best friend Claire and her colleague/friend Theresa.  Jordan agrees to meet a friend of Theresa’s at a bar he owns.  Jordan reluctance’s to start a social life is due to her ex-fiancé. While they are waiting at the bar Jordan’s nose for news picks up on a man dropping a roofie into a girl’s drink while she is away from her seat.  The man disappears before Jordan or Theresa can catch him.  Capri with Dexter help readers see Jordan’s unique capabilities of seeing a story before it becomes a story.  They illustrate her skills when she is gets an assignment relating to personal use of drones and she is able to see a story relating to their use.  Looking into how drones in the wrong hands can be dangerous, once again Jordan is willing to risk her own life to investigate how geeks can teach people to turn a drone into a killing machine.  Capri with Dexter are creating a growing intense unpredictable ending and with each new serial mystery in the FALSE TRUTH BOOK SERIES and is set to hook readers to keep investigating at Jordan Fox’s side as she looks for answers.  Readers will look for FALSE TRUTH BOOK #8 for additional clues to Jordan’s secret mission to her pursuit of a seat at the Channel 12 news table.

Capri with Dexter are creating a mystery full of interesting support characters and an engaging protagonist, Jordan Fox.  From the beginning of their serial mystery the authors have given readers an opportunity to see Jordan Fox begin to overcome some of her doubts and understand she has what her best friend Claire describes as a nose for news.When readers turn the first page of FALSE TRUTH BOOK #6, they are given insight to the events unfolding as the medical missionary team boards their plane to return to Miami and then on to Tampa.  Capri with Dexter give readers a look at how the turn of events at the grassy air strip have set in concrete Jordan Fox’s determination to write and air the dramatic truths on Channel 12 news.The action from the last few pages in BOOK #5 gave Jordan energy to plan the best way to unveil the information she found in Haiti.  While she is not sure who to trust from the missionary team, Jordan immediately knows two important people she can trust with the details of her story.  Jordan Fox is still on shaky ground in the news room at Channel 12, as she is still learning how to walk the tight rope of meeting deadlines.  The self-doubt returns and she worries she has lost her job. The authors demonstrate Jordan’s growth as she exercises her conviction to expose the illegal drug ring and help her friend at the police department bring people to justice regardless of what happens at work.  Readers won’t be able to put FALSE TRUTH BOOK #6 down until they find out what happens and find the hook in serial segment #6 to look forward to FALSE Truth BOOK #7 A JORDAN FOX MYSTERY.

Diane Capri with Beth Dexter continue to create a serial mystery hooking readers with their suspenseful plot and intriguing well developed characters. Their protagonist, Jordan Fox captures the hearts of readers as she fights for her story even if it put her own life in jeopardy.The fifth segment of FALSE TRUTH starts out with adventure and thrills as Jordan continues covering the medical mission trip to Haiti.  Readers walk down the path at Jordan’s side experiencing her feelings and worries when she learns she is cut off from her father and friends. Capri with Dexter continue to provide their readers with new details of Jordan’s backstory.  The authors also show how Jordan has grown stronger and more confident as the story progresses.  Jordan’s lack of access to the internet at the missionary camp makes researching her stories difficult adding to her frustration of being unable communicate with anyone.The authors create sub-plots adding support characters to their storyline in FALSE TRUTH BOOK #5. Jordan pursues background information on the people who support the medical missionary work.  She finds some of the staff are keeping secrets regarding a woman’s kidnapping.  She accepts and invitation to leave camp to investigate a source of illegal drugs.  Capri with Dexter build tension as Jordan uncovers information that has a connection to people in her home town of Tampa.  Jordan has found her hard news story and now has to smuggle the information out of Haiti.  The authors expand and strengthen Jordan’s ability to deal with the adversity she encounters.  Jordan deals with some unforgettable events as she worries she has put others at risk and makes a commitment to herself to write the story that may have cost some people’s lives.  FALSE TRUTH BOOK #5 A JORDAN FOX MYSTERY’s storyline gives readers goose bumps and chills as they hold tight to the arms of their chairs. Capri with Dexter keep increasing the drama of their serial mystery hooking readers to wait for FALSE BOOK #6.  Capri with Dexter have given life to serial mystery plots building suspense towards their unpredictable ending.

Yes - they're only 4 "sprigs" of elodia - but it's increasingly hard to find as it is classified as an aquatic invasive, closely related to the dreaded hydrilla. But if you are a moral and just person, you can keep some in a warm, well-illuminated tank and propagate it for years to come. (Just don't flush it, or put it into a drain - dry it out and trash it).  Don't be concerned with shipment - my sprigs arrived in good shape - I placed them in pond water in a small tank in a greenhouse, and within hours there were little oxygen bubbles emerging from the photosynthesizing leaves.There's nothing like elodia to demonstrate plasmolysis to students, is there?

Best deal I've found on a larger quantity of these foam type ear plugs. Use them regularly - on planes, while mowing the lawn, even if my spouse starts to snore  ;)  Comfortable, and barely noticeable with excellent noise reduction in all instances. So many in the plastic jar, you can just throw a few in the car and keep them handy in case you ever need them unexpectedly - like in an IMAX move theater with Dolby 27.0 sound with 78 speakers and 10 subwoofers blasting into your middle aged ears.  ;)

No quick burn-out problems here - don't no if those other reviewers are trolls, but I keep this lamp on 8-24 in my classroom, and they've performed flawlessly. Well priced bright illumination for "Frank's Tank".

I've really enjoyed this little pack on some of the day hikes I've taken recently. The hydration bag holds 2L, though I seldom fill it past 1L. There's enough space for the food items I bring, and I can throw my 4/3 camera in the front pocket with no worries. Comfortable contour fit, side mesh pockets for odds and ends, good overall design. I see little reason to purchase a more expensive pack.Not even if you're a camel.
Great deal (cost/pound) on standard hamster food - plus the convenience of not needing to drive to the pet shop to get it!

Just as good as catalogue coverslips - perhaps a bit better given the excellence of the packaging/container. With fast amazon shipping, I was able to plug the whole in my classroom inventory without needing to wait weeks for this little item. Great item, great price, very pleased!

I buy a new Lacie External Rugged Drive for my Macbook Pro each year. Not because I've ever had any problems with them, but only for my own piece of mind. I've needed them twice for a complete data recovery, and each time they've performed flawlessly. They are truly "plug-and-play" on OS X, and Firewire - not to mention Thunderbolt - makes data transfer extremely fast. Love 'em.

3M is still the best - have tried several alternative (i.e., cheaper) brands over the years, but have returned to 3M exclusively. Up here in New England it gets cold, and the house gets drafty, starting in October. The difference when the 3M film is installed is immediately noticeable in our house's ability to retain solar heat, and eliminate the need for evening "warm ups" with the furnace.True winter months are another story, but even then, the film really makes a difference keeping the house warm, and keeping energy costs low. We love these products.

These are great, economical packets for descaling your coffee maker (Dezcal - get it?) We simply pour them through our excellent coffee maker a couple of times, run a rinse through and  - voila! - clean, fresher tasting coffee. Couldn't be more pleased - see no need to purchase more expensive alternatives.
Cheap, yet tightly fitted to the m.zuiko kit lens. Easy to remove. It feels secure - more secure than the original Oly cap I lost. So pleased, I bought another…just in case  ;)

I nice succinct overview of Karajan's very good/great EMI recordings for those who have little desire to invest in the mega boxes that have been reissued. The remasterings are excellent, and there's room in the box to add a few individual EMI discs of personal preference (HvK's EMI Bruckner 4 and some Sibelius) to round out the collection a bit, as I have. At current prices, it's a good deal.

Now that the larger box cited by the lead reviewer has become much more dear, this smaller box provides a much more economical alternative for music lovers who want an overview of Menuhin's artistry. As noted, you get most of the famous "big" concertos with the exception of Tchaikovsky, which may be a deal breaker for some listeners. On the other hand, you will not be spending an exorbitant amount of money for a large box containing many historic recordings of violin bon-mots, and chamber works better performed by others (viz., Beethoven Sonatas)Still, it must be said, that classical music lovers seeking a one-stop overview of the violin repertoire would probably be better served by seeking out Oistrakh's box on EMI David Oistrakh: The Complete EMI Recordings which offers a broader scope, more music, and more consistent musicianship at about the same price point.Still, it's a nice box to complement others on the shelf. I added my Menuhin/Grappelli discs to the box and feel I have enough Menuhin to last me the rest of my life.

This is a large, heavy, substantial watch. That's great if, like the first reviewer, you have large wrists - but if you don't, you're gonna be shlepping a lot of horologe around. It's not thin - the watch alone has a thickness of 3/4 of an inch. How thick is that? I was able to stack 10 CDs on a tabletop right next to the watch. Ten.That said - it is a rather elegant design, as the initial reviewer pointed out. (I don't believe he emphasized the beauty of the transparent case - both front and back - revealing the inner old-fashioned mechanism of the watch).One extremely frustrating aspect is that the band has a clasp design that was virtually impossible to figure out. I've owned clasp band watches - most latch open easily, and then "snap" shut, keeping the watch on your wrist. This one doesn't. The pin that goes into the band holes is in an upright "closed position", necessitating to open the hinged top with amy finger nail, re-latching it, positioning the belt buckle in place, and latching the clasp. Putting the darn watch on was an extremely frustrating experience.  It take a lot of pulling, angling, pivoting, and clasping to figure the darn thing out.  This represents a serious design flaw. Never in my life have I seen a design like this. And I have a masters degree in science.And it's not merely frustrating - the band is uncomfortable.Don't be fooled by the lead Amazon description of Lucien Piccard on this page - there aren't any gemstones on this watch at this price point (don't be fooled by the alleged "list price"). No diamonds, no sapphires - just blue micro-screws holding the front plate on to the under assembly. The overall design is elegant, and I imagine that it would be complemented for its appearance.If I can ever get the darn thing on my wrist. Frankly, I don't anticipate wearing this watch - despite the fact that I got a free review sample. Putting on a wristwatch in the age of the iWatch should not be this frustrating.UPDATE 11/7/15 -  Having lived with this watch for a couple of weeks now, I'm deducting a star and bringing the rating down to 2 stars. Unfortunately - again - it has to do with the watch band, rather than the watch. It is simply awful - it has spontaneously opened and released the watch on two occasions (fortunately, onto a soft surface - no damage!). But I also dread putting the watch on and "fighting" with the clasp. It's become unbearably unpleasant.UPDATE 11/12/15 - the youtube video linked in the comments section below provided good instructions for clasping the band. The NEED for this video, however, just illustrates how non-intuitive this design is. Having successfully locked the watch in place, I anticipate wearing it more frequently! Which is good - it is very attractive.

Love this heater - just love it!Here in New England the evening chill is setting in - already down to the 30s. Not cold enough to start the wood stove, and I'm too cheap to start turning on the furnace. We heat individual rooms with a variety of heaters, including oil filled radiator DeLongie types, as well as the previous favorite the Lifesmart Large Room 6 Element Infrared Heater. Vornado wins - hands down.From the moment you open the box, you know that you have yet another quality Vornado product (I have previously owned their fans). The packaging is superb, offering great protection for this well-designed, colorful unit, Second, you immediately see a reassuring message on the inner box lid that Vornado "wants this product to be PERFECT" (their caps) and "if it's not WE will make it right". When was the last time you read something like that? It's designed and engineered in the US - but, alas, it is Made In China. As Thomas Friedman has said, the world is flat.Once out of the package, and the protective coverings are removed, you are looking at one well designed little unit. Simply plug it in, press the on switch, select your temperature setting and fan speed (low/high) and a warm, SILENT breeze emerges from the heater. It's really delightful. As quiet as a fan can be, and no "oil filled" order, no "red element glow" like the infra red - just a warm steady breeze that warmed our 12-x15 test room with no problem.It's strengths are that it is well designed, guaranteed for 5 years (!), virtually silent, odor free, cool on the outside regardless how long it was on, and has a safety switch on the bottom that turns the unit off if it should tip over.Are there negatives? At this early point, I don't see any. I've put the oil filled radiator in the closet (I've always hated its odor) and have no regrets. My wife enjoys its near silence - both the fact that its quiet, but also that it has the slightest sound of fan-whirl that produces calming sleep-inducing background sound. Again - it's virtually silent. This is not table fan loud. It's really great.Definately impressed, and pleased. It will get regular use in our home, while we sleep, and save money in the process.Well done Vornado! 5-stars!

This has been a great router - with a very easy set up. I cannot write about the technical aspects of this router - I'm basically a basic set-up guy with a multiple users in the house (including a gamer)All I can say is that I'm quite pleased - it seems fast - no problems streaming multiple videos and games simultaneously without hitches - and that was my main requirement.

I guess that I have had a very different experience with this lens than the lead reviewer.That lead review kept me away from purchasing this lens for quite some time. As the standard 4/3 format begins to wither and fade, zuiko lenses have dropped in price and it was possible to purchase this 18-180 zoom for $100 (!). So I thought - what the heck? For that price, how could I go wrong.Needn't have worried, This lens has proven to be an excellent "walkabout lens". It may not be as crystalline sharp as the 12-60 (still my favorite Zuiko lens, along with the 50mm macro) but take a look at these two images taken recently. Couldn't have been more pleased. I've enlarged images to 16x20 and have seen none of the deficiencies outlined in the lead reviews. (If you zoom in on the red maple leaves - an image already cropped - you can still see the silk threads of a web near the top right leaf).So, I'd suggest not hesitating if you're considering this lens if you can purchase it for 150-200. True, it's not the fastest lens, but if you shoot aperture priority 5.6-8 you really shouldn't have any problem. And it's a heck of a lot cheaper than the 50-200 ED.

I've loved this album ever since it's initial release. Given the critical drubbing it received (by friends as well as professional writers) it has always remained something of a guilty pleasure. But re-assessing it now, in its latest re-mastered incarnation, I don't think that Pipes Of Peace requires any apology. It is an immensely enjoyable disc. And now, in its remastered edition, it's better sounding than ever before.The title cut, McCartney's personal response to Tug Of War ("in love our problems disappear" - the melody of the intro alone is something to cherish) displays McCartney's melodic gifts as well as his seemingly effortless ability to pull catchy ear worm melodies out of the air (thinking now of those pipes and drums). While the lyrics still evoke a bit of a wince ("Help me to learn/songs of joy/instead of Burn, Baby, Burn" - ouch) the joyful spirit of the song prevails. In 2015 the message seems more apropos pos than ever before, and truthfully, the song itself seems less labored than McCartney's more recent efforts (Hope for The future, and Love Song To The Earth)What's different is the extraordinarily clear remastering, revealing sound textures and layers never before appreciated. The tablas! The flutes! The early electronics! Listening to this album on a pair of high-end cans is a wonderful experience.The Michael Jackson collaborations range from excellent pop (Say, Say, Say) to the dreadful (The Man - an album low point) Similarly, it needs to be acknowledged that Tug Of Peace is a bit of an enjoyable throw away as is Hey, Hey) Average Person is delightful - one of McCartney's ruminations about typical Joes living the average life he is about as far away from as possible. Similar in theme to both Penny Lane and On My Way To Work from the recent and arguably stronger album "New", Average Person is a bouncy, jaunty ode to an anonymous engine driver, a waitress, and a boxer. It's a minor theme, but McCartney bestows dignity on those folks - they were here today -  by making them the focus of his song.The bottom line is that McCartney has always been blessed, and cursed with a ridiculous amount of musical talent(s). Such excess may lead to greatness ('buff said about that) or mediocrity. On Pipes of Peace, even the mediocrity remains catchy and enjoyable. It's the heights that truly soar.In the case of Pipes Of Peace, the unquestioned heights are So Bad and Through Our Love. The former is an absolutely gorgeous pop ballad. I know a previous reviewer didn't hear it this way, but really - it's just one of those perfect pop melodies that McCartney creates by pulling melodic strings out of the air. Once heard, it is not forgotten. I'm prepared to call it a perfect pop song - a masterful composition. And oh, that simple melodic baseline. Pure Macca.Through Our Love, another McCartney ode to Linda, is simply beautiful. Perhaps not as perfect, not quite as unforced as So Bad, it remains none the less, a memorable love song that any of us should sing to our beloved on a special occasion. (Well, if we could sing like Paul. If only.) It is the type of song no longer being sung in this age of hard edged, cynical, angry pop music. Another song that benefits from the wonderful remastering. The production is an all out George Martin aural-gasm.Between the highs and lows you have perfectly serviceable songs that are fun, buoyant, and catchy. Pure McCartney. And at this point in time, you either enjoy him or your don't. My guess is that you're reading this review, you do. Folks may think of them as  silly love songs, but McCartney has always wanted to change the world with them. And in the long run - who has proven correct?As I've said in other contexts: God Bless Sir Paul McCartney. If you've ever attended a McCartney summer concert, you know just how special a musician and performer he is. to see and hear 50,000 people, whose ages range from 6 to 80 , smiling and singing along with him - I mean what can be said? Who else can do this? Whose songs are as beloved or well-known?Which other performer has brought as much joy, to as many people, all over the world during the past half century as Paul McCartney has?The answer, obviously, is no one. So cut him some slack. Pipes of Peace is not a masterpiece, but it's quite enjoyable. It harkens back to an easier time, and calls to the best in each of us. It documents McCartney's reaching out to a newly emerging star (Jackson) only to have the latter turn around later and stab him in the back (by purchasing the Beatles' catalogue out from under him)  And still, McCartney sings songs of love and peace. And now, they sound better than ever before.The day that there are no new Paul McCartney songs to listen to will be a sad day indeed. Cherish each one.Carpe McCartney.

This is a wonderfully sturdy hitch mount for my two bikes. My mechanic charged me $50 to install it on my rig (so I didn't do it myself) and said it was an easy mount. Our two mountain trail bikes go on easily, are securely fastened, and are easily removed.I appreciate the features of this rack, which include: ratcheting, rubberized hooks that firmly grip the bikes by the top tubes, it locks in place to secure bikes to the rack and protects bike finish from scratches, and sliding cradles with ratcheting straps secure bike wheels to the rack.Best of all, the upright mast folds down for easy access to my car's rear cargo area, and the rack arms fold up for storage when not in use. Oh - and did I mention that it's "Made in the USA"? Couldn't be more pleased!

It may be silly to add yet another 5-star review to this show that has already gotten 14,000+ votes - but let me just say that as a 60-something couple, my wife and I really enjoyed this show. Edgy, but lots of heart - the only scene that rang with falsehood was (unfortunately) the "big scene" in the final episode. Too much, too sudden, too soon. But I think I know where it's going.Guess we'll just have to war for next season to find out!
Great, solid, inexpensive "snap fit" frames - great for displaying 8x10 photographs in an office, classroom, or around the house.
Thanks to all the previous reviewers I've abandoned this product as well - despite the flashy banners, graphics, and promises of amazon Prime rebates. This was disingenuous and reprehensible.

If you do not have many recordings by Richter - certainly one of the titans of the 20th century - this is a wonderfully affordable introductory collection. Or, perhaps you have some of these recordings but couldn't be tempted to start another shelf of Richter CDs for performances that aren't quite top-tier Richter. In either case, this box set - at this price point -  can only be considered an embarrassment of riches for all those who admire and respect the artistry of Sviatoslav Richter.The DG recordings in particular are almost all classics. The Decca and Philips recordings are more hit and miss, containing fine pianism, but fewer of those magical "Richter moments" that collectors salivate over. Some are merely good (Richter never really got Mozart) Most are very good (Beethoven/Schumann - other SR performances excel), some excellent (Liszt, Handel, Haydn, Schubert, Bach, the chamber music, the 20th century music)). The justly acclaimed Philips recordings of the Beethoven Sonatas with Rostropovich contain many sublime moments from each musician, and deserve their classic performance status, as does Disc 34 containing the legendary Sophia recital.  Collecting other Richter moments on individual discs on other labels such as Praga, Orfeo, BBC Legends, DoReMi etc come at a steep price. This box set may serve as the foundation for further explorations, or as a worthy supplement to provide a more complete picture of the work of this extraordinary musician.For those interested in a broad overview of this pianists work, this is a solid investment. The recorded sound is generally the finest that Richter had, esp. on the Decca/Philips discs. The cardboard sleeves seem a tad thinner than usual, and its typically inconvenient to need to turn each sleeve's back to the front in order to flip through and see the actual contents rather than the disc number. The flip-lid style box is the sturdiest design I've seen for these boxes - much better than the half-tops that lift off.For those who are interested in fewer discs, but a generally higher level of musicianship - although recorded with significantly lower fidelity -  I suggest holding out a bit longer for the release of the 18 discs RCA set which will contain Richter's legendary Carnegie Hall performances as well as his legendary Brahms PC 2 with Leinsdorf Complete Album Collection.Better yet, purchase both! Here's what comes in this box:THE SET:-The performances in this set cover a wide range of Richter's large repertoire, spanning nearly four decades from 1956 to 1992 that include performances of solo recitals,  concertos, chamber music collaborations and even as Lieder accompanist (Schubert's Winterreise with tenor Peter Schreier).-A lid-off style box containing 49 CDs divided into 3 categories: Solo, Chamber and Concerto Recordings-2 Bonus CDs containing a celebrated recording of Richter and Britten performing works by Schubert. (These are excellent!)-A booklet in English, French and German including photos and an essay by Jed Distler.CONTENTS:THE SOLO RECORDINGSCDs 1-3 J.S. Just wanted to add my two cents - had an excellent experience hooking this stick up to my Oppo blu-ray player, primarily to stream PRIME/Netflix shows/movies. Quick hook-up, and fast streaming, even in my rural area (via Comcast cable). Shows stream in HD quality (projected on a large screen) and most seem to stream in 5.1 Dolby, so I'm pleased! At this price point, it seems like a no brainer.

More, more, more, more, more!!! I know I'm a sucker for this show - a former NYker who loves classical music - but this show is a knockout! Yea, the finale was a little weak, yea no conductor would ever get away with what Rodrigo gets away with (but then again, no conductor is Gael Garcia Bernal, no, not even Dudemal).And it is a consummate pleasure to see Malcolm McDowel in a role worthy of his talent - I've been a huge fan of his ever since If… and O Lucky Man.Regardless - more, please. Encore! More, more, more, more, more -  !

Justly classic performances in classic Philips full-bodied sound in a new budget box format issued under the Decca/Universal imprimatur.  This set could easily serve as a casual listeners sole set of the concertos. Or it sits as well on a shelf beside Schnabel, Arrau, Gilels, and Fleischer.

My wife loved these gloves - soft leather and lace, thin fleece lining provides additional comfort though not insulating warmth. Purchased as dress gloves for style, rather than warmth for snow shoeing in the New England winter. Good for temperate winter nights out and/or driving.

If you are considering this disc, you are no doubt familiar with the work of Arvo Part. Presumably, you have seen this listing as a result of your familiarity with other Part works, like Fratres, Tabula Rasa or the hauntingly beautiful Spiegel Mit Spiegel. If you are, you have probably come to these works through the exemplary singing of the Hilliard Ensemble who have established a very high bar indeed when it comes to Part performance.Polyphony meets, and perhaps exceeds that high standard, on this - their third disc containing music of Arvo Part. The vocal blend of this ensemble, under the direction of Stephen Layton, is extraordinary. Complemented by the state of the art recording provided by Hyperion, this is a treasure of a disc.The selections include many lesser known works composed between 1963 and 2012, each "delightfully fresh and translucently textured" as noted in the well written booklet. This is a disc of classic Part - simple, yet profoundly moving. Melodic and accessible. Music that touches the heart and soul. The standout for me is Solfeggio, from 1963. Upon my initial hearing of the piece, I got up and noted which track was playing so I could note it in this review.  Solfeggio is the earliest piece on the disc, and belies the notion that early Part is characterized atonal cacophony. This piercingly beautiful piece features voices singing the notes of the scale rather than words - each entry shining down like a ray of light from the celestial heavens. Truly, breathtakingly beautiful.Strongly recommended - for fans of of Part, fans of choral music, and fans of Polyphony (of which I am one! For more holiday/seasonal fare, check out their beautiful disc of John Rutter's Christmas Music: Rutter: Music for Christmas )

A great DVD for high school students. I use it as an introduction to Jane Goodall, preceding our reading of her book Through A Window. Conveniently split into the IMAX feature (around 30 minutes) and another "making of" featurette. Making science fun!

Having had good luck with other Honeywell air products including humidifiers and air cleaners, I was looking forward to using this little unit in my office. Alas - it was not to be. This cute little unobtrusive unit revealed problems right from its initial use.I've experience other small cool mist humidifiers, I was aware of their relative drawback (a small mist stream, a need for distilled water, as well as a need for frequent cleaning/disinfecting to eliminate bacteria and to keep the vibrating membrane clean).I did not however, expect immediate problems the first night I used the humidifier. Things started off great - the attractive unit was quiet, produced a great variable stream of mist, and was really quite silent. Unfortunately, at 3 AM that night (!) the fan began buzzing. I tried to ignore it, but within minutes, the volume became intolerable. The tank was full. I tried removing and re-seating the tank. I slapped the motor unit. I tried jostling the unit. Everything. Nothing worked. The fan is quite loud, making this unit unusable.Perhaps this could have been an isolated incident, but unfortunately, this is the same problem experience by the lead reviewer for this unit, suggesting a quality control issue. This - along with a detachable O-ring washer which if not seated properly results in slight leaks - makes this an unacceptable humidifier.Note that this is not a true Honeywell product. The box and manual both state that this unit is manufactured by KAZ industries under license for use of the Honeywell trademark. Honeywell can, and should,  do better. I actually had to throw this unit out.

Richter reigns supreme - even in the recordings in this box set which do not show him at the height of his interpretive powers. Re-sellers are currently charging exorbitant rates for this set. Unless you're a collector intent to put it in an acrylic box for safe keeping, along with your shellac 78 RPMs of Toscanini that were going to be worth thousands some day.There is another box set set for release in January 2015 that includes all of these recordings, as well as Richter's Decca and DG recordings: Complete Decca, Philips & DG Recordings (Limited Edition)A total of 51 discs from the three major labels. Of course, you will still want to supplement these with many of Richter's Praga and Archiv gems, but with the new box set you will have the nucleus of a solid Richter collection.And with all the money you'll save, you can purchase a few of those Pragas as well -
Inexpensive, good quality speaker wire for my secondary audio system. Pleased with this product!
Best, most cost effective replacement option for the Honeywell air purifier - always have been pleased with this pre-perforated product.

Still the best product for rust stains from iron-laden, hard water.My local supermarket stopped stocking this Lime-A-Way product, and has replaced it with the diluted spray bottle. This viscous gel has always worked much better, and I was pleased by amazon's box price.

I'll echo the concerns of others, that Honeywell has devalued their own product by changing the 1600 filter from a single filter to these two independent rings that bring a lot of solid rubber into the process.Meh.
The Real Deal - genuine pyrex flasks at a great "lower-than-the-catalogue" price for your school lab.

A lovely recording of Mendelssohn lovely, though fairly insubstantial, yet understandingly popular, work for piano. While the interpretation won't steer anyone away from other more famous interpreters, the quality of the piano recording - which is quite good - may be the determining factor here.For some reason, amazon has this described as a 3 disc set. It is not. So if you were expecting some bonus discs, a previously unknown extended edition, or bonus commentary (!) ... don't. Other than that, a worthy addition - and edition - for fans of Mendelssohn's popular keyboard work.
A well written overview of current major issues in environmental ethics. More appropriate for college level classes, rather than high school classes though.

Great lab demo table at a price point substantially lower than the science catalogues' cost for the identical item. Easily assembled, feels quite solid - table top looks durable.If you're considering purchasing this through Amazon Prime, be aware that you will not receive it in the typical 2 day period - in fact, despite whatever recent dates are posted on the item description it may take two or more weeks to arrive at your destination due to the desk's mass (hey - it's a lab demo table, I couldn't say "weight", could I? ;)  Amazon may contract with an independent trucking company to deliver it - which, I suppose, makes it an even better deal.

This fusion saved my butt - literally.Just returned from a cross country trip, in a Prius. Great car, but the front seat is a little low for such a long journey. Saw the TravelMate cushion listed as the most cost-effective ortho cushion. I admit, I had some concern re: materials at this price point - would it truly be firm enough to provide lower lumber support? Speaking for myself: it did. It was extremely comfortable, supportive, and durable. No problems with the middle ridge either.Great product, at a great price point - highly competitive with another more expensive cushion I have owned.

Fascinating dissection video, that adults and mature kids who are interested in such things will truly enjoy. My high school students were mesmerized at the tie-in between the anatomy of the lion's larynx and its physiology: the roar. Re-creating that roar with the larynx alone,  "ex corpore" , was an unforgettable sound and sight.

One of the things I dislike about my desktop computer is the shortage of USB ports that are easily accessible. With this, problem solved. You need another outlet for this, so be aware of that, but once you plug it in and hook it up to one of the USB ports on your computer, you have six new ports ready for use. (The device actually has space to plug in seven USB cords, but remember that it requires one on the computer, so the net gain is six.) It took me less than a minute to plug this in, plug in a flash drive and a hard drive, and be up and running with ease. The computer recognizes each device separately and automatically. I don't think I'm exaggerating when I say that this will save me hours of time switching cords over its life.

You pretty much know what you're getting with this assortment, reviews or no reviews. So I'll try to focus on things that might not be obvious. First, be clear that the packages inside here are the Halloween-sized mini candies. The Almond Joy, for example, contains one bar and one almond. The Reese's contains one peanut-butter cup. OK, that part was probably obvious, but I thought it worth mentioning just in case.So the box is ideal for Halloween, and one nice feature is the box itself, which is sturdy enough to prevent crushed candy. There's little chance of getting flattened peanut-butter cups when you open this. Beyond that, the only feature to consider, I think, is the price, but since prices change, sometimes dramatically, I am not factoring them into this review. What you get for your money is about three pounds of quality candies in a box that will keep them safe.

One box of this litter is enough for two standard-sized litter boxes. The box itself is difficult to open (in that it requires some strength to tear open the top flap), but the litter pours easily enough once the box is open. Six cats had no trouble adjusting to this litter from standard, non-clumping clay litter. I did notice little pieces of wood tracked about the house though.As for its ability to mask odor, I found that overall, it does a good job, though when the first cat used it, there was a noticeable odor of feces. That odor persisted for only a few minutes. The clumping ability is fairly good, making it easy to transport clumps from the litter box to the toilet or trash. (I like that this product is flushable and biodegradable.)The biggest factor for me is the cost, something I generally try to ignore in reviews since prices can fluctuate dramatically, but I will say that at the current price, this litter would cost hundreds of dollars for my six cats over the course of a year.

The box contains 16 small pieces, two each of eight different kinds. I shared these with several people at the office, and the uniform opinion was that these candies are good but not spectacular. In other words, they're better than the mass-produced candies but not on the level of, say, Godiva.The packaging, if it matters, is quite nice, and the presentation is too. But of the eight people who tried the chocolates, the taste was the only thing I asked about, and the consensus was as I indicated above.

Anna Shields stars as Emma in this character study that Fields wrote and co-directed. Emma is a young woman who works at an adult store (that sells movies and toys). Her mornings consist of waking up, fighting with her coffee machine, smoking, brushing her teeth, and feeding her dog. Many of her evenings involve dealing with a variety of customers, from a man with obvious psychological difficulties to underage teens to a man who is silent until she speaks, at which point he interrupts her to complain. When she is not at the store, she engages in a variety of hookups with men and women (hence the title, though I should note that the title also refers to the fact that she dresses up in various costumes as part of her job).The movie is more a character study than a plot-driven film. What plot there is involves Mason, a pre-op transsexual who seems to be everything that Emma desires. As the back of the box says, he might be "her knight in shining armor." But Emma's existence throughout the film seems predicated on revealing as little of herself to others as is possible and lying about herself in order to facilitate her hookups. With Mason, it appears that this approach might doom Emma's chances at happiness.I liked the film for a few reasons. One is that despite the prominence of the work setting (i.e., the adult store), the film does not devolve into salaciousness or prurient exploitation. That's not to say that there aren't adult themes or moments that parents would want to shield younger viewers from; there are, of course. But the film itself is serious and is not about exploitation or titillation. I also thought that the acting was generally quite good. Shields herself exhibits surprising personality for someone who spends about half the film trudging through the mundane life she lives. Her ennui is convincing, but when she does have the chance to show emotion, she does so well. Finally, I really liked the way that Emma responds to Mason's revelation about his status as a pre-op transsexual.There is one more thing to note, and it involves the ending of the film. I won't give away anything, but I will note that Little Bi Peep is self-reflexive. In other words, it knows that it's a movie, and it references that fact. To me, that bit worked. For others, however, it might be frustrating, as if the world of the film is suddenly shown to be fictional and the viewers' investment in it therefore tainted.

The first thing I noticed was the scent, which is hard to describe. It was decidedly pleasant and not at all like that of a perfume. I really wish I had a greater command of the language to convey the scent with greater specificity, but I will add that it was somewhat spicy. As for the product's effectiveness, I can't say that it outperformed other shaving creams (or even ordinary soap). It seemed to be, in that respect, pretty much the same as even the dollar shave creams for the most part. There was, however, one significant difference. The AHAVA cream did not come close to stinging or even causing the least bit of discomfort during a second shave of the throat. That discovery was most welcome.

Early in the summer, I used Frontline Plus on six cats. It did the trick, but toward the end of the summer, I noticed a flea or two on a couple of the cats. So I tried this product, and I have not seen fleas since. As instructed, I applied the medicine right between the shoulder blades (same as with Frontline Plus), and the cats responded well to it. They've adjusted.I'd give this product five stars, but I can't be certain of the product's efficacy. Certainly, I have absolutely no evidence that it did not work. But I can't be certain that it did. As I said, I noticed only a few fleas. That I haven't seen any since may be because there was no real problem to begin with but might be because the product really worked. So out of an abundance of caution, I'm giving four stars.

As with all of the "Best American" books, there are hits and misses in this offering, and which articles are hits and which misses is an entirely subjective assessment. I can say that I enjoyed the vast majority of the pieces in this work.When it comes to sports writing, I like the articles that go beyond who did what, that probe the personalities behind the stories, that raise sport in general to a higher level, one that can reflect and, indeed, shape humanity. Perhaps the best story in this category from this book is "Haverford Hoops," about the Haverford College basketball team during the early 1990s. If you've never heard of Haverford--or have heard of Haverford but wonder why it might be included in an anthology of spots writing--, you're no doubt not alone. Haverford (which, in the interest of disclosure, I'll note was my undergraduate school) is a small, liberal-arts school just outside Philadelphia. In athletics, it plays in division III. In the early '90s, though, it might be more accurate to say that the Haverford basketball team played the doormat for the rest of the teams in the division."Haverford Hoops," by Chris Ballard, profiles the impressive winless streak that the team amassed as it threatened the record at the time. It is a story about people who realistically had essentially no hope, not even a distant one, of becoming professional athletes. It is a story about people who went on to become doctors and lawyers. And it is a story about a naively optimistic coach. But what makes the story work is the writing.There are 21 articles in this book, and all have something to recommend them. "Haverford Hoops" stands out for me, but I'd also recommend "One Thousand Two Hundred and Fifty-Eight Pounds of Sons," "The Two Michael Sams," "Precious Memories," and "Sins of the Preacher" as being especially noteworthy.

There isn't all that much to say about a t-shirt, but I'll say what I can. First, the fit was slightly small for the size indicated. So those on the borderline between two different sizes might want to get the larger size. A related point is that the shirt is not that long. Other t-shirts I have in the same size extend lower. This one ends pretty much at belt level. Second, the shirt is soft and comfortable, even right out of the package. So far, the collar hasn't curled, and the shirt did not demonstrate any shrinking out of the wash. I like it, but it's not miles above generic t-shirts. As far as I'm concerned, it's just another shirt.

Here's what I absolutely do NOT look for when I read a book about faith: an author who agrees with me on everything. Reading such an author would be a waste of time. I could, far more quickly, look in the mirror and tell the image I see how wonderful it is. What I look for is new insights, new ways of looking at things, and opinions and arguments that force me to grow, either by expanding my consideration or by mustering up a solid basis to maintain my views."Gifts of the Dark Wood" has a great deal that I don't agree with (and, to be fair, much that I do). For example, the author quotes Forrest Church (a person, not a building or congregation) as having great insight about us by stating, among other things,  "However successful you are, you fail in ways that matter both to you and to your loved ones.  "Beyond all this, your life is stressful, your happiness fleeting, your health insecure.  "You worry about aging.  "You sometimes worry about dying."(The list of statements is much longer.) The author then asks, "How does Forrest Church know us so well? Because Forrest Church knew himself so well." No, I think. I see nothing more than the basic statements that are part of any cold reading offered by a "psychic," the vague generalities that everyone will agree with, to one degree or another. If the book is for "soulful skeptics," as the cover claims, I would think that many of them would wonder whether Church has any real insight at all here.That said, there is, I think, a fair amount of value here. If I am to condense the book's thesis to a single sentence (a risky proposition to be sure), it would be that our worst moments can be the catalyst to much greater things. To some extent, faith figures into this process, but I'm not really sure what the faith is that the book advocates. Author Eric Elnes spends a fair amount of time talking about Jesus, but the book labels itself "A guidebook for spirituality in a post-Christian world." Perhaps for some, this is just the right kind of book. I have a friend who considers herself deeply Christian and believes firmly in reincarnation. So maybe theologically we are moving in a postmodern directions. And I don't believe that one necessarily must adhere strictly and absolutely to a single, historical orthodoxy. So I'm inclined to agree with fellow reviewer Michael Wood that the book is "best suited for those on either extreme of the faith continuum."

I have to agree with most of the other reviewers. This product has several flaws, most notably the means of turning it on and off. (You put on the lid and twist it.) However, in the quest for brilliantly slushy ice, I was willing to overlook that problem. Besides, once I figured it out, it wasn't all that much of an obstacle. My experience, however, did not produce the slushiness I wanted. I was hoping for something that felt smooth. Ideally, I planned to make piña coladas with uniform consistency. Alas, the ice, while crushed, was not made that smooth.I agree, too, with the reviewers' complaints about the lack of sturdiness of this product. The thing just doesn't feel all that sturdy. That said, nothing has broken for me yet.

I’ve read literally hundreds of collections of short stories, and very often, I find that the stories are just small versions of novels. Joy Castro, however, shows why short stories are not just little novels but are a genre unto themselves. If you are looking for stories with beginnings, middles, and ends, you probably won’t like much of what you find in this collection of 28 stories, some as short as two pages and none longer than 18. Some of the stories in this collection might be better described as vignettes or tableaux than stories. But if you are looking for deft portrayals of complex characters in a wide variety of situations, you should be, as I was, delighted by most of the stories here.Castro takes the short-story form seriously and uses its flexibility fearlessly. The title story, for instance, is told backward. Another story (I won’t say which) depends heavily on its title for context: change the title, and you have a completely different story. In other words, these aren’t pithy little tales. They are carefully crafted stories that resist quick consumption. I spent a good 20 minutes on one story, compulsively reading and rereading to try to find as much meaning as I could and admire the craft as much as possible.If there is a theme to this book, it exists in the overlap of gender and ethnicity, with special emphasis on the former. But I think it’s probably better to focus on the quality, which is superb.

In many ways, Don’t Touch is just another YA story about love between two people, at least one of whom has a serious disability. In this case, it is Cassie, who suffers panic attacks whenever she is touched. And yet, she is drawn to Peter, whom she wants to--but cannot bring herself--to touch. He respects her situation but also wants more. So in many respects, there is not much new here. But there is a recurrent--and explicit--set of references to Hamlet here, from quotations before the chapters (or “acts” as they’re called here) to the school play to Caddie’s feeling of deep kinship with Ophelia from the play.So it’s hard to assess this book for me. I’m intimately familiar with the play, having both read and taught it, and I am thus aware that I have more knowledge of it than the average YA reader will. I see at times the author’s sometimes excessive efforts to create parallels between the stories, but I also see the times in which these efforts succeed, especially in exploring the character of Ophelia.So instead, I’ll do my best to ignore the ties to Hamlet and assess the book as a contemporary story about contemporary characters. The two main characters are well drawn and seem realistic. Their relationship is effective, and the portrayal of Caddie’s manifestation of OCD seems sympathetic and realistic, especially as the novel is told from Caddie’s point of view. I suspect that the book will resonate well with teens, especially those who see themselves as different or as outcasts. As Caddie is drawn to Ophelia, so might readers be drawn to Caddie. And if Don’t Touch inspires a few readers to explore Hamlet, all the better.

I have not read any of the previous novels in the series Smashed is a part of, but I did not get the sense that I was missing anything vital. It did seem clear that the characters, especially investigators Jim Snow and Alice James, have pasts that have been developed in previous books, but that’s to be expected.The pair is hired to investigate the murder of a gambler. Their client is the dead man’s ex-girlfriend, and she is probably the most interesting thing in the book, spectacularly inconsistent and unreliable. There’s also a hit-and-run that appears to be related to the murder.I can’t say that the mystery is all that compelling as the book seems to be more about action and mood. Having been to Las Vegas many times, I did enjoy the setting of the book, which goes beyond just the Strip with which everyone is familiar. And the book did pass the time, but I can’t say that I’ll remember it in a month. So my recommendation is qualified. I’d suggest the book as a quick diversion. (I am aware, however, that this recommendation comes from someone who has not read the series, so perhaps those who have will find more here than I did.)

Silence Once Begun is the second of two Jesse Ball novels I’ve read in the past month, and it’s the better of the two. Or perhaps I should say the one I enjoyed more. The premise is fascinating. An innocent man confesses to a notoriously unsolved crime involving multiple deaths. We know he’s innocent, and to some degree we understand why he confesses. He does so because of a bar bet he lost. (Yeah, that’s clear enough.) He is ultimately convicted, sentenced, and executed. OK, simple enough so far.After his wife stops speaking to him, a journalist becomes interested in the case above. After all, after his confession, Oda Sotatsu remains silent up until his execution. So the journalist is drawn to the issue of silence here and interviews many who knew the executed man. And what emerges is a welter of contradictory information. Even the man’s family can’t seem to agree on who he was. In other words, we have Rashomon except that the characters here can’t agree on the person (as opposed to the events in the film and the stories that spawned it).Oh, and for fun, let’s add one more wrinkle to the mix. The author’s name is Jesse Ball. The journalist’s name is Jesse Ball.The style is spare, poetic, occasionally profound, and often cryptic. Silence Once Begun seems to provide few answers but raise many questions. In other words, this is a book to ponder. And it’s generally a pretty good one at that.

The Ballad of a Small Player is about Lord Doyle, on the run after theft, and his time in the casinos of Macau, where he plays baccarat and sinks deeper and deeper into his gambling addiction. The book is also profoundly depressing (which probably is a strength since that depression seems to come from realism). Comparisons to James Bond are inevitable as the game for both is baccarat, a game noted for an apparent air of sophistication and its ability to bestow--or wipe out--great wealth. (A point is in order. As I understand it, there are different variations on the game baccarat. I’ve sat with a friend in Las Vegas as he played a game that appears to be entirely a game of luck with no chance whatsoever for skill, much like roulette. The novel gives the rules here, but it did not seem to me that the rules were actually followed in the book. I may have missed something, but I gather there is no element of skill involved in the Macau game.)Doyle is profoundly self-aware. He is completely in love with gambling and waxes poetic about it throughout the novel. Even his rescue by a Chinese prostitute does nothing to interfere with his gambling. Indeed, he steals from her to continue.The question here is what the novel has to recommend it. The writing, as I noted, is lyrical. There are times--many, in fact--when I thought the author was simply trying too hard. Nonetheless, there is a passion here that elevates gambling in general and each hand in particular above the ordinary. The novel may not be the paranormal story some synopses have suggested, but it does almost make the quest into a sentient character. If the writing doesn’t sell the book, there is the character of Lord Doyle (who is not a lord). He is not precisely sympathetic, but he does have a certain charm, a painful honesty, and a clear voice that establishes him as fully human and thus evokes our sympathy. Put another way, at no point does he come across as someone we would want to court as a friend, but he does seem to be someone we would enjoy watching in a casino and rooting for. And if the language and Doyle don’t work, there’s always the setting, which is as well developed a character as any human in the story.As I say, the story is depressing, but the book is rewarding as an intimate portrayal of a gambler and of gambling. You will come away from this short novel with a deeper understanding of gambling, and, I dare say, it will change the way you look at a casino the next time you’re in one.

Decompression begins by setting up an ideal that is instantly attractive. Sven has fled the bustle of Germany to the Canary Islands, where he runs a diving school with his significant other, Antje. Amid the beauty of the islands, the two have an idyllic life. However, two visitors soon change things. A soap-opera star (Jola) and a writer (Theo) show up, and things change quickly. The two new arrivals hire Sven’s services for a week, and Sven quickly finds himself besotted. He spends time online watching Jola’s performances. Meanwhile, the two couples begin to provoke each other into increasingly high-stakes dares.Where the novel departs from what we’ve seen and read many times before is in Jola’s journal entries. It turns out that her perception of events does not quite square with Sven’s. Theo, initially somewhat amused by Sven’s infatuation, grows less tolerant and ultimately decidedly hostile. And as Sven’s fortieth birthday approaches, events reach a critical point.Decompression is more of a psychological thriller than a mystery or action thriller, and it suffers from a somewhat serious problem, at least for me. Sven is not an appealing person. His attraction to Jola is understandable, I suppose, but understanding something does not mean liking it. Nonetheless, I might still have rooted for Sven were it not for his treatment of Antje, which seems to border on cruel at times. (The words “seems to border on” are actually understatement. He is cruel and dismissive.) Still, the setting, the inevitability of something very bad happening, and the desire to know the resolution kept me turning the pages, and I did enjoy the book, albeit marginally.

Many young or new writers are told the write what they know. Greg Kihn clearly has taken that advice to heart. Painted Black is a lot of fun. And it’s quite a history lesson at the same time. Oh, and there’s a paranormal element as well.Here, Kihn looks at Rolling Stones member Brian Jones’s death. Based on what seems to be equal parts documented truth and inventive fiction, the book follows Jones through the last year of his life before his death when he was found in his swimming pool. (I believe the death is officially attributed to an accident, but there have been theories that he was murdered.) Along the way, Kihn conveys a great picture of what it was like in the world of rock in the late ‘60s. If you are thinking about reading the book for the mystery of Jones’s death, you probably should move on. There is no dramatic revelation here (though there are suggestions).There are a fair number of problems with the book. The meshing of reality and speculation isn’t always seamless. The writing at times is clunky. And there are factual errors. But I trust Kihn’s love of and experience in rock, and I enjoyed the book as a look, however romanticized or ornamented, at much of the time and many of the people behind the rock of the ‘60s and ‘70s. I suppose those with a great knowledge of that background may find more to dislike about the book, but I enjoyed it.
