Oh, and it certainly doesn’t hurt that there are numerous songs mentioned, and many of those mentions brought tunes to mind. I understand this novel is the second in a series, but it reads just fine as a stand-alone.

Getting Even is an example of a book I expected to like much more than I actually did. It’s a story of revenge, and it would have been, for me, a really fun, albeit slightly guilty, pleasure. Instead, I found myself too often questioning the basis for the story.That basis is the longstanding friendship between the ingenuous Orianna and the hardened Ivy. When the former gets a promotion at the place the two work, the latter begins to plot her revenge. The pair are certainly an odd couple, and I can’t help but think of Of Mice and Men as an example of a novel with an equally unlikely couple. However, Steinbeck explains his pair’s togetherness. Here, it is hard to see how two so unlikely (and, frankly, rather unrealistically extreme) characters would form a bond of friendship. And that bond is the key to the novel as Orianna begins to realize, painfully slowly, what is happening and, concurrent with that dawning awareness, tries to dismiss so much of the evidence.So for me, the friendship was always dubious, and the remainder of the novel, or at least as much as depends on that friendship, did not fully work. I can see the appeal here, though, as the novel exposes all sorts of machinations, maneuvering, and deception. But ultimately, I found the story simply lacking in important ways. The ending, whose general terms are clear long before it arrives, may be satisfying, but it's too little too late for me.

I think there are probably three different possible responses to Endangered. As the title indicates, the book is tendentious. It is a novel, yes, but it is clearly advancing a thesis, namely one about the unjust treatment of African Americans in the current American justice system. The three responses I imagine are (1) that here’s a book that tells a truth that too long has been ignored or explained away, (2) that here’s a book that is intent on playing the victim card for an entire group of people by overlooking a variety of salient facts (such as crime rates and more), and (3) that for African-American readers who have gone through this experience, here’s a book that validates their fears, frustration, and misgivings.The story involves teenage Malik, who is arrested for a crime he did not commit. Thus begins his mistreatment at the hands of a justice system that is designed to discriminate, systematically, against the socioeconomically disadvantaged. However, there is possible help on the line, from a White attorney who seems more interested in Malik as a type than as a young Black man facing an unjust charge to a Black attorney who also takes an interest in Malik’s mother.The book clearly is intended to expose a fundamental problem in the legal system, and I suspect that some who read this will dismiss it for a variety of reasons, including the fact that it posits an innocent caught in the system and thus misses a chance to talk about a broader facet, namely the unequal treatment of guilty people. But the story is well grounded in many of the current events of 2015 and certainly should be relatively easy to defend. In particular, I think it’s a fascinating companion to To Kill a Mockingbird, almost as if it’s a response to that book.As for the three reactions above, I strongly suspect those with the second reaction will readily dismiss the plot and point here. But others should find this honest expression of frustration to be generally powerful.

I’m ambivalent about The Man Who Walked Away. On the one hand, I did find it often fascinating and mostly interesting in its exploration of a man who, in a fugue state, walks extensively (and I do mean extensively) and of a nascent psychiatric profession. The problem, at least for me, is that these two aims are often in conflict. The psychiatry of the late nineteenth century was simply not equipped to understand fully the mental states of the characters (including, of course, the title character) in the book. So we emerge from the book with an incomplete understanding of the fictional character Albert. I don’t know what the author could have done much differently, though. The novel is based on an actual man, so the story pretty much has to be restricted to the time and place in which the actual case occurred--unless author Maud Casey wanted to diverge substantially and thus lose a great deal of the flavor of the book.Thus, The Man Who Walked Away is more interesting than it is illuminating. I did see that one of the other reviews calls the book at times pedantic, and I see the basis for that claim. I found the story, however, of Albert and the other patients/inmates quite interesting. I have read also some readers’ frustration with the lack of a relatable character here, and I see that point too. This book may be a novel, but that fact does not mean that we find ourselves drawn to the protagonist (a term that may be inaccurate in this context if it conveys the sense that there is an antagonist). Rather, we have a mystery here, that of Albert’s fugue state, that ultimately is not completely explained. What we get instead is an investigation of the person, more understanding who he is than why he is that way. I enjoyed this investigation, but I was not expecting a standard, linear novel, and so I was not upset by the meandering, almost random, structure.

This book is based on an actual person, an actual time, and actual events. It combines, apparently, careful research and thoughtful speculation. I say “apparently” because I think it’s important that I confess my ignorance of Brazilian history in general and communism in Brazil in particular. It may be that the novel is a gross mischaracterization of the people, the events, and the time, but I wouldn’t know. I decided to trust the author, and my trust rewarded me with an enjoyable read. It may seem that trust here is irrelevant. Given my lack of knowledge, couldn’t I just enjoy the book as a work of pure fiction? The answer is that I gained considerably by believing that I was gaining legitimate insight to a people and a time.The title character comes from a humble background but ultimately becomes involved with a leader of the communist movement. She is ultimately murdered, and the book deals primarily with attempts to explain, Rashomon-like, the woman and the events of her death. The exploration is as much about the culture into which she made her surprising entrance as about the individual, and I can see why many of the other reviewers called the book slow or boring. Had I viewed the book merely as a novel, I think I might have had the same reaction. But looking at it as history and realizing that with each sentence, I was expanding my knowledge made the task of reading this short book far more pleasant.

A Cure for Suicide is certainly not what one might call a beach books, the appearance of the pages notwithstanding. There are similarities of Kafka in the start to the book, and shades of Joyce toward the end, when the pace of the text goes from sparse and leisurely to frenetic, and overtones of Orwell throughout.The book introduces us to a claimant and an examiner, whose identities are not revealed much more beyond those titles except through their conversations. Gradually, we begin to piece together what is going on (thanks in part to the revealing title), but there is always--or was for me--a substantial disconnect. Ball offers little for us to cling to for comfort in the way of familiarity. We recognize that the claimant and the examiners are human, but the society is not recognizably any place in particular, and the time is also somewhat vague. So the book requires a great deal of work to understand, though I’m reminded of Walt Whitman’s criticism of parlor-room talks: Have you studied all this time just to get the meaning of poems? (I’m paraphrasing). I’m not sure that looking to A Cure for Suicide for a clear meaning is likely to work or is even the point here. This is a book for those who like experimental fiction and are willing to invest substantial time into a book. For those who like to read a book, turning the pages quickly to get to the ending that wraps everything together, I would suggest moving on.

Though the third book in a series, Stay with Me works well as a stand-alone novel. The plot has certain superficial similarities to Tana French’s In the Woods. A crime whose victim is a young child seems to mirror a crime that happened years ago. The investigator is heavily invested in the case because of a relationship to one of the victims. And memory plays an important role. There, for the most part, the similarities end.Here, the investigator is Brenna Spector, and she is related to both victims. The first, her teenage sister, disappeared years ago. Now, her daughter has disappeared under similar circumstances. Spector’s memory is nearly eidetic, but this apparent benefit is not always helpful.The pace is fast, and the story is compelling. What I found best about the novel is the main character. Spector has her life together for the most part (apart from the obvious fact that her daughter has disappeared). Her hyperthymesia sets her apart, but she strikes me as a strong woman who has solid relationships with those around her. In short, she seemed to be a solid character to guide me through a story populated by treachery and some very unsavory characters.

First things first. Assembly is, for the most part, easy and intuitive. The hard parts (the base and handle) come in five pieces that snap together easily and securely. There is also a pad that must be added, and even with the instructions, it wasn’t all that clear how they fit in. I don’t want to make a big deal of this point since I managed to get a pad attached in a few minutes, and it appears to have been securely attached since it hasn’t come off since.Now, the product itself. The most important point is that it works only on hard floors. Essentially, there are two parts. A roller picks up big things, and the pad catches the small stuff (dirt and hair, e.g.). The product absolutely will not work on carpet. Trying it on carpet will, in fact, dump the previously swept-up material onto the carpet, not what one desires.This product worked reasonably well, but it won’t replace a mop, and I’m not sure that it’s much better than a simple broom. I am also not all that sure that I prefer it to a standard dry sweeper. The one I have works on carpets and hard floors. It may lack the pad (and I do confess that the pad caught a fair amount of stuff), but the advantage of being able to use it in all areas of the house makes me prefer it.

Fatal Trauma is the first book I’ve read by Dr. Mabry. It probably will be the last. I simply did not find the story all that compelling, believable, or unique. It’s not that the story is bad per se. I just didn’t find that much to recommend it.The book begins with a hostage situation at a hospital. When the situation is apparently resolved with some violence, Mark, the protagonist doctor, finds his life in danger. Nor is he alone. Members of the Zeta gang/drug cartel have vowed revenge on everyone responsible for the outcome of the hostage situation. Moreover, Mark seems to have become a prime suspect as far as the police are concerned in the death of an officer.The pace is fast for the most part with occasional breaks for romance (including a love triangle) and theological musings. The portions relating to medicine and the hospital seem authentic (no surprise given the author), but overall, I simply found the story was not very convincing. The police seemed incompetent, and the drug cartel seemed unduly focused on revenge when I can’t think that doing so would be in the best interests of the cartel, either in terms of making money or in terms of avoiding prosecution. There are smaller parts that seemed unlikely and took me out of the story, but the bigger picture was more of a problem for me.

I really wavered on the number of stars to give this book. The stories here are rich, and I think there is a great deal in them to spur thought and, better yet, discussion with other readers. And yet I can't say that I "loved" the book. I admired it, yes. I will read Lauren Holmes again gladly. But this first effort didn't completely captivate me.That said, there is quite a bit here worth recommending. First, the prose is smooth and accomplished. The stories are easy to read, so easy, in fact, that their depth may not at first be apparent. Take the first story, for example. In "How Am I Supposed to Talk to You?," a young woman travels to Mexico to come out to her mother. The two are not on the best of terms, but they're not really enemies, either. It just seems that they would rather do something, anything, than actually talk. So for much of the story, not much happens. The revelation does eventually occur, and then--nothing much happens again.When I finished reading this story about a month ago, I had the feeling that I had missed something. But I really hadn't. Not much happens. But that not much is the key to the story, which is about the disconnect between these two and, at least on the daughter Lala's part, the deep, deep ambivalence about whether she wants something to happen. In many ways, this story isn't a "story" per se. It is a character study and an adept one at that.The title story is probably the strongest story. Here, an extremely intelligent and self-aware high-school student bound for Princeton had endured the taunts and torments of her peers, in large part because of her autistic brother and, I think, in large part because her tormentors simply do not know what to make of her. In this story, which is both a story (in the sense that it presents a fairly clear beginning, middle, and end) and a painfully honest character (and societal) study, Holmes show a remarkable talent. The deliberately provocative title hints at either exploitation or deep insight, and I was delighted to find that it was the latter that prevails. The ending is especially skillful here.The least effective story, for me, is either the boldest or the laziest. "My Humans" is told from the point of view of a dog. There's no doubt what the author was trying to do here. I just found the approach almost certainly doomed from the start. I can understand why many would disagree with me and really like the story, though, and I certainly love the short-story form for stories just like this, pieces in which authors can take chances. This one just didn't work for me. That said, the collection is strong, insightful, and certainly worth reading. You will find humor (but not slapstick), emotion but not melodrama, and insight.

Doing Good Better represents a valuable resource for those who contribute to charities. Once you start contributing, you end up on sucker lists for all sorts of nefarious charities. There are lots of them out there that do almost no good for anyone. Yes, you get a tax deduction, but up to 100% of the donation can go to professional fundraisers. Of course, those charities tend to be the exception, but even some well-managed charities may not need your donation, however much they might protest to the contrary.What William MacAskill does here is set out a series of questions we should ask ourselves before giving. (Whether the supposed charity is in fact a fraud is not the focus of or even a major part of the book.) These questions may seem superfluous to many of us, especially those familiar with online charity evaluators such as Charity Navigator. After all, this website provides an easy-to-understand star rating, a few easy-to-digest numbers, and the CEO’s salary. MacAskill, however, finds this approach faulty, and he makes a good argument why.Still, the thought of reading a book to help determine giving (of time or money) may seem like a bit more effort than we’d ideally like to devote to such thinking, especially when it’s so quick and easy to write a check to the SPCA or Komen for the Cure. The good news is that Doing Good Better is interesting throughout. From the opening example of a movement to help African villages get water by putting children’s playground items (like a merry-go-round) in, hooking them up to a water pump, and--voila!--potable water to discussions about voting and more, Doing Good Better engages throughout. (A confession, though: I found the author’s argument in favor of voting less than persuasive. That’s not to say you shouldn’t vote, just that I don’t think you should vote based on MacAskill’s argument.)Ultimately, the questions here should make any donor think (even if the book does at time read as if it’s promotional material for givewell.org)--about necessary tradeoffs, relative good, desired outcomes, and more. And thinking donors are likely to be more effective donors.

Confession first: When a writer avoids punctuation, I have to ask why. Often, there is a good reason (such as pacing). More often, I think, the problem is simply that the writer doesn’t know. When the writer refuses to use quotation marks, though, I get the impression, rightly or wrongly, that something else is at work: contempt for the reader. Few things make me so immediately antagonistic to writing as the avoidance of quotation marks. I can’t be certain, but I don’t believe there are any quotation marks in this book.The story involves someone who just might be the perfect American. He comes from wealth and a line of the Harvard-educated. After the events of September 11, 2001, he joins the Marines to fight overseas. He is shot, but his injury and recovery turn into an opportunity for him to write novels that do very well. When his beloved uncle dies of an apparent suicide, Jack does not believe the verdict and vows to uncover the truth, ultimately finding what appears to be a conspiracy that goes to the highest levels.I don’t know whether this book is supposed to be a mystery, a literary mystery, or what, but I don’t have the sense that the author has respect for the genre. Or maybe it’s competence that is lacking. I find it hard to believe that the solution won’t be evident to almost every reader well before the book is half over. The writing itself, ignoring the issue of the absence of quotation marks, is at times good and at other times hackneyed, sometimes almost laughable. (Before writing this review, I read other reviews to see whether I was being too critical. One of the reviews has an extensive quotation from the book of a scene between Jack and a woman he fancies. That scene is a good example of how bad parts of the book are.)I really found little worth recommending in Killer, Come Hither. The portrayal of the law firm seems uneducated, and I’m therefore not willing to put much stock in the author’s portrayal of the upper echelons of power and wealth. If you want a mystery, pick a different one. If you want a literary novel, there are countless others that are better.

If I were limited to one sentence to describe The Dead Run, could not interject any opinion into that sentence (so that things like “I enjoyed it,” “It’s awful,” and “It revels in the macabre” are all impermissible), and had to try to let potential readers know whether they would enjoy it, I believe this would be my sentence: The book features an army of the virgin dead. That sentence alone should be sufficient for a potential reader. If the idea of an army of the virgin dead appeals to you, almost everything in the book should be right up your alley. That includes the wacko religious cult, a biker gang, a Mexican setting, complete with bar and corruption, a good-guy American in prison, and more. At this point, the plot is almost superfluous, but there is one, and author Mansbach keeps it moving along very quickly, pausing every so often for a great deal of bloodshed and gore.At this point, though, I’m not sure what more I can add. So I’ll just repeat myself. The book features an army of the virgin dead. Your decision whether to read the book should be based pretty much on that fact alone. (Incidentally, I’m serious about that point.)

Three Story House (why no hyphen?) is about three cousins who end up in Memphis refurbishing a house that needs a great deal of work—as do they. We have the athlete, Lizzie, whose Olympic dreams are in serious jeopardy because of a serious injury; the child actress, Isobel, who lives of income from a rental; and the disillusioned woman who is questioning life because her former boyfriend has married her sister. As the three try to figure out the next stages in their lives, they renovate the house.The novel was an easy enough read without any serious twists and turns and with an ending that you can see long before the characters can. The characters’ progress and the house’s run roughly in parallel; as the cousins pull themselves together, so they pull the house together. I never found myself terribly invested in the cousins’ lives, but I did find the sense of place in the book well done. Memphis comes alive as another character and works well to support the women’s struggles to rebuild (their lives and the house). As a rather light novel, Three Story House worked well, but there is not all that much depth here, and the knowledge of where the story was heading and mostly how it would get there prevented me from becoming too caught up in it. However, for those who like happy endings and stories of redemption, Three Story House is well written and probably just the thing.

The story revolves around Aurelia and the Ball, an annual event filled with all sorts of sexual escapades. Aurelia, orphaned by parents who escaped the ball, gave birth to her, and died, eventually returns to the Ball, which may be where she is destined to be. Gradually, her sexual desires come to the fore, and she seems to be drawn to the Ball and her deep connection with and to it. The plot is fairly straightforward, but it does at time seem to become secondary compared to the erotic elements, which pop up frequently.I found the book rather uninspiring. Perhaps part of that response is attributable to the fact that this book several books into a series that I have not read. But I think that I would have had the same response had this been book one. I never felt terribly connected to the characters; did not really have any emotional investment in Aurelia or her fate; and found the sense of fate or destiny, such as it is, too limited to be truly interesting. (Regarding the last point, I suppose my objection is this: Aurelia’s connection to the Ball seems to be more about an awakening of her sexuality than about any personal growth to speak of.) As for the erotic elements, and there are many, I don’t believe they really added much to the story after a point. That the Ball is Dionysian is clear early on. But once its hedonistic character is established, there comes a point at which the erotica seems to exist for its own sake, making the story somewhat secondary.

Those Girls recycles many of the themes in all sorts of recent teen fiction: the elite girls; the back-stabbing, cruelty, and manipulation of others; the sex and drugs; and the insecurity at the heart of these girls. Using themes we’ve seen before is fine. The question is what the author does with those themes. The answer I found here is: not enough.There are three girls at the core of the story, and though each is clearly distinguished from the others, they are all identical in the most important respects. They are of a type: privileged, cruel, and insecure. Though these facets manifest themselves in various ways (promiscuity for one, abstinence for another, e.g.), the end result is the same: damaged girls damage themselves further and lash out at those around them. I’m sure people like these girls exist, and I’m equally sure that much of this book will ring true for many. For me, though, it seemed like too much that I’ve seen before without adding anything especially new. There's too little exploration of the girls' pasts. Old tropes just aren't enough. And the ending . . . I won’t reveal too much except to say that I found it profoundly disappointing. On balance, I found this book a step up from some vaguely similar series (such as the Private series), but that's faint praise.

Acts of Contrition worked for me because of the well-drawn characters. Mary, the primary character, in particular, is complex, intelligent, strong (mostly)—and flawed in a human way. In simplest terms, the story involves Mary and Tom, a happily married couple raising a wonderful family and living what many might describe as the ideal life. They work, they love each other and their children, and they live happily and well. However, Mary has a secret that threatens to rear its head and destroy her marriage and her family. (That the couple is Catholic plays an important role in the story, but I left it out of the plot summary because much of what happens here and many of Mary’s deliberations would be more or less the same for people of any—or no—faith. Catholics, and Christians more broadly, might relate more closely to the novel, but I think that just about any adult who has been married or committed to another can relate to the story.)The nature of Mary’s secret does not remain a mystery long, and the book focuses on the humanity of its main characters. Acts of Contrition works, in many ways, I think, like a Jodi Picoult novel. The author focuses on the characters, develops them, and gives them both strengths and flaws. The look here at Mary and her family is a serious one, a sincere attempt to explore the effects of a bad decision in the past and the possibly good, possibly bad decisions that build on it in the present. This book may not be as deep an exploration of human psychology as one finds in Dostoevsky, but the book is human and effective.

As others have described the plot in detail, I'll avoid doing so here. I will, however, note that some of the reviews' summaries confuse me even two weeks after I finished the book. That fact is probably attributable to the novel's curious nature. Part science fiction, part mythology, part character study, and big part environmental/climate tale, The Man with the Compound Eyes is a meandering book that I enjoyed while reading but cannot really piece together only two weeks later. To the extent that the book is, in some ways, a collection of interconnected stories, I enjoyed the individual stories even if I didn't fully understand the big picture at all times. (Part of the failure, a big part, comes from the way I read, typically with at least four books going at the same time. Normally, I have no problems with such an approach. Here, though, the novel really should have been my entire focus.) What saved the novel for me was the beautifully drawn characters, the writing (with a big nod to the translator), and the sense of magic and mysticism, which always kept things interesting.

My background may be helpful here (if only to help prospective purchasers decide that my advice is not helpful). I have taught math at the high-school and college levels for many years. I have taken the GMAT and earned a perfect score. I have also tutored scores of students for the GMAT (though not recently). In general, I know both math and the test. Also, I have never in any way been affiliated with Manhattan Prep. I have not worked for, competed with, or studied under Manhattan Prep.So when I say that this book offers solid preparation for the GMAT, I do so from the perspective of someone with a fair amount of knowledge of the material and the test but no need for such a book. I do believe that anyone who can go through all 400 pages or so of the book and understand everything will be in an excellent position on the GMAT. But I do have some concerns.The positives: The book goes through not only the math but also the structure of the questions and a variety of means of solving, in many cases allowing the reader to sidestep complicated math entirely. Because some of the question formats will be foreign to students, Manhattan Prep's focus on what exactly these questions mean and how to do them will be especially helpful. The problems range from fairly easy to quite difficult and thus should give thorough preparation. The step-by-step solutions should be sufficient for almost everyone.The negatives: A 400-page book is awfully long, especially for those who have never really gotten along with math. Though many of the pages have a lot of white space for diagrams and equations, I still think that the book will be intimidating to some. Also, there are a few spots in which I thought the explanations could have been clearer. (I have sympathy for the book's creators on this point. Writing a book like this requires the authors to walk a sometimes hard-to-see line between saying too much and boring those who have a solid grasp of the math and saying too little and losing those for whom math is more difficult. Also, I believe the book could have had more problems.If I were considering buying this book, I would look inside using the feature Amazon.com has and see whether the explanations make sense. If so, then the book should work. If not, then perhaps starting with a book that is solely about mathematical basics would be a better first step.

The Rules is advertised on the back of my copy as Saw meets I Know What You Did Last Summer. I'm not sure about the Saw portion, but the second half of the comparison seems fairly accurate. I tend to hold books to a higher standard than I do teen horror films, and thus for me, this book was not exactly an enjoyable read. The characters are not especially sympathetic. They often die fairly quickly, thus not allowing us to get much of a chance to root for them. And their actions are often foolish (thus leading to their deaths).That said, I could see why this book might appeal to its target audience of teens. In fact, I think I would have enjoyed this in my teens, when I could relate to many of the shenanigans in the characters' lives. And certainly the plot races along, so those who want an emphasis on action will no doubt be thrilled. However, for me as an adult, the book just sort of sat there; it didn't engage.

I remember in elementary school having to do book reports in which I identified the main character. Had I been given The Shore then, I probably would have identified the setting as the main character. This book jumps around chronologically, from the twentieth to the nineteenth century and back and, ultimately, to the twenty-second century. The characters disappear and reappear until it ultimately becomes clear that they are from the same few families. (Just exactly how many probably will be clear in the final edition, but I did not have the benefit of the genealogy in my review copy.)Having read the book, I certainly cannot say that I enjoyed it. There is too much pain and cruelty here for that. I do recall at one point being grateful for the disjointed structure since it kept me from getting too close to any of the characters and thus feeling the pain and suffering as acutely.Though The Shore may not be pleasurable to read, it is rewarding. First, Sara Taylor’s writing, though sometimes raw, is generally accomplished and effective. Second, the book’s presentation of a narrow history, one mostly limited by the geography of this Virginia locale, is sweeping and does indeed help us see the big picture of historical and familial continuity, almost of destiny as established by genetics and geography.Like other reviewers, I found the first story the most compelling and longed to return to it (as we do eventually). Unlike other readers (I hope), I did not know the approach the book was going to take and thus was frustrated by the approach. But those who understand the nonlinear approach ahead of time should find the book more rewarding than I did.I dallied a long time before writing this review, largely because of the difficulty of assigning a star rating to it. I dislike these ratings in general (though I understand their purpose) and tried to think of what they meant. Ultimately, I decided that they are personal, subjective. So I asked myself whether I would recommend this book to myself. In other words, if I could somehow travel back in time to the point at which I selected this book, would I advise myself to get and read it? The answer is no, and that’s a fairly easy answer. For as much as I admire the craft here, it is the accumulation of rape, drugs, poverty, disease, abuse, and more that makes this not something I would want to read. That’s not a criticism of the book (and certainly these topics are important). It’s an indication of a mismatch between Sara Taylor as a writer and me as a reader.

My sister and I learned when we were very young that we were both adopted. For me, that fact was almost meaningless. My life was with the family I grew up in; it was the only life I’d ever known. The only time my adoption became an issue was when others made it one. My sister, on the other hand, ultimately sought out her birth parents. They briefly formed a relationship, but I don’t believe that much came of it. As for me, I’ve always been grateful to the woman who gave me life and understand that those nine months and the decision must have been difficult.So I have a personal connection to this story of a woman who gives up her baby. And as far as meshing with my own life—well, it didn’t. Part of the problem is the main character, Kate, who comes across as a thoroughly self-obsessed, selfish, trouble-causing jerk. (I’m not comfortable saying that because an author’s note at the end of the book reveals that Kate is based on a real person. But I do hope that the fictional Kate is not an accurate reflection of the story’s inspiration.) In fact, just about the only decision she makes that makes sense is giving up her child for adoption.I had a difficult time rooting for her in the romantic triangle that motivates many of her decisions. Given that the book is entirely predictable, much in the way a Hallmark made-for-television movie is, that lack of a rooting interest proved fatal. Nor is there much to recommend the writing. I do sense that this book was probably quite emotional for the author to write. But for me, the disconnect between Kate and me and the disconnect between my experiences with adoption and what seems to be the conception here were too great. And Then I Found You was definitely not for me, my pre-reading hopes notwithstanding.

Before We Kiss is the third Fool’s Gold romance that I’ve read but feels as if it is only the first or second since it is so strikingly similar to at least one other series entry. For the uninitiated, the Fool’s Gold series is set in Fool’s Gold, a small town in northern California. Like many small-town romance series, the cast tends to appear in multiple novels, and the town itself is as much a character as the people, albeit sometimes in a forced manner.In this book, there are two unresolved romances. The first involves Sam and Dellina. He is a former professional football player who now works in Fool’s Gold as a member of the company he, two other players, and a woman formed together. She works in party planning. Their first contact, before the book begins, was a one-night stand that ended when he went into the wrong room, saw several wedding gowns and a whiteboard with comments related to weddings, and freaked out, leaving almost immediately. When the novel begins, he is hiring her to help organize a party for his company.The other relationship involves one of Dellina’s sisters, who is in a long-term relationship with a man who will not ask her to marry him. In this case, he has good reason. She told him that she wanted to wait four years, and so he has been respecting her explicit wishes—much to her disappointment.The relationships here seem to be on the emotional and intellectual level of seventh-grade students. There is one scene at the end in particular that echoes an almost identical scene from a different Fool’s Gold book in which a character behaves abominably. In other words, the characters, though presumably of legal age, act as if they are children. Moreover, they know it. There are multiple instances in the book in which characters tell themselves or are told by others how stupidly they are behaving. I don’t recommend this book or, indeed, the series for anyone looking for insight or depth. There just isn’t much here.Other information: The sex is graphic, and there is one especially long scene that can be skipped, though it might work reasonably well as a how-to manual since the descriptions are quite precise. (The scene is at least interesting in one sense, though. The two lovers discuss his mother twice during their session.) There is some, but not much, swearing. The book does not require prior knowledge of the series. Though previous events are part of the plot, they are well enough described that the new reader should not feel lost.  And I have no idea what the title is supposed to refer to since the primary relationship develops long after the lovers have done much more than kiss.

In this collection, Karen Joy Fowler certainly provides variety. We have, for instance, a story about Albert Einstein and the daughter whose existence recently came to light with a series of letters. There is the science-fiction account of women living in Berkeley in the 1960s, an account that owes more to women's studies than to science fiction. There is the Shirley Jackson-like story of a woman whose son's trivia questions lead her to imagine a scenario that somehow bleeds into real life.I think the best part of the collection is the variety, but not just the variety in terms of subject matter. The stories are as short as four pages and as long as 50 or more. The forms are varied as well. Some have fairly traditional narration while others vary the form considerably. And throughout, there seems to be a focus on those who don't quite fit in, who exist on the margins. You may not like all 15 stories (I didn't), but if you are a serious reader and enjoy stories that challenge you to think, you're sure to find quite a few here to please you.

This re-imagining of the Sherlock Holmes stories takes place when Holmes is a schoolboy. Moriarty, here a schoolgirl, tells the story as she and Sherlock meet, come across a police investigation, and compete to solve it, ultimately drawing closer to each other. As a general rule, I dislike pastiches that deviate substantially from the canon. This one certainly does that, changing the gender of Moriarty. But it seems to work because of the most significant change, namely setting the story when the two are children.I would not recommend the novel to diehard fans of the canon, though, as this really is not so much a pastiche as it is a story that happens to use two characters who are featured prominently in a classic series of short stories. It also bears mention that the characters' brilliance is more told than shown. For example, Mori keeps three dice with her in part to relieve boredom. One day, she rolls them and comes up with a combination whose probability is 1/216. That probability is accurate, but it is also misleading, and the conclusions Mori draws from it are somewhat silly. After all, there are other 1/216 probabilities--35 others to be exact. But the original stories also had their problems, such as Holmes's deduction that someone must be highly intelligent because he has a large head. And this one's not likely to cause many of the target audience to balk.And for the target audience, youths who have not yet formed an intense attachment to the Holmes canon, the story and the mystery probably work. In fact, if we remove the fact that we're reading about THE Sherlock Holmes and THE James Moriarty, we're left with a reasonably well done and fairly standard YA novel about misfits who happen to be precocious. For devotees of the original, though, the story might be enjoyable, but it does not add much, apart from a change of gender for one character and a substantial exploration of her dysfunctional family, to the canon.

While I admired the author's craft and especially the translation, I found little emotional impact in the stories here. As a general rule, they are not plot-driven tales but instead focus on character and human interaction. Probably the best constructed, best written, and all-around best story is the first, "Hiding Places," which involves an untimely death, characters' reactions to that death, and characters' responses to those reactions. (It is hard to discuss the stories without giving away too many details.) I was immediately drawn into this story by the writing and the narrator's voice only to find myself slogging through the middle until an especially evocative ending.The worst story in the book, for my money, is "The Return," which is the shortest. In this tale, a woman kills her sister's husband to preserve family ownership of an ancestral house. The story seems to have the air of a fairy tale or a ghost story, both in the events and in the manner in which it is told, but ultimately the ending seemed to me a bit ridiculous for this treasury. That said, "The Return" is easily the most accessible story in the book.Ultimately, the stories are bleak with very little warmth, kindness, or charity shining through. And perhaps it's that bleakness that kept me from connecting more with this collection. And that failure to connect really is too bad given how much I admired the writer's and translator's craft.

I am not Jewish. My last name is of German origin, but that side of my family has been in the United States since the 19th century. I mention these points because there is nothing in particular that should draw me to "Hidden Inheritance," which deals with the author's discovery of a Jewish heritage of which she was completely unaware.The story of how she discovered this heritage is itself rather remarkable. An Internet search turned up the completely unexpected results. As far as Heidi Neumark (herself a Lutheran pastor) knew, her family was everything she thought it was: a fairly typical Christian family. But when she discovers her family's connection to the Holocaust (or, to use the term she prefers, Shoah), she is in for some serious questioning about herself, her past, the role of faith, and more.What makes this book so wonderful for me is the writing. Without being too informal, it is almost conversational, complete with all sorts of tangents and diversions and with references to things that haven't been fully explained yet. (As a simple example of the last point, there are multiple references to the discovery well before Newmark explains in more detail the circumstances.) It's quite hard for me to explain what makes the book so wonderful beyond that quality. I don't want to give away too many details. And the non-linear nature of the telling makes it difficult to know what can be revealed. But I can definitely say that "Hidden Inheritance" is an easy read and a fascinating one--even for those with few or no ties to the Shoah.

This snorkel and mask are wonderful. First, the fit is great. There’s no discomfort, and I had no problems with leaking. Out of force of habit, I spat in the window beforehand, so I can’t say whether that’s necessary. Too many years of doing so, I suppose. But I suspect the mask will not fog up otherwise. The fact that the snorkel automatically closes (one way, you can still exhale) underwater is great. I kind of miss the fun of rising from the water and blowing out a stream of water, but I got over that feeling quickly. And afterward, when I removed the mask, I didn’t have that oval of pressure that I’ve so long associated with snorkel masks. In fact, I think I could have worn this for hours. Finally, the view is great. It’s really about as close to being to see underwater (meaning as a fish must) as I’ve ever experienced with a mask. (And for the sake of clarity, I will note that I’m not anything near a professional or even habitual snorkeler. But I certainly have been snorkeling at least 100 times just as a beachgoer or off the side of a boat.)

“Bennington Girls Are Easy”—maybe, but since I didn’t attend Bennington and have not known any Bennington alumnae, I have to take the title of the book on faith. And for me, I think therein lies the problem. I did not attend Bennington, so many of the in-jokes and much of the background that the author seems to assume the reader share just are not part of my experience. So the book read a lot like something that I am not expected to fully understand.The story of two nearly lifelong best friends who grow up together, attend Bennington together, go to Cambridge and then New York together, and so forth just didn’t captivate me. Part of the problem, other than my alma mater (a small liberal-arts college, for what it’s worth) is that the book’s set-up relies far too much on telling rather than showing. I don’t really get why the two women are friends. We’re told they’re friends, but that’s not the same as telling us why. The closes the author comes is in one of the many instances of authorial intrusion in which we’re told that to be best friends two people must love and hate the same things. Another part of the problem is that in the majority of the book, neither character seems to develop that much. I really never cared all that much about what happens to either one.I’ve read that two reviews liken this to the film “The Last Days of Disco,” which I enjoyed. Other than some superficial similarities, though, I don’t really see the comparison. I’m giving this three stars because I believe it may appeal to Bennington alumni (both male and female), but it didn’t do much for me.

Here are the things I liked about the Konf-X Buds. (1) The cords are long. There is a cord from the ear buds to the control and then one from the control to the jack. Both are plenty long. I used this product while walking and had no difficulties with a short cord pulling the buds out of my ears. (2) The left and right buds are shaped differently to fit into the specific ears. (Well, they’re actually shaped the same, just as mirror images of each other. The do fit into the wrong ears OK, but they fit well in the proper ears.) (3) The buds fit snugly. (4) These work without the noise-cancelling feature on and without a battery. In other words, they function as simple ear buds. There’s no need to use a battery just to listen. (5) All of the buttons are easily accessible without the user having to look at them. (There are only three buttons or switches anyway.)Here is the thing I didn’t like: The buds are not entirely comfortable. They don’t cause any serious discomfort, but I could tell I had them in, and there was a very small amount of discomfort.Here is the thing I’m indifferent about: The noise-cancelling feature did not seem to have any great benefit. During my walk, I listened to an audiobook and to music, and I was near a heavily traveled street. Switching the feature on had no noticeable effect on what I could hear from outside (i.e., the traffic) and only a minimal effect on the thing I was listening to. The most obvious effect was that the volume decreased ever so slightly.So in the end, I like these ear buds, but I’m not sure that I’d spend all that much on them. In fact, if I had, I think I'd be upset.UPDATE: One day after posting the review above, I tried the noise-reduction feature once again, and this time I noticed a stark difference. It really does reduce noise substantially. I don't know that I'd say I experienced a 90% reduction, but there was a clear difference with the feature on and off. I've thought about what I might have done differently in the two tests, and the only possibility I can come up with is the placement of the buds themselves. I may not have had them firmly in my ears the first time, perhaps the result of having walked a mile. But I'm pleased to report that the noise-reduction (or noise-cancelling) feature really does work.

“A Dictionary of Mutual Understanding” is a magnificent novel. It manages to be both universal, reflecting a deep understanding of humanity, and especially Japanese, conveying Japanese culture with almost every sentence. (A word of qualification: I have never been to Japan and have no particular connection with Japanese culture, so it is possible that I am mistakenly judging the presentation here as a faithful reflection of Japanese culture. I don’t think so, however.)Octogenarian Amaterasu is a survivor of World War II and the nuclear bombing of Japan. She has spent most of her life since trying to deal with all of the emotions of that time and subsequent life and trying to understand things. Part of her means of dealing with things is turning to alcohol. This existence, although not much more than an existence, seems to work. One day, however, a man appears at her door. He claims to be her grandson, whom she thought dead. But he claims to have proof and provides her with this evidence. As Amaterasu begins to sift through letters and journal entries, she is compelled to face many of the questions about the past, questions that she had tried to put behind her.As I said, this is a wonderful look at humanity in general. Amaterasu’s past may be particularly Japanese, and her way of dealing with many of the events of her life is no doubt shaped by her background. But the book is really about much more than Japanese culture. It is thoughtful, insightful, and genuinely moving. I highly recommend it.

There are two primary characters in the novel: Jane, an ex-pat journalist come to Africa to do a story about the abduction of over 100 students in Uganda and to flee from her past, and Esther, one of the 30. The story alternates between them, giving them roughly equal weight, and therein lies one of the problems I have with the novel. The real-life abductions of so many girls and the subsequent failure to gain the release of 30 of them is a powerful story that needs to be shared and needs to outrage us (as, indeed, it did briefly). And Esther’s story is indeed powerful. But it’s treatment here struck me as unjust, making it share the stage with the frankly dull and self-obsessed Jane. There is a fair amount of good in “30 Girls,” but there is much that I did not like. Among the latter points is the writing itself. I got the sense early on that Minot has if not contempt for the reader, at least disdain. The writing struck me as deliberately turgid in some places and deliberately Literary with a capital L. Commas and quotation marks, for example, are rare. I know that there are strong passions about writing styles, and I suspect that some will view my comments as the disdain of the great unwashed for brilliance. Fair enough. But I would caution the reader, even the well-read reader, to read the first few pages before deciding whether to purchase this novel. In my mind, there is nothing wrong with punctuation to make meaning clear. At the same time, the writing is at times one of the best features of the novel. Esther’s voice comes through clear and strong, and I have little trouble believing that Esther is a real person. Indeed, her story, of lost hope, of torture and imprisonment, and of almost unspeakable abuse, is a powerful one and is rendered here in a way that keeps that power . . . except for the fact that we lose it so often when we switch back to the other story. As another of the reviews here put it, the girls deserve better (to which I add that they deserve to be the story, not serve another story).

"Blood Tattoo" is, I gather, book seven in the Nicholas Colt series, but it is the first for me. I did not feel as if I missed anything by jumping into the series in book 7.Nicholas, former guitar player of some note, is now living in Florida, where he runs a small shop giving guitar lessons and lives with his wife, a woman whose trust has begun to wear thin. One Sunday, a day Nicholas normally takes off, he gets a call from someone who claims to need an emergency guitar lesson. He is naturally suspicious, but the $200 she offers overcomes his suspicions. When he meets the woman, she tells him that she works for the government in a high-level capacity and that she needs his help. She has uncovered a plan to assassinate the president, and she knows the name of the intended assassin: it is hers. In exchange for the promise of much greater money in the future, Nicholas agrees to help out, though he really does not understand much of anything about the woman or her position.Thus begins an action-filled romp in which Nicholas tries to help the woman even as his marriage seems to crumble. Oh, and he continues to give guitar lessons.There were implausibilities in the book (excluding the entire over-the-top plot) that distracted me at times, such as Nicholas's reaching into the glove compartment to remove his gun while he is driving his car over 100 miles per hour during a chase, but I think that the book requires a certain suspension of disbelief. Once that small leap is made, the store is enjoyable, and the book is certainly a page turner. One slight caution may be in order. Nicholas's wife's diary entries are included, and they provide a great deal of back story--and, I assume, substantial plot details for the earlier books. As I haven't read those books (yet), I can't say whether there are intense spoilers. But there may well be. On its own, though, "Blood Tattoo" reminded me of some of the Elvis Cole books by Robert Crais, albeit without the smart-aleck remarks commentary. The styles are similar in that the protagonist has a clear and well-defined voice and the stories mix personal life with adventure well. Recommended.

6:50 Mins This is probably the biggest game collection ever spanning decades worth of Rare games.  Welcome to the SKILLED channel.  And today we're looking at the Rare Replay collection.  There's something for everyone in this package.  And it's a great idea for people who are life long fans or even those new to Rareware games.  Do all of these ports play well and did Rare do a good job at packaging 30 distinct games into one collection?  Let's find out and see if Rare Replay is worth playing.Everything about this Rare showcase is exceptional in its presentation.  It has a full musical intro that's more than a minute long showing the celebration of Rareware's history.  The menu is incredibly detailed with everything in chronological order of our favorite Rare games.  There's a snapshots mode which are short challenge sections of selected games.  Then there's a collection of Rare documentaries, from games that never passed the concept art phase to behind the scenes footage.  But in order to watch these, you have to unlock them by playing the games from this collection.  This video is more of a first impression and an overview of the features, because there's no way we could could complete all of these games for this review.Starting with the N64 era, it's nice to see that these games work as well as the original.  The N64 generation itself hasn't aged well, but the Rareware games are probably the strongest of the bunch due to their unique design.  They've also been a little harder to access in modern times so it's great to have it here.  With the incredibly unique Blast Corps where you blow up buildings and get money for it.  To the classic platforming of Banjo Kazooie.  Banjo Kazooie is actually the upgraded XBLA version, but that's great because it already has all the improvements of higher resolution and dual analog controls.  Some games don't hold up well like Jet Force Gemini.  They offer an option for modern controls, but no matter what you select it's incredibly awkward and can best be described as tank controls.The old school games looks incredible blocky with the low resolution uprezzed to 1080p.  There is an option for a CRT filter which makes it looks like an old TV and in my opinion it's a much more reasonable appearance even though it's designed for nostalgia.  There's also a beautifully crafted border tailored to each game.  I usually turn off these kinds of features because they are distracting, but these look so good I had to leave them on.  One of the Rarest highlights from the collection is Battletoads Arcade.  The game looks and runs really well for a 2D Beat Em Up because it was released exclusively for the Arcade and now this is the only way to get it without resorting to emulation.Xbox 360 EraThe Xbox 360 era was the category that I was most interested in, but also most disappointed in.  I was surprised how poorly some of these games ran.  All games run under an Xbox 360 emulator instead of being ported natively.  The game has to load the 360 interface and on the first game I ran, it took quite a while to initialize.  Kameo Elements of Power ran fine.  Viva Pinata runs ok.  But Perfect Dark Zero suffered some slow downs even during somewhat simple moments.  Then moving on to Banjo Kazooie Nuts & Bolts the slow down was unbearable.  Walking around in the town and even sometimes during cutscenes was atrocious.  I know I'm not the only one complaining about these slow downs you can look around the net to see other responses.  But a lot of people tend to downplay the slowdown problem due to nostalgia glasses.Other than that, the games handle and play the same as they did on 360, since they are the most recent games.  Aside from slowdown, functionality and controls are all intact.  It is nice to have access to these more modern Rare games in one place.  These games have their own unique values to them. There's Kameo which is as an adventure game that focuses on transforming.  Viva Pinata which is a strangely fun garden simulator.  Perfect Dark Zero has some fun elements and really sets itself apart from modern military shooters.  However it is dated in some ways.  The characters really exude the mid 2000 fashion style.  And the controls are incredibly floaty, it's very difficult to have precision when moving and shooting.RemasteringThe graphics are generally the same as the original versions, with the exception of the XBLA ported remasters like Banjo Kazooie.  Of course we would all love 100% touched up graphics in the 3D games, but it's not really going to be possible.The UI really shows a lot of care and they didn't leave you hanging in any way.  There's options for everything you could possibly need to beat these old games.  And even save states, rewinds, and unlimited lives in some of the old school games.  That way you can actually beat those hard classics without driving yourself crazy.I know everyone is wondering where's Donkey Kong Country?  Or how about StarFox adventures?  Those games are lost in licensing so you won't see them in this pack.  But the classics that are included here are loads of fun and still maintain everything from the original.Rare Replay is a huge package perfect for people who are hardcore fans of the old games.  And even new fans who got a taste of Rare and now they want to go back can play all of the games.  Rare Replay gets our rating of Try It.  The slowdown is really a killer on the recent 360 games.  And not every game has perfect controls, although Rare tried very hard to make it accessible.  But it's a ton of fun games in one package overall.  And for the most part these games still hold up ok.  The slowdown and the Xbox 360 emulation is very annoying and I wish that wasn't the case, but it's still a very valuable package.  It's priced fairly at $30 retail which kind of breaks down to a dollar per game.  But you shouldn't really look at it that way.  Rare is such a fan favorite and it's hard to hate on the company for how they've changed.  Hopefully this is a sign that Rare will be returning to their roots with future games.  These games aren't for everyone and some people may not have the same nostalgia.  But for those who do enjoy it, this collection is loads of fun.  And subscribe to the SKILLED channel for more reviews on cool XBOX games: http://bit.ly/SkilledSubscribe

4:09 Mins Telltale Games takes us back to Pandora and beyond with Tales From The Borderlands.  It's a mix between the story and gameplay of Gearbox's classic shooter with a few recurring motifs from the Telltale Games style of storytelling.  In this review we're covering episode 3, but this video should apply both to people who are new to the Tales From The Borderlands series as well those who have only played the first episode or two.  I'll try to keep the spoilers to a minimum, but it's essential to talk about the narrative in this story driven game.  Let's take a look at Tales From The Borderlands and see if it's worth playing.Tales takes place in the Borderlands universe, but unlike the Borderlands games you aren't playing as a Vault Hunter.  You play as Rhys, a Hyperion employee who is trying to work his way to the top of the corporate ladder.  You also control Fiona who is a con artist working on Pandora.  The two characters come together and through unlikely odds become allies.  The story takes place after Borderlands 2 in the wake of  Handsome Jack's demise.  Yet he still has a presence in this game.  Ironically, these non-Vault Hunters turn their primary focuses to finding a Vault.Episode 3 is the middle of this five part series and it definitely shows.  Character development starts to flush out more as everyone tends to reveal more about their past and their motivations.  We also see relationships develop as the characters learn that they have to work together.  Both Fiona and Rhys have to constantly prove that they are the leaders of this operation.  It manages to do all of this while still injecting a little bit of humor at the right times.  It's safe to say that the strong but light hearted humor remains intact from the borderlands series.Conversation branches have long term impacts on how your characters interact as each of them remember your choices and react appropriately.  Your actions can have very different outcomes as I've had certain character become disability or had big changes to their appearance when I made the wrong choices in different playthroughs.  And there are plenty of action sequences with quicktime events.  Most of the action sequences fit in well and keep you engaged.  They prevent you from putting the controller down just because you are listening to some dialogue.  Especially during some crucial moments of the story when you encounter a villain and the game really tests you to act true to your character.The graphics engine of Borderlands is getting dated by this point, but the art style still shines through.  Tales brings a lot more details in the environment as you get close views of everything through the cutscenes.The strong voice acting is probably the best part of the game and it's essential for an interactive story.  Troy Baker lends his classic voice for Rhys and Fiona is voiced by Laura Bailey.  Both veterans of voice acting in games.Tales From The Borderlands is fun, captivating, and manages to draw fans of shooters and interactive stories.  You definitely want to continue playing the series if you haven't picked up episode 3 and if you're new this would be a good time to jump on board and get up to speed.  Leave a comment and let us know if you enjoy the Tales episodes or if you are more excited for a possible Borderlands sequel in the future. 4:09 Mins Telltale Games takes us back to Pandora and beyond with Tales From The Borderlands.  It's a mix between the story and gameplay of Gearbox's classic shooter with a few recurring motifs from the Telltale Games style of storytelling.  In this review we're covering episode 3, but this video should apply both to people who are new to the Tales From The Borderlands series as well those who have only played the first episode or two.  I'll try to keep the spoilers to a minimum, but it's essential to talk about the narrative in this story driven game.  Let's take a look at Tales From The Borderlands and see if it's worth playing.Tales takes place in the Borderlands universe, but unlike the Borderlands games you aren't playing as a Vault Hunter.  You play as Rhys, a Hyperion employee who is trying to work his way to the top of the corporate ladder.  You also control Fiona who is a con artist working on Pandora.  The two characters come together and through unlikely odds become allies.  The story takes place after Borderlands 2 in the wake of  Handsome Jack's demise.  Yet he still has a presence in this game.  Ironically, these non-Vault Hunters turn their primary focuses to finding a Vault.Episode 3 is the middle of this five part series and it definitely shows.  Character development starts to flush out more as everyone tends to reveal more about their past and their motivations.  We also see relationships develop as the characters learn that they have to work together.  Both Fiona and Rhys have to constantly prove that they are the leaders of this operation.  It manages to do all of this while still injecting a little bit of humor at the right times.  It's safe to say that the strong but light hearted humor remains intact from the borderlands series.Conversation branches have long term impacts on how your characters interact as each of them remember your choices and react appropriately.  Your actions can have very different outcomes as I've had certain character become disability or had big changes to their appearance when I made the wrong choices in different playthroughs.  And there are plenty of action sequences with quicktime events.  Most of the action sequences fit in well and keep you engaged.  They prevent you from putting the controller down just because you are listening to some dialogue.  Especially during some crucial moments of the story when you encounter a villain and the game really tests you to act true to your character.The graphics engine of Borderlands is getting dated by this point, but the art style still shines through.  Tales brings a lot more details in the environment as you get close views of everything through the cutscenes.The strong voice acting is probably the best part of the game and it's essential for an interactive story.  Troy Baker lends his classic voice for Rhys and Fiona is voiced by Laura Bailey.  Both veterans of voice acting in games.Tales From The Borderlands is fun, captivating, and manages to draw fans of shooters and interactive stories.  You definitely want to continue playing the series if you haven't picked up episode 3 and if you're new this would be a good time to jump on board and get up to speed.  Leave a comment and let us know if you enjoy the Tales episodes or if you are more excited for a possible Borderlands sequel in the future.
