The author has a funny sense of humor.As another reviewer commented, he leaves out some good alternative solutions, such as glass water bottles.  Also you don't have to drink either bottled water or tap water (which often tastes terrible). We have a reverse osmosis filtration unit which we love. It's an affordable one from Sears. Read the book and learn the facts about plastic.
Aubrey products are always the highest quality. All natural. Would recommend it.
Well made soap holder with a strong suction cup that stays put. My husband likes it too. We would buy it again.

Interesting read  on the open view of  Scripture. Does God cause evil or only permit it? What about predestination and man's free will?  Do our prayers influence God;s decisions? While I do not agree with  everything the author writes, I learned a lot from reading the book. i now have a much better understanding of predestination and similar words such as elect. The part about Pharaoh's heart being hardened was enlightening. While not a light read, the book is definitely worth reading.
I wear my blue blocker sunglasses before bed to prepare myself for sleep. White their small  size would not fit a large man, they fit me fine.

Ugh! What a boring lecture about the supposed benefits of a vegan diet. I quit watching part way through. No matter how the speaker distorts the facts a vegan duet with no B 12 or D3 isn't healthy for anyone. Save your money.
Comfortable cotton t shirt. Fits nicely and is a pretty lemon yellow color.
I love this small double boiler.and use it constantly. My larger boiler is rarely used. The lid is see through and the handles stay cool.
Not all oils are created equal. Do Terra oils are distilled and have all natural ingredients. Marjoram is good for relaxing stiff muscles  I love the smell.

I love the lamp's petite size. I was excepting something much larger. It'll fit nicely on our end tables. The lamp is dimable and has a nice, soft, white color light. While the light is soft white, on the bright setting it is gives a very bright light, brighter than even our Coleman lantern. These lamps charge quickly They are also lightweight and the handle makes the lamp easy to carry. Perfect for power outages. I'm glad I bought two of them.

After reading a number of books on the harmful effects of electromagnetic fields, especially radio, microwave frequencies, all of which recommend this product, I decided to purchase one for my smart meter.  The wire mesh guard acts as a Faraday cage, reflecting radio waves and sending them back to the electric company. It lets  just enough radio waves through to give them a meter reading. I  also purchased a Faraday cage from these people for my WiFi router. The guy who makes these is an electrician. His video testing the strength of  the RF frequency with and without the guard is a must see. It made me decide to buy the product.  Go to the Smart Meter Guard website to find it. The best book on the subject is "Overpowered," by Dr. Martin Blank, PhD. "Dirty Electricity," by Samuel Milham, MD is also good.

The ideas contained  in this book are practical, sensible ones. I especially liked the one on organizing your clothes closet where she suggests matching your outfits so you know which tops go with which bottoms .I also very much liked her ideas on organizing you email and social media. I know people who disagree with my ideas on this, so having Kathy agree was a warm fuzzy. I would recommend this book.

An expert on the subject of Electrical Magnetic Fields, Dr. Martin Blank presents the history of various EMF technologies, the studies assessing their health and environmental dangers, and what sensible steps to take to limit their harmfulness in your home and workplace. Dr. Blank's remedial solutions are sensible, affordable and easily implemented. I have read a number of books on the subject. This one, along with Samuel Milham's, "Dirty Electricity," are in my opinion the two best. I would highly recommend this book.

I would love to live on Island time.Unlike some of the  reviewers, I really enjoyed the book. It shows you how to live on island time even in a big city. While their island hopping lifestyle was simple and unhurried, there was plenty of work involved in caring for their sailboat, fetching water, grocery shopping, cooking, doing laundry and navigating the boat through all kinds of  weather. They met lots of interesting people, from other boaters to native islanders. When after three years they returned to the states, it was truly reverse culture shock. The book contained some good advice on how to simplify your lifestyle. and build stronger relationships. The cover and title title first drew me in.

Just got the book and like all the author's other books am really enjoying it. Our walk with Messiah is all about relationship which is what the author's  other devotional books are all about. I have gleaned many valuable relationship insights from these books and would highly recommend them all. This book tells you how to go about studying various Hebrew words for yourself. Great book.
With this one of a kind seven outlet surge protector you can shut off individual outlets or all of them at once. I really like it and may order a second one.

Truly Enjoyable! The producer truly loves frogs. His excellent photography and look at the many kinds of frogs from all over the globe make this video well worth watching.The man is an encyclopedia off knowledge about frogs. The video was well narrated.

The book is short but good. No fluff. Just solid Biblical analysis of Psalm 91. I love and do mean love the Hebrew meanings to words. If you are unsure as to what a particular passage is saying, look up its main words in the Hebrew or Greek. The author gives us the Hebrew definitions to the main words in this Psalm and then shares her conclusions concerning God's character and provision for us based on the meaning to those words in their original language. The book is encouraging and faith (trust) building.

One customer said this book was not cutting edge. Does everything have to be cutting edge? Maybe we need to return to long established, polite ways of doing things. While there are a lot of specific points to remember in how to graciously deal with people, the book takes us back to kind, gentle ways (respectful) of treating people. For example, I have  always endeavored to do unto others as I would have them do unto me, even when they don't do it. The last part is my addition. Instead, as the author suggests, do unto others as their best selves would have you do.  Good book.

From your WiFi router to your cordless land line and cell phone to your smart meter  emf emitting devices are all around us. Are they harmful and if they are what do we do to protect ourselves? This book is written by an expert in the field of emf. The research is thorough. It is well written, free of errors and is an informative read. The suggestions for diagnosing and correcting emf radiation high spots in your home and work place are simple and doable. I really enjoyed reading the book.

Doable is the highest compliment I can give the author. From the dietary recommendations to the tooth brushing protocol, the information makes sense. It is a very thorough look at every possible aspect of dental health. It is a well written, error free book by someone who knows their subject matter. I have started using the author's tooth brushing tips and am really impressed.

The book was well written, thoroughly researched and informative. I especially enjoyed the author's description of the no poo method of hair washing and details about the numerous benefits of the various fats in coconut oil. The book was well worth the price.Update: I read that the pH of your hair is 5-5.5. Baking Powder has a very alkaline pH of 9, which is hard on delicate hair. White vinegar has has an acid pH of 7. Apple cider vinegar has a higher pH. Vinegar is put on at the end of your shampoo to make your hair less alkaline.  It is also hard on the hair. Also, it isn't acidic enough to leave your hair its normal pH. I used it twice and stopped. One lady who used it for three years had itchy scalp, dandruff and constant split ends. If you don't want the unhealthy ingredients, use a healthy shampoo.

While I've been married awhile, weddings now often cost a lot, so I decided to read this book on budget weddings. Also a good friend is getting married. The book was well written, with many doable ideas to cut your wedding expenses. Two ideas I especially like. Since your guests are so important and you want to it  to be a memorable day for them, don't send them away hungry. Skimp on something other than food. If I were to do my wedding over, I would certainly do just that. You can have a buffet, which is cheaper than a dinner served at your table, but send them away with a full stomach. My other favorite idea is,  if you have enough household stuff, let people contribute money toward your honeymoon. Just because you have a budget wedding, doesn't mean you can't have what's important to you included in it. Armed with the facts and proper planning you can do just that.

I'm not friends or family, but found the book practical, well written and enjoyable to read. It wasn't alarmist and the suggestions were sensible and doable. An off the grid lifestyle isn't for everyone, which the author recognizes. Also, it's not an all or nothing deal. You can incorporate as few or many of the lifestyle changes into your life as you want. It was a short book, hence the four star review, but as I said it packed much usable information.

I am the spouse of "Wholly His" so this is written from a man's perspective. For the product to be any good at all the phone has to be secure in the holster, the holster has to be secure on the belt and the phone has to come out quickly to avoid missing a call. The i-Blason meets all three objectives very well.  The belt clip has a stiff steel spring, not just springy plastic plus a hooked end that goes around the belt. I have had belt hooks be secure for several months only to get knocked off when hit a certain way, I don't think that will happen with the i-Blason. Maximum security is with the phone vertical so gravity add to the security; I think it would hold horizontally but haven't tested it that way. It can also be oriented at an angle as the clip rotates with 15 increments.  The fit is excellent and the port openings line up precisely. The phone's three side buttons are covered with corresponding rubber buttons but they still operate as usual. The review wouldn't be complete without mentioning the feel of the shape and material in the hand, I like it every time I pick it up.  The kick stand will require a firm if not hard pull to get it out so use two of your strongest finger nails. i-Blason has put a lot of thought in to the design of this one.

The New Testament tells us we should all desire to prophecy. So just what is prophecy? How is it to be used? John Schoenheit gives a Scripturally based teaching on the various facets of this important subject. You'll walk away from reading this book with a much better understanding of Biblical prophecy.

Is there life after death? According to John Schoenheit there is, but not until the insurrection. After a person dies, his body and soul (breath) is gone and he is dead or asleep in the grave. Our spirit (soul) isn't floating around heaven if saved or hell if wicked and lost without a body. Rather at death we stop breathing and our bodies decay in the grave. At the insurrection the saved will receive new bodies and eternal life.  The wicked will be judged and perish by being burned up in the lake of fire. The lake of fire is not eternal. Schoenheit gives thorough Scriptural backing for his beliefs about the state of the dead. He does the same with the history of the Biblically inaccurate idea of the immortal soul. Most if not all of us have consoled a person(s) at a funeral with the comforting but false idea that their loved one is in heaven. As Schoenheit rightly contends, death is nasty. It's the wages or punishment for sin. In the future I will console people differently. Having lost loved ones myself, I know how hard it is. You'll never see or talk to them again on earth. I highly recommend this book. I also most highly recommend Edward Fudge's excellent book on hell.

Is God who is love and there is no unrighteousness in all he does, the author of evil? Does he cause bad things to happen to good people or even bad people for that matter? John Schoenheit contends and thoroughly backs his ideas with Scriptural proof that God isn't the author of evil. He does not cause  bad things to happen to anyone. Satan is the author of the non-stop evil and  wickedness we see all around us. We do not have to nor should we call evil good. Evil like its author is wicked. While God is all powerful, he is not all controlling. He gave angelic beings and man a free will. That means man and angels can chose to disobey God and do evil and he won't stop them. This is also the reason God doesn't just eliminate evil in all its nasty forms. Ever since the fall where man relinquished dominion over the earth to Satan, wars, violence, power hungry, greedy despots has been the norm. Satan loves to blame his evil works on God.  This will soon end when our Savior returns to set up his kingdom.  Satan and all else that is evil will perish. Read the book and discover the details.

Reports of war and violence dominate the news. No thinking person will deny that the world is headed towards a third world war and the return of our Savior. Who is responsible for all the evil that is taking pace today and has been since Adam and Eve first sinned? One chapter after the fall Cain kills Abel. Gregory Boyd contends that God stepped inside of time and doesn't know every detail of what will happen in the future. He has perfect memory of the past and can use that knowledge to make predictions for the future. He is  all powerful and able to make his predictions come to pass in his time. Just because God is all powerful, does not mean he is all controlling. He has given humans and angels (good and evil ones) a free will. They can choose to do good or evil. God does not control either humans or angels every decision. Granted it's a limited free will and in the end God triumphs over evil and the wicked perish.The book is 293 pages long. It is not a fast read, but well worth every minute of the time it takes to read it. He thoroughly backs each of his assertions with Scripture. Boyd talks about the pagan concept of evil and what both Testaments have to say about the subject. Satan and his evil angels rebelled and have been doing all in the power ever since to destroy God, the cosmos and all beings who side with the Creator. Satan and his fallen angels  are created beings, with limited powers, who will day soon be destroyed. They are the authors of evil. I highly recommend this book.

You'll likely miss the salt of the original if you drink this straight up. It is a bit bland. There are no off tastes thankfully!I'm not terribly concerned about my salt intake (although I probably should be).I use this juice only in Virgin/Boodly Marys and it very well may be the perfect base. I add Worcestershire Sauce which adds considerable salt. I then add a high quality hot sauce.My current favorite hot sauce is Marie Sharp's Orange Pulp Habanero Hot Sauce. Yet, I've only experimented with 5 hot sauces out of the 40 different ones I have on hand.I think this juice may well be the perfect starting point for a fine Virgin/Bloody Mary. Were you to use the original V8 you'd have too much salt once you add Worcestershire Sauce

Use only in very small quantities. It tastes surprisingly bitter. Often used in pickling or you can make celery salt adding one part ground celery seed to two or more parts of finely ground saltCelery salt is the main ingredient in "Old Bay" seasonings, per the manufacturer's web site and which I confirmed by looking at a container of Old Bay in my pantry.Used in very limited quantities - it adds to a Bloody Mary but I think I'll stick with Old Bay.A wasted purchase.

These hard taco shells are wider at the bottom than those traditionally sold which usually narrow at the bottom. That helps prevent cracking as you fill them. Of course, they will still crack as you bite into them but at least you can fill them. They are, like all other hard taco shells - quite brittle.Certainly this shape is an improvement over those that narrow at the bottom.I found the 6 pack (15 shells each) shipped (90 shells total) was cheaper at $12.00 total than my over-priced supermarket. They should keep forever.There is nothing special here except for a better shape.I find their taste bland, which may be a good thing, because it allows your ingredients to shine. I view them as a crunchy, largely tasteless, edible container.I wish they were not so brittle.Warning: Amazon co-mingles reviews of various Old El Paso products as if a hard taco shell was the same as a soft tortilla shell!  So it will take some very careful reading to discover which product a customer is rating. Naturally if you are looking at a hard taco shell you'd assume all the reviews were related to that product. That is NOT the case
A major brand, easily found in any supermarket.Mediocre in the extreme. Made from "tomato puree" (seems like tomato paste to me), water and tasteless chunks of onions, etc

Mild but well balanced. This is a concentrate (just add tomato juice and vodka).  It is mostly Worcestershire sauce balanced skillfully with chilies and a variety of other ingredients..Ingredients/per label: Worcestershire Sauce (Vinegar, Molasses, Sugar, Anchovies, Water, Hydrolyzed Soy and Corn Protein, Onions, Tamarinds, Salt, Garlic, Cloves, Chile Peppers, Natural Flavorings, Shallots), Spices, Chile Pepper Puree, Prepared Horseradish (Grated Horseradish Roots, White Distilled Vinegar, Soybean Oil, Citric Acid, Sugar), Lemon Juice Concentrate, Red Pepper Sauce, Celery Seed, Natural Flavorings and Xanthan Gum.Want it hotter - add a drop or two of your favorite hot sauce.

Similar to Marie Sharp's Habarnero Pepper Sauce (which adds a bit of sweetness using carrots), this sauce uses oranges instead. Is there a huge difference between the two- no! This orange pulp variety is a bit milder and if you have a delicate palette you might detect the orange versus carrot taste.As I type this - I'm trying a taste of each side by side - undiluted.Make no mistake this woman knows how to make a good hot sauce! Fresh tasting, with a sense of "purity" is how I would describe her hot sauces. They are NOT overly complex - a nice bit of sweetness at first blush then just heat, lingering heat but no off tastes.I don't see how anyone could go wrong with any of her hot sauces even if they lack complexity.Very nice in a Bloody Mary!How hot? About equal to Tabasco. Think of 3 or 4 tiny drops in a large Bloody Mary.Why 3 Stars? I'm seeking perfection! BTW: I'd rate Tabasco's original at 1 star.Elsewhere on the web this sauce goes for $3.99
Weak, little flavor. The beans are not even the oily black one would expect.

As an audio engineer and past member of the AES (Audio Engineering Society) I was curious about this CD.Unfortunately it contains dubious and potentially dangerous test signals. The company appears to no longer existWhat first caught my attention about this CD was the 5HZ signal. That is far below the range of human hearing which is traditionally viewed as 20hz to 20,000hz.Want to experience 5HZ?  See if you can move the palm of your hand back and forth 5 times in a second. If you can, you just created 5hz which can also be referred to as 5 cycles per second. I can't conceive what use this signal is except to destroy a sub-woofer. It certainly can't be heardIf any reviewer heard anything - it was NOT 5hz. In all probabilty it was the harmonic distortion of his sub-woofer being vastly over loaded (harmonic distortion is a multiple of the original frequency - but is pure distortion of the original signal ; For example - a third order harmonic distortion would be 15hz (3 x 5hz yet still not audible), fourth order would be 20hz, and so on. Any reviewer that claims he/she was hearing 5hz was in fact hearing 4th order or much higher harmonic distortion.I'll add that "hearing" 20hz is more like feeling it There are very few sub-woofers that can produce a 20hz signal without excessive harmonic distortion. When I say "very few" I mean VERY FEW and they normally employ a 15" speaker and are quite expensive. Fortunately, except for wealthy purists, a very good bass response down to 30 or 40 hz is very satisfying. Still it won't be cheap.Testing room acoustics and frequency response is highly complex and from what I can see this disc is not a serious effort

As an audio engineer and prior member of the AES (Audio Engineering Society) I'd like to offer the following commentsMost reviews are very confused about this "Digital Sound Noise Meter". I also should note that many of the reviewers were supplied with free samples!I'M not sure exactly what a "Digital Sound Noise Meter" is but I'll assume that it measures db SPL, aka sound pressure levels, using the db scale.Without knowing the frequency response of the microphone, it is largely a useless device. One reviewer, in a video, says it is 300hz to 8,000 hz without specifying deviation. That's close to the range of a telephone. (Human hearing goes from 20hz to 20,000hz). Other reviewers state the manufacturer specifies it is plus or minus 2db at 1000hz at 94db SPL. To understand exactly how meaningless that spec is consider the meter claims a range of 40 to 130 db SPL yet it is only tested at 94 db SPL. Secondly human hearing, as noted, runs from 20 hz to 20,000 hz/ Most meters would cover maybe 130 hz to perhaps 8,000 hz. Finally, the manufacturer self certifies these meaningless specs and no independent lab confirms them which would be the norm with quality meters.I have no doubt the numbers on its display increase in some manner as the sound gets louder. So what! It takes a fair amount of money to manufacture a good microphone. It takes even more money to calibrate it so it accurately displays db SPL. I doubt, in a hundred years, you could manufacture an accurate microphone for $20.00But lets assume you have a quality meter. You still have to know how to use it!!Typical misconceptions: Distance from the sound source REALLY matters. Place your cell phone (using speakerphone) and this meter next to each other and you'll see a fairly high db SPL level. Move the meter 6 inches away and the db SPL will drop considerably. Move the "meter" a foot away and it will drop considerably more.I'm not sure what this device is beyond a microphone of dubious quality that vaguely increases its reading as a sound gets louder. That may or may not relate to true sound pressure levels.What is clear is that some top notch reviewers don't know what they are reviewing. For example: place this "meter" very close to a loudspeaker and you will then get a very high db SPL level as one video reviewer did. You could then incorrectly pronouce that speaker as damaging to human hearing. That is almost certainly the wrong conclusion. This shows a fundamental misunderstanding of how distance effects sound pressure levels.Another easy test: speak with any friend in some typical setting. Now move closer, without your friend changing their volume or tone. Put your ear next to your friends mouth (if you dare and I don't advise this) and you will see how distance effects volume (aka db - SPL)I'm afraid there are a number of very flawed reviews that have little understanding of this type of product or how to use it.The seller has capitalized on many well intended yet very flawed reviews by highly rated reviewers to promote sales. Many reviewers were provided with free samples.Within a day of when I posted this review I received a YES "Was this review helpful to you?" Yet the next day two negative votes came in. These negative voters left no comments. I wonder who posted those votes. I have my suspicions

My recommendation is to buy locally some cans of V8 or Tomato Juice (5 or 12 oz) and a good hot sauce. That way you can taylor the heat and also get a much better tasting virgin/bloody MaryV8 and supermarket tomato jucies are also available in these smaller size cans (5.5 oz). I mention that because this appears to be a prime reason that many reviewers recommend Mr & Mrs T.Have a look at the ingredients in this stuff (from the Mr & Mrs T web site).INGREDIENTS MR & MRS T:Water, Tomato concentrate, vinegar, High fructose corn syrup, sea salt, spices, onion powder, lemon juice concentrate, paprika, hydrolyzed corn protein, ascorbic acid, disodium inosinate, etc, etcJust for COMPARISON I went to the V8 website:INGREDIENTS V8 JUICE:RECONSTITUTED VEGETABLE JUICE BLEND (WATER AND CONCENTRATED JUICES OF TOMATOES, CARROTS, CELERY, BEETS, PARSLEY, LETTUCE, WATERCRESS, SPINACH), CONTAINS LESS THAN 2% OF: SALT, VITAMIN C (ASCORBIC ACID), NATURAL FLAVORING, CITRIC ACID.Frankly I just purchase cans of tomato juice locally which normally consists of just tomato concentrate, water and salt. Then I add a dash of one of my favorite hot sauces, a dash of Lee and Perrins Worchestor sauce and I'm done

El Yucateco makes some decent hot sauces but like many companies, they produce a confusing array of hot sauces - each different - hoping to capture every possible segment of the hot sauce market. This brand is rarely great but usually reliable - hence my two star rating which may be a bit harsh. The Chipotle and Jalapeño varieties are excellent - 4 or 5 star.This sampler will give you a good introduction. The brown Habanero is quite potent - mostly fiery heat. The red Habanero is almost as hot but has some tomato mixed in. The green Habanero has a bit of garlic and is still quite potent. Yet the brown is the hottest - mostly pure heat. I personally prefer the green.The Chipotle sauce is in an entirely different class, made from a smoked dried jalapeño pepper. No where as hot as the above but truly excellent.El Yucateco almost makes a superb jalapeño sauce that is not included in this sampler, which is a shame.

I've tried other so-called Worcestershire sauces and none have come close to the original Lee and Perrins.At $47.00 including shipping for 3 gallons it was a great buy. Three of us split this order. I use this sauce in Bloody Marys and on steaks, hamburgers or any other type of beef. It is also wonderful in french onion soup. Unlike other reviewers, I don't marinate my steaks in it. Rather I douse it liberally over steaks, a number of times, as they cook on the grill.But the question remains, what will you do with 3 gallons? You could split it up with friends as I did. That is 384 ounces!  First consider the price advantage. 10 to 15 ounces of this sauce costs about $11.00 on Amazon. Update (August 2014) - now $5.44 ($0.54 / oz) & FREE Shipping on orders over $35. So there is/was a huge price advantage even if you threw two gallons away. .Taste: a Bloody Mary would never be complete without a dash of this sauce. However you'll never need very much of this sauce for that purpose. But on steaks, hamburgers, etc using a heavy dose several times per side as they cook (I don't marinate) --- you can use up quite a bit of sauce. What I've found is this keeps the steaks very juicy and imparts a very subtle flavor that you'll miss when it is absent.Highly recommended for steaks/beef, french onion soup, and Bloody MarysUpdate (August 2014): Since smaller bottles are more fairly priced think twice about ordering 3 gallons

I buy french roasts quite often on Amazon. I've tried many different brands but this is the first one that stood out. Unusally smooth with a fairly rich flavour yet one might call it somewhat mild for a french roast.I think I've finally found a coffee I'll stick with.

After taste tesing about 40 different hot sauces (everyone needs a hobby), seven of which where Chipotle based, this is one of my two favorities in that category (Chipotle based). The other is Tabasco's Chipotle.If you are not familiar with the Chipotle pepper - it is a smoked dried Jalapeno. Low heat and a nice smoked taste.I highly rate this sauce.

I use these on a kitchen trash can that is 22" tall by 11" x 16".I imagine they would fit any trash can that is reasonably close to those measurements or smaller.The bags are quite strong and the drawstring makes them very convenient.Highly recommended.

Given all the positive reviews I was anxious to try these noodles. Now I'm stuck with 30 packets.I was very disappointed. Apparently the many reviewers who have rated this product so highly have never tried any other Asian noodle soups.The packets are quite small - a serving for one, at most. Much smaller than average!Taste - medium heat (using all of the flavor packets) combined with a hint of lemon grass and displaying no other flavors that I could detect. I found this soup rather bland although I did like that hint of lemon grass.Why the discrepancy in reviews? Lets take one example: "heat" or "spiciness". Some reviewers rate this product as being "very hot" and others rate it as "medium". Why the difference? It really is quite simple: different cultures and different palates. For most Americans (if there is such a person) this soup may seem quite hot. However in many Asian cultures it is fairly mild. The beauty of ALL these types of noodles/soups is they provide a spice packet(s) and you can add as little or as much as you want. However with this soup - after using all the packets - it was relatively mild to me. I called it "medium hot"Deceptive advertising: There are no whole shrimp or shrimp pieces as depicted on the label. As I write this review - I'm looking at a packet and reading from its label: The Major Single ingredient is wheat flour, followed by palm oil, then salt, then sugar, then MSG, then dried red chili powder, then Chile powder, then ... well it goes on and on to finally include very small quanties of fish sauce and dried shrimp powder along with many other lesser ingredients. BTW: Ingrediants are always listed from largest to smallest on an ingrediant labelNot recommended! A true two star product - mediocreAs an alternative try: Nong Shim Shin Noodle Ramyun soup, Gourmet Spicy Picante. That soup offers more flavor and comes in a much larger serving size. The soup costs about $17.00 (with free shipping) for 20 much larger packets. That is not only a better deal, the soup has more flavor. Yet I only gave that soup three stars yet having tasted this one maybe it deserves 4 stars or this one deserves 1 star. Interestingly when I rated that soup with 3 stars I came under considerable fire from the many customers that rated it 5 stars. It seems people fall in love with whatever noodle soup they first encounter.I am NOT suggesting that Nong Shim Shin Noodle Ramyun Gourmet Spicy Picante soup is some panacea. It is just another less than healthy quick noodle soup which I enjoy and I find tastes better than this one. Remember, I only gave the Nong Shin soup three stars.Conclusion: The many 4/5 star reviews of Mama Tom Yum strike me as having been written by people with a very limited perspective. In other words they had not tried many of the other availabe noodle soups.

There is not much more to say other than these are a fine and affordable set of test leads. They are longer than you probably need at 3 feet each. They are color coded, the wires are soldered to the alligator clip, and that is combined with a crimped strain refief. A LARGE alligator clip is used (about the length of a large paper clip but fatter). I can't, as an electrical engineer, imagine who would want more from such a simple product.PS: wire gauge (aka wire size/diameter) is in the range of 20. That is an educated guess. Far too many reviews have concentrated on this minor topic! FYI: A larger gauge number denotes a SMALLER physical diameter of wire. However at three feet in length, even a small diameter wire (larger gauge number) is perfect for 99% of all testing situations. While you don't want resistance in a test lead - resistance is calcuated by the diameter of the wire (a bigger diameter being better) times length (shorter lengths being better). Given the short length of these leads they are fine, typical of what has always been used in test leads for decades, and appropriate for most applications.Who might NOT want these test leads? While this list is hardly complete, no one should use these test leads going to a starter motor on a car for example, which draws massive amounts of current. I'm sure electricans can come up with other very heavy ampere (current) situations that would need a larger diameter wire too but in most "normal" situations these test leads are fine and most users should not worry about the wire gauge/wire diameter.Confusion: Apparently some people have received shorter lengths of cables and also inferior ones. I suspect these were NOT Elenco cables. I'd simply recommend to these people - if you are sure you ordered Elenco cables but did not receive them - well - return them at the sellers expense. The part number on my bag of cables is TL-6LG and says "Elenco Electronics, Inc". If you don't get what you ordered make Amazon take them back and also pay for return shipping, etc. Amazon is very good about that

Given all the positive reviews, I was anxious to try these noodles. Now I'm stuck with 30 packets.I am very disappointed. Apparently the many reviewers who have rated this product so highly have never tried any other Asian noodle soups.The packets are quite small - a serving for one, at best. Much smaller than average in my experience.Taste - medium heat (at most - using all of the flavor packets) combined with a hint of lemon grass and displaying no other flavors that I could detect. I found this soup rather bland although I liked the hint of lemon grass.Why the discrepancy in reviews? Lets take one example: "heat" or "spiciness". Some reviewers rate this product as being "very hot" and others rate it as "medium" at best. Why the difference? It really is quite simple: different cultures and different palates. For most Americans (if there is such a person) this soup may seem quite hot. However in many Asian cultures it is fairly mild. The beauty of ALL these types of noodles/soups is that they provide a spice packet(s) and you can add as little or as much as you want. However with this soup - after using all the packets - it was relatively mild to me. I called it "medium heat"Deceptive advertising: There are no whole shrimp or shrimp pieces as depicted on the label. As I write this review I'm looking at a packet and reading from its label: The Major Single ingredient is wheat flour, followed by palm oil, then salt, then sugar, then MSG, then dried red chili powder, then Chile powder, then ... well it goes on and on to finally list fish sauce and dried shrimp powder along with many other lesser ingredientsNot recommended! A true two star product - mediocreAs an alternative try: Nong Shim Shin Noodle Ramyun soup, Gourmet Spicy Picante. That soup offers more flavor and comes in a much larger serving size.  The soup costs about $17.00 (with free shipping) for 20 much larger packets. That is not only a better deal, the soup has more flavor. But I only gave that soup three stars.  Interestingly when I rated the Nong Shim soup at only 3 stars I came under considerable fire from many customers who had rated it 5 stars.I am NOT suggesting that Nong Shim Shin Noodle Ramyun Gourmet Spicy Picante soup is some kind of panacea. It is just another less than healthy quick noodle soup which I enjoy more. Remember, I only gave that soup three stars.Conclusion: The many over the top reviews of Mama Tom Yum (meaning 4/5 star reviews) strike me as having beem written by people with a very limited perspective

I'm an electrical engineer and for over 30 years I have relied on Deoxit for cleaning, rejuvenating, lubricating and protecting electrical connections. It is very close to being magical - cleaning noisy switches, intermittent relays, and potentiometers (volume controls). Once applied, you will get many more years of additional service.Craig (aka Hosa/the name of their distributor) Deoxit is the very best electrical contact cleaner available and it also improves electrical performance and protects contacts for years to come. However Craig makes a dizzing array of cleaners/contact shields so their products are rarely used by non-professionals. Yet, for decades, these products have been and remain the platinum standard for cleaning/improving/lubricating and protecting any type of electrical connection. Often these products seem almost magical in their ability to rejuvenate switches, relays, potentiometers (volume controls), etcDespite a confusing array of products their most universal product is what Craig or Hosa (Craig's distributor) calls its D5 series. If you see D5 in the product number you've likely got the most appropriate product! In fact, a D5 series cleaner is required for any connection that is NOT new or already perfectly clean.The most universal product is a DeOxit D5 series SPRAY. It cleans contacts, flushes away the garbage, lubricates and leaves behind a protective coating that improves the electrical connection and also protects it for years to come.The only problem I have with the brush on version is that it is rare that you can actually get to the contacts of whatever you are working on. The spray-on version eliminates that problemHighly recommended!

DeoxIT is manfuctured by Caig but is often sold under the name of one their distrubutors "Hosa". Whether the product you buy says "Caig DeoxIT" or "Hosa DeoxIT" - it is the same product. "DeoxIT" is a registered tradename and that is what you are looking for. Hopefully that information eliminates some initial confusion.As an electrical engineer I've used DeoxIT for over 30 years. In fact - it is the only contact cleaner, lubricant, and contact enhancer I trust. From Boeing, Bose, General Electric, Hewlett Pack, etc, etc this product is the gold standard and widely used in manufacturing and within small professional circles.Prior to the internet and companies like Amazon this product was unknown and largely unavailable.Having said that ---- every consumer should know that ALL DeoxIT products are superior, ALL formulas are virtually guaranteed to do NO harm and even if you don't use the optimum formula of DeoxIT it will still, quite likely, improve a poor connection and/or protect a new one.DeoxIT is sold in 4 broad categories.D series - first and foremost a heavy duty contact cleaner with contact enhancer/protection - I'd say this is Caig/Hosa's most universal productS series (aka Shield S series) - for outdoor environments. Particularily benefical in salt or other harsh outdoor environments. If the connections are not new - cleaning with a D series is required. I'd use this on a boat, an outdoor generator, etcG Series (aka Gold series) - designed for gold and base metals. It offers minor cleaning properties. For gold contacts it offers near perfect protection and will enhance electrical connections for gold, etc. However its cleaning properties are minimal and since gold does not oxidize and usually offers a near perfect connection to begin with this product is largely unneeded. Yet, if you have highly sensitive circuit boards with gold plated connectors, operating at very low voltages, using gold plated connectors that might act up from time to time then this is your product. If you have other gold plated connections such as used in audio, etc this product is largely unneeded yet it will do no harm and may slightly enhance the connection over the very long term (years) as would the D series product.F Series (aka Fader F series) - desiged for "faders" aka "volume controls" aka "pots" or potentiometers aka rotary controls. If that applies to what you are working on then this is the most appropriate cleaner/lubricant. It works on carbon based (extremely common) or conductive plastic controls which essentially encompasses the entire universe of rotary controls.In the end, I hope this description helps you pick the best formula for your needs but the bottom line is the Caig/Hosa contact cleaners/enhancers are all first class and even if you pick a less than perfect formulation it will not only do NO harm but likely still fix your problem. The most universal product, as previously noted, is the D series spray cleaner/restorer.You can call Caig at 800-CAIG-123 for advice

Now no one should expect much from a radio in the ten dollar price range and I didn't get much.Volume was fairly weak and the reception was quite poor.I first tested it against my car's radio parked 10 feet away. The car's radio picked up probably four times as many FM stations. It was startling how poor the FM reception of this radio was.I then tested it against Panasonic's RF-2400 portable AM/FM Radio - side by side and the Panasonic played much louder and picked up a few more stations. I'm an electrical engineer and the antennas were orientated the same and I meticulously compared the sound and number of stations received. But that is certainly not an entirely fair comparison - the Sony is a $13.00 radio and the Panasonic a $30 radio. And I don't want to give anyone the impression the Panasonic is a good radio - it isn't - certainly it plays louder than the Sony but it also has rather poor FM reception.I'd pass on this radio - it reeks of cheapness although if you need an inexpensive radio for emergencies when your power is out - the large D cell batteries this radio uses should give you many weeks of service. But D cells are not all that cheap and a battery operated radio would be a poor choice if you use it daily.As an emergency radio I'd give it 3 stars. As a radio I used daily - 1 star.Consider Sony's ICF-38 radio, at about $30.00. It might be a wisher purchase. I have not tried the Sony ICF38 but the reviews are quite positive. The Panasonic is decent but far from good. My Sony ICF10 is being returned. I've had cheap portables purchased 20 years ago that were much better.If I wanted an emergency radio to pack away - given the D batteries it uses - which have huge power reserves compared to AA batteries - I'd buy it for a survival kit.Conclusion: Poor reception, relatively low volume and given it is battery powered only, it is a poor choice for regular use.

This is a simple extension cord - it is 15 feet long and a little thicker than your average pencil. It comes with a MALE stereo mini-phone plug on one end (plus an adapter to turn the mini male phone plug into a male 1/4" phone plug) and a FEMALE mini stereo jack.I used it to plug into the "audio out" jack on the back of a current model Samsung High Definition TV and ran it around the room and then plugged it into in a set of inexpensive headphones (most often used for an Ipod, etc). Since the headphones had a built-in volume control - my Dad now had a set of headphones he could use and not blast my mother out of the room by turning up the volume too high on the TV. This proved to be a simple yet elegant solution. It was also cheap at $6.00 for the extension cable and about $15.00 for the headphones. It also should be very reliable since nothing beats a "hard wired" connection.This is a simple 15 foot EXTENSION cable that features a stereo MALE mini plug (or a MALE standard stereo 1/4" plug using the supplied adapter) on one end of the cable and a stereo mini FEMALE receptacle on the other end.The cable appears robust and the connectors seem to be gold plated which means they will not oxidize and thus should create a long term, reliable connection.Highly recommended. I'm an electrical engineer and can NOT find any fault with this cable. The price amazes me.

HDMI cables are almost universal for connecting high definition audio/visual equipment. A single cable carries audio (stereo, multi-channel DTS, Dolby, etc ), plus digital video signals (these cables are capable of carrying video signals far greater than are currently in use) plus ethernet.You will see various descriptions and HDMI.org - the organization that creates these standards has used a confusing mix of categories and descriptions over the years. This organization now "forbids" designations such as HDMI 1.4 which these cables are. Now their highest rated cables can only carry the designation "high speed" (or not) and if it applies - "supports ethernet". In the past, designations such as HDMI 1.3, etc were allowed. Many manufacturers ignore the current rules so you may see HDMI 1.4 advertised.The bottom line is every HDMI cable ever made, including ones made years ago, have the same pin to pin connections, the same connector and the same number of pins. What has changed REGARDING CABLES is the organization has now required better shielding, construction, etc so the cable can carry more data at a much higher rate. So you can buy this cable sold by Amazon with the assurance it will work with your oldest gear and your newest gear -- equally well and likely will work perfectly for new equipment made years in the future!What is confusing and rather sad is your actual equipment may not support many of the features a high quality HDMI cable supports. What features a manufacturer creates in their equipment has always been a matter of choice for the equipment manufacturer. They can choose what features are present in their equipment and more often than not, that is not clearly stated in the specifications. So one manufacturer can legitimately claim HDMI 1.4 compliance yet many of the potential features of that spec are not be present. Picture this: One manufacturer could employ every feature available in the specification while another choses not to. Yet both manufacturer's could label their equipment as compliant with the current HDMI specification.But the simple beauty of purchasing a "high speed with ethernet cable" is you have purchased the BEST possible cable that is almost certainly better than the gear it connects to. And this cable is cheap and will work perfectly with your oldest gear too (assuming it has an HDMI connector).If there was ever a simple buying decision it is with these cables - just buy them! There is zero possibility they won't work perfectly (putting aside a manufacturing defect).To repeat myself: The ultimate bottom line - a "high speed" (aka HDMI 1.4 high speed) cable "with ethernet" supports any and all features available on the newest gear and will work on the oldest equipment available too.  So if you see "high speed" and "supports ethernet" - that is the very best designation you can find for a cable. In all likelihood many of the features/data rates this cable can transmit will NOT EXIST even on the most current equipment, including something you bought just yesterday. But given the low cost of the cable do you really care if the cable is better than your gear?BTW - older HDMI cables will likely perform just as well as these newer ones and I would not upgrade your cables needlessly.PS: "Audio return" does not affect the cable itself. It is a new feature some manufacturers may or may not employ in their gear. To quote HDMI.org "All HDMI cables will support Audio Return Channel functionality when connected to Audio Return Channel-enabled devices"Length: add a couple of feet to what you think you need. Remember you want to be able to pull a piece of equipment from a rack or shelf while it still remains connected.I'm an electrical engineer and I passed the test to become a "certified HDMI installer" after studying various white papers on the technology. I scored over 90% on my first taking of HDMI.org's test. Somewhere in my downloads is a nice certificate that I guess I'm supposed to display.

What more can I say is I bought one and it failed in three years and after about 8 uses. There are far more detailed reviews (including mine) on the 85lb spreader.This is not the case of one bad sample but what I believe is a fundamentally flawed design.Buyer beware!I should note that during the three years and approximately eight uses - it was a perfect spreader. No one could ask for more - it worked perfectly.If this review seems contradictory - it is. What you have is a near perfect spreader that suffers from a few cheap components that severely limited its lifespan.

True Junk - the spreader mechanism corroded in three short years to the point of becoming non-functional. It had become completely frozen, despite light use.History: I purchased this spreader at a local Home Depot. I used it twice a year to spread fertilizer/lime on a small lawn. I stored it (empty) in my garage between uses. Within three years (about six to eight uses) the metal drive shaft (that spins the propeller) had corroded so badly in its bearing that it could not be freed with oils, solvents, etc. Even an air racket would not free it!I thought I was buying a professional spreader that would last a lifetime but rather I had bought an expensive piece of junk.One last failure: While the spreader was already junk, I put the spreader away in the garage - postponing throwing it out. Come spring cleanup this year - I pulled it out of the garage for trash pickup and noticed the plastic hopper have developed stress cracks and a hole. That is how poorly manufactured the plastic is. And these flaws appeared while the spreader was empty, in storage, in a well ventilated garage!I can honestly state this is the worse piece of equipment I've ever purchased in the last twenty years. If Agri-Fab were willing to ship me a new one of these, each and every year, for life -- I'd pay the asking price. Otherwise - I'd look elsewhere.(BTW: During its short lifetime; it worked extremely well)Free advice to Agri-Fab: Upgrade your drive/propeller shaft to stainless steel and improve the grade of plastic you use in the hopper. Then, you'd have a true winner - everything else is well made. Also - as noted - when it worked - it spread perfectly and with ease. It is a shame these design flaws exist because when it worked, this spreader worked flawlessly.If this review seems contradictory - it is. What you have is a near perfect spreader that suffers from a few cheap components that severely limited its lifespan.

First of all lets define what this product is. I'm an electrical engineer and I hope the following helps.This device has 2 female Ethernet connectors - one at either end. So it is meant to join together two Ethernet cables (which almost always have male connectors on both ends). You can use it with CAT5, CAT5e or CAT6 cables since all share the same pin connections and use the same connector. (It is only the cable itself that differs between these different types of cables). So, quite simply, this coupler can be used to join together two ethernet cables to create a longer length.  If you look at many of the reviews published here - people have done just that with this coupler and, not surprising, it worked perfectly.However, this coupler ALSO fits a "keystone" wallplate. Notice in the picture the various latches etc on it. What that means is it will snap into a wall-plate with a "keystone" opening/hole (which are common enough on wallplates). So you can buy a wall plate with a "keystone" hole (opening), snap this coupler into place on the wall plate and then you take an Ethernet cable with pre-attached male plugs and plug it into the rear of the coupler. Now you have a wall plate with a female jack on the front and you can plug any standard Ethernet cable into this wall plate. Nice and simple, except, of course, that you have to fish the Ethernet cable through your walls, cut an opening in your wall and install a box for the wall-plate.What is NOT to like.1.) This type of coupler generally costs about 90 cents to $1.50 for just one (try monoprice) not $5.00.2.) It assumes you are using pre-wired Ethernet cables - that means you are stuck with purchasing finished cat5e/6 cables of a FIXED length with connectors already installed. That is hardly ideal if you are wiring a Whole House (NOT just joining two existing ethernet cables together) but hardly a problem if you want just to make one or two  connections.This type of connector is useful for those of us that want to either join 2 ethernet cables together OR want to create ONE or TWO wall plate connections, using a pre-purchased cat 5e/6 cable (obviously make sure you purchase the right length of Cat 5e/6 cable) and don't forget you need a keystone wall-plate plus an existing wall box.HOWEVER --- AND HERE IS WHERE I TAKE EXCEPTION WITH SOME POPULAR REVIEWS - This is certainly NOT the best solution for wiring or re-wiring a WHOLE house let alone a small office. If you are starting from scratch and wiring a whole house or office you should use raw cat 5e or cat 6 cable and terminate it without a coupler. Couplers are always a potential weak point (all connections technically are) and keeping your cable lengths as short as possible is another sound guideline. Terminating cat 5/6 cable is reasonably easy. So if you are doing a whole house you should run raw Cat 5e or Cat 6 and terminate it with a "punch down" female ethernet keystone jack. The advantage of this is you can keep your cable runs to exactly what is needed and you eliminate a coupler. The disadvantage is you need a tool kit (stripper, crimper and punch down tool). These are often marketed as a network tool kit (at least that is the term Monoprice uses) and they cost about $80.00. But that price ALSO includes a cable tester which is very nice to have and it assures you that you have created very reliable connections.There is nothing wrong with this coupler other than being vastly overpriced or over used as a common connection in a whole house/office setup. If you are just connecting two ethernet cables together this coupler is a perfect solution. But if you want to install a wall-plate - you also need to know that you need to purchase a keystone faceplate, have an existing box in your wall (or buy and install one) and you must purchase pre-finished Cat 5/6 cables of a fixed - and hopefully - correct length.HOWEVER - If you want to install more than a few wall-plates - this is the wrong solution!!!! You should buy bulk cable and eliminate these couplers.CABLE INFO: Cat 5e cable is excellent (100 MHZ) and Cat 6 cable (250 MHZ) is essentially overkill even in a large home/medium sized office but there is no disadvantage to using Cat6 cable except for a slight increase in cost (which is fairly minor). Another comment about Cat 6 -- it is a bit thicker and not quite as easy to run/terminate. Avoid plain Cat 5 cable (in other words: you ONLY want Cat 5e or Cat 6). It is extremely unlikely you will ever need Cat 6, even in a mansion but if you want to future proof a home installation then go with Cat 6 cable if it makes you feel better. Cat 6 is overkill but many of us prefer to use the very best despite no real gains. In a large office environment (and I mean LARGE -  NEW CONSTRUCTION) - CAT 6 is the only way to go assuming a new installation. However, in many offices (small,medium or large), now and in the future Cat5e will work perfectly.Hope this helps!

A simple portable radio that can be powered by the supplied AC power cord or by 4 AA batteries (not supplied). No storage is provided for the AC cord - an annoyance.I'm an electrical engineer. This portable certainly plays loudly enough but reception, particularly on the FM band, is not good. AM reception was decent, pulling in signals from high powered AM stations that were 60+ miles away without a problem.FM reception was not nearly as good. This radio had trouble pulling in many FM stations in my area. I first compared it to my car stereo parked just 10 feet away and then an old, beat up portable radio, from Radio Shack that was 20 years old. Both were much better than the Panasonic. FM signal reception is mediocre at best. Both the sensitivity (the ability to pick up a station) and selectivity (the ability to tune into one station that is near another one) was fair to poor. On the plus side, this inexpensive portable will work in a power outage and provide music when you are out and about. Its volume is fairly loud.So for $36.00 what can you expect? Maybe (?) no more than this radio provides.In short, I was expecting far better reception from this radio. A mono radio, technically should have far better performance than a stereo one such as that used in your car (yet car radios are very well made) so maybe that is not a fair comparison.The Sony ICF38 may be the better choice. The Sony ICF-38 seems almost identical to this Panasonic (offering both battery and AC power) yet it has far better reviews.I ordered the Sony ICF10 and tested it side by side with this Panasonic. Now this Sony is battery operated only and costs about a third of the Panasonic. The Panasonic was  better in one important aspect: it played much louder! It also pulled in a few more FM stations. Now this is not an entirely fair test, given the difference in price but many reviews lead me to believe that ALL Sony portables were better. That is certainly NOT the case regarding Sony's ICF10. The Panasonic is much better regarding volume but only slightly better in reception.The Sony ICF-f38 is roughly comparable in price and offers both battery and AC operation. It is a model you should consider but candidly I'm tired of testing portable radios and I'll live with this Panasonic - its OK (at best) but years ago you could get far better for the same price. I wish I had the energy to test it against the Sony ICF38It is hard to recommend this radio but I'm too lazy to ship it back. This review is far from complete because I can only tell you the the very inexpensive Sony ICF-10 is even worse (hard to believe) and just possibly - the Sony ICF-38 MIGHT be better.The one take away from my review should be that this Panasonic is a mediocre radio

I like Knorr/Lipton side dishes. They are all easy to prepare, cook in about 6 minutes and all you will need is a pot with a cover.This Rice Pilaf is NOT some culinary delight, but the taste is certainly decent, some might say "good" and it is definitely both easy and quite quick to prepare. I'm not sure anyone should expect more than that from a packet of rice and a bit of seasonings; designed to be cooked in just a few minutes.You might disagree with my 3 star rating but I tend to grade products on some absolute scale (meaning 5 stars = gourmet). This product is far better than the Rice-a-Roni pilaf I recently tried and also much simpler and quicker to prepare too.If you want a simple, easy to prepare rice pilaf and you are comparing it to other "rice in a box" mixes - give it 4 or 5 stars.

This product worked for me but I underwent a long and intensive regimen of in-hospital antibiotics for many months. My entire digestive system was out of order and the doctors were largely clueless about how to treat it.Then one fine physician "prescribed" this product. Within a few weeks I was returned to normal. I've since discontinued its use and I'm fine. But it made a huge difference within about a month and I credit this product for jump starting my digestive system where all other regimens had failed.While manufacturers of these products would like to suggest that this become a daily supplement - used day after day - month after month - year after year --- I strongly suspect that this type of product has a limited usage but that does not mean it is without merit. Far from it!I'm certainly not a doctor and there may be other circumstances/treatments you've undergone that have killed off the normal bacteria in your digestive tract. But I am of the opinion that for most people this is an expensive supplement that will likely produce no results unless your circumstances are a bit unique.At the same time, it produced dramatic improvements in my rather unique case and I only used it for a month and now, many months later, I'm doing just fine, without ever using it again.A simple suggestion: try it, at most, for two months. See if you get any results. Follow the instructions regarding dosage and be sure to store it at or BELOW 75 degrees (that is written on the product's label and in summer, even with air conditioning, you could exceed that temperature).

My first piece of advice is to check the date of any review. Much has changed over the years! I'm writing this in March of 2013.This is a fine device and it works quite well. I recommend its purchase but everyone should be aware of the modest yet mandatory monthly fees. After you buy this device you MUST pay between $3.50 to $4.00 a month (that is the absolute minimum - actual cost varies by zip code) every month to OOMA. For that modest fee you'll get unlimited* free phone calls through out the USA, Caller-ID, 911 service, answering service, etc at this basic rate. OOMA's basic service is quite good and far from crippled.What is the OOMA Telo?A device that connects between your existing phones (wired or wireless or both) and the internet to make phone calls. Your computer does not even have to be on and no software is needed/used and/or supplied. To repeat myself, you only need an active high speed internet connection for this device to work. This is identical to what cable providers (such as Comcast, ATT Uverse, etc) offer in their TV/internet/phone packages. These cable providers also dump your phone calls onto the internet and then charge you $40 or $50 a month for just the telephone portion of your service. OOMA is also nearly identical to Vonage yet much cheaper too.Is OOMA free?NO (although it once was). Figure about $4.00 a month (it varies slightly by zip code) for unlimited* USA calls with caller ID, 911, answering service, etc with OOMA's "basic" service. Their "premiere" service, offers a number of very advanced features (see their website) and costs an additional $10.00 a month added to the previously mentioned $4.00 a month charge. So to be clear - the premiere service costs about $14.00 a month and OOMA's basic service costs about $4.00 a month. Keep in mind OOMA's basic service has a wide range of features so it is far from basic and/or useless. In fact, their "basic" service is exactly what I use. Thankfully - OOMA only offers two levels of service - basic and premiere so you can easily review the differences on their web siteWhat equipment/services does OOMA require?Simple - a "high speed" internet connection but OOMA does NOT require your internet connection be very fast. In fact, by todays standards, it can be incredibly slow. Interestingly, OOMA does not clearly specify a recommended internet speed but, given various forum posts, it seems that even a lowly speed of 1 MPS is more than adequate. So if you have any type of internet connection other than an old fashioned dial up connection, this device should work just fine. Your existing phones will also work just fine too. No actual phone is included with the device but it is easy to hook up your existing home wiring and existing phones via a single telephone cord plugged between the OOMA telo device and any telephone jack. That type of setup is identical to what cable providers or Vonage uses.Is OOMA a good deal?I'd say it is a GREAT DEAL but here are the figures. You pay a fairly hefty up front cost to purchase the OOMA Telo device (between $150 and $200) and then it will cost you about $4.00 or $14.00 a month for OOMA's services. Compare that to your monthly costs for internet based phone service from your cable provider. Within the first year you'll likely come out ahead and after the first year --- the savings really add up. OOMA is also considerably cheaper than Vonage which charges about $25.00 a month PLUS taxes and fees of about $9.00 to $13.00 for their unlimited* USA/Canadian calling plan. So Vonage really costs about $35.00 a month. However, Vonage does not charge for their equipment.  Yet you will still come out ahead with OOMA in the first year and keep saving considerably more thereafter.Voice Quality:It is generally excellent and since OOMA has put a lot of technology into this device I suspect it is not only as good as what you get from your cable provider but likely better. I did several test calls from my OOMA system, calling myself on another line (which was an actual, old fashioned, hard wired landline - the gold standard). Beyond a very slight delay, the voice quality was superb. BTW: I'm an electrical engineer. Yet nothing beats a hard wired, old fashioned, telephone connection.The Disadvantages:The only disadvantage I can see is it takes a (tiny) bit of effort to install the OOMA in comparison to just having a tech from your cable provider installing everything. OOMA has made this device very simple to install but some folks like everything to be done for them and here (obviously) the cable provider comes out ahead. Also to be fair - an elderly person or someone who is absolutely clueless might have some difficulty but OOMA has gone overboard in making it a very simple device to install. Yet, to be very clear, you have to know where your modem is and find a telephone jack near it and run the supplied cable. Then go to OOMAs web site and supply some simple information (like your name and address so 911 knows where to go) and a credit card number so they can bill you.Another problem for OOMA, Vonage, Cable providers, etc is you need electrical power to keep your phones working. Traditional, old fashioned telephone lines provide their own power that is sent over their wires. I can't tell you the number of times my home has lost power (I'm in a bad service area and we loose power at least 4 times a year but rarely more than 20 days total in a given year) but my traditonal landline phones always keep working. I use OOMA for a second line only. If you have good cell phone service this may not matter or if your electrical power is far more reliable it probably is not a concern. For the infirmed and those that need a lifeline - you want a battery backup or an old fahioned telephone line.Other Comments:I really like my OOMA telo unit but I resent OOMA's current advertising. This is NOT a one time purchase nor is ANY free service included except for the first 2 months!!! At minimum - figure about $4.00 a month after you spend between $150 and $200 for the device. Without paying at least $4.00 a month you will find you have purchased a useless device (meaning a "brick" - techno parlance - for an electronic device that is as useless as a brick)! Now $4.00 a month is not much but why advertise OOMA as free????? That strikes me as deceptive. Shame on you OOMA when you have produced such a fine device and such a reasonably priced telephone service.* Unlimited calling is NOT unlimited calling. OOMA says (in the fine print) that it includes up to 5,000 minutes per month and Vonage says (in even finer print - actually this was quite hard to find)  their "unlimited" plan includes up to 3000 minutes per month. Clearly both services want to discourage call centers and businesses from using their products. OOMA, on its web site says "We have never terminated a customer that has used the service for residential purposes." Vonage says their "unlimited" (actually a 3000 minute plan) suits 95% of its customers. I believe both of them. These minutes apply ONLY to out-going calls for OOMA. I'm uncertain about Vonage. I also suspect that cable companies have similar caps but I have not researched this.I would NOT RECOMMEND the OOMA HD2 handset. I tried it and then returned it. I recommend you just stick with your existing phones. This handset is not required and I preferred my existing cordless and wired phones. See my review of OOMA's HG2 handset, but be aware, there are some advantages to users that use OOMA's premiere services if they purchase this handset.

This is one of those books that I call a digressionography. The idea is that the author starts with a single event, and then to flush out his story he follows every thread from the original story, adding a subplot repeatedly to the main one. This can be annoying, if the author lets the subplots take over the story to the point that you get confused about the main plot, but it works here because author Schechter doesn't let things get out of hand. The main plot is the murder trial of Roland Molineaux, the son of a minor Civil War General (try looking him up in a serious or even lengthy history of the war and see where you get) who was a prominent figure in the business community after the war, and very active in city politics and veterans' organizations for the next 50 years or so. Roland was a man-about-town and businessman who worked at a paint factory (the business his father was so successful in) and he was accused of poisoning someone accidentally, while intending to kill a man he really hated. The interesting thing about the case was that a *second* person had been poisoned to death earlier, and in that instance Molineaux had a more concrete motive: he was rivals with the guy for the hand of a young woman. The problem there was that the dead guy's attending physician insisted that his patient had died of diphtheria, and wouldn't change the cause of death on the death certificate even after testing was done on his organs and the presences of the poison conclusively proven. When Molineaux came to trial for the other killing, the prosecution was allowed to bring in all sorts of evidence relating to the earlier killing, and things got interesting as a result.I found this book to be interesting and reasonably well-constructed. It is a bit long, but this sort of book usually isn't short. I really enjoyed it.

I'm something of a C.J. Box fan. I like the cowboy-as-detective thing and I've been following Box since he only had 1-2 books in print. This current entry in the series is actually one of his better books. Sometimes authors who write series get into ruts, and the plots begin to repeat themselves. Here Box, when he revisits themes he's touched on before, has a fresh take on them, doesn't just rehash what he'd already done.In the current entry, Box's protagonist Joe Pickett learns that his middle, adopted daughter has been badly injured, apparently attacked by someone, and left by the side of the road for dead. Pickett immediately suspects her no-account boyfriend, a rodeo champion who is a bit full of himself, and who Joe has never liked. However, the kid has an apparently unbreakable alibi: he was badly injured in a rodeo riding a bull, and has the injuries to prove it. Then a crazy survivalist is found to have some of the daughter's things in his trash, and before they can question him properly he kills himself.Meanwhile Nate Romanowski, a survivalist and falconer who's also Joe's best friend, has been released from prison. However, as soon as he's out he runs into trouble, and things go completely sideways from there. I won't tell you any more because it'll ruin the plot, but it's all quite interesting, fun, and suspenseful...Very good book and a good entry in the series.

I stumbled across this book at the LA Times Festival of Books, where I paid $10 for it...a steal considering it runs between $25-50 here on Amazon when I look. I'd never heard of Platt before, but I've been looking for some time for a book about the Taiping Rebellion, or Civil War, or whatever you wish to call it. Unfortunately this book is more a history of the Taipings' attempts to contact Europeans, and Britain's relations with both the Taipings and their Qing Dynasty rivals, than it is an actual history of the war itself. Oddly Platt does exactly the same thing that Jonathan Spence does in his "God's Chinese Son", he tells you there are lots of good books, doesn't specify any that are good general histories of the war, and then proceeds to tell you what his book *is* a history of. I just find this annoying.The book itself is quite interesting and thorough, and the author makes some interesting points. He missed one interesting coincidence though: the war was ended when the Qing soldiers exploded their mine under the walls of Nanjing and overran the city...and the Petersburg mine was exploded 11 days later. The latter was longer but much smaller, using maybe 20% of the explosives.Anyway, I thought it an interesting book and I learned a great deal about the Taipings. I just wish someone would recommend a general history to me, one that would be reasonably priced or accessible in the library, balanced and informative and not overly scholarly (though I can do that if I have to).Good book though.

I'm probably the biggest fan of "The Killer Angels" I know of. I have reread it several times, and I don't reread novels, and I certainly don't reread them more than once. However, his son has essentially taken his dad's best-known work and turned it into a cottage industry. "The Killer Angels" is considered pretty influential even in a historical sense (it's led some historians to rethink James Longstreet's reputation, for instance, and prior to the book only specialists had ever heard of John Buford or Lawrence Chamberlain) but son Jeff's work is much more workmanlike, a novelistic retelling of events from the perspective of the participants. This is interesting, and it's pretty well-done here...it's just not quite the father's original work.The siege of Vicksburg is one of the pivotal moments of the Civil War, yet few know anything about it. Grant so outmaneuvered his opponent, John Pemberton, that he managed to pen his army up in the fortress city of Vicksburg, after defeating it at the battle of Champion Hill. The surrender of the Confederate army in Vicksburg on July 4 1863 (the day after the end of the fighting at Gettysburg) was the beginning of the end for the Confederacy. They were cut off from the states on the other side of the Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, and Texas, and for the rest of the war this major waterway was completely under the control of the Union forces. Though paroled, the army disintegrated and mostly never returned to the ranks, regardless of parole, draft, or anything else. Grant of course went on to win the war and become President.This is a reasonable book if you're not that knowledgeable about Civil War history, and you want to read fiction rather than a historical account of the campaign.
Cute little grocery bag that hooks via the carabineer onto my messenger bag, and goes with me everywhere. Opens up into a large shopping bag when I need it. Highly recommended.

This book is pretty much a precursor to Alan Furst's more recent espionage novels set during World War II. The plot revolves around an English engineer who can't find work in his own country, and so takes work in Italy. There, he services and maintains shell-loading machines that have been sold by an English company to various factories in Italy, but of course the production of artillery shells in Italy in 1938 is of considerable importance to other countries, and so eventually he's approached by 2 different spies, who bribe him and threaten him to get him to keep them informed. The result is interesting and frankly fascinating, made all the more interesting by the fact that the book was written before the war actually broke out.It's quite good, and worth reading

This is your typical War memoir from a Soviet soldier. They tend to be long on anecdote and short on things like specifics of where units were, who they were fighting (beyond "Germans" or even "Hitlerites") and are often characterized by wooden prose. I think this latter at least in part stems from the translation from Russian into English. Regardless, this book recounts the adventures of an artillery officer who served on the Eastern Front for 3 years, being wounded 3 times in the process. He started out fighting in the Rhzev salient, then his division was reassigned to the southern front and fought through the Ukraine and southern Europe, winding up in Austria and Czechoslovakia. He started out commanding a battery, at one point commanded the artillery battalion's unit of spotters, and eventually commanded the battalion itself. The book is interesting in that the author displays a good deal of disdain for those who shied away from the front. He actually threw one of his battery commanders out of the unit and told him to not come back, even though the guy had connections somewhere in headquarters, or so he says. It's interesting.Recommended for those interested in the topic. Not exactly a classic war memoir though, too esoteric and not well enough written.

Shiloh is one of those battles that's been somewhat neglected, in terms of historical studies. Gettysburg, by contrast, has been written about a great deal. In part I think this can be attributed to the fact that the Yankees won, and the Confederates don't have any real significant heroes present at the battle, at least in senior positions. Albert Sidney Johnston, the senior Confederate General, was killed at the battle and as a result doesn't generate too much interest. His chief subordinate, P.G.T. Beauregard, is generally regarded unsympathetically, because he wasn't much of a general for most of the war. Anyway, regardless of the reason, there are only 2-3 decent studies of the battle, the best probably being Shiloh: Bloody April by Wiley Sword and Shiloh: In Hell before Night by James Lee McDonough. This current book is much newer, and Daniel uses sources and materials not available to the other authors. He also spends a lot more time trying to fit the battle into the context of the campaign and the War, and dismantling or debunking the various stories and anecdotes surrounding the battle. The result is quite entertaining, and frankly there's a lot of material here that's definitely worth the purchase price, if you're any sort of Civil War buff. Recommended.

I've never read any books by this author before, and I'd wondered if I was missing out on something. I picked the current book up at a library book sale, and I'm glad I only gave them a buck for it. It's entertaining, but frankly the most fun is that it's unintentionally laughable at times, enough to make me break out in peals of laughter on occasion.The main character is Alexander Hawke, an English nobleman. He's essentially a British version of Clive Cussler's Dirk Pitt with a bit of Lord Peter Wimsey thrown in for good measure, though frankly the combination makes him sound much more believable than he is when you read the book. He's an international plutocrat, filthy rich, ex-Royal Navy Tomcat pilot and SBS frogman, and of course a descendant of a pirate who was executed for his crimes, and who left a vast treasure buried somewhere, complete with X-marks-the-spot map for Alex and his friends to follow. He has a yacht that a Bond villain would think over-the-top, with a crew of who knows how many butlers and waiters and crewmen, who can double as instant commandos and policemen when needed, and there's a hanger in back with a seaplane, several vintage sports cars, a couple of motorcycles, and a ridiculously fast speedboat all hidden inside.
