He has a sonar array on the yacht he uses to track Russian subs, and the crew can do everything from mount a tailhook on the seaplane (so he can land it on the deck of an aircraft carrier) to mount a .50 cal. machinegun on the speedboat.He cruises around the world in his yacht and plane, meeting people, dodging bullets and bombs, flirting with beautiful women (one of whom is the Secretary of State) and drinking lots of expensive liquor. There are numerous bad guys for him to defeat, and he does so in predictable fashion, though I will admit the author keeps the plot rolling along. At times the author's understanding of military technology is a bit lacking (you don't fire an air-to-air missile at a ground target; it won't hit it, and if it did it wouldn't have much effect) and the plot and dialog are very predictable. The characters are all stereotypes out of comic books, to the point that one minor character, a French commando, has an accent that makes it sound like he learned English from Pepe Le Pew. It's actually funny at times, and rather enjoyable, if you can just put aside how silly the whole thing is and enjoy it. At least the author keeps things moving.I think if I ever buy another book in the series it'll be the same way: at a library or garage sale, where I'm not investing anything other than time.

I'm somewhat interested in the subject of criminal and terrorist acts in a historical context, and this book, describing one of the central acts of terror of the Gilded Age, the bombing of Wall Street in 1920, is right in the center of that. The difficulty for me is that the author did too much contextualizing for my taste, and didn't spend enough time on the investigation itself. While she's a decent writer she's nothing spectacular, and as a result the narrative sort of plods along. While there are interesting things going on in the book itself, the subject gets at least somewhat ignored and the topic sort of gets lost in the trees.Recommended only for those interested in the subject or era.

I have a pet peeve about books. They should tell you what they're about, and be honest about it. This otherwise fine book is somewhat deceptive on the front cover, in that it promises to be a history of Naval Warfare during the era of Napoleon, while in reality it's a history of the Royal Navy during the period. This is perfectly fine, provided you tell people that, but the book's cover doesn't say that, and it's not until you read it that you realize. There's nothing, for instance, about America's Quasi-War with France, or the conflict with the Barbary Pirates. These were important conflicts during the era that involved the United States, and the book ignores them.Instead the book focuses on the British war effort, especially against Napoleon. This is well-handled, detailed and intelligent. The authors recognize that the period of fighting (1798-1805) shouldn't be overshadowed by the later campaign, and there's a detailed account of the fighting at Walcheren Island in 1809 for instance. The treatment of the United States during the conflict we call the War of 1812 is reasonably good if a bit incomplete, and certainly fair to the Americans, but again things are left out.Over all I liked this book, but there were gaps where the authors didn't live up to the cover of their book.

I've read a number of Alan Furst's novels, and all of Philip Kerr's historical "mysteries" so I was intrigued by this book, which gets recommended on Amazon for those who like those other authors. Zoo Station is the first in a series of books featuring John Russell, who in this episode is a journalist working freelance in Berlin before the war. He's British, but speaks German fluently. He has a German girlfriend, and a number of characters with whom he works. As this book progresses, he signs on (in some cases voluntarily, some not) to spy for various countries (USSR, UK, Germany) all of whom seem to know vaguely about each other paying him, and not care. As time goes on the book is more and more complex and involved, and pretty suspenseful.I generally enjoyed this book, and will look for the next entry in the series.

I've been reading Alan Furst's historical spy novels for some time now. He's very reminiscent of Philip Kerr, with the exception that Furst's novels aren't a series; each one stands alone, and typically the plot covers several years. In this episode, we follow the exploits of a decorated and wounded (in World War I) French cavalryman who's stationed as a military attaché at the Warsaw embassy. Of course much of his job is really spying on the Germans, trying to discover their intentions and targets, get military secrets, that sort of thing. He also has to deal with a number of other issues, involving everything from a vengeful Nazi intelligence official he humiliates to various liaisons he's either participating in or has arranged. The characters are well-drawn and inventive, and the action is a little better than typical in a Furst novel. I generally enjoyed this book a great deal.

I have a previous edition of this book, and I enjoyed it a great deal. The Civil War was a bloody affair, and the fighting wasn't confined to large battles on dramatic occasions. A lot of the fighting occurred in small fights and skirmishes, and this is the setting and basis for this book recounting the exploits of a fictional character who's a sergeant in a black cavalry regiment stationed in Northern Mississippi during the latter part of the war. The author makes almost no attempt to explain the historical situation to you, instead just sticking with the pro- and anti-slavery arguments, and he spends much of the book following various people. Some are Union and some are Confederate, both genders, and he makes a serious effort to not just portray the Confederates as evil Rebel slave owners. The effort is largely successful, and so is the book. The main character is rather lucky in that he rides through all these battles without ever getting seriously wounded, but real-life soldiers have done this also, and other than that quibble, the book is essentially flawless. Highly recommended.

This is one of those books that steams along at full throttle, with you hurtling towards the end...and then there's sort of a whimper and it's over, and you're feeling a bit let down. The plot--an insurance investigator who's a disgraced arson investigator investigating a fire--is interesting and pretty conventional, but Winslow's choppy writing style makes it quite fun and a very quick read. The characters are interesting, and while I guessed a few of the plot twists, several were a complete surprise to me. This is a very good book but as I said the ending wasn't quite what I'd hoped, so it loses a star.

I'm a firm believer in the Library of America collections, and I have a number of their volumes. This one is quite well-done, and it manages to pack 4 of Mark Twain's best-known books into one volume. Pretty much essential reading for anyone interested in American culture or even history, and classics, of course. Highly recommended.

This is one odd book. It's quite informative and interesting, but it's written in the first person, as if Sgt. Basilone was speaking to you directly. Since he was killed on Iwo Jima in 1945, this is obviously impossible, so the authors have attempted to channel him and recount his thoughts and motivations. Jerry Cutter, the coauthor, is the Sgt.'s nephew, but he was a year or 2 old when Basilone was killed on Iwo, so he never knew the subject of this book. Other relatives (notably a brother and a sister) authorized this book, so it must have something going for it, but it just felt odd to me, given that the guy's gone, and we can't really know exactly what he was thinking in a particular case. Still enjoyed the book for the most part, though.

This is a complex, involved, and very interesting book on not just Lawrence but a whole panoply of characters in the Middle East during World War I. Moving back and forth between the various characters as they interact, author Anderson interweaves the paths of the various Zionist Jews, soldiers and spies of the various nations, and so forth, and creates a fascinating narrative of the war itself, and how it influenced the modern world. Intricate and involved, this is not a book for the faint of hear or the short of attention span, but there's a lot of interesting information here for the serious reader and student of the region, Lawrence, or World War I. Highly recommended.

I've been a fan of the Library of America series for years now, and this book is one of the better ones they've produced. The authors are incredibly varied, and all of them are participants in the debates surrounding the latter stages of the ratification of the United States Constitution. Alexander Hamilton, James Madison, Patrick Henry, etc. debate with various other characters who aren't familiar much to modern readers: James Iredell, Melancton Smith, and so forth. The result is a fascinating discussion of the finer points of Constitutional Law 220+ years ago, and how the founders thought law would progress. It's interesting how they imagined things would develop, and fun to compare their fears with what has actually occurred in the interim.

I think I'm a Stephen Carter fan. I read his first book, which was largely a memoir, when it came out in paperback, and I've read or at least have several of his other non-fiction books. He makes good points and discusses the issues that interest him intelligently and clearly, and he's a very good writer. When he turned to fiction, his characters are nuanced and intelligent, and the books he writes are fascinating, cerebral suspense stories, for the most part. For the most part, his protagonists are blacks with privileged backgrounds and names like Lemaster Carlyle. They're academics and white-collar professionals, typically from the Northeast somewhere, who summer on Martha's Vineyard and have prominent jobs, and families who have managed to be wealthy for generations, in spite of Jim Crow and co.The current book takes place in the late 1860s, but in an alternative universe. In this world, Booth shot Lincoln but didn't kill him, while George Atzerod was more successful as an assassin and managed to kill Andrew Johnson, the Vice President. Secretary Seward's assassin didn't kill him, but the wounds were much more serious than they were in fact, and so he's bedridden, and invalid and a shut-in. Mary Lincoln was killed the next year, falling into a lake while visiting family in Illinois, with a strong hint that it might have been suicide.As a result, Lincoln is somewhat weakened from the shrewd political operator all history buffs are by now familiar with. The main protagonist of the story is a young black woman, from one of those "old money" black families I told you about earlier, and she is working as the clerk in a law office which has been hired to defend the President during his impeachment trial. As the trial progresses, she's able to slowly have some influence on the trial and its outcome, largely because she wants to be one of the first black lawyers, and the first woman of any color to practice law.This is a wonderfully drawn book, complete with fictional portraits of several leading historical figures of the day. Thaddeus Stevens, Daniel Sickles, Kate Chase Sprague, Lincoln himself, wander in and out of the pages and are very well-done. The story is interesting, though I found the ending a bit of a letdown. Nevertheless, getting to the ending is quite wonderful and well worth reading the book.

The publicity on this page says that this book is intended for the general reader. I semi-believe that, but I also believe, from the way it's constructed and the way the facts are laid out, that it's at least partially intended to be a textbook for a college-level course discussing the history of warfare. Either way, the authors do a good job laying out the outlines of the more violent portion of world history.The book begins with an interesting outline of ancient history, and works its way through the ages up to after the Cold war, stopping just at the end of the 20th Century. Brief mention is made of the World Trade Center attacks in 2001 right at the end. The focus of the book necessarily has to be very wide, so the authors insert "case studies" in which an incident, battle, campaign, or war from the era can be examined in brief detail, giving you some idea of how conflicts worked during the era. Of course given that the authors are trying to cram several thousand years of conflict and hundreds of wars into 600 pages, it's no wonder that even with the case studies, the focus is still very broad, and many important incidents and battles are skimmed over if not just left out of the narrative.The writing is very clear and insightful, and the overall effect of the book is quite interesting. The general reader certainly can get a fair bit out of this book, and I would recommend it.

I'm a fan of murder mysteries, and I liked the author's first book in the series, "The Yard". This second book follows the two partners, now firmly established as the investigator and his sidekick, as they investigate a suspicious disappearance and a curious discovery, that of an eyeball in a bird's nest. The setting is the countryside in England's coal country, where a particular village has been undermined by the mines to the point that houses simply disappear into the ground occasionally. I thought this part of the story a bit overdrawn, perhaps a remnant of the author's background as a graphic novelist, but the overall setting is interesting and the characters fascinating if a bit overdrawn. As is often the case the plot is secondary to the characters, setting, and atmosphere, all of which are fun if as I said dark.

This is one of those books that collects a series of pieces (mostly articles, here) written by various characters, with a common theme. The theme is naval warfare, and the time period is from the Spanish-American War and the last part of the 20th century. Of course since then there hasn't been much naval warfare; frankly the parts of the book after the World War II section are pretty mundane as it is. The editor is a guy whose main claim to fame, in terms of naval history, is the rediscovery of Hector Bywater, the guy who sort of predicted the Pacific War in a book he wrote in the mid-30s. That was interesting, this isn't really. Some of the pieces are of some small value, but overall there's not that much here.

By now we've come to know John Ray Horn pretty well. He was a B-movie cowboy star back in the '30s, screwed up his career by punching the studio head's son in the face, and served in World War II, reaching his breaking point in combat and spending some time in a psych ward. The books are set in the early '50s, when the McCarthy era was just taking off, and the author sets the plot of this story around an accusation that one screenwriter was a communist, When that guy gets killed, Horn feels obligated to investigate and figure out what happened, largely because he feels bad about the individual in question getting accused and never getting the chance to defend himself.I'm always a bit leery about books with political messages, regardless of whether I agree with them or not, and this one was no exception. For one thing the issue is usually drawn in black and white, when of course in the real world there are often shades of gray. I'll agree that McCarthy was a piece of work (I've often played with the idea that he actually was a Soviet agent; he sure gave anti-Communism a bad name for a good long while) but that doesn't mean that there weren't communists trying to overthrow our country: it just means he accused the wrong people.Anyway, as I climb down off my soapbox I'll just tell you it's a pretty good mystery, and I think it's a shame the author has apparently decided not to write any more Horn books, at least for a while.

Eric Jaffe is a journalist, a writer and editor. His grandfather served in World War II as the division psychiatrist of a unit that briefly saw combat in the last days of the war, in Europe, and then performed occupation duty in Japan. While he was in Japan he was tapped to evaluate one of the Japanese defendants at the Tokyo war crimes trial, in terms of whether he was mentally capable of assisting his defense during the trial. The elder Jaffe decided that Okawa Shumei was incompetent to stand trial, and ever since it’s been assumed by many people that Okawa fooled everyone, including the psychiatrist, and got off scott free as a result.This book is a dual narrative. In alternating chapters author Jaffe chronicles the life of his grandfather, Daniel Jaffe, and Okawa Shumei. Daniel Jaffe lived on Long Island, growing up with his father, siblings, and mother (the author’s great-grandmother) who was institutionalized for much of her adult life. She actually killed an infant child (by dropping him out her window 3 stories up) early in her marriage, and clearly couldn’t be left without supervision, especially not with her children. Author Jaffe discusses his upbringing and the state of psychiatry in America at the time, while also covering everything from family life on Long Island in the interwar period to the fact that more foreign immigrants wound up in mental hospitals than did natives. The chapters discussing these topics alternate with chapters discussing Okawa, who spent much of his adult life as a lecturer and editorialist who argued for expansionist political policies for Japan.  Okawa’s a fascinating character, as is the Japanese expansionist political impulse of the 30s. Most of the instigators of this policy are at best obscure outside Japan, because no one individual was essential to the movement, and no one seemed to stand out. It’s interesting to read about, and in response to this book I looked in my own library in several books, seeking Okawa’s name in other indexes. It doesn’t occur at all.I found this book interesting, though the ending is a bit anti-climactic. I’d recommend it to anyone interested in psychiatry or World War II.

Back in the day I used to pay more attention to various detective novelists. I read a bunch more books back then, especially lighter fiction. Rex Burns was one of the writers I followed pretty closely. His main character was a Denver cop named Gabe Wager. They weren’t my favorite books but they were good enough for me to follow for a good long while. At some point the store where I bought murder mysteries closed, and my tastes shifted from them to more non-fiction. Somehow I lost track of Rex Burns in the shuffle: nothing intentional, it just happened.Now I’m reviewing stuff on NetGalley, and Rex Burns shows up with a new book. Now, instead of chronicling the adventures of Wager, Burns has developed a new pair of characters. They’re a father and daughter, and they’re both private eyes who work in Denver. Since I was familiar with Burns from back before, I decided to try out this latest book and see what I thought. My reaction is more or less so-so.The detectives, father and daughter, are OK, though I didn’t think their characters were that well-defined. We learn that the father is in ridiculously good shape, in that he can qualify to be a pro wrestler (in a small regional circuit) without having to get into shape. The father used to be a lawyer, but screwed up a particular contract negotiation so badly he decided that he should find another line of work. The guy who lost his shirt because of our hero’s incompetence as a lawyer hires him again, this time as a private eye, to protect him. He claims he already knows the source of the threat. He’s now a professional wrestling promoter wannabe, and the guy who runs the regional circuit locally apparently doesn’t want any competition. The Touchstone Agency (that’s their name) investigates, and soon discovers that the promoter who’s supposedly the source of the threats has mob connections from back east, and might easily be able to arrange what’s happening.This was only a so-so book, as I stated above. Some of the characters seemed a bit over the top, some of the dialog wasn’t that good, and as I said the characters weren’t that well-drawn. Wager himself makes a cameo appearance, and frankly I was more amused when he was around than I was with either of the protagonists. Not horrible, not that good either.

This is what I consider a very interesting book. The author recounts the main event of the book--a collision of 2 ships in Halifax harbor in December 1917, one of them carrying explosives. The explosives-laden ship caught fire as a result of the collision, and then the explosions occurred. Many residents of the city were watching what amounted to a free accidental fireworks display when the ship exploded again, in what is generally thought to be the largest non-nuclear explosion in history. It flattened the city of Halifax (every building in town suffered some damage) and killed more than 3,000 people. In some instances, victims of the explosion were thrown more than a mile, and landed with barely a scratch, wondering how they got where they were. There was a subsequent tsunami that swept ships onto shore and caused more havoc, and that evening a blizzard hit and cut the ravaged and wounded city off from the outside world for a day or 2.The author recounts all of this with considerable aplomb and a sure hand, but what's fascinating is the other stuff that she comes up with. It turns out that the doctor who founded the first pediatric medical unit in an American hospital (in Boston) learned how to treat children who were seriously injured by implementing theories he'd never been able to invoke in America, and since they worked (non of the Canadian children under his care died, considered at that time a miracle) he went on to be essentially the father of modern pediatric medicine. Similarly an eye surgeon who worked long hours in Halifax (a lot of people were watching the fire from indoors, through windows, and when those windows blew in they suffered eye injuries) learned a great deal about his craft also. You even learn about the Christmas tree that the city of Halifax sends to Boston every year.I really enjoyed this book, and would recommend it to anyone who's interested in history.

I picked this book up on a whim at a used bookstore after reading the blurb. The protagonist is essentially a younger version of the author, near as I can tell. Said protagonist is a financial journalist who lives in Hong Kong, though he's an American citizen. He's asked by a colleague, a Brit, to try and help his brother extricate himself from a pickle he's gotten himself into: he's fallen in love with a Russian prostitute who works in a brothel in Macau. For those who don't know, Macau was a Portuguese territory across the harbor from Macau, tiny by comparison, and the whole of it was mostly taken up with hotel-casinos, which were pretty much the only thing in the city that took in money. Since the book takes place in 1995 (which the author mentions almost casually about 100 pages into the book) the city's still a few years away from Chinese rule. Anyway, Ray Sharp agrees to try and help his colleague's brother, and journeys to Macau, where things get off the rails in a hurry.Essentially, Sharp gets told in no uncertain terms that he shouldn't interfere with a Russian hooker's pimp. *All* the pimps are homicidal and unstable, and the one who owns this girl is the worst of the lot. Though it takes a while to get going, once the action begins the story really moves along. Sharp's more of an observer than an actor for much of the story, but it's still interesting and suspenseful.I docked it one star because the backstory first third of the book took too long to get where it was going, or so I thought, and I was a bit annoyed by how passive the main character was at least at the beginning. That being said, I enjoyed the book.

J. Robert Janes has been working on this series for some time now. The premise of the whole thing is pretty odd: during World War II, while the Germans occupy France, a French homicide detective, Jean-Louis St-Cyr, is partnered with a Gestapo agent who's really a Bavarian homicide detective named Hermann Kohler. Despite their opposing nationalities, they work together to solve murders in Paris, and various parts of France to which they are sent. In the current episode, they've been sent to Elsass (Alsace) to solve a pair of suspected murders, which look very convincing as suicides. Given the coincidence of them happening so close together, however, the authorities have sent for these 2 detectives, in the hope that they can investigate and figure out what's going on.The dead are involved with 2 different establishments in the area, one a textile plant that makes synthetic material for the German army, the other one of the early concentration camps, where political prisoners and some Jews are incarcerated. Kohler and St-Cyr have to navigate both these institutions at least somewhat to figure out why the revival of a local Carnival caused the deaths of these 2 people, and how. By the end of the book it's pretty obvious who the perpetrator(s) is/are, but getting there is fun, if a bit convoluted.It's not Janes' best book, but if you're following the series you won't want to miss it.

This is one of those compilation books that contains a bunch of "stories," typically running to a page or two, in this case all involving World War II. Many of them have appeared elsewhere, so some are probably familiar to the average person who reads about World War II, but I seriously doubt much of anyone has read all of these books. I certainly hadn't. It results in the sort of book you keep next to your toilet, or give to a 12-year-old who's just starting to express an interest in history. It's not for the serious scholar, really, but given that it's not bad. I enjoyed reading it (on the pot, as I said) because the stories were about the right length for one sitting.

David Liss now has a reputation, with me. He writes these historical thrillers, somewhere between spy novels and murder mysteries, where his main character(s) are caught up in government misdeeds and conspiracies, and must attempt to thwart evil forces who hold all the financial cards. In this book, the third entry in the Benjamin Weaver series, the boxer-turned-thieftaker must figure out a way out of the hold on shadowy figure has on him, while also trying to thwart that man's enemies. The Company of the title is the East India Company, which essentially had a monopoly on trade with India during the early 1800's (when the story takes place) and of course with a monopoly there's ample opportunity for corruption and favoritism. Weaver must navigate through it all, taking care not to make a misstep...This is a reasonably good book, given that you accept the premise involved. At times it's probably over-done in terms of the conspiracy aspect, and the author seems fascinated by insider trading and market manipulation, which is sometimes tedious enough that I doubt more than a few readers are following. However, the author does a good job with his characters, and that's the saving grace of the book.Guardedly recommended. It's good, though a bit complicated.

This is a biography of Melvin Purvis written by his surviving son, an art teacher in Boston. Melvin Purvis was of course the most famous member of the FBI for much of the mid-30s, and it's generally conceded that J. Edgar Hoover hounded him out of the FBI and kept him from obtaining decent employment after, mostly because he was jealous of Purvis's fame. Purvis of course was the guy who led the teams that killed Dillinger and "Pretty Boy" Floyd, and Hoover felt that modern "scientific" practices should have gotten the credit (even though they had little or no impact on the investigations).This book works pretty well as a discussion of crime-fighting techniques in the '30s, when the cops were just learning how to do actual detective work. It reads quite well and is interesting. I'd recommend it if you're at all interested in true crime and/or historical stuff.

I've been following Philip Kerr's Bernie Gunther series all the way back to when he'd written the trilogy called *Berlin Noir*. Kerr resumed writing the series after 20 years or so, saying he'd always intended to revisit it but other things kept getting in the way. Since then he's been running back and forth along the timeline of Gunther's life, showing us episodes involving mobsters in postwar Cuba and pimps and prostitutes in Berlin in the '30s. Occasionally he's at least provided a scene involving the war itself, and this current book is the 3nd one, from my memory, that takes place mostly or completely during the war. In this episode, Bernie works for a unit of the Gestapo that investigates war crimes. Yes, it sounds silly, but the Nazis actually did this sort of thing, trying to exonerate themselves and at the same time implicate the Allies (primarily the Soviets) in atrocities that the Nazi authorities thought would help them with world opinion. Generally this sort of thing didn't have much effect on what happened, but in this particular instance, the Soviets were guilty as hell: they murdered thousands of Polish army officers after overrunning eastern Poland. This is generally undisputed now, but back in Bernie's day it was by no means a fact, more of a guess.So Bernie goes to the Ukraine in early 1943. The 6th Army has just surrendered at Stalingrad and morale is low everywhere. People are asking what will happen if the Soviets win the war, and those Ukrainians who collaborated with Hitler are getting nervous. There are other deaths that have happened more recently of course, and Bernie's skills as an investigator are called on, to sort out what's going on.This is a good book. Recommended

I've reviewed a number of books for NetGalley now, and this is probably the worst one that I've actually finished. It's not a terrible book, reads pretty quickly, and has a plot with some twists and turns. A number of people were turned off by the profanity (really?) and what they considered gratuitous sex (it doesn't offend me, I just find it annoying) and violence (always fun).The premise at the beginning of the book is rather far-fetched. The protagonist is a female FBI agent who came to the States after being a police officer in China. The backstory at the beginning makes it sound as if she just showed up one day and the FBI gave her a job. Her FBI partner thinks she needs to learn to drive (isn't it a requirement with FBI agents? Wouldn't he know that?) and for whatever reason they get pulled away from regular duty in the San Francisco Bay area and sent to Detroit to try and figure out why a serial killer, who everyone thought had been caught  8 years ago, has resurfaced (or is there a copycat?). There's a lot of plot and action in this book, and thankfully it moves along at a decent pace. You have to wonder why the local detectives couldn't follow the leads that Abby finds, but the whole plot is more or less unbelievable, so that doesn't stand out. Bodies fall everywhere, seemingly once every 20 pages or so, and the characters don't always act in a logical fashion.In the author's defense though I will repeat one thing: it read fast and was reasonably well-written. I don't mean spelling and punctuation, but the sentences weren't unreadable and the plot more or less made sense. As I said, worst book I've read to the finish through NetGalley, but I *did* finish.

I wasn't always a Doris Kearns Goodwin fan. Back in the day I saw an interview with her, where she ripped the first volume of Robert Caro's biography of Lyndon Johnson. Her argument seemed weak (she seemed to think that since Johnson was in her mind a "great" President, his flaws should be overlooked) and she seemed very biased about Johnson. Later, she got caught up in one of those plagiarism scandals that plague historians intermittently, when one of their researchers writes a passage for the historian's book, and essentially lifts it from the work of another, less-well-known author. So I was deliberately avoiding her, but somehow finally got my arm twisted hard enough to read Team of Rivals, and found it quite good. When this book came out I decided I needed to read it, especially Roosevelt and Taft are two of my favorite presidents.The first part of the book is essentially a dual biography of the two men and their wives. Roosevelt of course has been written about extensively, with Edmund Morris having just concluded is three-volume biography, and many other books having been written over the years. Taft has been the subject of many fewer books, so it was here I expected Goodwin to shine, and she does come through in a big way, filling in the gaps in our knowledge of Taft and rounding out his character a great deal.If she'd chosen to write simply a dual biography, I suspect I'd be giving the book 5 stars, but she chose to digress in the middle of the book, and examine the beginnings of investigative journalism, as seen through the rise of McClure's Magazine during this era. This is an interesting subject, and I expect if the author had wanted to she could have produced a 400-page book on this subject also, but instead she chose to fold it into this book about Roosevelt and Taft. The result is the thing that often turns me off to a dual biography: when the author's writing about subject "X", you wish they would write about subject "Y", and vice versa. Here, the dual biography aspect worked pretty well, but the grafting of the McClure's subject onto the rest of the book seemed very awkward to me.In addition, just to make things more annoying, Goodwin essentially ends the book with the 1912 Presidential election. Once Taft is defeated and Wilson enters the White House, there's only a few more pages. Taft's decade as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court gets less than a full page, and there's almost no mention of what happened to the journalists she was following in the McClure's thread.In short, if she'd fleshed out her material a bit more, I think she'd have had 2 books here, and they both would have been excellent. Instead she tried to graft one onto the other, and it only partially worked. The book is still well-written and interesting, but it could have been more than it was, at least in my opinion.

This is one of those books that you're supposed to put next to your toilet, so you can read while you're doing your business. It's about 500 pages of stuff, mostly on the U.S. military, and it contains a lot of trivia. The pieces tend to be short (1-5 pages) and to the point, with an eye for humor here and there. They're also very patriotic, so there are no accounts of atrocities or anything like that. That's fine with me (it's not like this is going to be my sole resource on the American Army, after all) and the writing is pretty good. I only found a few true errors (for instance they screw up the father-son Medal of Honor thing) so for the most part what they tell you is just fine, as far as I am concerned.I found the book fun, and good for what it's intended.

James Lee Burke has been putting out these books for decades now, and I've become a pretty big fan over the years. I read most every one as it comes out, and enjoy them a great deal. The protagonist, Dave Robichaux, is a wonderful character, beaten and partially broken but unwilling to give in that last little bit; he's also utterly devoted to his former partner and good friend Clete Purcell, who's a force of nature and more than a bit out of control. The result, when both men begin to look for young women whom they believe are in trouble, is a sort of kaleidoscope of violence, confusion, conversation, and suspense that's frankly amazing at times, though at this point it's also a bit predictable.I did enjoy this book though, and will continue to read the series in the future.

This is a very improbable and badly-plotted "suspense" novel written by the lady who does the Stephanie Plum books, and some Hollywood guy. The result is a bad pastiche of the old TV series "It Takes a Thief" with the Malachi Throne character replaced by a sexy female Navy Seal turned FBI agent. Old bald guys don't get into stuff like this anymore, much. Our heroes are a super-sexy con man and thief and the abovementioned FBI agent, who at one time was tasked with catching him. Somehow he's had his arm twisted into stealing things for the FBI (you wouldn't think they'd have much use for that) and of course he and the FBI-gal have a "spark of sexual tension" that keeps intruding into the ridiculous plot.The whole thing is so relentlessly cute it's enough to almost make you gag. Added to that, the bad guy in this entry is a combination of Karl Rove and Dr. Evil from the Austin Powers movies, but unlike Austin Powers this isn't written with the same tongue in cheek wink at the audience humor. Instead we're supposed to buy this guy as a mega-mogul, summoning an Apache attack helicopter to blow a village in Scotland to pieces, then summoning drones to attack his enemies with rockets outside his home somewhere in the states. By the point the drones appeared I was so annoyed with the whole thing that I just wanted it to be over. Fortunately it reads fast, and that's why it gets more than one star. Silly, but at least it went by quickly

If you've never read one of John Mortimer's Rumpole stories, then you're missing out on something. The author produced a bunch of these short stories, which were more or less a British cross between Law & Order and Monty Python. Rumpole himself is an ancient lawyer, always defending people and always taking the poorest clients, who barely finance his middle-class, middle-brow lifestyle. He rereads one book of collected poetry constantly, along with legal tomes, always drinks cheap wine in a dreary "wine bar" across the street from the courthouse, and has little time for vacations, what with the work load being so heavy. His "chambers" are full of amusing characters, who one after the other get themselves into and out of predicaments, often with Rumpole's assistance in one direction or the other. It's often very amusing.This collection, as all of the Omnibuses, has about 20 short stories in it, between 25-50 pages in length. They're marvelous, and I would recommend them.

Let me start out by saying that I got this novel from NetGalley thinking it was a war novel. When I actually looked at what I'd gotten it was obvious it wasn't: it's a romance novel set in Italy during World War II. The author doesn't engage in any of the typical silliness with war novels, turning the heroines into commandos or spies or whatever. The women are what women were, in wartime in that era: nurses, office-workers, refugees, perhaps code-breakers.The story centers around three men who are officers in the British Army, and the women with whom they get involved. The plot is the fairly typical star-crossed lovers variety, with one of the soldiers falling for the other's fiancée, and the whole thing having to sort itself out. It does, and in a reasonably realistic, if not particularly surprising fashion.Though this is a romance, the author did include battle sequences, and they're pretty well-done. I noted a few mistakes, but only a very few, and overall I thought those parts of the book quite good.Recommended, especially if you like romance novels.

I am always pleased to see books for the general reader that undertake to explain some facet of the Supreme Court, since the Court remains a mystery to many (much like the fourth or administrative branch of the federal government).  This book focuses upon one very important dimension of the Court, the philosophy of judicial restraint or deference to Congressional policy, and to contrast it with judicial activism.  The author is a Senior Editor at "Reason" magazine, an important voice for libertarians who value individual liberty above all, seek to maximize autonomy and freedom of choice.  Sometimes libertarians take positions identical with conservative; in other instances (as this book well illustrates) the two philosophies come into conflict.The author covers a wide range of issues as he dissects l(and rejects) judicial restraint as a controlling judicial principle. While I found the individual chapters to be solid, my concern is that they did not flow together smoothly in developing an argument. There is one area, I will mention later, where it all  does come together very well and where I believe the book makes a major contribution.The author begins with a general discussion on judicial restraint, basically targeting Justice Holmes as the major progenitor of the concept.  He also includes a good discussion of Justice Field, the genesis of the 14th amendment, and the much criticized "Slaughterhouse" decision in which the Court emasculated the "privileges and immunities" clause of the amendment. With this clause nullified, the Court was free to employ a judicial restraint viewpoint, which allowed government regulation to expand and individual liberty to contract (e.g., the "Munn" doctrine). While liberty of contract did have a brief run, the Progressive movement's emphasis on majority rule and regulation by experts prevailed until the Old Court battled the New Deal, where the ultimate victory of FDR over the Court led to the Court backtracking from questioning Congressional economic and social policy statutes. To do this it employed an undemanding "rationale basis" approach. Until fairly recently, the Court had not declared any such statutes unconstitutional--for the author an unhealthy development as regards safeguarding liberty.The author next devotes an interesting chapter to the late Judge Bork who favored judicial restraint, unless the Constitutional provided specific guidance on an issue to the contrary. This chapter serves as a preface to the most important topic the author discusses, the continuing battle between conservatives and libertarians. This is a masterful discussion of a topic too often overlooked. The author discusses and parses the views of Bernard Siegen, the 1984 Cato Institute conference here in Washington where Bork debated Richard Epstein (who advocated use of the 5th amendment's "taking clause" as a device to fight government over-regulation), and Justice Scalia's preference for judicial restraint. This battle continues today and the reader is equipped by this chapter to better grasp the important contrasting philosophies at issue.The remainder of the book looks at some actual cases, such as the Kelo eminent domain litigation, the second amendment gun rights case and the Obamacare decision.  Chief Justice Roberts raised the very point central to this book in the ACA litigation by in part basing his surprise vote upholding the law by stating an "it is not our job", pro judicial restraint argument. The book has extensive notes and a good select bibliography.  It would have been helpful had the author done more discussion of the libertarian philosophy and the vital role of the Cato Institute here in Washington in educating us about this approach. As I said above, the book could be better integrated in my opinion--but the individual chapters stand on their own as important contributions.  A book well worth reading by anyone interested in the Court and its role..

Living in Georgetown, I was naturally interested when I heard about this book.  I assumed it was a light discussion of some of the goings-on involving prominent politicians and journalists who made Georgetown their home.  I could not have been more wrong.  Rather, the book, authored by a prominent University of California diplomatic historian, is a compelling history of Georgetowners who were involved in the Cold War, the founding of the C.I.A., the "loss of China", the McCarthy scare, the Marshall Plan, the Korean war, Vietnam, the missile gap, the New Frontier, the Cuban missile crisis, and Watergate to name some of the book's topics. The development of the "containment" policy, formulated by George Kennan, which largely shaped the Cold War, is also well dissected. The formative early stages of the C.I.A. are illuminated as well.The central figures throughout the book are Joseph Alsop (1910-89) and his brother Stewart (1914-74), two highly influential columnists when people actually still read newspapers. The book begins just after the end of World War II and roughly runs through to the breakup of the Soviet Union. Making appearances are Dean Acheson; Phil and Kay Graham of the Washington Post; Felix Frankfurter; George Kennan; Paul Nitze; Chip Bohlen; Averell Harriman; Susan Mary Alsop; Allen Dulles; Frank Wisner; John Paton Davies; Richard Helms; and JFK among others. The book is most perceptive in examining how the interaction between high-level government officials and their journalistic neighbors, living in the same compact Washington community, impact upon important government policies.  For example, Alsop's intimate interactions with the Nixon administration (including Henry Kissinger) during the Vietnam war are particularly well documented.By focusing upon the actors' key public and private interactions, the reader is afforded an invaluable insider perspective on each topic. However, as the author recounts in his Epilogue, Georgetown is no longer the center of the world no matter what some of my neighbors may believe.  We surely still have many high and low government officials and journalists in residence; Republicans are still concerned about the notorious Georgetown cocktail parties which they believe subvert good conservatives. But the era of political giants like Dean Acheson, George Kennan, Averell Harriman, and JFK residing in Georgetown, close by journalists such as the Alsops, Ben Bradlee, and the Washington Post's Grahams, is long gone--probably because their are so few giants these days in Washington.The book is some 472 pages including extensive notes and a helpful bibliography. One problem is that the book covers so many folks and topics that anybody under 50 or so may have a problem keeping them all straight.  I had this problem at points even though I am well above 50 and lived through this entire period.  One the other hand, I learned a lot about folks I did know about, like Phil Graham and his tragic suicide, and critically significant individuals like Frank Wisner who helped shape the CIA, whom I knew nothing about. The author is to be commended for his outstanding research--the book covers a lot of ground.  Anyone interested in this period of the "American Century" needs to read this fine book..

Although I was somewhat familiar with John Adams and especially Henry Adams, I was pretty unfamiliar with John Quincy Adams 1767-1848).  So, I was glad to read this extensive study by Fred Kaplan, which as is the current trend for bios, runs somewhat long at 622 pages. The book, however, has many more virtues than just being an extensive and comprehensive review of JQA's life. While the author focuses upon Adams, of course, he also pays attention to what else is going on around Adams, in order to establish the proper context. So, for example, we learn much about John and Abigail Adams and their activities and the development of partisan national politics.  Kaplan is also interested in more than the political Adams.  As an English professor, he discusses frequently Adams as a pamphleteer, poet, and diarist. I think to understand Adams the politician, it is essential to have some familiarity with the literary Adams as well.  JQA's extensive diary, maintained over most of his life, and heavily relied upon by the author, allows Adams to speak for himself in describing his motivations and views.  This is particularly important in understanding Adams' amazingly expansive diplomatic and political career before he became the sixth President., as well as his eventual hostility to Jefferson.The bio follows a conventional chronological format. I was surprised to see how extensive a career Adams had had before the Presidency: expansive diplomatic experience at the highest levels throughout Europe (including negotiating the Jay treaty and the Treaty of Ghent); an early term in the Senate; a nomination to the Supreme Court by Madison which was foreclosed by his diplomatic absences; and serving as Secretary of State under Monroe. Along the way he is involved in the Missouri Compromise; fighting New England secession during the War of 1812 period; fighting to protect native American lands; pushing for internal improvements and a national bank system; contesting the spread of slavery; ``and just continual writing of political and historical tracts.I think today Adams is most remembered for his incessant opposition to slavery.  He most prominently fought this battle surprisingly after his Presidential loss to Jackson during serving more than a decade in the House, the only former President to do so. First, he fought to protect the right of citizens to petition Congress for redress of grievances, particularly as regards slavery and its expansion. This led to multiple censure attempts and criticism, but surprisingly his colleagues respected his determination.  It is one of the many strengths of the book that the author initiates us into the bitter hostility and hatred that developed in the House during this period (1834-48) just prior to the Civil War. In addition, Adams argued on behalf of the escaped slaves in the famous Supreme Court Amistad case (1841).  Kaplan is at his best in his careful analysis of Adams' argument--Adams' use of language is particularly noteworthy.The author's research is impeccable and complete as reflected in 38 pages of end notes and a wonderful 8 page Bibliographic Essay. There are some helpful illustrations, many in full color.  But most of all, the book is just beautifully written.  At times, the length of the book makes it "a slog" to keep reading, but it is all here.  Perhaps now JQA can claim a more appropriate place in our political history.

John Grisham and Scott Turow pioneered the "legal thriller" format; Grisham has continued to develop his skills as a novelist, not just a legal novelist, in some 27 novels.  When he started, particularly with "The Firm," his books tended to have a good deal of razzle dazzle excitement, and I could not turn the pages fast enough.  But reflecting his maturity as a novelist, and perhaps also his move (at least part time) to Virginia, his more recent books have undertaken to inform (I hesitate to say "educate") the reader about important issues while not diminishing the impact of the story line. For example, his books have dealt with the death penalty; judicial campaign abuse; mass torts lawyers, as well as various criminal justice issues. This approach has placed a significant extra burden on Grisham: namely to hold the reader's interest while these other issues pop up.  He has met this challenge very well in my opinion, having read virtually all of his legal novels.This novel is just chock full of interesting issues that contribute to the development of the story line.  Grisham is no fan of mega firms (nor am I having practiced in a couple), anyd why they are often unpleasant places for especially young lawyers to practice is a point repeatedly raised here. The story is set in New York City, Washington, D.C., and a small southern Appalachian Virginia town, and Grisham is accurate in describing NYC and DC (although I am still puzzled by his term "central D.C."). The central character Samantha, a large firm associate who moves to a small legal aid firm, learns about many new things she had not previously experienced, as does the reader. They include: the horror of black lung disease and how seeking compensation can drag on for years; how local governments hire private contractors to "strong arm" minor violators to pay up their fines or go to jail; how caps on punitive damages (as in in Virginia) limit recoveries even for wrongful deaths; and how garnishments can be imposed based on old out of date judgments.  These are all important factors in Appalachia.But the most interesting theme is the power of the coal industry in these areas. Particularly effective is Grisham's discussion of "mountaintop removal" where mountains are literally destroyed to get at the coal, with the resulting detritus pushed into surrounding valleys and streams. We learn about sludge and how slurry impoundments can fail and discharge 300 million gallons of sludge onto surrounding communities.  We also discover that giant coal trucks generate an enormous amount of deadly auto accidents. But the key problem remains black lung.  The law fails to protect the local residents for several reasons: juries that fear to penalize the industry for fear of retribution or the loss of precious jobs; the expense of litigation; and state laws which favor the coal companies.  It is all quite an education as one reads the novel.The novel manifests some of Grisham's weaknesses as well.  His villains tend to be somewhat "cardboardish"; his vendetta with the FBI and U.S. Attorneys continues (perhaps a legacy from his criminal defense days in Mississippi); and sometimes major ethical issues are skipped by (such as Samantha trying to get her high level DOJ mom to call off the bureau). But these are small blemishes.  I am happy to report that Grisham can still deliver some exciting page-turning razzle dazzle (beginning at page 352).  This book is just typical Grisham which means it is another interesting and informative well-constructed yarn by a master of this genre.

For a number of years now, a somewhat ferocious debate has ranged around the issue of how federal judges should interpret ambiguous statutes.  One school of thought, most prominently advocated by Justice Scalia, limits the judge's options to what is explicitly stated in the statute's text, dictionaries,  and certain canons of construction.  An alternative approach argues for the use of "legislative history" such as committee and conference reports to cast light on ambiguous provisions. In this fine book, Judge Robert Katzmann, Chief Judge of the U.S. Second Circuit Court of Appeals, discusses these issues from the perspective of his long consideration of the topic.  Before he was placed on the bench, the author spent many years at the Brookings Institution, The Governance Institution, and Georgetown University examining judiciary-legislative relationships, including publications on statutory interpretation. Despite the explosive nature of the topic, this book is coolly analytical and exhaustive in its consideration of related issues. But to be sure, the author is firmly in favor of reliance upon appropriate legislative history where necessary.One of the author's major themes is the need for the judiciary to have a better understanding of Congress and the lawmaking process.  So, a valuable early chapter focuses upon this topic, especially the important role of legislative staffs. Another theme is that probably the best place to look for assistance in interpreting ambiguous statutes is to the administrative agencies that implement them. The legislative staffs intentionally generate legislative history material (particularly in committee and conference reports) to guide the agencies; they seem to get it, why not the courts?  Ignorance of Congressional rules, norms, and practices is one big reason. So a very insightful chapter focuses upon this relationship, including discussion of the tools Congress utilizes to insure the agencies implement the intended purpose of statutes.  These include confirmation hearings, investigations, authorization and oversight hearings, floor statements of key legislators, appropriation hearings and other devices. This material would seem to be of great potential value to courts as well.The core of the book is found in chapter 4, "Judicial Interpretation of Statutes." Here the author argues that the hallmark of interpretation should be a search for the purpose Congress intended in ambiguous statutes.  He then discusses how legislative history can contribute toward ascertaining Congressional purpose.  He places much emphasis upon the materials generated by staffs that is relied upon by legislators when voting, even if they have not thoroughly reviewed the proposed bill itself. This analysis is used in oversight of agencies; why should courts not rely upon it as well.  This chapter also contains an excellent analysis of the arguments put forward by the "textualists" such as Scalia in rejecting legislative history. There is much insight and virtually no vitriol in this critical dimensions of the issue, despite the author's own position on the question.  This is followed by a critique of textualism, particularly the judicial lack of familiarity of legislative processes and tools. An interesting section discusses the canons of construction so heavily relied upon by Justice Scalia and Bryan A. Garner in their important "Reading Law: The Interpretation of Legal Texts." The author points out that few staff members are familiar with these canons.  Judge Richard Posner in my opinion really lacerated the canons argument in his recent "Reflections on Judging" book.One strong point of the book is that an entire chapter is devoted to three case studies in how the author and fellow second circuit judges interpreted ambiguous statutes, and how the Supreme Court viewed their handiwork.  These cases well illustrate how different judges can reach opposing but reasonable interpretations of the same ambiguous statute. Finally, the author devotes a chapter to suggestions of how greater understanding can be promoted between Congress and the judiciary--another constructive contribution to the debate.Anyone seriously interested in this important topic needs to read this thoughtful book. In 100 pages of text and 38 pages of invaluable end notes, the author can thoroughly educate a reader as to the pros and cons of textualism v. purposivism.  But the most important message remains: courts need to know a lot more about the procedures, techniques, and cues of Congress in order to do a satisfactory job of interpreting statutes.

Today, we occasionally see references to Thomas Malthus (1766-1834) and his famous prediction that population would grow much faster than the resources available to support it. Malthus supported his prediction with an extensive analysis in his "An Essay on the Principle of Population" (1803). However, as this excellent book informs us, Malthus is more than just a footnote to history. Concern about the growth of population, and related concepts like life expectancy, fertility, and mortality rates, antedated Malthus' birth. On the one hand, Europeans felt that growing population indicated economic health; but was it growing or declining?  Moreover, it was assumed that the physical environment could support greater population. Some thinkers, such as Godwin, felt a golden future would lie ahead. When Malthus not only challenged these rosy predictions, but supported his position with mathematical analysis, his book attracted immediate attention.Malthus, a talented mathematician, based his analysis on empirical rather than theological truth. His dismal prediction, he argued, was beyond government power to mitigate. He also took aim at the Poor Laws which he argued did far more harm than good. These controversial theories were widely challenged, particularly by the British Romantics (particularly Wordsworth and Coleridge and the Lake Poets) who saw a bountiful future in contrast to that of Malthus. Particularly his criticism of the Poor Laws set these folks off against Malthus. The author credits Malthus with the creation of environmental economics in particular and modern economics in general. Malthus continued to seek empirical support for this theories after he published his book (often updated), through extensive travel, reading, and the accumulation of economic and census data.The author traces Malthus' influence after his 1834 death through the Victorians.  He discusses Carlyle, Ruskin, Herbert Spencer, and Thomas Huxley among others. I found it most interesting that Malthus made a real impact in the 20th century of all things.  Some writers traced the interest in Eugenics, the spread of contraceptives, and the decline in population all to Malthus. Both H.G. Wells and Keynes advocated his ideas. The themes of overpopulation and resource depletion attracted writers like C.P. Snow, Bertrand Russell, Sartre, Buckminster Fuller, and Julian and Aldous Huxley.  At mid-century, Ehrlich and his "Population Bomb," the Green Revolution, carbon footprints, and Spaceship Earth were all traceable to Malthus' ideas.  The final chapter on "Malthus Today" demonstrates his continued relevance particularly in connection with our concerns about environment, water supplies, and migration.This is a pretty concentrated volume--heavy on analysis and ideas.  It is a remarkable thorough and thoughtful analysis of a number of important intellectual ideas and public intellectuals. It has ample endnotes but no bibliography. The author's ability to demonstrate Malthus' relevance even till today makes this an extremely interesting book--but one that is best read in small pieces at a time.

This turned out to be a somewhat different book than I had anticipated.  I had read with great benefit the author's two judicial biographies on Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia, so I assumed that this book would be another judicial biography. In fact, it is something quite different, and I am glad it is.  In her own words (at p. 7), the author declares, "Rather than biography,it examines the cultural and political shifts that merged with Sotomayor's life and led to her appointment."  This is not to say there is not a good deal of biographical material here--but its focus is far broader.  The Justice's well-received autobiography, "My Beloved World," opened to me the story of Puerto Ricans in America, both the good and the challenging.  It was an important education for me.  This book is concerned with the political, social, and economic factors, coupled with Sotomayor's own incredible drive and talents, that she maneuvered through to secure her Supreme Court appointment. That is, why was she right for the times when the Court vacancy arose? For those really interested in the Justice, I recommend that the two books be read in conjunction.Particularly interesting is the discussion of Puerto Rican interest groups dedicated to promoting the appointment and advancement of Hispanic candidates for the judiciary.  The author recounts how years of effort had preceded Sotomayor's arrival on the scene.  Judge Jose Cabranes in the opinion of many had the best chances for the Court--yet he aged out of contention because of the lack of Hispanic political muscle. Political factors were clearly at work in the denial of a D.C. Circuit seat to Miguel Estrada, which the author discusses in a highly insightful chapter.Yet Sotomayor made it and why this is so constitutes the central recurring theme of the book.  Once again, the book reminds us of how bizarre sometimes the process of selecting nominees for the Court can be, especially in these days of intense partisan warfare.  One need only read John Dean's book on Nixon's selection of Rehnquist (whose name he could not even remember at times) to see a further example. Here the author effectively traces the final competition between Sotomayor, Judge Diane Wood, and Elena Kagan to secure President Obama's nod for the nomination. Confidential letter writing to the White House; activating long-term contacts with White House and DOJ staffers; the use of published articles and books (I had forgotten about Jeffrey Rosen's harsh "New Republic" appraisal of Sotomayor) all played a role here. Sotomayor's offhand "wise Latina" statement and its impact is thoroughly reviewed by the author.  The famous "Ricci" firefighter qualification case, where Sotomayor's Second Circuit panel was accused of devoting insufficient attention or analysis before denying the appeal, also played a role in the nomination battle.  And of course, facing some confrontational GOP members of the Senate Judiciary Committee injected yet further unusual elements into the process.In short, the Justice's autobiography is her view of her challenging pathway to the Court, focusing as it should upon her own battles, talents, and successes.  This book is concerned with the environment in which Sotomayor developed from a poor Bronx childhood, into degrees from Princeton and Yale Law, a stint in Robert Morganthau's district attorney's office, years in private practice, and her appointments to the Southern District of New York and the Second Circuit (some 17 years worth of judicial experience).  But why her time had come had much to do with the context of what was going on external to her own efforts--the increasing political influence of Hispanics; the particular outlook of Obama; her contacts, colleagues, and other influential supporters.  This book melds the personal Sotomayor together with the context of American politics to fully explain how she made the leap to the Court.The book cover a lot of ground in 260 pages.  There are helpful end notes; a brief selective bibliography; some pictures and illustrations; and a helpful index.  I only wish that the author had chosen to discuss a few more Court cases, but the ones she discusses are certainly important, though it is hard to say how representative they are of the Justice's oral argument techniques and ability to influence her colleagues.  The book also raises the issue implicitly as to whether the Justice is too publicly active outside the Court, or just a much-needed breath of fresh air in a stodgy old institution.  Quite a masterful study that adds much to our understanding of this most unique Justice who has a long career ahead of her.

This is really two books in one.  First, the author focuses upon FDR's efforts to circumvent isolationist opposition and suspicion, in the form of Charles A. Lindberg among others, and the Neutrality Act to get assistance to Britain and France as the specter of Hitler grows ever more ominous. The author argues that FDR was weakened in his ability to act as a result of (1) his failed court packing plan of 1937; (2) his ineffectual attempt to purge opposition Democrats from Congress in 1938; and (3) because his second term was soon to run out, he was a very lame duck indeed. Using devices such as "cash and carry, "lend lease," " and "trading" war materials for British bases, FDR was able to get some aid to Britain and France, arguing that these nations were our "first line of defense."The second focus of the book is extremely interesting: will FDR defy the two-term tradition and run for re-election in 1940? We enter thereupon the strange period of FDR as a Sphinx; that is, will he won't he and if so, why.  FDR had planned to retire to Hyde Park and his new (the first) presidential library; he also needed badly to replenish his finances.  Yet, as the specter of war grew, and he surveyed the field, he did not see more than a few Democrats (such as Cordell Hull) who could win a presidential election, fight a war, and protect the goals and ideals of the New Deal.  Moe argues, and I think he is correct, that for most of 1940 FDR really had not made up his mind whether to run.  But as a proven leader in crisis, and because of GOP threats to the New Deal, he eventually opted to run.  Of course, this may all be bunk and he intended to run all the time--but I think the author is persuasive in rejecting this theory.But by not stating his intentions clearly, he ran the risk of the convention nominating somebody else.  So this need to be "drafted" to offset his deviation from the third term tradition led to some puzzling actions.  Even when it became clear that the convention would nominate him, he almost threw it all overboard by his insistence that Henry Wallace had to be the VP nominee or he would reject the nomination.  This threw the convention into a confused cauldron of hostility before Wallace was ultimately selected. Given that FDR was one of the most astute political operatives in American history, this whole Sphinx/Wallace episode is most puzzling.This book is outstanding for several reasons.  It is extremely well written--good history does not have to be hampered by professional historian lingo and approaches.  Moe is quite good on focusing on the key individuals around (and in some cases such as Wendell Willkie opposing) FDR, including Joseph P. Kennedy, Harry Hopkins, James Farley, Harold Ickes, and Cactus Jack Garner.  His discussion of the early FDR-Churchill relationship is quite illuminating. Most importantly, he is quite astute in probing FDR's likely thought processes as 1940 approaches.The book is supported by some outstanding photographs, helpful notes, and a good bibliography.  The appendix consists of two key memos I had never seen before drafted by Felix Frankfurter and Archibald MacLeish, at FDR's request, on the topic of whether he should run again.  Encompassing 300 or so pages, this book stands as our most complete analysis of FDR and the third term issue and the dilemmas he faced.

This interesting volume is a collective history primarily of the first three generations of the Thomas H. Huxley family.  Huxley (1825-1895) was the grand old man of 19th Century empirical science that emerged with Darwin and came to dominate Victorian Science and into the twentieth century. Often known as "Darwin's Bulldog," Huxley was not only a vigorous defender of Darwinian evolutionary theory, but also a leading scientist and scientific educator himself. The book also discusses his son, Leonard (1860-1933), who was an important educator as well as the author of several leading biographies of Victorian scientists--his father and Joseph Hooker primarily.  These bios, which still merit reading today, are in the Victorian format of "The Life and Letters of ......"  Usually they were multiple-volumes and chock full of documents.  This format has largely disappeared today which I think is a shame.The third generation is most familiar to us today.  Growing up in Southern California in the 1950"s, I certainly was familiar with Aldous Huxley ((1894-1963), author of "Brave New World" among other works.  Aldous became the model Britisher who left the misty and rainy isles and flowered in the warmth of Southern California.  He made money writing for the Hollywood Studios, lived in remote cabins, and was one of the earliest advocates of LSD--somewhat ahead even of Leary. He was also just a remarkable writer.  His brother, Sir Julian Huxley (1887-1975), was a distinguished biologist, head of UNESCO for a time, and the author of several important books. It is easy to see why this is such a scintillating book given its central characters.A word should also be said about the author, Ronald W. Clark (no relation, unfortunately).  Clark wrote an enormous amount of books, principally outstanding scientific bios on folks like Darwin, Einstein, Freud, Edison and Julian Huxley.  Yet, he had no scientific background--holding no university degree and having been a war correspondent during WWII--but this was actually his strength.  He dug into each new scientific area and mastered it; that made him a superior choice to explain it to layman readers in language they could understand.A fine book well worthy of serious consideration so many years after its publication in 1968.

This excellent book should be of interest to anyone concerned with Victorian intellectual/scientific history.  It is the most recent addition to the outstanding lineup of books on this general topic published by the University of Chicago Press. In addition to a helpful introduction by the editors, which ties themes together and offers a preview of the essays to follow, there are 12 essays collected under four categories.  Unlike some collections of essays, here every one is a winner and they tend to complement each other.  There is no more knowledgeable a scholar in this area than the co-editor, Bernard Lightman, and his mastery of the field is evident throughout the collection.The introduction spends several pages in trying to define "scientific naturalism."  After reading the essays, it means to me that empirical, secular, sometimes agnostic, often confrontational group of scientists who emerged during the 1850-1900 period, in the wake of the Darwinian revolution, and were determined to free science from any religious constraints  and to transform it into a true profession.The first collection of essays are grouped under "forging friends."  How did these scientists come together?  Co-editor Gowan Dawson argues that even before Darwin's "Origin" was published in 1859, a small group had unified in order to attack the Cuvier techniques in paleontology.  Principally, the group was led by Thomas Huxley and Joseph Hooker, both of whom were major figures in the scientific naturalism movement. Later, it was natural for this group to join together to defend Darwin (who avoided conflict and confrontation) when his book was vigorously attacked by religionists and more traditional scientists, such as Richard Owen. An interesting essay relates that reliable Victorian hobby of mountain climbing to unifying the scientific group. George Levine focuses upon the literary quality of the group's writings and asks whether these strict empiricists really started from some metaphysical assumptions that took them beyond science.The second heading is "institutional politics."  An important essay focuses upon Huxley and his service on various royal commissions and in institutional positions and how they were utilized to promote scientific naturalism and enhance the teaching of science. Huxley, who is really the giant during this period, used his control over national examinations (the focus of a second essay) and the establishment of a new science school at Kensington to professionalize scientific education and further reduce any influence of religion. In short, the group was effective in utilizing politics to secure their objectives. One secret to the groups success, as discussed in an essay on Joseph Hooker, was that with few exceptions, the scientists conformed to the Victorian idea of a "gentleman." No outright attacks on religion; courteous and moderate to a fault. They were not scary but rather polite, while firm in their views.  Only Huxley, "Darwin's bulldog," had difficulty in following this "Christian gentleman" approach.The third grouping of essays is captioned "broader alliances."  These essays focus upon allies the scientists developed.  One interesting ally was the Sunday Lecture Societies, who sought to put on programs of lectures on Sundays, often meeting firm religionist opposition. Some of these lectures were given by the scientists.  An interesting essay discusses the famous "metaphysical society," which presented lectures to its members on many intellectual topics including science and religion. Once again, good manners prevailed in the meetings and in extensive published articles, which further publicized scientific naturalism themes. A final essay in this section deals with the argument that the uniformity of physical laws either proved or disproved the existence of God.The final set of essays appear under the designation "new generations."  The topics here include the alliance of the scientists with modernizing religious writers; the impact of statistical analysis in published articles which tended to turn off many general readers; the role of Nature magazine which became the preferred mechanism for younger scientists to present theses and respond to disputes; and finally the Rationalist Press Association, another device by which the scientists could draw upon radical thinkers.The book includes notes at the end of each essay; a bibliography of major works on scientific naturalism; a list of contributors; and an index.  I find this entire topic extremely interesting, and this book serves as a good introduction to why this is such a fascinating area.

I have never been intimidated by the term "popular history"; good historical writing is good historical writing. And especially given the current proclivities of academic historians to write only for their own colleagues, in their own unique jargon, solid historical analysis aimed at the general reader is to be encouraged. Joseph J. Ellis is undoubtedly well known to the general reader for his string of outstanding books focusing on the founders.  His Pulitzer-Prize for "Founding Brothers" attests to his significant impact. But this book was even so much better than I had expected.Ellis' focus is upon the summer of 1776 just at the beginning of the Revolutionary War. He develops an effective dual focus: the political juxtaposed against the military. In nine chapters, we see the interplay of these two elements--how the military impacted the political developments, and vice versa. Since Ellis has written individual bios of Jefferson, Washington, and especially John Adams, he is well versed with the main characters. Yet, I found his analysis surprisingly fresh and engrossing, especially his recounting of the key early battles in New York where the Americans came perilously close to losing it all.Ellis is particularly skilled in focusing on the human dimension in his writing; this book is no exception as his insights into Washington and his strategy are most impressive. One can only wonder about the level of GW's military skills, and how lucky he was. Similarly perceptive are Ellis' insights into Lord William Howe, the overall British commander, and how his paradoxical desire for reconciliation overrode his military leadership as he permitted the Continental Army (such as it was) to escape destruction.Ellis leaves off at the point when Washington has evacuated his troops out of NYC. At this point, several issues are clear. First, it will be a long war since the British blew their chance for early annihilation of the Continental army. Second, no matter how dark the military situation, and the summer of 1776 had been the darkest during the war, the Continental Congress and the American people they represented, would never settle for anything less than total independence.I found the final chapter,  on "Necessary Fictions" especially interesting, as Ellis explodes some myths held by both sides of this military and political confrontation.There are some helpful notes that demonstrates Ellis solid research, particularly his reliance upon correspondence and documents. There are also three helpful maps and some colorful illustrations. Ellis has produced 240 pages of effective and perceptive analysis that will enthrall both the professional historian as well as the motivated general reader. A vital experience that both can share and benefit from.

This is an excellent murder mystery/trial tale, with some unusual dimensions. First, this was one of the first American trials to have a complete record kept; so the author's accountof the trial is replete with detail and authenticity. Moreover, you may have heard of two of the lead defense counsel: Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr--not exactly allies under normal circumstances. Finally, we learn much about the rough and challenging life followed by New Yorkers during this period.
