So there are several dimensions added to a fascinating murder mystery.I found the author highly attentive to the procedures followed in criminal trials of this period. There are some stark departures from current procedure, and it is obvious we have evolved in the right direction. The murder trial is also set against an interesting political background, namely in the wake of George Washington's death, Burr is at work trying to undermine the Federalist Bank of the U.S. in favor of his water company, so as to enhance his political influence in the upcoming presidential election of 1800. The potency of the fever sweeping the area, and its substantial death toll, also are recounted.So, this is more than just a fine murder mystery--one can pick up some valuable information about early trials, the pre-duel careers of Hamilton and Burr, and life in a very fearsome NYC. The author has done solid historical research, as his ample notes and list of sources establish. But fundamentally, this is a solid mystery story above all.

I recently took a trip to the beach and thought it would be a great opportunity to try out this product. This is the first messenger bag I have used, and I found this one to have many good points but also some deficiencies. First the good things: it has ample capacity (I shoved in a fair amount of paper files, books, and writing materials). It held all this easily so its capacity is a great advantage.  It also appears quite durable, being made of top-flight materials. Particularly effective are the Velcro strips that are easily engaged (with one hand even) and really secure the contents quite effectively. The interior design is well thought out with several internal pockets and two large divided compartments, either of which can hold a laptop or table securely. It is touted as being waterproof, and it sure looks it when closed up.There are several problem areas as well: I most missed a handle on the top of the closed bag. Without one, you must use the strap to handle the bag at all times. There is a small handle attached, but it is toward the bottom and is covered completely when the bag is closed. It also would have been helpful if the bag had some built in structure when empty; as it is, when empty it just dissolves into a heap.All and all, it worked well for me on the trip and I am sure will do the job for others also. I am informed it comes with a lifetime guarantee as well.

This is an interesting and quite extensive (532 pages including end notes) study of how the Nazis both utilized and attacked culture. The author has chosen as his principal source the issues of the Volkischer Beobachter, the Nazi newspaper that began publication in 1921, which was the principal cultural and political propaganda source for the party. The author claims to have read virtually every issue of the paper, and I believe it given the extensive and sometimes overwhelming detail reflected in the book. This is principally a book for the specialist or those well versed in the history of the Third Reich--otherwise a reader risks simply being overcome.While most of us are generally aware of how the Nazis attacked what they termed "degenerative art," this is but a small part of the culture war that they fought up to and including the end of the war. The Nazis sought to demonstrate that their central values and ideas were identical to the key concepts of western civilization. They did this by analyzing art, literature, music and other cultural elements to demonstrate that the ideas expressed therein were parallel to their own ideology. Moreover, they sought to identify past artists (e.g., Bach, Mozart, Goethe, Durer, Wagner) who embodied Nazi values.But even this was but a part of the story: they also launched an anti-Semitic campaign to show how prominent thinkers in the past (e.g., Luther, Shakespeare, Wagner) were emphatic in sharing their anti-Semitic perspectives. As part of this campaign, they also undertook to purge Jewish cultural influences from German culture, by attacking individuals like Heine and Mendelssohn. It is amazing how much energy and resources the party poured into all this cultural activity, validating Plato's warning about the political impact of art.The author also discusses additional key themes in the Nazi cultural offensive. The party embraced classical and Romantic culture, while attacking the Enlightenment as a French subversive force. Their love for Romanticism (rather than realism and Modernism) was fervid. Music was particularly a key area for this, with Beethoven and (of course) Wagner playing major roles. Interestingly, the party utilized culture to attack Weimar and the Versailles treaty. Not surprisingly, culture was used to glorify battle and prepare the German population for the "ennobling" experience of war. All of this is gone into in exhausting detail.The amount of research undertaken by the author is amazing--the notes alone cover 68 pages. He has also included a large number of illustrations of paintings demonstrating his themes (those of Durer are particularly helpful). But it is a very long and challenging work.  However, it really covers the waterfront on this issue and is well worth looking at if you have any interest in the Third Reich period and/or the political uses of art. There can be no better discussion of the issue.

There exists a mountain of books discussing, arguing, explaining, and disputing H.L.A. Hart's "The Concept of Law" (1961) (CL).  This is understandable since it has been the dominant work of legal philosophy published in the second half of the 20th century. Most of these books are heavily analytical, and some such as those by the late Ronald Dworkin are highly critical.  Despite the title, this book by A.W.B. Simpson occupies a somewhat unique position in this literature. It certainly focuses upon Hart (whom Simpson knew at Oxford), but it also discusses Oxford jurisprudence, Simpson's own life, American v. British legal education, and some juicy gossip. I found it one of the most valuable books on the CL that I have read and recommend it without reservation.Simpson first of all introduces the reader to Hart, his philosophical education, Oxford (ordinary language) linguistic philosophy, and his teaching at Oxford. This section is particularly interesting because Simpson asserts Hart was not interested in legal issues or the common law, but rather philosophical issues. The second chapter discusses the Corpus Chair of Jurisprudence, which Hart occupied, how law was studied at Oxford, Hart's legal education, and the role of philosophy in Oxford legal education  during the 1950-1970 period. One learns that Oxford during the 19th and 20th centuries had Corpus Professors who really did not focus on jurisprudence but upon other interests. The author contrasts Oxford legal education with its American counterpart.In the third chapter, the topic is how jurisprudence had fallen into disrepute by the time Hart assumed the Corpus Chair in 1952. His job was to rejuvenate the discipline and raise the intellectual tone of jurisprudential study. This he did by coauthoring a book on legal causation, but most directly by unleashing the CL in 1961. Simpson begins his detailed examination of the book and its key concepts in this chapter. Basically, Hart sought to answer the question: "what is law?"I found the 4th chapter especially valuable, since Simpson there tries to identify the sources of Hart's ideas that reached maturity in the CL. While some of his conclusions can be debated, the author thoroughly reviews the pertinent literature in making his argument. All sorts of folks are discussed, including Kelsen, Weber, Salmond, John Austin, and many others. Whether Hart was a Isaiah Berlinian hedgehog or fox occupies chapter 5.Next, the author focuses upon some defects in the CL--but in a fairly gentle way unlike Dworkin. Interestingly, Simpson points out that the CL deals exclusively with the English (and probably) American legal systems, and has had little impact in the Civil Law countries. Simpson is particularly critical in asserting Hart ignored the common law and how it functions--so much so that Simpson wrote an important book on this topic. This chapter is probably one of the best ways to really get at the heart of the CL.The final chapter "judges" Hart from a number of different interesting perspectives:  his role as editor of the Clarendon Law Series; his famous exchanges with Lon Fuller of Harvard Law; the structure of the CL; and Hart as a philosopher. It struck me that the late author really had a great deal of respect for Hart, particularly since he started a great dialogue that revived the professional discussion of the philosophy of law.A quirky book, to be sure, but extremely valuable, including Simpson's annotated bibliography of jurisprudential literature. It is quite helpful to have a copy of Nicola Lacey's superb bio of Hart close at hand. Whether new to Hart or an old hand, there is much to savor in this interesting book.

Whatever one may think about Judge Bork (who died on December 19, 2012), and believe me I have had my moments, the core essential truth about him shines throughout this brief book: he was first of all always a teacher, whether at Yale, while in the Department of Justice, on the D.C. Circuit bench, or while serving in conservative think tanks. I found this, presumably his last book, extremely fascinating. This is because he writes with his usual clarity and precision; injects some examples of his infectious and subversive sense of humor; and makes sure the reader understands what in his view the actual facts were, let the chips fall where they may.While the book is obviously concerned in part with Watergate, there is much more to indulge in here as well. He first takes the time to educate the reader a bit on the office of the Solicitor General, about which I have found few non-Washington types are familiar. Bork then discusses how he got the job of SG, including his few interactions with President Nixon. Bork observations on Nixon, throughout the book, I found extremely interesting and much more perceptive that most of the material I have read on the President. A particularly interesting discussion involves when Justice Douglas (no hero to Bork) enjoined the continued bombing of Cambodia and how SG Bork was able to neutralize this action with the help of the remainder of the Supreme Court.While the main event, Watergate, is developing, SG Bork becomes involved in the investigation and resignation of Spiro Agnew. The possibility of dual impeachments of the President and VP is the background overhanging Bork's actions during this episode. Even more pressure arises when he is invited to undertake the role of Nixon's lead defense counsel. When it rains, it pours, as they say.The core of the book is, of course, his discussion of the the "Saturday Night Massacre." The insights Bork adds, having been the key participant, to this drama alone justify reading this book. Particularly important were the steps now Acting AG Bork undertook to ensure the professional completion of the Watergate investigation, the continued independent functioning of DOJ, and that things did not fly out of control. A cool hand on the wheel is always nice in a major crisis.The book runs around 130 pages, including a few endnotes. I found only a few mistakes which I am sure the Judge would have corrected had he seen the book in galleys: Griffin Bell was not the Maryland U.S. Attorney who led the Agnew investigation (p. 37); Earl Silbert was the Washington, D.C., U.S. Attorney (not an AUSA) during the Watergate investigation (p. 71); and Johns Hopkins is not located in Annapolis p. 113). I don't know if the Judge left behind material for a complete autobiography--but I sure hope so after reading what may be his last important lesson for us.

Anyone interested in Winston Churchill and the politics of persuasion will find this a delightful as well as informative book. The author focuses upon a somewhat unique characteristic of WC, his use of meals as opportunities to learn facts from guests or to persuade allies that they should support his policies.After an initial chapter ("The Importance of Dinners"), author Cita Stelzer (currently a researcher at Churchill College) devotes Section 1 of the book to actual studies of WC in mealtime action. These include WC and FDR off Newfoundland meeting at sea in August 1941; WC at the at the White House for Christmas 1941 to seal up an American alliance after Pearl Harbor; big three meals at Teheran, Yalta and Potsdam; and a less successful 1953 effort with Ike in Bermuda.The heart of the book is the author's careful analysis of the mealtime techniques WC employed as part of his effort to persuade. He carefully set the stage by picking the location; he minutely oversaw the menu and other preparations; he did all that was possible to relax his guest(s), including abundant cigars, liquor and good cheer. Whether he was making his weekly wartime reports to the King, having picnics with American generals, or probing his own military leaders for information, WC was a master at using meals as prime opportunities to ingratiate and persuade those who had something he needed, including alliances to win the second war.The second section of the book is also quite interesting.  It discusses WC's preferences in foods and tobacco. An important chapter seeks to knock down the presumption that WC drank far too much; the author here exposes his techniques for appearing to drink more than was actually the case. But this is an important point given criticisms that WC's alcohol intake impacted on his war leadership. A final chapter discusses how WC was fairly meticulous about conforming his own consuming behavior to wartime rationing requirements.The author's discussion is supported effectively by abundant illustrations--of bills, meal locations, menus, and the key leaders with whom he interacted and dined. Also included is a section with brief bios of his dinner companions, endnotes, and a bibliography. All this runs 314 or so pages, and it goes quite quickly as this is one of those rare books that is both informative and just plain fun to read. Winston, we do really miss you!

I have never been that much into the Civil War, but a recent trip to Charleston, S.C., sparked my interest in this book--and I am glad it did since this is just an outstanding piece of historical writing. This is not a book of military history, although as Ken Burns' "Civil War" demonstrated, that can be engrossing.  While there is plenty of battlefield coverage here, the author's focus is on the context of the Civil War. That is, he discusses the social dimensions of the war, the economic considerations, internal Confederate conflicts, and other key elements that put the war into a fuller setting.For example, the initial chapter discusses the economic realities of the southern states, which controlled most of the wealth in the country prior to the war. One question I always had was how possibly the southern leadership ever felt it could win an armed insurrection. Now I have a much better understanding of that issue. Moreover, the author takes great care in explaining what factors (e.g., growing northern electorate; militant abolitionism; the election of Lincoln) pushed the South toward secession.After this background, the author proceeds chronologically through the war, explaining the military developments in just enough detail so the reader can follow what is occurring in that aspect. So early on, significant Confederate military victories emerge, but the four key border states remain in the Union. But then Union victories, particularly at Gettsburg and in Tennessee, alter the military situation.This development has a direct impact on one key focus of the book: the role of African-Americans (initially) as slaves, a large number of whom abandon their masters, some of whom join the Union forces, others of whom demand land to cultivate and education. The emotional impact on the southerners of this change in slave conditions as the Union armies penetrate deeper into the South, and their wealth and control begin to evaporate, is a vital component of the war story.A further important dimension is the internal dissenion within the southern ranks between large land owners, who are running things, and the smaller farmers upon whom demands are made for more taxes, joining the ranks, and contributing food and slaves to the war effort. As the war continues to go badly, the psychological pressures build upon the southerners as they see their entire way of life dissolving. With Lincoln's 1864 re-election, the proposed 13th amendment, and the loss of Atlanta, the picture becomes increasingly bleak as pressures build.I found it surprising that even after the war is lost, some southern leaders still felt they could negotiate terms that would permit them to retain their plantations and slaves. While this proved not the case, the author discusses postwar developments where elite control continued via black codes and the "Jim Crow" system.The book runs some 412 pages, including notes and bibliography. The author's research is extensive; his judgement and analysis reasoned and perceptive. The Civil War was a lot more than just battles; the reader now gets the full picture of what was occurring and what was to come.

Despite many years studying Jefferson, I never cease to be amazed by the multiple dimensions of his intellectualism. This is particularly true of his independent career in science, at a time when he was writing the Declaration, serving in several high government positions, representing the nation in Paris and elsewhere, founding the University of Virginia, and building and rebuilding Monticello. While there are other books on this topic, the one is particularly effective since it focuses almost entirely upon TJ's scientific activities, discusses enough of the scientific context to orient the reader, and explores the topic is significant detail.The range of scientific topics is surprisingly vast--one wonders where the man got the time to carry on this sideline. TJ was not just a gifted amateur but a scientific mind of this first caliber. I had not been aware of his astute mathematical abilities. The author discusses how TJ was infuriated by the French scientist Comte de Buffon who ridiculed American animal and plant life as weak and degenerate. In response, Jefferson wrote his famous "Notes on the State of Virginia," shipped off Moose antlers and Mastodon bones to Paris, and confronted Buffon in person while serving in Paris. But this was just the beginning.The author discusses TJ's interests in geology; sea shell fossils; mineralogy; paleontology; the culture of Native Americans; slavery and race; astronomy; botany; chemistry; agricultural science; climate and geography; surveying; and exploring the West via Lewis and Clark.  Equally important, the author probes why TJ was so scientifically oriented, focusing upon his studies at William and Mary, his exposure to Scottish Enlightenment thought, and his years in the stimulating intellectual environment of Paris.There are some surprises uncovered by the author as well. He believes Jefferson was limited somewhat by his continuing belief in Biblical creation. For example, he could not accept that some species had become extinct. Jefferson was not interested in science for its own sake, but primarily if it had practical applications in the new nation. Hence his interest in designing plows, ciphers and sundials. The author provides a nice comparison on this point between John Adams and TJ. Finally, the author suggests that there was serious opposition to free-wheeling scientific inquiry by some, because they feared it would undermine religion and remove absolute values.The book runs 303 pages, including extensive notes attesting to the author's thorough research, and some helpful illustrations. While many topics are covered, the reader is not buried in detail since the book is very cogently organized and flows nicely. It is interesting to see this dimension of Jefferson examined so skillfully because it adds greatly to our understanding of the man.

Justice O'Connor did not mean this book for an academic audience, and that is its principal strength. We have scads of fine academic treatises on the Supreme Court. What is needed is a book that introduces the Court to general readers in an engaging fashion. This is that book. Incidentally, I might add, I have been a student of the Court for more than 45 years; yet I learned a few new things from the book myself.The book is almost conversational in tone, since it is akin to a collection of stories--yet packed with important information. The author has chosen to focus on a number of themes which one might not encounter in other books on the Court.  For example, she devotes chapters to Supreme Court humor; Court "customs and traditions"; four justices she considers "larger-than-life"; Supreme Court "Firsts"; and how the Court came to occupy its present iconic building. I found her chapters on circuit riding, judicial retirement, the inauspicious beginnings of the Court, and how oral argument contributes to the work of the Justices to be the most interesting. The only "dry" chapter is the short one on the Court's changing jurisdiction--an important but not exactly an engrossing topic. The book runs 165 pages, not counting appendices, notes, and index.The author writes in an comfortable and informal fashion, incorporating helpful examples from her own period of Court service.  I found only one chapter to be one that I felt might overwhelm the general reader: that on "Judicial Appointments." While she does not discuss every appointment, it almost seems as if she does in 22 pages, and that's a lot on the reader's plate. I must say her passion for exclamation marks (!) was beginning to drive me up the wall after a while. The editing sometimes is lax, and the same information is repeated. She has included some very interesting illustrations, many of which I had not seen before, as well as some helpful endnotes. It might have been helpful to include a brief "wrap-up; as it is the book seems to end abruptly.If you have any interest in the Court and its role, but have not explored it because you felt it might be too complicated, you will find in this book an introduction that is informative, yet relaxed in tone and easy to understand. Writing such a book on such a complex topic is no small achievement!

The Mineral Sunscreen SPF 25 - Beauty by Earth Natural, Mineral Sun Block SPF 25 has a lot going for it. It smells almost like coconuts or almonds or something I can't think of. The aroma is light so it doesn't enter a room before you do. I like that it is a natural SPF, water resistant and biodegradable. All those things are quite nice. He read the apply liberally, and took it to mean just that. However, he really shouldn't have done that. He wound up with a white clown face. I'm not being mean or anything like that. I'm just telling what happened. He smoothed and smoothed it, I tried to smooth some of it off of him. He tried to rinse it off but it was just like the water beaded right off. That would have been terrific except that he couldn't go out looking like that. Fortunately, we had taken another sunscreen and we used that when we got to the beach.When we got home, I decided to make sure he hadn't just applied it incorrectly. I took a very small dot and rubbed it on the back of my hand. It took a little doing to get the white to absorb some. I was left with a whitish shimmer that exaggerated my wrinkles.Like I said, it does smell nice and it feels smooth on the skin but if I use this again, I am certain it will take only a 1/4 teaspoon to apply it all over my body. Nope, I didn't think I needed one. When I sit at my computer, I am facing the wall, the window is to my back. If someone walked up behind me, I would see them on my screen because they pass between it and the glare on my screen from the light behind me...Oh... then I got it. I didn't think I wanted it on there permanently so I just leaned it up against the screen of my laptop. I don't have a desktop so I don't have to try to make it "fit". I just leaned it up against it. One thing I noticed was that my screen was a bit darker than before and that there were little lines and it was difficult for me to see. After examining it and looking at the picture instructions I found out that there was a sheet of clear plastic on both sides that I needed to remove. So, I decided I should adhere it to my screen afterall.I will admit that it took me a while to figure out how to use the adhesive tabs to hold it in place but once I did that I discovered something amazing.... I no longer had the glare from the window behind me on my screen.
