"London Falling" opens with two undercover police -- the cynical and  crooked Costain and the earnest and not-entirely-open homosexual Sefton -- being told by their boss Quill that their long and largely fruitless investigation of powerful crime lord Rob Toshack must end tonight. The police successfully lower the boom on Toshack, but he slips through their fingers yet again, this time when he dies hideously and inexplicably in a police interrogation room, right in front of Quill. As Quill, Sefton, Costain, and their intelligence contractor Lisa Ross comb through the remains of Toshack's organization, they stumble into an occult ritual that leaves them cursed with the ability to see into the dark magical dimension that underlies London's mundane reality. Encouraged by Quill's boss, this mismatched team must conquer their fear and loathing in order to bring down the evil creature that fueled Toshack's violent reign ... and ultimately brought him down.I was not expecting such a bleak, dread-ful, and horror-ific book from Paul Cornell. I didn't think "London Falling" was going to be an imitation of Neal Gaiman's mostly-whimsical Neverwhere -- another novel about an supernatural world below the surface of London -- but Cornell's fantasy is as about as dark as they come. Without appealing characters and with a plodding pace, I found the book difficult to finish. Nevertheless, it's imaginative and well-written, and I will probably read the second book in the "Shadow Police" series, "The Severed Streets."

Melissa F. Olson's Scarlet Bernard series got off to a slow start and, though the later books are better than the first, Olson painted herself into a corner by, among other things, destroying virtually every relationship in the main character's life, including the character's own relationship with her life. Olson probably made a good decision when she decided to set her new Boundary Magic in the same universe but give it a fresh set of characters and a new locale. While Allison “Lex” Luther's experience as a traumatized female Iraq war vet who also happens to be a witch doesn't exactly make her the girl next door, it does make her more understandable and relatable than "null" crime scene scrubber Scarlet Bernard.In fact, with Lex in her home town of Boulder and her community of sometimes-friendly/sometimes scary witches and vampires, Olson seems to have consciously or unconsciously modeled her new series on Kat Richardson's Greywalker series, with her tough PI protagonist Harper Blaine, her home town of Seattle, and her hot and cold relations with witches and vampires. Both women see ghosts, both women have died multiple times, and both women have to delve into the histories of their home towns in order to achieve their goals. My point is not that the Boundary Magic series is a rip-off; actually, I think that Olson has picked a good model and is doing well with it. Furthermore, I think it's fair to say at this point that Olson's work is at least on par with Richardson's.I haven't said anything yet about the plot of "Boundary Lines." It's a bit convoluted, but the upshot is that somebody or something is fooling around with the magic in Colorado, the potential consequences are dire, and in order to prevent the world from coming to an end (at least in a small way), Lex must heal past wounds, work with her friends, and gain new powers. There's some romance, some revisiting of past traumas, some best-forgotten nonsense with the police (best forgotten because it's not handled well by Olson), some action involving werewolves, vampires, witches, ghosts, and a giant people-eating monster, and and some not great/not terrible use of Colorado history to provide a sense of place and context. Not everything works, but when you take it all together, it's a satisfying read. Recommended to those who have followed Olson's work so far.

The high ratings this set has received from some people will probably get your hopes up, but ... you get what you pay for. The quality of the tools is fair. The quality of the case is poor. As with every set of tools-in-a-case I've ever bought, you will find the inability of the case to properly hold the tools frustrating every time you open it up. If you just need some tools "for now" and plan to upgrade as you go along, this is not the worst investment you could make. You should probably plan on replacing the case in the short term, however, and replacing the tools in the medium to long term.

Ramez Naam's Nexus Trilogy is probably the best science fiction treatment to date of the emergence of the "posthuman." Unlike some authors, Naam does not assume that AI leads unconditionally to catastrophic singularity (as in Charles Stross' Accelerando), nor does he simply wave his hands and shoot off to a far future where posthumanity is an established fact. Naam wants us to confront the choices we face as humans in an age where technological mind alteration, mind connection, mind control, and non-human minds are all possibilities. His characters do make choices -- sometimes foolish choices, sometimes paranoid choices, and sometimes angry choices -- but none of them are simple or necessarily morally right or rationally correct. If his writing and characterization are not entirely top shelf, they're still quite good. The result is a thoughtful, well-paced, well-sustained techno-thriller that should be able to reach a broad audience. I recommend the entire trilogy.

The SoundTouch Controller Android app allows you to take control of the relatively modest network capabilities of your Bose SoundTouch system. You can use it to turn on your SoundTouch device, control the volume, pair SoundTouch devices, and connect your SoundTouch device to Internet radio, a small selection of Internet apps (limited to Deezer, iHeartRadio, Pandora, and Spotify), or your local music library. The interface is initially confusing, but doesn't take long to master. Power and volume are easy to figure out. If you have multiple systems that you want to pair, the first device you choose becomes the host, and the second (or third, etc.) becomes a client. Setting up a multiple-system connection can be frustrating because the systems (in my experience) are so slow to respond that you may give up and try again ... only to find the first attempt beginning to work just before it is terminated by the second attempt. (That's probably not the app's fault.) Setting up the 6 presets (yes, that's all you get, for no sane reason) is not difficult, but for reasons I'm not certain of, they don't always "take". Presets can be internet radio stations, one of the built-in apps, your music library, or Bluetooth (I think; I haven't tried making Bluetooth a preset).The app design is not as intuitive as I would like, but it's not terrible, and it does have a more professional look to it than many other product-specific apps. My three-star rating is less a reflection on the app itself than a judgment on the (slow) speed of pairing and on the limitations of the Bose SoundTouch system, including the small number of built-in apps, the small number of presets, and the inability to use Bluetooth to play whatever you'd like on the system. (E.g., you cannot play Prime Music on your SoundTouch system even if it's installed on your phone or computer.) Regardless, you *must* install this if you have a SoundTouch system and want to take advantage of its network capabilities.N.B. This app is not a substitute for your physical Bose remote. For example, if you have a Bose Wave IV with SoundTouch, you can use this app to turn it on or off, to change volume settings, and to select SoundTouch presets, but you cannot use it to switch to CD, change tracks on the CD, switch to AM/FM radio, or do any radio tuning.

These IMEEA® Iced Tea Spoons are a reasonable value for the money. They have pleasant, simple modern styling, and they appear to be of reasonable quality. They may not be as solid as your regular stainless silverware, but they're not flimsy, and they should last a long time ... as long as you don't use them as pry bars. They may be a bit modern in style for some silverware collections, but most iced tea drinkers should be perfectly happy with them.

The Monoprice 108320 In-Ear Enhanced Bass Hi-Fi Noise Isolating Earphones sound quite good for the price, but they have a fatal flaw: their ultrathin cloth-covered wires are impossible to keep from getting tangled. If you're willing to spend minutes untangling them every time you use them, they might be worth the sub-$10 price; otherwise, they're not worth the frustration. I recommend you look elsewhere for your budget headphone needs. FWIW, I think the Amazon Premium Headphones are a better value.

My wife has been the main one using the Gaiam Beginner's Barre Kit, so here are her impressions (edited & augmented by me):It's always nice to have new exercises to do, and new equipment makes it easy to vary your routine. This barre kit is an inexpensive way to add new options to your daily or weekly routines. It includes a small, uninflated rubber ball, a needle for inflating the ball (pump not included), a rubber resistance band with handles, a simple guide with five exercises, and a URL for two free exercise videos. It is easy to use, and it doesn't take up a lot of room (even when inflated) for storage.The guide and the videos were helpful in showing me some good exercises to do, and they sparked ideas of other ways to use the equipment. For example, I'm such a literal thinker that I only thought about using the band solely by holding the handles with my hands. But you can also use the handles on your feet! Or you can hold the band in the middle! (I'm short, so I already thought of putting a knot into the band to shorten it when necessary.) The exercises aren't too hard or crazy (this IS a "beginner's" kit), but I still felt them, and you can certainly come up with your own ways to make it harder if you want.N.B. The provided URL for the exercise videos didn't work. I called the toll free customer service number on the guide, and the friendly and helpful representatives there sent me a working link.

These Amazon Collection 18k Yellow Gold Plated Sterling Silver Two-Tone Knot Drop Earrings are reasonably-priced and reasonably attractive. My wife -- who, unlike me, has actually worn them -- says: "These are fine earrings. They aren't as fancy as they look in the picture, but they're nice enough to jazz up a casual night out. They are an unusual shape, which seems strange to say, because there's nothing really that unusual about them when you think about it. I guess I'm used to more long and dangly earrings and not quite ones so squared. They're lightweight, and the posts are thin enough to be very comfortable."

Adam Rakunas's "Windswept" is a fun, fast-moving, and suspenseful sci-fi novel inspired by the "one last job" crime genre (a la "The Italian Job). Clever, pushy, manipulative, but good-hearted union recruiter Padma Mehta needs just one more handful of new members to earn the credit she needs to fulfill her dearest aspiration and buy the Windswept rum refinery. When a competing recruiter uses underhanded methods to steal her most recent batch of recruits, Padma gets desperate. She takes a tip from one of the most thoroughly disreputable characters she knows -- beginning a rollercoaster succession of temporary successes and setbacks that leave the reader constantly wondering what will happen next.Padma lives on planet Santee, a agro-industrial backwater known mostly as an interstellar truck stop and bio-diesel exporter. On Santee, there is an uneasy peace between the WalWa corporate combine and the Union that the workers who process local crops and turn grain into fuel. (It's not clear why the big corporations haven't been able to grind the Union into the dust like they have in our world; we just have to take it for granted that the Union has more leverage than is apparent.) Most of the Union members, including Padma herself, are "breaches" -- men and women who take advantage of the stopover at Santee to flee their interstellar transports and break their contracts of indentured servitude with the big corporations. Unfortunately for these people, Santee is becoming less and less relevant to galactic affairs, and economic opportunities are disappearing. And, as Padma will eventually learn, some of the locals resent the corporations and the declining status of Santee enough to take drastic action.The One Last Job and Evil Inc. tropes are not exactly news, so what Rakunas does to keep this novel at fresh is to give it a frantic pace, inject a lot of unexpected goofiness, and lean a lot more heavily on Solidarity Forever than I can recall ever seeing in a sci-fi novel. He also gives Padma more depth than her initial actions appear to indicate; her ambitions have much less to do with wealth than with maintaining her sanity. Furthermore, while jaded Padma may think she knows how everything works, she is in for almost as many surprises as the reader.Bottom line: This is a fast and fun book that reflects current concerns about corporate dominance, ecology, human, social, and economic rights, and racial/ethnic diversity without ever getting preachy or particularly heavy. It's not going to earn many brownie points with the Sad Puppies (look it up), but too bad for them. Recommended.N.B. I received an ARC from the publisher in return for writing an honest review.

I can't claim to be a big fan of the color palette available for the 16oz Aladdin Stainless Steel Vacuum Mug, but the mug itself is solid. It does not leak. It keeps hot hot and cold cold. It fits snugly into the cup holders in my car. The top, by the way, is an unusual flip-up arrangement that has the tension necessary to keep the mug sealed -- but also enough tension to make one-handed operation a bit awkward. This makes it a good travel mug, but if you're going to drink (non-alcoholic beverages) while driving on the highway, you probably want to leave it open or ask a passenger to open/close it for you.

This is a cool little gadget, with its rocketship-like shape, its shiny stainless steel exterior, and its solidly-engineered feel. At least when new and sharp, like it is now, it does a fair job of trimming. On the other hand, it sometimes pulls at sensitive hairs while it is cutting them and can have difficulties trimming even the most obvious hairs. It's superior to less-expensive battery-operated trimmers mainly in posing less danger of snagging skin, being more compact, looking cooler, and (duh) not requiring costly and environmentally unfriendly batteries. Bottom line: it's a compact and stylish grooming accessory most likely to be appeal to frequent travelers, who won't have trouble fitting it into their luggage and will enjoy not having to worry about the state of its batteries or whether it will explode if their bags are left out in the sun.

It's been a while since I read "Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance," but if recall the author's views correctly, a Bose radio is like a BMW motorcycle. They're both expensive and polished and known for their elegance and smoothness. You can find something else that does the job equally well, but nothing else will deliver the sense of style or the level of confidence that comes with the Bose or BMW. The best reason to buy a Bose is *because* it's a Bose.That said, the Bose Wave SoundTouch Music System IV is a nice package. It looks nice and it sounds nice. It plays AM/FM radio, it plays CDs (just one at a time, slot-loaded), and it can connect with other devices using wi-fi or Bluetooth (via the SoundTouch base). It also has a remote control and can be used as an alarm clock (a feature I have not tried). I have no idea how many watts its amp puts out, but it can pump more volume than you would think, without noticeable distortion. When Bose says that the Wave IV delivers "Lifelike, room filling sound" they're not exaggerating -- at least about the "room filling" part. As for "lifelike" ... that's a tall order for any system, and it's not one this system can fill. The Bose IV sounds great for a kitchen or bedroom radio, and it can be the life of the party in a pinch, but it will not blow you away with solid lows, sparkling highs, or incredible levels of detail.A word about SoundTouch: This is Bose's new system for filling your whole house/apartment with sound. Using Bose's SoundTouch app (available for Android, Mac, iPhone, and Windows), you can link two or more Bose SoundTouch systems together, using one of of the systems as a sound-generating host and the others as clients. I have two SoundTouch devices (this is and the Bose SoundTouch 520 Home Theater System) and I have joined them together more than once to deliver music throughout the bottom floor of my apartment. (Note that range within the home is not an issue; the linkage occurs via wi-fi, so as long as your devices are on the same network, you should be OK.) The other system doesn't even need to be on when you initiate the link; you can do it all through the app. Unfortunately, the linkage process is on the slow side, and the app is ... less user-friendly than one would hope.) Once the link is set up, however, it's quite cool to control all that sound from your phone or computer. N.B. While you can connect to the Wave IV from your phone or other devices using Bluetooth, you cannot connect to Bluetooth speakers from the Wave IV. If you want to broadcast sound all over the house, you will need to buy other Bose SoundTouch devices.Additional details: (1) The remote is easy to use, but it's also tiny and mandatory. Tiny = easy to lose, and mandatory = there are no controls on the unit besides on and off so you better not lose the remote. (2) The app allows you to create music six presets for the Wave IV. (Why six and not ten or several dozen? I have no idea.) I have three radio stations (via the Internet) set up on mine right now, plus a Pandora channel. The app allows you to access Deezer, iHeartRadio, Pandora, Spotify, and at least one local music library (i.e., on a PC or NAS drive) natively, in the sense that you don't have to involve any other device to run these services. (3) N.B. You can't determine what you will hear on these services without your phone, tablet, or laptop, because the Wave IV has no controls; if I want to change Pandora channels or hear a specific artist on Spotify, I will have to pull out my phone. (4) The ability to send sound to the system from your computer has limits. You can play music via Windows Media Player or iTunes, but you may not be able to hear the sound on your computer (I've had mixed experiences with this, so I'm not sure how it's supposed to work), and you cannot simply play sound in a web browser and have that relayed to the system. (5) Like so many slot-loading CD players, the one on my Wave IV is slow to load, makes scary noises when it's loading, and isn't guaranteed to load even a brand-new CD on the first try. (6) You can turn the unit off with a touch on the top. This is nice when you can't find the remote or left it on the other side of the room and you need immediate silence. (7) The Wave IV is compact, but it's not small, and Bose says that it performs best when you keep it away from corners, don't back it up flush with walls, and spread out the power cord (for FM reception). This means you might have some difficulty placing it properly, especially if you want to use it in the kitchen. (8) Broadcast radio reception was so-so, and the Wave IV does not receive broadcast HD radio; if you want to hear HD radio, you will have get it over the Internet. If you can -- I haven't tried yet. (8) There are no tone controls. At all. If you want more treble or bass, you will have to control them at the sound source (i.e., the app on your phone, if it has an EQ).Bottom line: Nobody would turn down a Bose Wave IV as a gift; that would be nuts! If you're shopping for a sound system, however, you will need to think through a number of issues, from whether you have a suitable space for the Wave IV, whether you really want to spend that much money, and whether you're interested in buying additional SoundTouch devices to fill up your home. (Bose uses proprietary technology, so you can only link the Wave IV to other Bose devices.)  All else being equal, if you can afford it and you value the simplicity and elegance and general BMW-ness of a Bose system, go for it.

I've had the Bose SoundTouch 520 Home Theater System for nearly a month. This is not a great surprise, but t's a vast improvement over TV speakers alone (I have a LG 65UB9200 65-Inch TV). I honestly don't have enough experience with similar systems to make apples-to-apples comparisons, but I will share my impressions of the system.SHORT VERSION: I'm very happy to have the SoundTouch 520. The subwoofer gives the system heft, the surround effects are good, the ability to play Internet sources is great, and the capability of sharing music with another system in the house (I have a Bose Wave SoundTouch music system IV) is cool. The sound quality is generally good, but there are weaknesses in the high bass/low midrange and high treble ranges. The system is less adjustable and configurable than most audiophiles and techies would like, with, e.g., no graphic equalizer or program/music type presets but only bass and treble controls. The SoundTouch app allows you to configure 6 radio station or app presets, while my car radio gives my 30 presets for FM alone. In other words, this is a system that will especially appeal to people who value compactness, simple setup and operation, seamlessness, and good design, and don't mind spending a few extra bucks and being locked into a proprietary system. It is less well-suited to tinkerers, eclectic mix-and-matchers, spec junkies, and those who value economy over elegance.OVERVIEW: The SoundTouch 520 consists of a central console, a wireless (wi-fi/Bluetooth) attachment to the console, a wireless subwoofer, four right-left front-back speakers (all the same), a center speaker (slightly larger), a "universal" remote control, and a bunch of wires. The console has 4 HDMI inputs to connect to devices like your cable box and DVD player, an HDMI output to the TV, and three non-HDMI inputs for older devices (Coaxial audio input (digital), Optical audio input (digital), R-L audio input (analog)) that can be accessed through AUX. It does not include any stands or mounting hardware, but it does include a special headset that can be used to adjust audio settings to best suit the room. Everything is controlled through the console, which includes a 5.1 channel amplifier of undisclosed power (Bose does not publish amplifier characteristics), can connect to the Internet via wi-fi, and can connect to your cell phone via wi-fi or Bluetooth. It has a small number of built-in apps for common services like Pandora, Spotify, and iHeartRadio that it can run without an external device, can access many radio stations over the Internet, and can stream from your phone, tablet, or computer, but it does not include an AM/FM radio receiver. It can also operate as a "host" or client to another SoundTouch device in your home, meaning that it can play sound on the other device or can be made to play whatever is already playing on that device.SETUP: The system is easy to unpack and assemble, though you might have some difficulties figuring out where to place the small front and rear speakers. The quick-start sheet and the larger manual are both clear and easy to read. Note that the speaker wires are proprietary, which means if they're too short, you will need to buy longer ones (assuming they offer them) from Bose. The SoundTouch app is easy to find online and download to your Android phone or Windows computer. (I don't have an iPhone or Mac to test, but apps are also available for those.) Getting the system to interface with your phone is not difficult, but the app can be a little puzzling at first. The remote is easy to configure but my not do everything you'd like. It supports the HDMI CEC device standard, but I couldn't get that to work with my TV or DVR/cable box. Instead, I had to look up codes. The TV works OK, but it's lacking one crucial feature for the DVR -- "go back," as in "I'm done looking at episodes of 'NCIS', let me see what else I have recorded." It also lacks the capability to turn everything on or off at once; it can do power, but only one device at a time.SOUND: Like I said above, the SoundTouch 520 generally sounds pretty good. Volume is not a problem in our mid-sized living room (but it might be a problem for the neighbors!). The subwoofer gives you that boomy theater sound, but the upper bass/lower midrange is lacking. In other words, it works better with explosions than with drums or cellos. The high end does not stand out particularly, but that's not necessarily a flaw. The system can give you a good surround experience, but that depends in part on where you're sitting (inevitably). Overall presence is OK but not great. The system sound can be configured for the room (using manual controls or the Adaptiq device), but it is not very adjustable for different types of music (no graphic equalizer, no classical or rock presets), and there are no special effects (e.g., concert hall sound vs. small club sound).INTERFACE: A really obvious feature to give this system would be an on-screen TV interface. It does not have one. It has a small LCD screen that most people will have to squint to read from the couch. The SoundTouch app cannot be run from the TV; it requires a phone, tablet, or computer. If you want to play Internet music, you will need to have one of those devices handy. As I mentioned previously, the app allows you to set 6 presets. Why 6 and not 8, 64, or 128? It seems like the cost of adding more would be essentially $0, so it's unclear why Bose stopped there. As I also mentioned, the app allows you to play the same source on multipel SoundTouch devices, which is nice. On the other hand, the devices tend to respond slowly, and this means that it can be very frustrating to get the host/client working together properly. Once the relationship is set, though, it works seamlessly. On the other hand, if you, say, use the app to run iTunes from your computer (which you can do), it will play iTunes on the SoundTouch device or devices, but you won't get the sound on your computer. So, the interface works, but it's a bit clunky, and it seems designed to shut your computer out of the mix except as a sound source. One other thing: the remote seems to glitch now and then. We've had problems with the console switching from the cable box as a sound source to the TV with no obvious reason or input from us. We've also had problems where the TV seems to get spontaneously reconfigured so it's no longer sending sound to the console. (This could be a problem with the TV and not the Bose, of course.)OTHER: You need to consider what you're going to do with the speakers. We have the rear speakers sitting on the back of our couch, which is not as bad as it might seem, but isn't ideal either. You will have the best experience if you're prepared to purchase professional installation or some combination of stands and mounting brackets, or if you already have furniture with sufficient space to place the speakers. Remember also that the speakers aside from the subwoofer are wired, and you're going to have to hide them, put them inside the walls, or find some way of making them less ugly -- and less trip-inducing.BOTTOM LINE: Choose this system if you're willing to pay a premium for a brand you recognize, good sound, and a stylish look. If you have the bucks to buy 1-2 additional SoundTouch systems for, say, the kitchen and the bedroom, that's even better. If you're on a budget or you want a seriously customizable system (or a full set of wireless speakers), however, you're probably better off looking elsewhere.P.S. I just did the AdaptIQ calibration (included; you wear a headset and sit at 5 different listening positions) and it improved the system's audio imaging. Not a dramatic improvement, but a noticeable one.

I was hoping to be wowed by the Ear Force Recon 50 Gaming Headset, but I wasn't. There's nothing major wrong with it; it just doesn't impress. The Recon 50 is a medium-weight all-plastic over-ear headset with an adjustable/removable boom microphone. It connects to your PC or other device using either a combined mic/headphone mini-plug jack or (via the included splitter cable) separate mic and headphone mini-plug jacks. (The cable with the combined jack is not terribly long, so I'm using the splitter cable to add length.) It is unpowered (no USB, no battery), which translates into relatively low gain from the microphone, no noise cancellation, and no amplification beyond what your computer/device supplies. The ear cups fit snugly -- with a bit too much pressure for my taste -- and do a reasonable job of filtering out external noise. The pads are soft but not especially thick, so my ears are touching the headphone drivers -- something that will probably get worse as the light foam in the pads wears down. The padding on the wide, hard top band of the headphone is minimal, potentially causing discomfort for those without thick hair. The sound is not bad at all, however, even for music (contrary to what some say). The bendy boom -- it has an internal wire that can be manipulated pretty extensively -- is a nice feature. The microphone mute switch has a teeny little label, making it tough to be sure whether it's set on or off, and the volume dial next to it is both very small and no better labeled.Overall, the Recon 50 is OK. It works OK, it looks OK (if you like red plastic), and its pricing is OK. Personally, I would consider spending just a bit more to get a more full-featured USB headset. Still, the Recon 50 is worth considering if you're shopping for a headset for under $40.

In "The Rest of Us Just Live Here," Patrick Ness tells the story of how aliens from another dimension are trying to consume the earth and its inhabitants in order to feed their insatiable need for power, and how a group of misunderstood kids are doing their best to save us from complete and utter destruction. Except that, in a complete reversal of the usual order of things, all the insane and tense sci-fi/fantasy action takes place off-stage while the main characters are focused on their struggles with OCD, anorexia, unrequited love, alcoholic dads, absent moms, loneliness, jealousy, and impending graduation from high school.Our narrator is Mikey, an OCD-prone high school senior who tends to wash his hands obsessively and count things compulsively when he is under stress. And he is under a lot of stress now because he's going to be moving away to college soon, he's worried about leaving his little sister at home with his irresponsible dad and his barely-present mom, his best friend is acting weird, and the girl he has a huge crush on is between boyfriends but about to leave town. Strange lights are appearing in the skies and the "indie kids" seem to be dying right and left, but the indie kids will take care of it and afterwards let everybody else know what happened. Probably.The book revolves mainly around Mikey's loving relationships with his sisters Mel and Meredith, his friend Jared (whose grandmother was a god), and his tentative not-exactly-romantic relationship with Henna, and how these develop in good and bad ways as graduation (and Armageddon) approaches. The off-stage fantasy story about Immortals and princes and amulets is silly, convoluted, and generally a nice foil for the more mundane turmoil in the lives of Mikey and his circle of friends and relatives. As Mikey's inner crisis intensifies, so does the fantasy battle, but Mikey's world and the broader world barely intersect except in a few isolated instances where each perturbs the other's narrative just a little.It's a good book for people who'd like to see heroic fantasy lightly skewered; it's a good book for people who want to read about conditions like OCD and anorexia without seeing sufferers treated either like lepers or saints; and it's a good book for people who have created families of choice or who can imagine themselves doing so. Also, it's not a laugh-out-loud funny book, but Ness treats everyone and everything with a (mostly) gentle and sympathetic humor that's less crotchety than Garrison Keillor and less aggressively over-the-top than Terry Pratchett's. So, it's a good book for that, too.I suspect that kids, and especially teenage boys, will be disappointed by the relative lack of action in the book and the touchy-feely nature of so much of the story. On the other hand, I'm certain that there are many teenage boys whose problems and worries are not so much different from Mikey's, and, with a little patience, they might find some reassuring and useful reassurance in Ness' story of Mikey's progress and missteps.pokes fun at the heroes and anti-heroes of young adult fantasy and sci-fi by telling the story of regular folks trying to get on with their lives while "special" kids tangle with aliens, gods, the undead, or

The Folkmanis Snowy Owl Hand Puppet is exactly what it looks like online: a fluffy, cute hand puppet. When you put your hand inside the lined interior (a mark of quality), you can turn the owl's head around (360 degrees) by grasping and twisting a dowel, and, if your fingers are long enough, you stick them into the wings pockets and flap them.(If you're a little kid, you're going to have trouble flapping more than one wing at a time.) The beak does not open and the feet cannot be directly manipulated.The quality of the owl -- design, materials, and the stuffed animal equivalent of "fit and finish" -- is very good for the price. My only complaint about quality control is that the fur around the left eye keeps wanting to cover it up, giving the owl a bit of a squinty look.Bottom line: A fine gift for a child (I would go with 5-and-up rather than 3-and-up) or an adult who likes stuffed animals and/or puppets. Though it does not claim to be a replica of Harry Potter's owl Hedwig, it's still particularly apropos for fans.

This router may look like a bug flipped onto its back, but it offers three independent high speed wireless channels, one at 2.4GHz (600Mbps) and two at 5GHz (1300Mbps each), promising high levels of wireless throughput to households and offices with multiple high speed-capable wireless devices such as computers, network disks, game consoles, and TVs. It also includes USB ports to allow network access to otherwise non-networked storage.My experience with the unit so far has been mostly positive. The installation instructions are well-designed and clear, as is the provided paper documentation. The unit's built-in menus are also well-designed and understandable and have intelligible and useful help information. Installation was not difficult, although I did have to use a network utility to find the unit's dynamically allocated IP address. The only real glitch I've had so far with the unit is that my printer, which I have left on an older, lower-speed wireless router, cannot "see" my computer when it uses the TP-LINK. The computer can "see" the printer, suggesting that this may represent be a flaw in the HP Officejet Pro 8620 networking code. (I'll update after further troubleshooting.)Pros:- Delivers high speed wireless networking- Can be attached to any router with a spare Ethernet port- Good instructions, documentation, menus, help system- Available USB ports (1 USB 3.0 and 1 USB 2.0) for storage or whatever- Appears to be well-made- Isn't too large or obtrusive if you can get over the six bug legs sticking in the air- Plenty of configurability- Can shut down channels if not using them, possibly conserving energyCons:- Not an ideal living room fixture- Not designed to stack easily- May have issues with legacy equipmentBottom line: This device is designed to deliver high speed wireless service to a home/office with several bandwidth-hogging networked devices. If it's just you and your laptop, this device is overkill. If your incoming network bandwidth is low or your router doesn't support high speed Ethernet, it may still be overkill. It's not like fast wireless is going to speed up your external Internet connection. If you have a need for multiple high speed wireless channels, however, this device (which I have not tested under a heavy load) seems like an excellent choice.

I've owned this chair for more than six months. It felt comfortable initially, and I figured I would be able to adjust it to allow me to work comfortably at my home office desk. Unfortunately, comfort has been very elusive.Pros:- Highly adjustable for the price- Reasonably well-builtCons:- Seat cushion may be overly long for men of below-average height (and most women)- Inadequate range of adjustment for arm rests -- not wide enough and not high enough- Inadequate range of adjustment for chair backrest -- does not go high enoughThis chair adjusts in multiple dimensions (both the seat and the backrest go up/down, back/forward, and tilt up/down, and the armrests go up/down and in/out), but the range of available adjustments will not be wide enough for all. I've recently come to the conclusion that the chair is best suited to men of slightly above-average size (width and height). If you're above average in weight or shorter than the average man (I'm over 200lbs and 5'8"), this might not be your ideal chair. Maybe I'm missing something, but that's the way it seems to me.

We use vacuum sealer bags and rolls a lot, but we don't always use FoodSaver brand bags or rolls. (FWIW, our machine is not a FoodSaver, either. We had one and loved it, but it was lost in a fire and we ended up trying a competitor's machine: the Nesco VS-02 Food Vacuum Sealer, Black/Silver, which isn't as shiny, but still does the job.)We decided to try the FoodSaver DAM Bags because sometimes moisture from food, especially raw meats, gets vacuumed out along with the air, making a mess in the machine and in the top of the bag. If you'll pardon my language, these DAM bags seem to do their DAM job. They have an absorbent strip (about 2-1/2 inches wide) above the food but below the seal line. Any juice or moisture gets trapped there by the strip, so the area above the seal stays clean! We usually use smaller bags, so we probably should have gotten the quart-sized bags instead of the gallon-sized, but that's our problem and no reflection on the bags. These bags are about twice as expensive as garden variety FoodSaver gallon bags, so we won't be using them every day, but for juicy meats, we'll definitely turn to these DAM bags.

The Tech Tools Desktop Madness Series Hand Pencil holder is very cute, but I am disappointed with the product. The biggest problem is the shallow pencil-holding cup -- it's only 2 inches deep! Normal-sized pens and pencils, which are about 6 inches long, are likely to tumble out of the cup if lightly bumped. There is no way that you would put normal-sized scissors in the cup (as in the photo of the product). The capacity of the pencil holder is much too small given the product's large, er, desktop handprint. I would also have preferred a ceramic hand, but the product IS clearly labeled as plastic/cement mix (whatever that means). It does look nice on the desk, but given its size, cost, and low capacity, I'm still not sure if I'm going to keep it. Buyer beware.

"Dark Eden" was not an easy book to read, and "Mother of Eden" is even tougher. The problem is not author Chris Beckett's writing skills, which are good; his rapid switching between first-person narrators, which is a mechanism I don't like, but which is easy to follow and does not disrupt the narrative; or his simulation of several centuries of linguistic drift, which is more atmospheric than annoying. Instead, the main problems are unsympathetic characters and a difficult-to-escape sense that Beckett is less interested in telling a compelling story than he is in advancing a particular view of human history. I see where Becket is coming from (I think), and I mostly share his views, but I still find his approach stultifying.What am I talking about? Beckett's story is driven by at least three strands of narrative. The first is pretty obvious: the story of Adam, Eve, Eden, and man's fall. The second is environmental, and was more obvious in "Dark Eden" than in the second book: when you live in a world of finite resources and you have a growing population, something's got to give, and pretending that everything will be fine because everything has always been fine is going to end in disaster. The third and much more complex thread is the whole complex set of intertwined social processes that bind politics, economics, social status, reproduction, gender, and violence together. (If you've read Engels' 1884 "The Origin of the Family, Private Property and the State," then this is familiar territory.) "Dark Eden" is much less about the Fall of Man than it is about the Fall of Woman and the Rise of Man. At the outset of Beckett's Eden, women enjoyed slightly higher social status than men in a largely egalitarian society where the biggest differences in status were those of age, symbolized by the rule of a council of elders. As the population of the original valley began to exceed the valley's carrying capacity, adventurous John set out to find new lands, but not before incurring the wrath of conservative David. The actions of John and his followers, as we see in "Mother of Eden," kickstarted a web of social, economic, and political developments, that included the development of trade, the invention of money, the growth of a stratum of male soldiers, mercenaries, and ne'er-do-wells, the rediscovery of torture and execution, the accelerating subordination of women accompanying the growth of large gaps in social status and wealth, the emergence of warlords and princes, and, most recently, the development of metal weapons and tools and the prospects of large scale warfare.It's no accident that Beckett places Starlight Brooking and her friends, who live in a peaceful egalitarian backwater, at the center of this tale. They are outside observers almost as much as we are. Ambitious and self-absorbed Starlight becomes our unwitting tour guide as she gives in to the seductive allure of the the city and, almost immediately on arrival, falls in love with an exotic princeling from a faraway land. This allows her to experience both the glories of economic development and the horrors of militarism and extreme social stratification. She is drawn in and repelled at the same time. Beckett repeatedly suggests that economic development sucks, but also that it sucks us in; the rewards of social and economic development outweigh (in some sort of calculus) the costs.I don't have problems with any of that, or very little of it. What I do have a problem with is how difficult it is to care about the characters or get into the story. Fortunately, this problem wanes (but does not disappear) before the end of the book's first half.High points include the subplot about the sentience of Eden's "bats" (I am still intrigued by what Beckett hints is the artificial genesis of the rogue planet. And why do all the animals have hands? That's weird.); the tortured, narrow, silly, and transparently sexist logic by which a philosopher concludes that the president of Earth was a man (even though it had always been known that she was a woman) and Starlight's to-the-point rebuttal; and the viscerally angering accounts of self-importance of the "big people" and the obvious suffering of the "little people".Bottom line: Beckett is not a clumsy or unskilled storyteller, but the "Dark Eden" books are difficult to enjoy. I like them a lot more for the sophistication of the message they send than for the quality of the story they tell. I might have used them in my sociology courses if I they had been around while I was teaching and if I had thought that students would read them. But for the general sci-fi reader ... I really don't know.

The striking JBL Horizon Bluetooth Clock Radio is a quirky product with a number of design flaws, but I can't help liking it. Let's start with the flaws. The controls for the unit are all on the top, which is fine, but all but  two of them are flush with the surface of the unit and cannot be located by touch and there is (as far as I know) no way to light up only those buttons. (Only the "set" button and the snooze/light bar stand out.) If it's dark and you want to change the alarm without turning the light up and waking your partner, you have to keep pushing down in random spots until you feel a click. Because the unit is tall and has a relatively small base, it's easy to knock over, and the power cable, which just slides into a hole in the bottom of the unit and does not have any sort of bracing, so it comes out too easily. (Fortunately, the unit has battery backup and ships with a battery. Note that you will need to open up the battery compartment, remove, and replace the battery to activate it on a new unit.) The unit comes with three preset alarms, all of which are musical. This may minimize the degree to which the alarm annoys the neighbors, even when it's at maximum volume, but it's not for traditionalists who prefer the customary beep-Beep-BEEP-BEEP!!! alarm sound. At least it doesn't startle you too much, as long as you don't choose a radio alarm and set it to a heavy metal station. (Note that some early units appear to have had a bug that quickly accelerated the alarm from 0 to amazingly loud. My unit did not have that problem.) Finally, there is no documentation available, not even online, beyond the mostly language-free quick start guide. What does the "sleep" setting do? I thought it would let me set a short-term (up to 60 minutes) nap, and it seems like it should do that, but when the timer reaches the end of the period you set, it just flashes a light for a few seconds. How useful is that? There must be a way to get an audible alarm, but -- and this was my point -- there's no documentation.On the plus side, the USB charging ports are a nice feature, as is the ability to set multiple radio presets -- something rare on a clock radio. The sound is good for a reasonably-priced clock radio, but it's a bit bass-heavy, a little muddy, and the maximum volume is not too impressive. While the design looks like something out of "2001" and probably clashes with your furniture and furnishings, it looks kinda cute. The auto-dimming white light of the clock is not at all bothersome while still being legible at low levels. Radio reception is decent, though not amazing. The Bluetooth feature worked fine with my Kindle, but I can't claim to have tested it widely.Bottom line: This product's biggest flaw is probably the fact that too few of the controls can be located by touch. The absence of a decent manual is also a major problem. On the other hand, if you like the unit's looks, and if you're actually going to listen to the radio or the unit as a Bluetooth speaker, you may be able to overlook a few shortcomings. It's not for everybody, but it might be for you.P.S. Having used this product and grown increasingly frustrated with its flaws and limitations, I have reduced its rating from 4 stars to 3 stars. The near-impossibility of finding by feel the buttons to turn the alarm on or off is my biggest frustration, followed by the unnecessary difficulty of changing the alarm time.

In “Simple Rules: How to Thrive in a Complex World,” Donald Sull and Kathleen M. Eisenhardt argue forcefully that governments, organizations, and individuals seeking to master the growing complexity of the contemporary world will find their salvation not in equally complicated policies and guidelines, but in simple rules. In a diverse array of examples, most drawn from business and government, they show that “Keep it simple, stupid!” is not a simple-minded principle, but rather one that requires a good deal of experience, insight, focus, and thought to accomplish. In the end, they cannot show that simplicity always or even usually trumps complexity – they cannot refute Einstein’s “A scientific theory should be as simple as possible, but no simpler” – but they do a good job of reminding us that there is both elegance and value in emphasizing fundamentals and paring away the cruft.

I've had enough bad experiences with 2-in-1 shampoos that I generally stay away from them. Being an Amazon Vine reviewer, however, I was given the chance to try this shampoo at no cost. I've been using the shampoo for several days, and my impressions are mixed. On the plus side, I like the scent of the shampoo, and I especially like the tingly feeling in my scalp after I've washed my hair with the product. (It feels like menthol, but menthol is not listed as an ingredient.)  I can't say for certain that my thinning hair is any thicker than usual, but it feels nicely conditioned in the morning after I shower. On the minus side, I am experiencing more scalp itching since I've been using the product, and my normally dry hair has become a bit oily. I'm going to keep using the shampoo for a little while to see what happens, but I'm strongly inclined to switch back to my usual generic shampoo-only product if I don't experience a turnaround really soon. (I will update the review if that happens.) My experience does not mean that others should avoid this shampoo, but those who have not had good experiences with 2-in-1s in the past should consider starting with a smaller, less expensive bottle.P.S. About 25% of the way through the bottle, I've finally given up and moved on to a bottle of Dove Men+Care Shampoo that I hope will get my hair and scalp back under control. We shall see.

"The Dark Side of the Road" is the first volume in a new Simon R. Green series featuring Ishmael Jones, an apparently-immortal alien who arrived on Earth in the 1960s and hasn't aged a day since. Vulnerable to Men-In-Black-type agencies that think the best alien is a dead alien, Jones has enjoyed the protection of a super-secret group called "The Organization" for the past 15 years. In return, Jones has been an alien hunter himself, keeping the good ones in line and terminating the bad ones with extreme prejudice.In the wake of an enormous Christmas storm, Jones' boss -- "the Colonel" -- makes a personal plea to Jones for help. Something has gone terribly awry at the his family's English country estate, and the Colonel clearly believes that Jones' specialized skills are needed. But when Jones arrives, the Colonel is nowhere to be found. This leaves Jones to mingle with the bitterly bickering cast of characters, including the doddering old patriarch, his bitter first wife, the ex's opportunistic companion, the patriarch's scheming second wife, the wife's uninhibited daughter, the daughter's unwilling-to-let-go ex-fiancee, the patriarch's money-hungry business partner, and the patriarch's butler-cum-bodyguard. When guests begin dying off one by one, Jones must use all of his limited detecting skills -- and his superhuman hearing, sense of smell, and strength -- to find the killer and protect the survivors.If you've read Green before, you know the drill. The first-person narrator is sardonic but vulnerable; hard on the outside but soft and a bit heartbroken on the inside. Ishmael Jones isn't John Taylor (from Green's "Nightside" series) but the two men bear a strong family resemblance. The plot lurches along, the dialogue is terribly artificial, and the denouement is tidy but not in the least bit elegant. Agatha Christie's detectives may solve their mysteries through brilliant deductions, but Green's characters are more likely to find the murderer by waiting until most of the suspects are dead. You read Green for sharp wit, not sharp wits; for a brief diversion, not a lengthy meditation.Bottom line: Recommended to Green fans who want more of the same. I haven't read anywhere near half of Green's novels; still, I'd wager this one is above average but not in the top third. Also recommended to those who are not familiar with Green but think they might enjoy a locked-room murder mystery featuring a heartsick immortal alien with special powers. On the other hand, if you love traditional mysteries, you will probably hate this book; Green has about as much respect for mystery genre conventions as he has for naive tourists who wander into the bad part of town looking for a good time.N.B. I received a copy of this book for free from Netgalley in exchange for an honest review.

How can you criticize a guy who has built his business career on improving the world by bringing people closer together (in his earlier efforts to build bridges between Israelis and Palestinians) and improve the quality and nutrition of the food people eat (KIND bars)? You don't.His book, on the other hand ..."Do the KIND Thing" is a self-help book focusing on how to live the purpose-driven life you choose for yourself. Sort of. It's also fighting to be the autobiography of a brilliant young(-er than me) social entrepreneur . And the biography of a successful retail brand. And a primer on social entrepreneurship. It is all of these things, but enough of the book works at cross purposes to itself that it mostly winds up being a bunch of anecdotes organized around themes like "grit" and "originality." If you're new to self-help books, you might find this sort of thing cool and inspirational; to me, and I will admit to being jaded, it's more of the same.Another of the book's problems is that, despite Lubetsky's social orientation, he is very focused on Lubetsky. This makes sense if your view is that we change the world by encouraging individuals to act. Act how? He really doesn't say. There's no overarching vision of the Good, and no sense that the Good will come from anything beyond individual people deciding to make things better. So, while Lubetsky has a story about how he did good, and about how maybe you can do good, he doesn't have a convincing story about what's wrong with the world, what a better world looks like, and why social entrepreneurship ... or being KIND ... is what will get us there.Bottom line: Not actively bad, but too focused on Lubetsky and his narrow conception of how to fix the world. If it sounds interesting, don't be afraid to give it a shot, but if it sounds like the book would put you to sleep, you're probably right.

I just finished reading the re-released version of Joe Haldeman's 1981 novel "Worlds." It's fantastic.Or very good, anyway. A brilliant young woman born in the orbital colony of New New York is awarded a trip to Old New York for an academic fellowship. A restless non-conformist, O'Hara sleeps around a bit, runs afoul of some violent men, and drifts into the orbit of some people who talk about themselves as libertarian revolutionaries. When New New discovers some precious resources on the moon, the relationship between the USA and the Worlds -- that is, all of the orbital colonies, big and small, weird and arguably wonderful -- destabilizes. A cycle of tit-for-tat economic warfare ensues, and, mostly because the wrong person is in the right place at the right time, things get wildly out of hand.The novel is filled with politics, sex, romance, conflict, odd characters, and oddball groups. Sci-fi novels about conflicts between Earth and its early offworld colonies are nothing new, and weren't all that new in 1981, either. Ditto for sci-fi novels about the early stages of interstellar exploration. What makes "Worlds" shine is the the emergence of O'Hara as an independent young woman whose experiences in orbit shape her experiences on Earth which in turn inform who she becomes when she returns home to orbit. She's a vivid and compelling character, if not necessarily an authentic one.On the downside, the book is bound to leave the reader with some questions that will never be answered, like: what the heck was this US revolution that came before O'Hara arrived? What the heck did the new revolutionaries think they were doing? How the ... heck did they let General Nutcase do his thing? What was Haldeman trying to say about politics except that it can get dirty and nasty?In any event, I wouldn't say that "Worlds" and its two follow-up novels are absolutely essential reading, but those who enjoy Haldeman's thoughtful writing should definitely consider picking them up. Also, if you're one of the people who's jumped on the new polyamory bandwagon, you might well enjoy O'Hara's living arrangements.

When young Medo innocently (more or less) stumbles into black magic and gets herself exiled for it, she finds herself hunted by an evil dragon. Turned out by the people she loves, accompanied only by a pet squirrel (who used to be a human knight named Hewbert), she soon picks up traveling companion Owyn, a boy of roughly her own age. Owyn is suffering a different sort of exile; he saved the life of a rebel leader and is on the lam from authorities that want to execute him for treason. The trio (Medo, Hewbert, and Owyn) must face the dragon and its human servants more than once as they struggle to survive in a cruel and unsympathetic world, helped (somewhat) by Marlin, a not-especially-effectual wizard with his own problems."The Dragon Beshrewed" is a well-told tale of adventure, heroism, loyalty, and self-realization. The book is suitable for early teens and up, but may be a bit intense and scary for kids at the lower end of the age range. (And it's not a "kissing book.") As an adult reader, I can testify that it's a great read for not-so-young readers, too. Highly recommended.

One thing you must understand about this pitcher is that it is not a French Press and it is not a Takeya-type pitcher with a removable brewing basket. It's a thin glass heat-tolerant, dishwasher-safe pitcher with a non-movable French Press stainless steel mesh filter just under the spout.Potential uses for the pitcher include brewing hot tea that you will be consuming right away, cold-brewing tea or coffee in the fridge overnight, and serving water infused with lemon or cucumber. It can also be used for any other purpose you'd normally want a moderate-sized pitcher for, like serving orange juice. But it's definitely not for brewing hot coffee or tea if you're not going to be consuming the beverage quickly or moving it to another container, because there's no way to remove the grounds/leaves without removing the beverage first.Pros: Looks nice, less fragile than it seems.Cons: Not a substitute for a hot brew pitcher like a Takeya, a French Press, or a nice teapot with a removable filter. On the fragile side. (The first one I received arrived broken.)

I’ve used Bio Bags for years – 3 gallon bags for my small compost bin as well in the bathroom bin for paper waste. Then I came across the similar World Centric compostable bags and decided to try them out. So here is a comparison of the two.Quality: For me, the World Centric bags are a clear winner. This is based mostly on how well they perform as… well, bags! If they fall apart then I may as well just put my food scraps directly in the bin and skip using bags altogether (Hmmm… perhaps I will!). The World Centric bags hold themselves together pretty well – even in mid-summer with lots of wet food waste. The BioBags will fall apart within a week under the same conditions, accompanied by the smell of rotting food along the way. However, I found out the reason for this: BioBags have a high “Water Vapor Transmission Rate” – in other words moisture leaks out of your bag o’ scraps pretty efficiently. This may explain why the bags don’t perform so well for me: in my Simple Human pedal bin there’s nowhere for this moisture to go other than the lid. If I used a properly ventilated composting bin apparently this would not happen as much. But the World Centric bags don’t have these issues in a pedal bin – as well as not falling apart they also don’t generate as much odor, fungal growth, or dripping moisture as the BioBags.Note that both types bags have a limited shelf life – you should use them within a year (or shorter in humid places) and they should also be stored in a cool dry place.Price: BioBags are the winner if you go by pricing on Amazon. They are about half the price of the World Centric bags. However, in stores I’ve bought World Centric bags for around four bucks for 25 bags (about the same as BioBags).So, as far as gold stars are concerned (quality and price) I think BioBags deserve 4/5 gold stars (I’m being generous, assuming that they hold together better in a compost bin than a peddle bin) and World Centric deserves 5/5 gold stars (if you can get them for around 5 bucks, but even at 8 they may be worth it for some people).Based on social and environmental factors (read on for more details) I think BioBags deserve 4/5 green stars while World Centric deserve 5/5 green stars. So WC bags win both in terms of quality (gold stars) and sustainability (green stars).Both types of bags are certified for composting both at home and industrially. I don’t think there’s any doubt that these bags will compost fairly quickly. Also, in both cases (and all compostable bags that I know of) they are made from a mixture of resin that is made from oil and a renewable polymer, typically PLA (poly-lactic acid) made from corn or potato starch. If you need more info, BioBags uses Mater-Bi from Italy, while World Centric use Ingeo (PLA) made by NatureWorks. On the company website, World Centric shows an in-depth comparison of their materials versus conventional alternatives, looking at energy and water inputs and waste or CO2 outputs.World Centric are most known for utensils and plates; compostable bags appear to be a more recent addition to their product range. They offset all of their carbon to have a zero carbon footprint. They donate 25% of their profits to grassroots social and environmental organizations. They offer compostable lunch trays at cost to schools to replace Styrofoam trays. They aim to be a zero-waste office and member and sponsor of the zero waste business council. They audit their outsourced factories under Fair Labor Organization guidelines to ensure fair wages and working conditions for workers. Their packaging is FSC-certified and the bags are printed with soy-based inks.BioBag devote most of their website to the benefits and practicalities of composting. This is useful, but they don’t have a lot to say about themselves as a company. The cardboard packaging doesn’t say anything about being recycled or FSC-certified (or what kind of printing inks they use). I think BioBag deserve a lot of credit for launching a successful line of compostable bags - they created a positive change by making it easier for a lot of people to starting composting their food waste. But right now, based on the information available, it looks like World Centric has gone the extra mile in terms of overall social and environmental impact.

I’ve used Bio Bags for years – 3 gallon bags for my small compost bin as well in the bathroom bin for paper waste. Then I came across the similar World Centric compostable bags and decided to try them out. So here is a comparison of the two.Quality: For me, the World Centric bags are a clear winner. This is based mostly on how well they perform as… well, bags! If they fall apart then I may as well just put my food scraps directly in the bin and skip using bags altogether (Hmmm… perhaps I will!). The World Centric bags hold themselves together pretty well – even in mid-summer with lots of wet food waste. The BioBags will fall apart within a week under the same conditions, accompanied by the smell of rotting food along the way. However, I found out the reason for this: BioBags have a high “Water Vapor Transmission Rate” – in other words moisture leaks out of your bag o’ scraps pretty efficiently. This may explain why the bags don’t perform so well for me: in my Simple Human pedal bin there’s nowhere for this moisture to go other than the lid. If I used a properly ventilated composting bin apparently this would not happen as much. But the World Centric bags don’t have these issues in a pedal bin – as well as not falling apart they also don’t generate as much odor, fungal growth, or dripping moisture as the BioBags.Note that both types bags have a limited shelf life – you should use them within a year (or shorter in humid places) and they should also be stored in a cool dry place.Price: BioBags are the winner if you go by pricing on Amazon. They are about half the price of the World Centric bags. However, in stores I’ve bought World Centric bags for around four bucks for 25 bags (about the same as BioBags).So, as far as gold stars are concerned (quality and price) I think BioBags deserve 4/5 gold stars (I’m being generous, assuming that they hold together better in a compost bin than a peddle bin) and World Centric deserves 5/5 gold stars (if you can get them for around 5 bucks, but even at 8 they may be worth it for some people).Based on social and environmental factors (read on for more details) I think BioBags deserve 4/5 green stars while World Centric deserve 5/5 green stars. I ate Kettle Chips for years, then stopped, and now have gone back to them having found the flavors that work for me. I liked the New York Cheddar but found them a bit sickening after a while… then my interest was sparked again with their Salt and Pepper flavor and now I’ve been working my way through the newer flavors. The Roasted Garlic is my current favorite.It’s a good thing for me to have intensely flavored potato chips (as long as the ingredients are identifiable as “real” food) as I’ll eat fewer of them compared to your more everyday plain potato chips. The only caveat is that if you eat too many Roasted Garlic chips late at night on an empty stomach, you may end up lying awake for hours, being chased around your bedroom by a huge garlic bulb (OK, perhaps I was dreaming). The Red Curry is also well worth trying; the Dill Pickle and Backyard BBQ were interesting at first but not outstanding for me.I’m giving Kettle Foods 5/5 green stars for social and environmental impact. They use 100% green energy (either on-site solar and wind or through credits); convert all of their waste oil to biodiesel; had the first LEED gold certified (i.e. green) manufacturing plant in the U.S.; support various efforts from wetland conservation to hunger relief.The last frontier that Kettle needs to reach is sustainable packaging. I’m tempted to give them only 4/5 green stars because their packaging is non-recyclable and non-compostable. After all, Sun Chips (a subsidiary of PepsiCo, for goodness sake!) introduced a compostable bag back in 2009. The bag turned out to be hilariously loud but they improved the packaging to make it quieter in 2011. Boulder Canyon, who make really tasty chips, introduced a better compostable bag made from wood pulp. Recently, Ocean’s Halo began selling seaweed chips (which are interesting) in nice compostable bags, also made from wood pulp. So why can’t you, Kettle? Hmm? Until you do, I’m tempted to curb my cravings for fried potato by making them at home – slice, par boil for 10 min, pan fry in olive oil for 5 min, season. Hey presto!Until Kettle come up with a compostable bag (please do this soon!) there is another option – you can recycle your chip bags by collecting a bunch and sending them to Terracycle (postage paid by them).

It’s hard to keep up with PACT - they change the styles and materials frequently. Almost every pair of Pact socks that I’ve tried has been slightly different in terms of composition and fabric weight. I’ve been happy with them all and find it useful to have a range of styles (crew, dress, work socks and outdoor socks) for different shoes and temperatures. These crew socks are fairly thin (in a good way - they are well made) and fit snugly on my size 9.5 feet (they may be a little tight on size 10.5 upwards). They are ridiculously cheap now and I suspect will be gone soon.As another reviewer pointed out, these particular socks are only 51% organic cotton (not 75% as advertised) with the remainder being mainly regular cotton and nylon. So, I’m going to still give them 5 gold stars because they are very comfy and look good but perhaps 4/5 green stars because the organic content is not as high as other PACT socks, and not as advertised. More on the green star rating below…I think Pact socks offer many benefits to society and the planet: they are a certified B-Corporation, obtain cotton from farmer-run cooperatives, knit their socks in energy-efficient factories powered by renewable energy, use water-based dyes, and recycle the water used to wash their fabric. They also pay their factory workers a fair wage, and have started getting Fair Trade certification for some items. Their packaging is also sustainable – although Amazon will often ship them in a plastic bag (but you can reuse this).I would say that the only issue from sustainability standpoint is whether you want to buy cotton socks or go with an alternative fiber. If you are going to go with cotton then there’s really a world of difference between organic and conventional, since the non-organic cotton is one of the most pesticide-intensive crops out there (accounting for 25% of the world’s insecticide use, and nasty ones too), with run-off into rivers and water supplies. Whether organically farmed or not, cotton farming is water-intensive and also requires a lot of land. Bamboo and hemp may be good alternatives, depending on the maker.So, overall I’ll give PACT outdoor socks 5 gold stars for quality and 4 “green” stars based on the social-ethical-environmental aspects of producing them. They would deserve 5 green stars if they contained more organic cotton and also if they didn’t ship them from Amazon in plastic bags. I’d also like to see some figures from Pact to support their assurance of good factory conditions. But overall they look like one of the most socially and environmentally responsible textile companies around.

“The serpent, the king, the tiger, the stinging wasp, the small child, the dog owned by other people, and the fool: these seven ought not to be awakened from sleep.” - ChanakyaOh, Celia keeps on keeping on . . . and what she keeps on with is writing funny, insightful, and suspenseful and, yes, totally hot books that cheer me up and engross me. Mostly quick reads, always with an undercurrent of the human condition, Celia is, in a word, AWESOME!So, here is the thing. She has a new series, Tiger Tails, that reaches, and in some ways exceeds, her other super-fun series. Ahhh… better than a cup of cocoa on a cold day. Well, even better when you can read her tales while drinking a cup of cocoa, just sayin’.Now, it’s a tale of a tail – or rather, a bunch of tails. Being literally shoved out of the closet is never pleasant. And for the tigers, well, they never wanted to come out of the “Shifter Closet” at all, no matter what the lions and wolves and bears chose to do. But, things being as they always are, secrets don’t last. And this whopper is going to cause a world of hurt for the tigers. Because, well, grabbing a tiger by the tail has a whole other meaning in Celia’s newest world.This new series by Celia is a blast. So far centering around the “coming-out-of-the-closet” of the tigers in her much-like-ours world, the first story, Fast and the Furriest introduces us to the tiger pride, and its leader, Ares. Poor Ares. Even though the lions and wolves and bears (Oh, My!) are “Out” to the public, the tigers just want to be left alone. And they stay hidden – that is, until they are rudely shoved out of the closet by an article, complete with photos, in a nasty little bit of yellow journalism. An article printed under the byline of the woman Ares thought was his. Oops. Of course, it doesn’t help that the article points out that, if you can pull a tiger’s tail, he (or she) belongs to you forever. Ah, Hell, thou hast no idiocy such as that of a human shifter stalker. “Uh, hey, lady? Really not cool to terrorize the poor pregnant tiger lady up a tree trying to pull her tail. Uh, yeah, I said PREGNANT tiger LADY.” Oy. Needless to say, it was a zoo. And it doesn’t help that DoPE (Department of Paraphysical Entities) is trying to capture high ranking female shifters in order to force them to mate with humans, so that said humans puppet masters can take over the shifter groups and control them (read: Turn them into war machines). Again, Oy.As with all of Celia’s work, there is both a large dose of humor and an even larger dose of pathos to be had in her stories. Humans in this world pretty much suck – not surprising – and there are deeper stories here of the ‘human’ condition. But be prepared to burst out laughing in public as well, if you are brave enough to read on the train ;-)I received Fast and the Furriest from Celia in exchange for a realistic review. I posted this review in a couple of spots, but I apparently pulled a Senior Moment and wandered away while posting, hence a late post to my site and multiple others. Oops! I still Love Ya, Celia!!!

Here is the thing, Celia. You are pretty much the Queen of Awesome-sauceness. So say I, and so say we all! And who couldn’t agree? Everything that flows from your pen (computer? Tablet? Whateves.) is a delicious blend of funny, dramatic, suspenseful, and just darn fun!Take You’re Kitten Me. The newest series by Celia is a blast. So far centering around the “coming-out-of-the-closet” of the tigers in her much-like-ours world, the first story, Fast and the Furriest introduced us to the tiger pride, and its leader, Ares. Poor Ares. Even though the lions and wolves and bears (Oh, My!) are “Out” to the public, the tigers just want to be left alone. And they stay hidden – that is, until they are rudely shoved out of the closet by an article, complete with photos, in a nasty little bit of yellow journalism. An article printed under the byline of the woman Ares thought was his. Oops. Of course, it doesn’t help that the article points out that, if you can pull a tiger’s tail, he (or she) belongs to you forever. Ah, Hell, thou hast no idiocy such as that of a human shifter stalker. “Uh, hey, lady? Really not cool to terrorize the poor pregnant tiger lady up a tree trying to pull her tail. Uh, yeah, I said "Pregnant tiger LADY.” Oy. Needless to say, it was a zoo. And it doesn’t help that DoPE (Department of Paraphysical Entities) is trying to capture high ranking female shifters in order to force them to mate with humans, so that said humans puppet masters can take over the shifter groups and control them (read: Turn them into war machines). Again, Oy.In this second book, the women are still under attack, and the stakes continue to get higher. A few women have been taken or attacked and had their tails pulled – Ares sister among them. And the daughter of the national wolf alpha, Veronica, “Ronnie” to her friends, has been attacked twice. Desperate to protect her, her father sends her back to the tigers, where her best friend and Ares mate, Zoe, lives. Only, they aren’t on the ground for ten minutes before Ronnie is attacked by humans – twice. Though she has a knife at her throat, the human press don’t catch that part, only the part where Ares’ Second, Branden, and two of his security team kill two of the attackers and critically injure one. Don’t mess with an Alpha Second when his ‘gonna be mate, no matter if she is a wolf or not’ has a knife at her throat. Ah, well. So much for the whole “We really are just harmless little kitty cats” motif.And of course, DoPE (perfect acronym, BTW) jumps on the opportunity to lock up Branden, his security team – and Ronnie as well. And you can just bet what will happen to poor Ronnie if a certain manipulative General gets his hands on her. Daughter of the National Wolf Alpha, chosen of the National Tiger Second? Score for General Disgusting Monster, all the way around. Hum… you know, as usual, the humans come off as the true monsters. Well, yeah, I can see it. If shifters showed up amongst us tomorrow, you can pretty much call it from the UF books – some salivate to get themselves a piece of ‘critter ass’ while others variously hate, intend to kill, and intend to force them into military service – or onto autopsy tables – in the name of ‘National Security’. Sigh. Hey, as if the guy next door who mowed your yard for you when you were sick and his wife who brought you chicken soup are suddenly monsters just because you suddenly found out that they like to run on four legs when the urge strikes. Ugh. Humans. The gift that keeps on needing a good gene pool cleaning . . .So, again, Celia is Awesomesauce to the Max! And you really should rush right to your reading device, or local book store, and grab up everything she has written. But starting with the Tiger Tails series is a great start if you haven’t done so already. Enjoy! I absolutely did.I sometimes get books from Celia in exchange for realistic reviews, but in this case, I just bought it. Couldn’t help myself – So excited to get the next in the series!

Not a book - this is a serial, drug out to be three partials, when severe editing could have made it a half-way decent book.. However, the editing was missing, the story line plastic and the characters bland. I couldn't care about any of them.

ZERO STARS. NOT RECOMMENDED!Horrible. DNF.I expected a book about a strong, confident female fire investigator. Instead? I got a diatribe about how if you aren't "god fearing" you aren't worth dirt. Smarmy, acrimonious, sanctimonious - you get the picture. I never can fathom the mindset of the rabidly religious. Supposedly, Jesus said something to the effect of being kind, considerate, understanding, and to love your neighbor. This book falls on the side of "If you don't fall in lockstep like Hitler's little soldier, you aren't as good as me and better fall in line and understand that everything is 'gods will', no matter what atrocities happen to and around you (and believe me, if this 'god's will has caused a tenth of the things I have seen in my life, that is one vicious bastard - just sayin') - and if you don't, you aren't worth love, compassion, consideration, kindness or understanding."Observe.The police chief is supposedly 'taken' with her, but since she isn't fall-on-her-knees and 'thank the lord' every time something horrible happens (for example, the fire that killed her parents - which she accidentally started at 7 years old being a prime example) she isn't good enough for his holier-than-thou self. Believe me, he doesn't deserve a strong, capable, intelligent woman (one he looks down on not only because she doesn't buy into the religious fervor, but because she isn't "ladylike" and works on car engines instead of doing needlepoint. ) And she buys into it - because she is working under a car and has oil on her face, she is humiliated (?!?!) when he shows up unexpectedly and sees her being a real, live person instead of a plastic Barbie doll. Gag.And: He was "appalled"(!) that she ". . . doesn't have a 'personal relationship' with 'him.' Oh, and I really loved the ". . . he knew right away she was a McGregor, or according to her wedding ring, used to be." (So, because she got married she belongs to her husband now, and can't lay claim to her original family? What, her DNA changed or something?)But the best zinger?
