I don't know if I just haven't been using it long enough for the problems complained of to appear or if the manufacturing tolerances have been improved. I would think the latter is possible because it fits well, the same as the OEM filter.  So after three weeks I have no complaints.

Three stars for a toy that a four year old would enjoy (packaging says four and up), five stars for a nicely made fun sort of collectible that would appeal to both older kids who love dinos and adults who also love dinos.  I've had this sitting on my desk since it arrived and everyone who comes by wants to hear the stomping sound and see the chomping action. We are talking adult professionals here.  It's electronic and battery powered-- the batteries were already installed when I opened the package-- NOT frustration free packaging may I add,  but it doesn't move by itself, have a remote or respond to voice commands like the last dinosaur toy I received.  Essentially you get a nice loud noise and some limited motion of the jaws when the tail is pressed down and the head comes up. It's enough to entertain me.It's made of both hard plastic and soft plastic.  The tail and neck are covered with soft plastic.  The legs are arms are articulated-- the arms at the shoulder but not the elbow and are independently posable.  The legs look like they have three points of articulation at ankle, knee and hip, but they do not move freely and independently.  The movement is associated with the sound.  The speaker, BTW, is in the stomach and the batteries need a screw driver to change. The toy is well balanced so when you do pose the T Rex either in the older upright position or the more recent head down, tail up position it holds its pose very well.

Important to appreciate what this shower head replacement is and what it isn't.  It's metal and plastic. The back is chrome colored plastic but the part that screws into the shower neck is metal. The white part is rubberized (or some other process of treating plastic that makes it softer.  The jets are in the chrome colored strip across the middle.  The white part contains the 118  apertures that provide the rainfall effect.  The switch that changes the function is in the center of the shower head so not really suitable for small children unless you are there to change the function.  Also you really need to make sure that your current shower arm would allow the proper placement.  The shower head needs specific placement.for maximum advantage and minimum overspray.

Quite a hit with a five year old boy.  I think that it is at best a child/adult activity that provides an opportunity to see how much life there is even just in the back yard as well as to teach empathy as we catch/observe/release. This is much better than the glass jar with holes punched in the lid that I had as a kid to keep tadpoles or fireflies in (depending on the time of year).  Not a substitute for a terrarium or an aquarium, but a good place to keep bugs, small reptiles or amphibians, and fish for short term observation.  The light is a nice touch. This is what requires the batteries.I don't have a bug vacuum to use with it, but that's something that would make a nice addition in the future provided his interest (and his parents' tolerance for small critters) keeps up.

One dog loves it, one dog would rather eat catfood-- I don't let her eat catfood by the way, I just got a bag of cat food at the the same time as this and she actually tore open the bag of catfood while turning her nose up at this particular dog food as she has ever since.  Now to the dog who loves it. He is totally delighted with it.  I usually let him self feed because he doesn't over eat, but I've had to ration him.  I have also noticed that his stool is well formed and solid since he has started this food.  Forgive me if I gross anyone out, but changing from one food to another is sometimes a time for tummy upset with dogs.Now, here's for the part that may just be coincidental.  My setter tends to have seasonal allergies, and I was just complaining that he was chewing on his back again and it was probably time for steroids again.  However, when he started on this dog food he stopped chewing on himself within a few days.  Is it the lack of grain?  Don't know.  When this bag is gone I'm going to do an experiment where I put him back on his regular kibble and see if he starts chewing again.  If he does then I'm sending for another bag.

Revised - although it works on lots of other devices, it does not work with the Samsung Galaxy S5.Original review:I installed this on the load side of a Leviton surge protector receptacle. It is large - so you will need a deeper gang-box. Also, it cannot be "back-wired". Its been working fine to charge several devices. And I do like that it shuts off when there is nothing plugged into it.Be aware that the 5 Amps refers to the total charging capacity for this receptacle - and not each port.

I bought two of these receptacles to use outdoors. They are larger than the Leviton Smartlock Pro Slim GFCI receptacles that I've used indoors. However, unlike the Leviton slim GFCI receptacles, these can be "back-wired" with 12 gauge wire - so they fit comfortably even in a single-gang box. Both line and load sides can be "back-wired".Both receptacles tested fine with a GFCI tester. An amber light is displayed when the GFCI trips. And as expected, the GFCI trips even when tested from a downstream load-side receptacle.They're marked on the front as WR (for weather resistant) and TR (for tamper resistant) as required by code (NEC 406.8). And the current price (<$15) is very good.

I purchased it because I was installing GFCI receptacles at the start of the two circuits in my kitchen, and wanted to be sure that a ground fault on load side receptacles would trip the GFCIs.  The tester worked perfectly for that purpose.I also tested the other GFCI receptacles in our home. Unexpectedly, I found that a GFCI receptacle in one bathroom was NOT working - although it was wired correctly (i.e. grounded), and the test/reset buttons on the GFCI itself worked as anticipated. However, the GFCI wouldn't trip when tested, indicating it was faulty. This happens to be a receptacle that my wife frequently plugs her hairdryer into, and I would have never known it was faulty without this tester. I shudder to think what could have happened had the hairdryer malfunctioned, especially in the context of a wet/humid environment and a non-functioning GFCI.

Our dryer duct vent runs from about 30 feet (including two 90 degree bends). It used to take our electric dryer about 100-120 minutes to dry a full load, while a half-load took around 1 hour. I just installed this dryer booster last night and tested it this morning. With the dryer heat set on medium, it took 20-25 minutes to dry a half-load. That's a terrific decrease in energy consumption that will pay for the booster within 2 years. With the added bonus of saving time.It was fairly simple to install. I chose to use DryerFlex semi-rigid transition duct, and run the dryer exhaust through a secondary lint trap (Fantech). It also seemed a good opportunity to use stainless steel duct clamps.For this installation, I needed longer rigid tubing (~6 feet) for the pressure switch. This tubing has to have a 1/4 inch outer diameter. 1/4-inch OD polyethylene ice maker tubing, available from Lowes/HomeDepot/Amazon is cheap (<$3 for 25 feet), and works great.One last suggestion. I calibrated the pressure switch while running the dryer on the "Fluff/Air" cycle. This morning, the Dryer Booster cut in and out when I had an actual load in the dryer, and I had to re-calibrate it. It might save you time to do the initial calibration with a load in the dryer.

Our water heater(s) are in the attic - two stories above the bathrooms. Because heat rises due to convection, hot water in the pipes gets cold very rapidly, and we end up running a large volume of "cold" water from the hot water faucet, before it turns progressively hot. The Watts recirculating pump certainly solves that problem. Tepid water flows out of the hot water faucets within 10-15 seconds, and it gets warm/hot rapidly after that.I need to run the pump for the hours we're at home during the week, and all day weekends. The mechanical timer on the unit doesn't permit flexible scheduling such as this. For this reason, I have rated it four stars and not five. A second issue with a mechanical timer is that any power outage renders it unsynchronized vis-a-vis the actual time. Both these problems are especially tiresome to deal with if the water heater(s) are in a location that cannot be accessed very easily (ours are in the attic).My solution to this was to purchase an Intermatic DT620 "heavy-duty" indoor digital timer and plug the Watts recirculating pumps into it. It has two timed receptacles, a 15 amp capacity, and up to 4 on/off settings can be set per day. It's also possible to have different settings for weekdays and weekends. The Watts recirculating pumps appear to draw 0.2 - 0.3 amps individually - so the timer can accommodate their electrical requirements easily.One other suggestion - it is a good idea plug the pumps into a GFCI electrical socket, or at least ensure there is a GFCI socket on that circuit.

Whether you wish to reduce water use in your home for economic or environmental concerns (or both), there are a number of retrofit kits on the market to convert a single-flush toilet into a dual-flush toilet that permits either a "half" flush or a "full" flush. Some of these products do not require replacing fill valve or the flapper valve body. Installing them is considerably less work and may be better suited for your needs.I chose to replace the entire mechanism inside the tank because the fill valves were 20+ years old, the flapper valve body and rubber seal were also original as were the bolts that attached the tank to the toilet bowl. I chose the FlushSaver dual-handle retrofit kit because FlushSaver products received relatively good reviews on Amazon (albeit very few reviews) in contrast to lower overall ratings for competing products. I also liked the fact that the kit came with stainless steel bolts to attach the tank to the bowl.The product seems relatively well made; as pointed out in other reviews, it would be nicer if the handles were metal and not plastic. The rubber seal on the valve body felt to be of quality, although I don't think it is silicone rubber (perhaps Water Saver Products can clarify this). The seal for the filler valve is silicone rubber. The retrofit install is a DIY project, but you should keep several things handy in addition to standard tools:1) Lots of towels - you will spill water.2) A WetVac or siphon to remove any water remaining in the tank prior to detaching it from the bowl.3) Some steel wool (if you decide to clean the inside of the tank before putting it all together again).4) A metal saw, should you have to cut through the bolts that attach the tank to the toilet bowl.I installed this kit in three toilets. Two of them took me about 45 minutes each, including 15 minutes spent scrubbing the inside of the tank. The third tank took me >2 hours and some back-breaking labor because I had to saw through the bolts. Whoever installed this tank had used aluminium nuts with brass bolts; by corrosion over 20 years, the nuts had frozen in place and wouldn't budge. Fortunately, brass is a "soft" metal and can be cut through relatively easily. In this regard, the new stainless steel bolts and wing-nuts are great - should be very easy to remove the tank in the future (hopefully never!).Once installed, everything worked as claimed. I estimated the volume of water used for a full and half flushes (W*L*H); full flushes take about two gallons of water and half-flushes about 30% less than that. It is simple to adjust the height of fill valve and the valve body stem. It is also very easy to adjust the amount of water dispensed for full/half flushes. One thing to keep in mind is that when filled with water the tank will sink a little on the seals, so I tightened the bolts again after filling the tank with water.A word about after-sales service from Water Saver Products. The flush mechanism on one of the three units I purchased didn't work as well as the other two. They shipped me a replacement within a day of my contacting them.I cannot comment on durability because it has only been a month after installing them. Two changes would make this product "perfect" - a) If the plastic handles were made of metal; and b) If it were sold through Amazon Prime.

I've used this product for a year to amplify signals received by a Mohu Leaf antenna. It has worked extraordinarily well. Signals from four channels that weren't seen by my HDTV are now received, and display clearly with no flickering/stuttering etc. The crappy reception on these channels returns as soon as I unplug the BDA-S1.I have it mounted in my attic; it has made it through 1.5 Louisiana hot & humid summers without failing ..... so I'm happy with its performance and the build quality.

I just replaced the internal 512 GB hard-drive in my late-2012 Mac Mini with a 256 GB Vertex OCZ 4 SSD. So far, everything works really well. The replacement was relatively simple. One minor point of dissatisfaction - the screw-holes on the top of the drive are slightly off relative to the original HDD (hence the 4 stars).Also, for anyone else doing this - consider using SuperDuper! to copy the original drive to the new drive while connecting the latter to your Mac using a SATA to USB connector. You can also boot from the new drive to make sure everything works as anticipated before replacing the HDD.One other thing - shop around for the best price. When I bought the drive (first week of 02/2013), Amazon had it listed at $219. Today (second week of 02/2013), Amazon has it listed at $244. That's a big hike ....I'll post an update on reliability after 6 months (sooner if the SSD fails!).August 2013: Everything is still good.

I purchased two sets of these batteries two months ago (Dec. 2012) after confirming with Hyperion that their batteries for the GSM Galaxy Nexus (GT-i9250/Maguro) support NFC. The batteries arrived promptly and I verified using Android Beam that they supported NFC. Therefore, the batteries being shipped for at least the last month support NFC (as claimed), although clearly older versions did not.As recommended by Hyperion, I've taken all four batteries through multiple full charge/discharge cycles (discharge to the point the phone shuts itself off with less than 1% remaining battery life). So far, because the batteries are being rotated, I've charged the batteries only using the provided charger.Battery life has been comparable to that observed with the original Samsung battery, as measured using the following two parameters: 1) Both the Samsung and Hyperion batteries support about 2-2.5 hours of screen time; and 2) Under these conditions, a fully-charged battery discharges to the point of the phone shutting off in 18-20 hours. Both WiFi and cellular radios are powered the whole time, with the cell radio being used about 30% of the time. The cell radio is set to use 3G/4G when connected to the data network. I use the default display settings (automatic brightness, etc.). I have attached screenshots indicating typical battery use & discharge to this review.The charger seems to be relatively well-built; after daily use for two months the spring-loaded pins function haven't developed any problems.In summary, I am completely satisfied with the Hyperion batteries for the GT-i9250. They support NFC and last an entire day with 2-2.5 hours of screen use.

Our media cabinet is small, but jammed with equipment (TiVo, BluRay player, UPS, two iOmega ix2-200 NAS, and a gigabit switch) that generate a lot of heat. The temperature within ranged from 100-120oF (yes, that hot!). The ix2-200 internal fans, which kick in at temperatures over 59oC, were constantly running at 1000-1500 rpm, and they reported an internal temperature of 60-65oC. The only ventilation in the cabinet was two 3-inch cutouts for cables near the bottom of the back panel - not very good to remove hot air passively.It may be coincidental, but about a month ago, our year-old TiVo had a drive failure. After replacing the TiVo drive, I decided to actively cool the cabinet with dual intake fans (near the bottom of the back panel) and one exhaust fan (top of the back panel).The reviews for the AC Infinity fans were excellent, so I purchased a dual AC Infinity 120 mm quiet fans for the intake (this product), and a single AC Infinity 120 mm quiet fan for the exhaust. The fans were very simple to install (and look good after installation). The cutout mask provided made it easy to mark the back panel and a I used a dremel to make the cuts. Because our media cabinet is up against a well, I need to remove the fans from the inside to clean the filters. Therefore, rather than use the provided nuts and bolts to mount the fan, I used industrial strength velcro. I tried using nylon push rivets, but couldn't find ones in the right size that popped out relatively easily.The fans are very quiet. There is no speed control on them, but the specifications state they run at 1200 rpm. As provided by AC Infinity, the fans are configured to serve as intakes, but it is easy to reverse the direction of airflow - need to remove 8 nut/bolts. Note that cable length will make it difficult to configure one fan as intake and one fan as exhaust for the dual 120 mm cabinet fan.After one day, the fans seem to be working - the temperature in the cabinet is around 80oF. Hopefully, they will last .....

I just received "new" version of this case. It fits the nexus 7 really well; the little magnetic clasp that turns the tablet on/off is a good feature. If I could change one thing, it would be to make the case thinner.

We had two kinds of flakes in the water from our fridge: 1) Translucent flakes that floated; and 2) White flakes that sank. Thawed ice-cubes from the ice-maker had both kinds of flakes, and like the water it smelled terrible and was undrinkable.Thinking the translucent flakes may have resulted from bacterial/algal biofilms in the lines and the white flakes were mineral deposits, we changed the filter within the fridge, and ran gallons of water through the new filter. This didn't help - the translucent flakes never disappeared and the white flakes came back 2-3 days. Ice-cubes remained as bad as they were before (here too, I dumped at least 10-15 loads of ice made over 2 weeks).Finally, as a last resort before getting a new fridge, I did the following after unhooking the fridge from the main water line:a) Pump two liters of bleach through the fridge water lines (letting the bleach sit in the line for 20-30 minutes).b) Pump several liters of clean water to flush the bleach.c) Pump two liters of hydrogen peroxide through the fridge water line, letting it sit for 30 minutes.d) Pump 10-20 liters of clean water to flush the peroxide.e) Replaced the filter within the fridge.After reconnecting the main supply line, the water was clean for exactly two days before we started seeing very small white mineral flakes again. After reading the reviews here, I decided to install the Watts filter as a pre-filter.I mounted the filter behind the refrigerator; two problems encountered by other reviewers are that an additional supply-line (connecting hose) or a mounting bracket are not provided with the filter. Supply-lines are readily available - Watts' makes these lines that are available from Amazon. The bracket is more troublesome. I was going to fashion something crude using zip-ties when I found that 2.5 inch conduit hangers were the right diameter to hold the filter. I replaced the bolts/nuts on the conduit hanger with longer bolts/wingnuts to make loosening/tightening easier. All put together (supply line + conduit hangers), it cost about $12 to mount the filter. I've attached photographs to make my descriptions clearer.It has now been a month since the filter has been installed and the neither the water nor the ice from the fridge have flakes of either kind. The water tastes great and is odor-free.Its only been a month, so I cannot comment on the filters longevity, but so far its been great.Update - June 17, 2013It has been just over a year. Filter is still working very well.

Edited Review - October 30, 2012:The switch worked well for ~7 months. Toward the end of September (i.e the 7th month after purchase), a NAS (or a TiVo) connected to one of the ports would disappear off the network, even though the light indicating connectivity was lit. Connectivity was restored by plugging the ethernet cable into another port, or powering down/up the switch. So I stopped using that port. As of yesterday, the same symptoms have appeared for another port. Therefore, I am replacing this switch with another brand. I no longer recommend its purchase.Original Review:This switch works very well, and is a real deal for the price. I purchased it as an open box item from Amazon for about $14 + shipping. In my setup, the switch is connected to a wireless router (Netgear WNDR3300 running dd-wrt) via a 100 mbps connection. File transfer rates between "gigabit" peripherals connected to the switch are excellent - ranging from for 60-90 megabytes per second (i.e. ~450-750 mbits/sec). Those rates are particularly amazing as they do not take TCP/IP header overhead into consideration. The switch supports jumbo ethernet frames up to 15kb in size, and our peripherals use jumbo frames up to 9 kb in size.Connecting all the peripherals to a dedicated switch rather than the router has yielded a benefit I didn't anticipate; it has improved router performance, probably because the Netgear WNDR3300 is memory and processor speed limited (16 megabytes, BCM4704 CPU @ 264 MHz).Speedtest results used to indicate download rates of ~15-18 Mbps, and upload rate of ~3 Mbps. After connecting everything to the switch, and with a 100 Mbps connection between the router and switch, I reproducibly observed 24-28 Mbps down and ~3 Mbps up (10 trials over 2 days). This increase can be attributed solely to the switch because connecting everything back to the router returned download/upload rates to those observed previously (three trials over 20 minutes).Apparently, off-loading the processing power and memory necessary for switching to a dedicated switch "frees up" the router. I'm not implying that the switch has magically increased the bandwidth provided by my ISP; it most certainly hasn't. I think that "off-loading" bandwidth "distribution" to a dedicated switch lets the WNDR3300 function better vis-a-vis processing packets to/from the cable modem it is connected to.If this observation can be generalized, its quite spiffy considering it has cost <$20 in total.

This enclosure does what it is supposed to. I tested RAID0 and RAID1 modes with two Seagate Barracuda Green ST2000DL003 2TB drives. The drives SATA interface supports a transfer rate of 6 GB/s, but the enclosure's controller supports maximum transfer rate of 3 GB/s. Everything works (including rebuilding a RAID1 array). I've only had the enclosure for a few days, but there are a couple issues that one should be aware of:A) For whatever reason, RAID1 read/write times are better when the drives are formatted as FAT32, rather than Linux ext2 or Mac HFS.B) Processor power in the RAID1 is limiting; practically speaking, read/write times with journaling file-system like Linux ext3 is _significantly_ slower than Linux ext2, which is not journaling. For example, copying 1.5 TB of small/large files (mp3 and movies) took about 4 hours when the drive was formatted as ext2, and about 5 hours when it was ext3 formatted.I had expected "B". In the late '90s, when desktop CPUs were slower, ext3 was often slower than ext2. "A" really surprised me; I need to repeat it to confirm the observation.The cooling fan isn't as loud as I expected it would be. I have the enclosure contained within an entertainment center and the noise isn't particularly noticeable.Overall - at a price point of $50-60, the enclosure meets my expectations.

There are very few options currently available to record over-the-air (OTA) TV in HD, namely the brite-View BV-980H Digital Antenna HD DVR and the Channel Master CM7400 1080p Internet Compatible HDTV DVR. The brite-View gets horrible reviews - for example the enhanced programming guide (EPG) is very slow to load, the interface is difficult to navigate, and scheduled recordings often don't record. The initial reviews (as of January 10, 2012) of the CM7400 aren't very promising either.So, that leaves a single choice - the TiVo Premiere series of HD DVRs, which provide 7 days of EPG to schedule recordings - using the name of the show. The TiVo works well for this purpose, and the interface is intuitive.  To use the TiVo you have to purchase service; we found it convenient to get the product lifetime service ($499), along with a 3-year warranty. All put together, this cost $617, which works out to ~$17 per month (over 36 months). Presumably the warranty will let us get more than 36 months of service, and there are plenty of 3rd party options to fix a broken TiVo, install a larger HD etc.Monthly service is currently $20, although occasionally TiVo offers a $10 special for exclusive OTA recording. At $20/month, three years of service would be $720 + the initial cost of the TiVo Premiere. Therefore, if it is possible, lifetime service is a good service option to consider.The TiVo Premiere downloads the EPG using an ethernet connection, or a WiFi adapter (sold separately) - the TiVo AN0100 Wireless N Network Adapter. The video outputs include HDMI, component and composite video - but there is no S-video output. Audio outputs include HDMI, digital audio (optical), and regular stereo. E-SATA and two USB ports are also available - for expansion, adding a WiFi adapter or a phone adapter (also sold separately). You can record encrypted cable if you have a Cablecard from your cable provider, as there is a cablecard slot.The TiVo remote is well put together, but it was more convenient to use a Logitech Harmony Universal Remote because it controls multiple devices at the same time - setting the proper inputs on each etc.Be aware that the TiVo stays on all the time, and I haven't yet measured the current draw.The Premiere picks up the same list of channels as the TV did when connected directly to a Mohu Indoor HDTV Antenna. It has two tuners - making it possible to record one show while watching another. Our primary uses for the TiVo are to watch PBS documentaries/shows and college/NFL football - they tend not to be at the same time. However, dual tuners can be very useful to others.No complaints at all. It would be nice there were additional OTA HD-DVR options available as "competition" against the TiVo. The anticipated price for the CM7400 is $399, and $50 (or $100 - depending on where you look in the ChannelMaster website) for annual EPG service.If you want to transfer TiVo recordings to a DLNA server, mobile device, or tablet, google "kmttg". It's free, and does a great job.

The many positive reviews here persuaded me to purchase the Mohu Leaf Antenna for over-the-air digital reception. While I don't have another product to compare it against, I'm very satisfied with the Mohu. It arrived within a few days of the order; I initially positioned it on the wall behind the TV and received about 15 digital channels and one analog channel. We didn't feel that it was aesthetically pleasing in that location; because there is a run of coaxial cable from the wall behind the TV to the attic, I positioned the Mohu in the attic. After fiddling with the positioning for 5-10 minutes, the Mohu permits us to receive 28 channels, of which 26 are digital. The number of digital channels exceeds what is predicted by antennaweb.org for an indoor antenna. Most of the broadcast towers are south-east of our home, and the best position seems to be when the flat surface of the Mohu faces that direction.I thought it would be useful to others in general vicinity of New Orleans/Metaire/Kenner to list the channels received using the Mohu antenna:4.1 WWL-HD (CBS)4.2 LIVEWEL6.1 WDSU-DT (NBC)6.2 ExactWX8.1 FOX8 HD (FOX)8.2 FOX8 SD12.1 WYES-HD (PBS)12.2 WYESSD112.3 WYESSD318 - Analog Channel (weak reception)20.1 WHNO-Digital20.2 WHNO-D2 Digital22 - Analog26.1 WGNO-DT (ABC)26.2 AntTV28.1 KNLD-LD32.1 WLAE-1 (PBS)32.2 WLAE-232.3 WLAE-338.1 WNOL-New Orleans CW38.2 THISTV41.1 KNOV-DT42.1 KGLA-DT47.1 HSN49.1 WPXL Digital Television49.2 WPXL qubo49.3 WPXL ION Life54.1 WUPLThe broadcasting towers for these stations are between 4.7 and 25 miles away from our home (most are 11-12 miles away), and the area is pretty flat. There are a couple taller structures within 1000 feet of our location. Because it is positioned in the attic, the antenna is approximately 25 feet above ground level.There is one "negative" I want to point out - the photo of the antenna makes it appear that the the surface is a flat/matte/satin black. It isn't - the laminate on both sides renders the black and white sides glossy.Edited 12/4/2011: I added a TiVo as an OTA HD DVR between the antenna and the TV, and found that reception turned sour for ~5 channels, even though the position of the antenna wasn't altered, and length of cable between the antenna and TiVo was exactly the same as was between the antenna and TV (in fact it is the same run of cable). Upon re-positioning the Mohu to be closer to one of the outside walls in the attic reception through the TiVo returned to that seen previously. The TiVo Premiere lets you measure the signal strength per channel, and they are all between 50 - 98 now (scale 0-100). Anything above 50 is green. Most channels are between 70-85.Its no surprise that antenna position alters reception, but I was surprised that the quality of tuner varied so much between the TiVo and the Philips TV previously connected directly to the Mohu. So it is likely that your experience with the Mohu will be dependent on the OTA tuner in the device it is connected to.

Add us to the list of cat owners who rave about this litter-box. It really works well (even in a small space). We use litter that clumps well, so maybe that's why it has worked so well. As noted by a few others, the clips that hold the two halves together aren't well designed (or well made). But, there's plenty of inexpensive fasteners that most hardware stores have to use as replacements.Bottom line - it works as advertised. And I like it more than the ScoopFree ....

I use this charger with a replacement PowerGen Battery for my Nexus One, as well as the OEM HTC battery.  The charger automatically detects polarity, and its movable charging pins makes it easy to charge a variety of battery formats, as long as the contacts are on an edge. The LED color changes from red to blue when the battery is fully charged.I have no complaints at all.  However, before purchasing it, you need to be sure of two things:a) That the charging contacts for your battery are on the size (i.e. one of the edges), and not on the flat surface.b) That charging at 600 mA is sufficiently quick for your needs.  At this output it can take 8 hours or longer to charge a 1400 mAh battery.  For example, the output of the OEM charger for the Nexus One is 1 amp (i.e. 1000 mA), so it charges the battery a lot faster.The slower charging rate doesn't matter to me; my needs are to charge the battery to full capacity overnight.  Before using it the first time, I did confirm the voltage output was a steady 4.2 volts, and current output was 600 milliamps.  The USB output is supposed to the 5 volts, but I didn't measure this.I am a little concerned that the charging pins look a little fragile, but in 2.5 months of daily use, they have held up.

The HTC battery in my Nexus One lasts about 8-9 hours with heavy use, so I bought this Powergen battery as a backup battery.  After an initial extended charge and full discharge cycle as recommended by Powergen, I find that it lasts at least as long as the OEM battery (maybe marginally longer).I have no complaints and recommend it.A couple suggestions:1) Root your phone and use SetCPU - it can dramatically extend battery life, especially under heavy use.  With light use (email, browsing for 1-2 hours, 4-5 phone calls for < 10 minutes each), the battery charge decreases from 100% to ~50% in 24 hours.  It takes a day or two to figure out a SetCPU configuration that works for you.  With really heavy use (described below), the battery charge decreased from 100% to ~20% in ~9 hours, at which point I'd switch batteries.2) Get a PowerGen Rapid Battery Charger. Works great.  I was out of town for about a month, and relied exclusively on my phone for email, browsing, editing small documents, and off course phone calls.  One battery would run from about 7:00 AM - 4:00 PM, and the second battery would go to about 40% by time I went to bed (~10:00 PM).  I'd charge one battery overnight in the phone, and the other in the Powergen charger.  Worked great!Overall, this has worked as well as could be expected.The battery and charger run about $14 each.  Not bad at all, considering that an HTC-branded battery alone is much more than that.
Didn't work. The control had power with batteries, but the cord was obviously junk because it didn't vibrate. Also, it is a really mushy, gummy material that is not optimal for this kind of toy.

I was a little worried the silk would have more of a sueded hand, but one side is very "silky" (a.k.a. satiny)- good for your skin and your hair. The other side of the case is woven cotton (like a sheet), breathable and keeps the pillow from sliding all over your bed.SILK vs. the usual satin: Silk is a natural fiber, as opposed to polyester that most satin/"silky" pillow cases are made form. Poly satin make you hot and sweaty. These silk pillowcases breathe so it helps you stay comfortable at night. Plus there's a zipper so your pillow doesn't pop out (a common satin pillow case issue). As for looks, poly silk is shiny and cheap looking, this pillow case is lovely. And if it's a color issue, white silk can be easily dyed to match your bedding.

My friend had a very hard time finding a wrapper that didn't strangle & kill sensation. Average length, but more width than other brands could fit comfortably. While the base is still a bit snug, it fits and feels way better than other brands.Most condoms made for sensitivity are made of a less stretchy material.  These stretch (less breakage) and are very thin, reportedly having maximized sensation. To everyone's satisfaction.Works well for oral too, only lightly lubed and don't really smell.

This is not a giant condom, but I've learned 10 sizes do not fit all.My friend had a very hard time finding a wrapper that didn't strangle & kill sensation. Average length, but more width than other brands could fit comfortably. While the base is still a bit snug, it fits, feels and works way better than other brands he tried.Most condoms made for sensitivity are made of a less stretchy material.  These stretch (less breakage) and are very thin, reportedly having maximized sensation.These are only lightly lubed and don't really smell, so they work well for oral too.

I bought this to wear under too revealing spaghetti strap summer dresses and low v-necks. When I tried it on, it's comfortable fabric/lace and fit true to size, but it covered more than pictured and ended up just looking weird under tanks.

IT WORKS. I had no idea a primer could grab so much powder! I got it for eyeliner pencil that kept disappearing, and it helps everything stay put. It doesn't have a lot of drag when going on. Since it starts creamy I've had to set it with powder to avoid creasing, but be careful! You only need the smallest amount and it will take layers of powder, be careful not to put too much eye shadow on because this will grab it. This is good if you want to cover up the light tint completely with a color. I'd suggest carefully applying it just exactly where you apply your eye shadow.I also tried it under my eyes and in the inner corners to enhance concealer. It certainly works and my dark circles were covered all day. But the primer, concealer and powder combo brought out little eye wrinkles (I used it with Lancome concealer and Tarte Smooth Operator face powder).Color: Despite the photo looking flesh toned, this does look almost white going on. I have very fair skin and wear physical sunscreens that leave me even whiter, but it was still too light. That said, you don't need much. A tiny bit applied smoothly is not very visible. I do apply it before anything else to blend or cover with sunscreen or foundation.The reason for this is partly because it has mineral sunscreen as an ingredient (titanium dioxide). Which is a bonus if you don't want eye wrinkles long term.Compared: I also bought the elf eye primer at the same time and this is superior. Gabriel primer takes less and has an even, smooth consistency. Again, it holds a lot of powder too.Sensitivity: I have very sensitive eyes, they are often itchy and irritated even if I haven't worn makeup for weeks. So all eye makeup is a bit irritating, but this primer doesn't cause itching or burning or swelling- nothing that I don't experience with all other makeup. My eye makeup stays on better, but it does require a make-up remover with this primer.Gabriel line: New favorite! It's natural, non-toxic, non-irritating. The Gabriel liquid foundation has really impressed me too. It feels good on my face, almost like there's nothing there, not dry or stinging or greasy. Aside from my rose cream there is no other product doesn't irritate my some level. Gabriel foundation is moisturizing, it has some sun protection, and the color is really amazing; warm and pigmented, but not yellow like so many other natural foundations.

Based on the reviews from Americans and my measurements plus the size chart, I ordered up. It's huge. Even the collar and embroidery seem exaggerated in size. I wear a L/XL, US 14, am 5' 4" and 36DD. I got a 3X. I will order an XL next time. Nice crisp, lightweight fabric for summer, but the collar sort of kills that bonus.

I got the red plaid dress. I ordered up a size and it fits my waist, but is at least 6" to small around the bust. I got an XL, I'm 36DD. Other than that, it's a summer dress made out of non-stretching flannel with a high neckline, not ideal. Also, the side zipper doesn't stop a few inches below the arm as most dresses do, but instead opens into the arm hole.

The color (teal) is very nice. The fabric is stretchy, substantial and not clingy. The cut is flattering. Sizing is forgiving because it has a lot of stretch, and it retains it's shape very well. I wear a US14, and am 5' 4", 36DD. XL fit nicely.My only problem is that it's pretty low cut and short for modest me. If I pull it down, I can see the top of my bra and it is still 6 inches above my knees. I was hoping for a little more coverage without a crinoline or something. I'll probably add a ruffle on the bottom.Update: The boyfriend loves it, including the length.

What I received is a cheaper looking version of the tool pictured. It is silver, not brass colored. It also has no logo and no visible joints.It is too large for packing Pax, which is what I bought it for. The tamper end looks like it will fall off soon, it's on crooked. The joint end has a gap in it so that won't work to tamper either. I know it's not terribly expensive, and it's nicer looking than the really cheap tools, but it doesn't work for me.

I live on a septic system and 1-ply toilet paper is a must. Every other brand, including the regular Scott, are pretty impossible to use: they fall apart, etc. The Scott Extra Soft has been a life saver in my household.

This is a very thick hat, very warm. The look is kind of Medieval Russian Ghengis Khan or something. It's kind of neat. but...The first hat I received had what looked like white dog hair and lint all over the inside, some on the outside, like it had been sitting on someone's floor for a month. I contacted them, and after sending the hat back for an exchange I got my "new" hat weeks later. It looked like the same hat slightly less dirty.I have ordered Luxury Divas hats before and been very happy with products and service.

I needed this item. But it is NOT well made, NOT sturdy. While the concept is a good one (it's nice looking and functional?) it is deceiving. I didn't watch the first reviewers video- so it's smaller than expected. 4 inches tall, and longer WITHOUT the usable space to match. It's a little over 4" wise, there is less than 3" of usable space. I can fit one, maybe 2 TV controllers in a spot, then they fall over because it is too short. Good for storing styluses, and travel size hand lotion, or even a nasal spray. MAY work for pens and pencils, but only if you have a big collection so they can't lean. Don't even think about small items like thumb drives because you are not getting them out without tweezers or turning this mess upside down.Good for storing styluses, and travel size hand lotion, or even a small-medium prescription bottle.So the main issue is poor design. The 2 sides that pull out are very thick and do not slide straight; they are loose but also awkward to pull out. Loose like they were measured wrong. It wobbles and is crooked, but looks like they intentionally used the wrong measurements. The cool looking spaces are not practical.It is not as nice looking as the photo, and does not work well.

Nice, but of course not what they used to be. They still look cool, people notice and complement. But not as beefy as the originals in the 80s.The shell top starts at the top of the sole, not covering the whole toe, and is thinner rubber. Also, the upper is thinner, and will undoubtedly wear out fast. They have no arch support and less cushion in footbed, but good ankle support. A little narrow, but true to size. I had the first run of the original shoes so I don't know when quality went down, but it was probably when the price went down.I guess I'm saying: These look good and are comfortable, but if I skated in these they would be destroyed in a month- beyond the help of duct tape and shoe goo.With casual use as a sneaker, I expect them to last 3-6 months tops. I can live with that for the price.

If your hair is REALLY dry, I mean breaking off, this oil makes your hair look less fried and softer without being too oily. I put it on the ends and a little on the roots, which reduces breakage. Great for short hair.Unfortunately, the seller "Blue Fade Marketplace" sent me one without a secure lid, oil was all over the box and plastic bag and the $2 coupon was still attached (and not applied! bummer).UPDATE: They were very nice & responsive in resolving the situation. So good on them!

I feel ripped off. About a quarter of the tape is just a strip of paper & unusable.I use a lot of this labeler tape. I have been buying it for 10 years. I purchased this item in August 2014, worked as expected, until one day it cut off my print, the strip ended. I assumed it was empty. I took out the cartridge and there was still plenty of tape in in. I tried to use it again and it started the new piece of tape. Not only did it not print, put the tape was just paper. No sticky side, no shiny side, just paper that wouldn't print.I don't know if this is how they're ripping people off these days or I got a defective one, but I'm inclined to believe it was intentional or I was purposefully sold a "second". I'm giving it 2 stars because I like the product in general.

The shape makes them even easier to break. I had 2 break right out of the box before I knew what was happening, and we're talking sharp shards that are still strong magnets. You could easily cut yourself.On the other hand, they are very small and very strong. Great for a crowded fridge because they fit along the edge of a paper without obscuring the view and NO worries of falling.Next time I'll buy the round ones.

If you don't have a huge room and don't mind the noise this is a nice little humidifier, especially for a child.First thing to know, you cannot see the steam, but it produces humidity. It is probably a better output for my relatively small bedroom than the Ultrasonic, but has some drawbacks.Pros-The star lights, especially on my slanted ceiling.  They don't spin, but do change color like a kaleidoscope. It would be nice in place of a night light.-You're not going to over-humidify a child's room. It is the right size and a nice shape.Cons-It is very bright, even with the star lights off (the knob lights up a lot)-It is Loud even with earplugs. I had trouble sleeping with it on.-It has a filter that needs regular cleaning and changing, even if you use distilled water.So in contrast, my regular unit is a Vicks Ultrasonic Cool Mist Humidifier that is the bomb. It can steam up my bedroom like I took a shower. It is quiet and only has one light that is less bright than my clock radio. I change the little box filter every 3 months, but it hardly needs cleaning if you use distilled water. I've had it 2 years and when my hard water (I used a filter and filtered water) slowed it down with limescale, the company sent me a new or fixed one. It seems new. These are both Kaz products and it seems like a good company.

My first impulse was to return it and I should have. It fits, it's pretty soft and cozy. Nice color brown, good size brim. Not too small, and has some hair room.Problems:-Has a thick seam down the center back and it hangs out on the bottom.-Every time I wear it I get a bruise on my forehead where the brim hits me, even though it is not tight.-It slips down my forehead/bangs. I have an average sized woman's head.

The best felt hat of this style I've found. The brim is slightly floppy when down, but you can turn it up too. I like the very neutral, almost grey color, it looks high quality. You need to store it well or it will loose it's shape. Also, if you pull it down, you push out the "dent" or shape, in the top of the hat.It's warm and the brim blocks sun, so it's very functional too.

The photo shows this has a slightly pebbled surface. This is not the same- it's smooth like regular contact paper which means it won't grip chalk as well. I didn't try it so I can't say how well it worked.I bought what seemed like this exact roll of chalkboard contact paper at the hardware store. It was perfect to cover my old beige refrigerator, and was matte with a little texture to hold the chalk, and hide any little application mistakes I made. It wasn't too thin and has stayed up. But I only had enough for one door so I ordered this online. This is slightly different.
Just imagine trying to keep a grip if there's any lotion or oil on the handle...Especially as a woman with smaller hands this was impossible.

I love that these come in wide widths. They are very soft and lightweight and accommodated my oddly shaped feet well. BUT there is no support of any kind. It's cushioned a little on the bottom and the elastic and fabric make a very comfortable shoe for not walking too much. There is no arch support or room for an insole, so I returned them.Style wise, I got pink and it was pretty gross, I think to pull these off in a non-slipper capacity you need brown or dark grey or something.

I buy these at a local box store, and I can't get by without them. I have an HP, a Toshiba, and a MacAIr with a peripheral s burner. I work with small business with tech support on many levels.I have found that both my HP and my Mac have up to 10X higher failure rate than the Memorex discs. Even better, I love the printable feature, I can print out data CDs or DVDs for clients that are printed with my logo and the disc contents on my printer or you can just write on them.

Exactly what we needed. Installed it as a liner behind our fabric curtains. We have a nice, big antique tub with a single pipe going up to the shower head. We installed a screw-on brass soap dish, but there is no where for shampoo, body wash, etc. So much easier than putting the bottles on the floor of the tub for every shower.Now my shampoo and conditioner and body wash and loofah and comb are all easily reachable without bending over. And my husband has his shampoo and soap higher up. There are plenty of pockets, and the bigger ones hold 3 medium sized bottles easily. It has held up great so far (several weeks). Even if I take a bath I can leave the curtain in the tub as it sticks well to the sides instead on me.The drawbacks are irrelevant, or at least minimal. I can't reach any pockets when I'm taking a bath. And when the lights are out, you can see the silhouette of the pockets and contents. But If the lights are on, you don't see anything unusual, except the absence of all our shampoos bottles on the floor.

They sent the wrong product. I ordered 2 of the "Bird Smoke"  to use as sheer curtains. They arrived weeks early. They are very soft and the print is good quality for the price. I was expecting a smokey blue color, but the color I received is a kind of green yellow, I think it's the yellow color. They are both the same color, and it's not too bad, but not what I wanted.They are very sheer, the birds are equally spaced, covering the whole scarf. All four edges are straight and hemmed. It doesn't look like it would hold up well to anything but light use. Certainly would be ruined by a pin, and easily ripped.

He really liked these pants. The material has a nice textured look, they have some give, which is great for skating or off road bikes but they look sharp with a tee or untucked shirt. The Fatigue Green is a nice subtle green that can go anywhere with almost anything. The waist has no stretch or give BTW, just the legs. The legs seemed a little baggier than the photo. Not skinny or fitted. They are very nice pants.BUT, no ball room- imagine a dude with camel toe. Oh yes, it's possible. They need a gusset or something. And not the only problem in that area. They were a little loose around the waist so with a belt the front sort of pooches out like he's wearing diapers or has a load in his pants, but in the front, which makes it more disturbing.

I'm buying many hats to find the right look. This looked cute, but it is literally for people under 12 months of age. It was a little big on my cat. I tried to stretch it out, but alas, it is traditionally crocheted and not terribly stretchy. I would give it to my 4 year old niece, but it would be too tight and hurt her little head. And it came from China, so I guess I'm not returning it.

I wanted a nice, lacy, red bra. And this was a very reasonably priced bra that fit. The problem is the front clasp. If you fill out the bra (the correct size) the underwires stick straight out above the clasp. There is no shirt that would hide the little "horns". Bummer, back it goes.

These would be nice summer capris. They are shorter than a lot of capris, maybe because of the ruching, but hit just under the knee- if they fit. I guess I ordered a size up, but the waist was a full 10 inches too big. That is huge, maybe 3 sizes too large. I'd suggest sizing down.Otherwise they are a nice lightweight, deep black fabric. They have good pockets and the correct length to be more flattering. Good alternative to those who find shorts too revealing or uncomfortable.

I never ended up using it because it was too big, shaped weird and pulled at my neck. It was confusing how to put it on, what went where? The neck strap was uncomfortable woven plastic-like material, and my arm just didn't fit in it correctly. No matter how I adjusted it my arm was in a weird position, making it more painful. Mostly it didn't keep my lower arm up because my elbow kept sliding down. I am 5'4" with proportionally short arms and a bit busty.

This shirt really surprised me. most tops are too tight in my shoulders and hips. This is cute very flattering and fits very nicely. The color is a little brighter than the photo, but wearable. It is comfortable in the mild heat, summer in Northern California.

I needed to start wearing hats, although I'm not a huge hat girl. I don't feel like I can pull off baseball hats anymore, so I have trying a variety. This little bowler has the cute bow touch, but looks very Clockwork Orange/ Al Capone.

I had this on tape (yes, I'm old) and I wanted the tracks in "high def". So I bought the CD advertized as new "factory sealed", and the seller sent me a used CD, scratched with the liner notes bent up and cracks in the CD case.Aside from the actual product I received, this is a good soundtrack. I love the Juliette Lewis "Born Bad" track. But a lot of the songs do have soundtrack dialogue over the song, like L7 "S*** List" and the Cowboy Junkies great cover of "Sweet Jane".

PRETTY: I do like this top, but I expected the sleeves to be more flowy like the bottom. It is really cute, I bought a smaller size in a different color too because the embroidery and colors are nice. It would disguise a flabby mid-section or tummy.WEIRD FIT: The arm holes are super tight- you can't wear them as it unless you size way up and have skinny arms. I will take the seams out and make them split sleeves. My arms are larger than average, and most tops are tight across my shoulders, but this is ridiculous. The bust is as snug as I would want it, but it is loose around the hips. My body type is (though large at the moment) fairly well proportioned with larger bust and hips than my waist. It might work better for a pear or apple shape.

I have had one of these for years and it is the best purse I've ever had. It's a perfect size; not too small, not too big to lose things, good pocket placement and size (inside and out help you keep track of stuff). A cell or sunglasses easily fits in the outer zipper pocket. I get compliments on my green one all the time, it's cute.The best part of it is that it very quickly and easily converts into a chic backpack (much cuter than any other backpack I've seen). This is ideal for shopping, walks, festivals, anytime you need your arms free. It is not too heavy. I don't usually spend this much money on purses, but I see it as an investment.I think the magnet is perfect- It secures the bag enough, as there is no zipper. It's fast and easy access with enough security that you would feel it if someone was messing with your bag. The leather is soft and the liner fabric is quite nice too.The only thing that bothers me about this newer version is that the straps have that plastic stuff on the edges of the leather. It always ends up cracking and peeling and it looks a bit cheap.

I bought these for my husband for work, his belt has been bothering him since he had surgery so I thought something with some stretch would be better. No stretch but apparently they fit him perfectly so he doesn't need a belt. The 40 actually measures 41" at the waist. I think people think they are small because of size inflation (it's a real thing!).For cargo pants, they look awesome. Neither of us are fans of sloppy cargo pants, especially in public. He looks goooood in these. They are trimmer in the leg and the pockets are sewn to not stick out, but long enough to hold a pruning saw and leather work gloves, maybe a soda. Good material for work, seems tough. To bad they don't have a little stretch or they'd be perfect.

I know how desperate you are to find help when suffering with Fibromyalgia, so don't waste your energy reading this book. I have been following a very similar protocol for over 8 years, for my own reasons (eating anti-inflammatory diet and taking guaifenesin for allergies congestion).I have since been diagnosed with Fibromyalgia and most days I can't even hold a up a book and read for more than 30 minutes. And sorry, but Vicodin, Flexeril and Modafinil have really helped me on bad days. Reducing stress and regular movement are even more effective.Mucinex or guaifenesin can help with some allergy symptoms and congestion. If that's why you feel awful, you lucked out.Please don't vote my review "unhelpful" simply because you have a differing opinion. I tend to find this kind of bullying when I review books with bogus cures. I am trying to help people, like me, who are suffering from a disease that is not fully understood.If you have Fibro, look up Dr. Teitelbaum on Amazon. His protocol has a much higher success rate and is endorsed by 3 of my specialists.

The worst part is the awful scratchy fabric. It's rayon/linen blend, but it's the horrible rough kind of linen and enough rayon to have a sheen. Just trying them on I felt my thighs getting rashy.They don't look, feel, wash or breathe like linen pants. I buy basic linen pants almost every year, I'm familiar with how quality linen feels.CUT: The cut is SO unflattering. I like a high waist, but these are drawstring and 4 inches above my waist, which doesn't actually work in practice. Super saggy bottom and crotch with tapering towards the ankle. My friend laughed when I tried them on. I wanted a strait leg/ palazzo, not old lady meets MC Hammer pants.These are about 2 sizes too large, maybe more. Really. Mixed reviews confused me.RETURN: Not only did I have to pay return shipping, but a restocking fee! And it's their fault that the sizing was off and the product was inferior, misrepresented and over-priced. I paid $40 for something unwearable and got $30 back. I didn't know Jessica London was the same company as Woman Within or I would never have ordered from them. One star because they are pants, they are black, and they have pockets. I hope this helps you from making the same mistake I did.

This dress is a very lightweight, somewhat see-through fabric.  I was expected the thicker polyester scrubs-like fabric (they still call it cotton) that many of these are made from, but this seems to have more cotton and is thinner- good for summer. I still doubt the 100% cotton claim.The only real problem is that the seams are all unfinished, so if I wash it (and I must as it reeks of clothing preservative) the fabric at the seams will all unravel like cut-offs do unless I fix them myself.I have a similar dress that is a little small on me, so I ordered 2 sizes up to a 3x. That was a mistake. Stick to your size. I expected it to look like a sack anyway, and it does. I'll probably put some elastic in the back of the waist or sides when I finish the seams. This is just a summer house dress for me.I wanted a toned-down version of my smaller bright blue Mexican dress so I went for this khaki, but it just makes the embroidery look gaudier and the dress looks a lot like a giant paper grocery bag. On the other hand, there is a lot of embroidery, including on the back shoulders.I would have been happier if I had paid less. Hope this review helps.

I have bought a few of these ArtsyClothing Tees. I like them a lot, but this design (and probably all the lighter colors) have a screen printed "label" that is like 3" tall and black and is totally visible through the back. They should make it smaller and on a side seam or something. I was buying the men's XXL tee (HUGE) and tailoring them to fit, so I was happy to see the women's cut. The new women's sizes are proportionally smaller than the men's sizing. So, it is more snug than I like around the hips.They say they're working on the label issue, so I'll wait for the sunflowers.

It's magic fabric. For years I've only worn filament silk, or nothing. In a week I'm converted. The give-n-go fabric feels like silk, or almost nothing, same thing. It's more sweat absorbent and longer lasting and more stretchy than silk. Another reviewer said the cut changed, but these women's briefs had a lot more fabric than I expected- over the belly button and into granny pantie status. That's OK, nothing more comfortable and no more reasons to skip the underwear. I'm sold for life, I even got some camis to protect my modesty completely.

The hat is just too small, but I like everything else about it. I wear a women's medium in hats, and other San Diego brand ribbon hats have fit a little loose; which I prefer so I don't get hat hair and have some air circulation. This hat is not just snug, it's tight enough to be uncomfortable. Having bought multiple hats of the brand, I thought sizing would be consistent. And I tried loosening the "adjustable ribbon", it made no difference.Otherwise it's exactly what I wanted: wide brim that is shape-able and stands out straight if you want (I want!). UV protection for scalp and face. Wide range of colors. Suitable for casual beach or nice parties. Lightweight with some stretch. So cute on me. But it would completely flatten my hair, give me a headache and mess up and sunscreen or makeup I have on- immediately. So it's useless unless you have an unusually small head.

I buy a far amount of Coolibar stuff since developing a sun sensitivity. But I don't want to look like I have a problem or like I'm all sporty all the time, like grocery shopping or socializing. So I ordered this and I ordered a UV Buff, pretty much the same thing. BUT this Coolibar gaiter was not as soft and had irritating seams (that are really obvious: black on pink). The Buffs have a huge selection of designs and are the Buff Coolmax fabric was very cooling, so there wasn't much comparison.

Especially in the middle where you want your knees to be. 2.5 stars because after a little modification it is great to have a body pillow for adults over 4.5' tall. But they basically took two of those cheap, short "body pillows" and put a long cover on them. There are two distinct lumps of batting/fill on either end. So you can push them together and sew up the extra length or do what I did, This will probably flatten out quickly as the fill is really cheap. I added more fill (of a higher quality) after the first option made it a little too stiff.  It does NOT come with an extra cover as one reviewer said. So I made my own cover out of an old sheet. At this point, I think the price is too high in comparison to other body pillows.Someone complained of headaches, I assume they were using this under the head as the photo shows. I don't use it that way and find it very comfortable from the neck down, I wake up feeling better. And I prefer down head pillows, so I wouldn't even consider this for head support. I was just diagnosed with Fibromyalgia and Lupus and this pillow is helping me get the sleep I need.It helps your joints and supports side sleepers. Just keep in mind that this thing is as long as my queen mattress. Once it's under the covers I have to fold it behind my feet. It is challenging if two people are in the bed- it like having 3 people in the bed.

These baskets are a lot like the ones you can find at Ikea, but more fragile and not as tall. They will work for my purpose and my cats LOVE them. Cats like boxes, but add to that the soft, kind of wicker material and they want to scratch and sit in them 24/7.Seville Classics was not a good seller however. These arrived very late and were "undeliverable" because they put in the wrong address by one number. I had to drive an hour both ways to get them from the UPS facility.

I bought 2 buffs after falling in love with the UV Bugslinger Buff I bought first. But these "originals" aren't the same fabric. These feel more synthetic, are a little shinier inside and not as sweat absorbent. Plus, they apparently don't have the UV protection I need. But I like the much larger selection of designs on the originals. I bought two that looked more like scarves, the ginko camo-colored leaves and the black and white tree branches. They are nice, especially the Ginko was a nice surprise (aside from the obvious Buff logo on them in 4 places). I have to keep my head covered every time I leave the house so these are a nice addition.The headbands are also quite useful and look good, as they are double sided and stay in place well. You can do a full on Axl Rose with a bandana headband.

UPDATE: OK, I'm not a super light nerd who bought 10 different bulbs and took photos, sorry. ButTHESE ARE AWESOME. I see why they might want to limit people. I bought 4 different LED brands. These had a nice warm light very similar to my old incandescent bulbs. The whiter ones were just so harsh, one I just had to return. These are warmer than the other LEDs I bought, including the Philips "urinal" shaped bulb.It's been months of daily use and not one has burned out. Plus, they are smaller than the old bulbs so they will fit in any normal fixture (not candelabras). In addition to knowing they will fit your fixtures (even my ceiling fans), they have a textured surface to make them easier to install AND they have good "spread". Meaning not just a beam of light, but they light up the area.ORIGINAL apparently unhelpful: I just tried to buy 3 of these 3-packs. We have 6 chandeliers in the house that are too bright and use up so much energy. I want to switch to LED and this is a good buy for just a fraction of what I need in ONE ROOM (we rent, so redoing the lighting won't happen).When I tried to check out, I got a message from Amazon saying I had exceeded my limit by 3 (I only tried to buy 3) and couldn't buy them, like I'm a light bulb hoarder or something. It appears the order went through anyway, so I will update with results.

I liked the fit of this bra a lot. But it has a kind of mesh/tulle edging on the cups (instead of the soft lace you often find) that immediately started irritating my skin. It was already red on that sensitive skin after trying it on. If I had worn it for even half a day, I would have had lasting chaffing. I wish Vanity Fair would go back to using the soft lace edging that helped smooth edges under shirts.

I love Vanity Fair bras, and really wanted red. But this bra was a little scratchy and did not have the smooth coverage or support I expected. It also creates those back buldges and has straps that kind of cut into your shoulders. Vanity Fair has some bras out now that eliminate those problems, and I bought a few of those instead.

These are handy little containers that each hold about a cup of whatever loose parts you might have.  I am using mine to hold various screws in my shop.  The lids screw on and off easily, and they do lock together to keep the stack neat, although that isn't as easy, which is why I took off one star.  They are very clear, so the contents are easily visible.  These would also be good for sewing supplies, office supplies, etc.  Just keep in mind that they are, as advertised, 8.0 ounce size, which is just one cup, so they aren't for bigger stuff.

We have used parchment sheets for cookies before, and if you haven't, I recommend you start.  Easy and no sticking.  These are great because they are precut and fit standard cookie sheets.  You can use each sheet several times, too.  It's cookie baking season, so you'll need these!

This is an excellent pack with a lot of great features.  First, the construction seems very sturdy.  I examined all seams, zippers, etc. and could find no problems.  It has the usual padded straps you would expect on a decent backpack.  It also had a comfortable, molded top handle, and I often carry my pack that way.  In addition, it has the strap that goes over the handle on your rolling suitcase, making it easy to move through airports or in and out of hotels.  There are two water bottle mesh pockets, and a lot of other pockets, many with interior arrangement, pockets, etc.  The back compartment unzips on three sides, so it will lay flat when you are putting in your laptop and tablet.  For a long weekend, this pack has enough room that I can carry everything I need -- electronics, clothes, etc.  The red and black color is also bright and attractive.  At this price, I was very surprised at how good a pack this turned out to be.  This will be getting a lot of use.

This is a food for grown up dogs at least a year old. The first ingredient is lamb, and the company talks about the excellent nutrition.  It has no corn or chicken, which is supposed to be better for your dog.  I have no way to test the nutrition, but I can say that I have three dogs, ranging from 10 to 90 pounds, and they all love it.  It has also caused no stomach upset, which sometimes happens when you switch food brand.  This is good stuff.  I really liked that they had a Basenji on the bag.  It isn't a common breed, but I like them.

This is a very nice doormat!  It is rubber on the back, so it is non slip and waterproof.  On the top it has a nice, attractive pattern with enough relief to do a good job of wiping feet.  It is heavy enough that it won't blow away easily.  Bring it in during Katrina.  It is also the width of a standard 3' exterior door.  I think it is also attractive.  Don't let the name fool you.  Unless grey clashes, this will look good by your door.

This crossbow took about two hours to assemble, but the process was fairly simple using the wrenches supplied.  The last step is to install the string, which requires you to cock the bow using a longer string supplied.  This is where we discovered that we could not make the rope cocking device work, so we just had to cock it by pulling the string directly with gloves on.  This is not easy! Now that it is assembled, we have to cock it that way every time.  It does shoot well, and is accurate enough to make one inch groups at 20 yards.  The trigger is smooth, and the red dot scope is plea try bright.  You will want different tips for hunting.  This bow would be very adequate for taking deer out to about 75 yards. The bow mounted quiver holds six bolts snugly.  Except for the cocking issue, this is a nice crossbow and not too expensive.  Check your local regs to see if you can use this during archery season.Update:  once we found an online video explaining how the rope cocking system worked it got much easier.  So, some challenges with the documentation but a nice bow overall.
I both use and install a lot of cameras.  The kits always come with really long cables, but these are a big help when the camera is closer to the NVR.  Same quality as what comes with the cameras.

As the name implies, these are fairly basic, but good quality sheets.  The 200 thread count makes them pretty smooth and soft, and should wear well.  The fitted bottom sheets have corner pocket depth of over 13", so they should fit even very thick mattresses.  They fit ours, which also has a 2" memory foam topper.  The graphite color is a bit hard to describe.  It is basically a medium grey, but with a slight brown overtone.  I find the color neutral and pleasing.  The pillow cases are ample for queen sized pillows -- we have the queen set.  These are a good value.

This unit is perfect for a small business or even a home network if you have a fairly large quantity of data to protect.  As a professional photographer, I have a lot of photos, and they take a lot of room.  This was easy to install.  Just plug it in and connect it to your network with the supplied cable.  I connected it directly to my router, but it can be connected anywhere on the network.  Then run the software supplied on the included CD and you are ready to go.  The cabinet is solid, and it will keep your data backed up.  As always I suggest at least two backups to two different places.  We also do periodic data backups to a hard drive located in another computer on our network.

I have a couple of Big Bang shirts.  OK, I have a few.  Alright, back off.  So I own every one I can find?  What's it to you?  I'm a professor of computer science, so this one has the perfect sentiment for me.  In addition, the t-shirt itself is pretty well made and fits as expected.  The printing is clear, bright, and seems durable so far.  Now I just need one of those folding things that Sheldon uses....  Oh, wait, I roll my t-shirts.  They take up a LOT less room that way, and I have a few.  OK, I have dozens.  I'm done here.

This is a very high end power supply suitable for a powerful server or serious game machine.  It has 750 total watts, and can power multiple hard drives as well as high end video and sound.  It is very full size, so it won't fit in a compact case.  The wires serving the various devices are separate, and plug into the back of the power supply as needed, so you don't have loose cables lying about.  The supplied cables seem very high quality.  The fan is large, and moves a lot of air, but the power supply is very quiet.  Like all power supplies, it is easy to install.  Four screws hold it in, and then just run the cables to the various devices.
This attached easily and provided a place for the tadpoles to sit when they became little toads.  It works well and looks pretty good.  It seems to have enough flotation for a larger frog as well.

I used to have some magnetic glass cleaners that looked like a frog and turtle.  I liked them better.  This one is TOO strong.  You have to be very careful or it slams into the glass when you are putting it together.  It is so strong it is actually hard to slide around, and, unlike my old ones, there is no way to go around a corner without taking it out and putting it back.  It does do a good job of wiping the algae off.

I have a LifeProof case for my iPad Air 2, and it does a great job of protecting it.  This one is very similar.  It snaps on and has an O-Ring that seals the screen, meaning the screen is exposed and easy to use, but the case is still waterproof.  I don't plan to take it scuba diving, but it is good to know it won't be a problem if I get caught in a rain shower or drop it into a puddle.  It also does a good job of protecting against drops, and all of the controls, camera, etc. are still easy to use.  All in all, this is a nice looking case, does a good job of protecting the phone, fits well, and doesn't interfere with using the phone.  Good stuff.

This is an interesting system.  It is very sturdy, and has a myriad of different accessories and hooks which easily snap into the channels. This kit has a single piece of the track which is 32" long and 6" wide.  It can be attached to most any kind of wall -- open studs, sheetrock over studs, or masonry.  It comes with wood screws, but for some surfaces you will have to provide your own fasteners.  Keep in mind that the directions say to not let it hang past a stud, so the 32" track in this box is suitable for installation on a wall with studs 16" apart, but not 24" apart.  You could easily cut it to a shorter length.  Now that I have this starter set, I am shopping for more track and some more hangers and other accessories.

I have used Lexar JumpDrives for a long time, and I find them to be very reliable.  This one is about half the size of my other Lexar 32 GIG USB 3 stick, and has a nice sort of tiny strap designed to let you hook it to a keyring.  The big thing to remember is that it is USB 3.0, which is MUCH faster than 2.0.  The actual speed you get will depend upon the mix of files you are copying.  I have a folder of mixed files that I like to use for testing.  It contains 425 assorted files in 26 different sub-folders, and is 3.81 Gigs in size.  It took 155 seconds to copy this folder to the Lexar drive, which is about 25 MB per second.  Read speeds will be faster, and fewer big files copy faster than a lot of small ones.  Your experience may differ, but this is a fast memory stick, and comes in capacities up to 128 GIGs.  Good product.

This standard sized kitchen bag fits our trash can well.  It is strong, and has an excellent drawstring.  The bag itself has a texture, and it has a fresh scent which would help with stinky garbage.  Filled full it showed no sign of breaking.

This 30 gallon bag has the usual drawstring, and seems quite strong.  The drawstring works well, and it worked well for leaves and other lawn debris from our recent fairly violent thunderstorms.  Like most of these type bags, it will stretch quite a bit before breaking.  I took off one star because these don't resist punctures and stretch breaking as well as the house brand from a membership club, which is also listed as extra strong and is similar in thickness.  Still an excellent bag.

We bought this mainly for travel.  We check into a hotel, hook this up to the TV and wireless, and just like that we have all of our Amazon library, Prime, etc.  It works well, and only one older TV so far has been a problem.  It has worked fine in a half dozen hotel rooms.  Once we got it, however, we discovered that it is also nicer in many ways than our smart TV.  It is easier to use, and the voice search is great.  For such a little box, it does an amazing job.

These little hoops (one inch in diameter) are quite lovely and appear well made.  The inset crystals are from Swarovski, and the metal is sterling silver.  They sparkle well even in lamplight, and really shine in sunlight.  I looked them over carefully and didn't see any flaws in construction.  For the price they are a very nice pair of earrings, and look every bit as good as more expensive pieces.  My wife likes them a lot.

This grill was easy to assemble.  The parts just slide or snap together.  There are just two Phillips screws to hold the handle on the cover.  It took maybe 10 minutes to put this together, and I didn't hurry.  It has a large grilling surface, and cooks well.  It isn't a charcoal grill, but if you like how George Foreman grills cook, you'll like this one.  It heats up quickly as well, and is easy to clean.  Non-stick tools only of course.
This is a nice little cover for my quite expensive key.  All the functions are still easily accessible.  Protect that key!!  Easy to put on and fits well.

I am on my second VW Jetta TDI, and I love them.  Fast, handle, and still get 45 MPG.  Why not wear a shirt that rubs it in a little.  Be proud of our diesels.  The shirt is nice quality and the size label is accurate.

This is a nice little kit, and my granddaughter is having fun with it.  Basically you suck up the insects or spiders with the gun, and then transfer them to the little cage.  Both the gun and the cage have a magnifying glass and a light.  After observing them for a while, you can release them.  My only quibble is that the vacuum action could be a little stronger, but it does work fairly well.  It is a cute design and should build a child's interest in science.

As is usual for Thule products, this bag is very well made of sturdy materials, and will last indefinitely.  I have other Thule bags, and I have never been disappointed with the quality.  It is also very well designed to hold my GoPro equipment.  The two places for cameras hold a GoPro with the waterproof case around it, and there are slots for the other gear as well.  My camera is a Hero 3.  The strap is very comfortable, and you barely notice it is on.  The other compartment holds smaller loose items.  The bag is very well padded, and will do a good job of protecting the gear.  It is also lightweight.  Hey, the GoPro is a nifty little camera, so why carry it around or store it in a big, clunky bag?  This one is perfect.

Real, metal vacuum bottles work better than other types of insulated beverage containers.  This is no exception.  It's stainless steel, so no worries about contamination from plastic or aluminum.  It has a spill proof drink-through lid.  You press a button to allow the liquid to flow.  Right now, in Arizona, I am using it for cold stuff, and it keeps a beverage cold for easily two or three hours.  It fits well in the cupholders in both my Expedition and Jetta.
