this pump works great but its doesn't seem to push the same amount of water as my old pump, which was the same size as the replacement pump. I had to move up a size to keep my pond clean. it is more energy efficient and that should tip you off its not going to move as much water as your old pump did. at least the store we bought from would take back the smaller one. what I love about this pump is the cage on front, no more frogs getting sucked in to die. the last pump I spent each spring cleaning out the dead.

perfect for sun! I walk a lot and I dont like sun to get on me, this is the perfect parasol for walks. I get so many compliments on it. its just very pretty and its easy to carry along. this has a hooked handle at the end. it is not too big and in crowds I only have to angle it around people. this is meant for rain but its too pretty for just raining days.

works on breath for a short term, which is nice. my dog has bad teeth and they smell. the only problem I have is she stopped eating them. I believe its because she has such bad teeth (rescue dog who was not cared for, so its taking time to get her back in good health) but if your pup has some smelly breath, this will make you enjoy her kisses so much more. my dog is a small 8# dog and she has to chew these to eat them, which I think helps freshen her up. they are about an inch long and a bit flexible. I am hoping she will try them again later.

great tasting and so nice to get a big bag for the price as one shaker at the store. I bought the fine ground, it pours freely from any shaker I have. I used to use a grinder and coarse salt but when I am doing some cooking I dont want to have to grind salt, I just want to shake it. I might get a bag of coarse too, to keep on hand for when you need a ground or coarse flake. if you have not tried the Pink salt, you will be glad you did.

I have no idea why , I dont understand it all, but I put these in each spring and my water clears up. I have a large pond and I coral them in areas in the rocks to keep them in one place.  if I dont put them in , the water dosent clear up. I like to keep my pond running naturally. I have two bio filters.  my fish dont seem at all bothered by them in the pond.

I was nervous this would not work, as its not exactly the same as the battery that was in there, but it works! the incessant beeping has stopped. so much cheaper than Verizon wanted to fix the problem.  I can tell you, there is no way to silence that horrible box till you break down and buy a new battery.  keep the old battery till the new one comes, you need the connectors to hook up the new one- you can do this.... I like to take a photo of something before I uninstall a part, then I know what it should look like when I am putting the new one back in.you will be sleeping again soon

I really like this professional salon product but I dont know why they call it "peel". it is a light scrub. it does not peel off. its a cream, with a pumice in it.  I use it for dry patches on oily skin. I apply to clean dry skin, then let it set on, the lightly buff off with my fingertips. and rinse well with water. follow up with a good moisturizer.  if you have very sensitive skin, apply to skin and gently buff right away and wash off, this will help remove dead skin at the top and cleans the skin.  you do get a nice fresh glow. for great skin- dont use hot water on your skin, dont rub hard, and always wear sunscreen.

keep in mind, these are not regular ping pong balls. they are a more solid thicker plastic. I was told by my son, real ping pong balls have a gas in them? these do not. I drilled holes in some of mine as I was using them for a craft project.  if you plan to glue these, I found hot melt worked really well. some glues will not stick to the slick surface of this type plastic. the hot melt sort of melts the balls together a bit and made fast work of it. liquid nails was working but slow to set and some of my rubbery glues held but also slow to dry. these are very fun for art projects and stuff like that and you cant beat the price!

this stuff was a really good fake wood grain for a project I had to make. I used up the last of the roll as a temporary fix to a missing threshold where I am doing some remodeling- looks so much better than the gap I had LOL I ran out and will have to get more. I have seen brands with a better grain look to it, but I know this brand, it is sticky and durable like you would expect in a duct tape.

tasty way to get your vitamins in. do keep in mind , in order to get the full amount listed on the label, you must take 4 of these, but I don't feel I need to get 100% or more of my daily needs in a pill alone. I do eat real food too. I use these as a way to ensure I dont miss too much each day if I am not eating all my good foods. this is easy to take and I like that it did not have calcium or iron in it. and since you don't have to swallow it, its easy for people who have trouble digesting stuff or swallowing pills. I take two each day at separate times with other foods.  I am on my 3rd bottle and its been going well.they come with a good year + on the expiration date too, so you are getting nice fresh stuff. (something you always worry about when buying sight unseen)

super cute cutter. the only part I did not like, they are a bit large.  this can be hard to stamp with some cookie dough. chose a recipe that is stable while baking and wont puff up too much. be sure your dough is not too sticky and dip the cutter in flour to help. they were a huge hit at a party we had. I just wish they came in smaller sizes.

nice sized bulb and it wont over heat.  I use these in decorations and I dont want a high heat out put bulb that could cause problems or put out too much light. this was just perfect.  I would say these are great for holiday decor when you need a nice color glow but not bright light output.

this is my second time buying this. so I guess I can say, I like this one. ( I have tried another brand, non chewable ones, and had to toss them. )  these taste good so you will take them. I keep them in the fridge as others had suggested and I take one in the morning to help keep things in balance.  I did notice a difference after the first month. I suffer from a lot of stomach problems and I do think this product , along with some other stuff and diet changes, is working for me. it is not a quick fix pill. this is one you have to stick with and notice over time. but the great tastes and easy to take pill will help you on that. you could easily get a child to eat these too.

we handed these out to kids at an event, and some felt they needed to turn them back in at the end of the night. I felt they were a very nice quality for the money spent. they are sized and meant for children. I would get this again for next years event.
I like to keep extras on hand, vacuums work best with clean parts. this fits perfect and when you put the old next to the new, you really see how dirty the used one was!
fits perfectly, just the same as the original.  you sometimes worry if a generic brand will fit, this one does. so nice to have a clean one in.

I picked up a used vacuum for $10 because it smelled. I figured I would either get the smell out or keep the parts, but once I popped in this new filter, smell was gone and my used vac is now a nice extra in the lower level (no more hauling a heavy vac up and down stairs)  fits exactly the same as the original. best price was found here too.  when you vac no longer preforms as you like, replace some parts... dont get rid of it so fast.
fresh and delicious.  you just cant find this in stores, and I like a big bag on hand. they were chewy and fresh and right at my door.

I needed a longer rod but had the holders, this was such a good savings from starting from scratch. glad to have found this. I went from the 18 inch that was only good for hand towels to the 30 inch so now I can dry a bath towel.  worked great.

this is a great way to get your probiotics in, I do store them in the fridge after I opened. easy to eat and taste good, I do think kids would eat these with out any fuss. I am taking them for digestive help. I think they are helping. I suffer from reflux, ulcers and other stomach issues. this has been added to my other pills to help combat the trouble.  so far I am not seeing any bad side effects. I take mine first thing in the morning before my hot cocoa.

on my second one now. I bought this for my son to protect his new phone we got in Dec of 2012.  its been through so much abuse. he tosses his phone around and drops it often. finally the case cracked after one more drop to the tile floor. his phone by the way, has no damage what so ever at all, it looks brand new when you take it out of the case. it was time for a new screen protector anyway. so I am getting him another of the same. for the money this was a great way to keep the pricey phone safe! I say this is a must have for any younger person or anyone who lives a real life where things get dropped :)

the fish are loving this. I got the large size kibble.  the smaller fish, which are about 4 inches yet,  have to steal a kibble and hide while they soften it up but the bigger fish, over 7 inches, chow down 2-3 at a time. I mixed it in with the color enhancing food I have been giving them,  and the big fish seem to pick through to get this bit. it floats so I can keep track of when to stop tossing it in. with sinking food I never know what gets eaten or lost.this does not cloud the water. this is also a fun size if you like to spend some time hand feeding your koi. I have a mixed pond of different Koi , goldfish, comets and others. they all seem to love this new food. I cant wait to see growth results at the end of the season. I will report back this fall.here is my spring update, they grew, a lot! the small fish were more than twice their size by end of fall when they went down to overwinter.  they are all coming back up now and very healthy looking. I think this food was good for them. I will be getting more this spring.

its so hard to find someone to put sunblock on  your back. now I can do it myself. I was skeptical, I thought this would just smear it around, but the pad has a bit of a texture to it... it helps the lotion rub in. its a lot easier than I thought it would be. no more tan spots for me! I am finally covered.  found the best price here on Amazon too!

I already owned a copy of How to Raise Your Adult Children: Because Big Kids Have Even Bigger Problems, and this is the same exact book with a new title and ISBN #. but costs more in paperback. I was hoping they came up with some better advice this time. I already know what I did wrong.... was hoping to hear how to fix it.... this is a format of very random questions in "dear Abby" style, with snarky responses by both authors afterwards that merely point out the obvious mistake the parent is making and the quick fix response of "dont do that".  thanks for nothing. was hoping for insight not jokes about my situation.
this is easy to work with, i thought i might loose cookie parts in the tail but it comes out clean! they are a lot of fun to frost. its probably the cutest cutter in my collection.
I am using this for much more than I thought I would. so much easier than the old hanging weight scale I had been using. and easier to store.
the first two cartridges seemed just fine, but the third one in would not work. they also tend to leak all over. I have to return them as my printer wont print at all now. I would not try this again.

After reading several reviews here, I decided to add this one to my extensive 60's Spy Film collection. I love David Niven, so how could I go wrong?O, let me count the ways, brethren, 'cause this one's a drag from start to finish.First, you expect me to believe that British Intelligence didn't have enough agents to go around (at the height of the Cold War?), so they had to recruit a surgeon (Niven) named Dr. Love. How? By promising to appease his car fetish + provide him with some extravagant vehicle which, by the way, never materializes.Secondly, there is no real villain in this film, so it gets rightfully dinged for that disgrace. How can you have a Cold War spy film w/o a tangible villain wringing sweaty palms while plotting a world takeover?Thirdly, and let me remind you we're talking about a spy flick here, there is only ONE woman in the film, and she's nothing to look at (and I don't care who's sister she was or that she died in a car accident shortly after this film; which would have been a better plot than what we're succumbing to here). Again, ONE woman - no leggy, mini-skirted, scantily clad vixens or dollies to ease the pain or divert one's attention to prurient fantasies like all other spy flicks. Harsh? Sure, but it's my review - be as kind + forgiving as you want when you write your own...Weapons? The obligatory spy pen, cyanide pill, a silly ring and a watch used to identify agents, given to by an uncle - had the Brits never seen Man From U.N.C.L.E??? One cheesy cheap cliché after another.Locales? The ass-end of Beirut, full of squalor and no evil henchmen residing.  Not even a high-end hotel, no exotic scenery, major landmarks, nada. Yeesch. And apparently, British Intelligence was completely inept as far as field agents go, which makes me wonder how we won the Cold War, 'cause this common, middle-aged Dr. Love (sounds like a 70's exploitation character) manages to violently kill a slew of people (isn't that a violation of the Hippocratic Oath?), out-maneuver the Reds and save the world in what other reviewers have stated as 'realistic' for a spy flick... huh?It's about 20 minutes too long, seeing as we know how this is going to play out about 30 minutes in. My tolerance for the tedious when it comes to 60's cinema is remarkably high, but this clunker was a drag throughout. I should have seen it coming when I saw how many times Val Guest's name was splashed during the opening credits - he's a hack along the lines of Harry Novak, only less subtle (lol).The only two things this film has in its favor are David Niven and a great soundtrack featuring B-3 organ legend Jimmy Smith and some frantic percussion to simulate action sequences that really aren't there..In conclusion, I'm sure I've ticked off a boatload of folks, but I've sunk many a ship before this. I'm just trying to warn other like-minded fools not to fall for all the hype I did when I plopped down coin for this cinematic swill.'Where the Spies Aren't' would've been a more appropriate title.

After looking forward to receiving this all year (Dynamite's notorious for pushing release dates back, just like Sideshow), I am sorry to say it's incredibly disappointing on all levels.It's cast from an extremely lightweight porcelain(?) and weighs less than 2 pounds, which means it's porous + waiting to fall apart.The cape is attached to her hands at a very weak wrist - another accident awaiting.Her arms are joined below her armbands, and poorly at that. The 1st one I received was broken at that joint + had to be returned...it's boxed poorly w/ Styrofoam that doesn't really accommodate the cape properly - another tragedy awaits...Now we come to the mold problems - there are multiple rough spots that require sanding, which can't be done once painted, unless you're skilled enough to airbrush her entire body in flesh-coat.No resin or polystone is utilized, so it's VERY fragile as mentioned. But I can't stress this enough - it's cheaply made for the 2 bills you're shelling out for her.Then there are the paint issues - sloppy lines on Vampi's boots, costume, bracelets, etc., and her face needed a few more details as well. And the base is hastily and weakly executed w/ all the customary clichés that sit flat and lack depth or detail. And she's only around 9 1/2 inches tall - 12 inches includes the base. So, not 1/6th scale.Finally, after telling us that the statue was to be strictly limited to 1969 pieces (the year she first graced our eyes), the box plainly states that there are diamond eye versions, B+W versions AND artist proofs, bringing the corrected total up to 2317 pieces in all. So much for honesty from these rats.I own around 28 Vampirella statues; some I made + painted myself, some bought from other artists + collectors, but this one I ended up returning - it wasn't adding to my collection one iota.And I'm usually a completest, but this one lacks 'bite'...Sorry, very sorry in fact, to be bearer of bad news, but you should lower your expectations accordingly if planning on parting w/ your hard-earned coin.

CONAN RED SONJA - 2015 -Gail Simone has once again woven a fine tale that rings true to both of these iconic characters in this outing, and with admirable results to fans of both characters, unlike most crossovers I read.In addition, Danial Panosian and Randy Green have moved away from Sonja as we're used to seeing her in her ongoing Dynamite series and returned her to a more modernized version of the Roy Thomas originals from Marvel back in the 70's. AND it works wonderfully without appearing dated at all.Great tale, smoking art and coloring coupled with time-honored characters make this one to add to your collection, and would make Robert E. Howard proud.On top of all that, this HC book is extremely well made - strong cover boards, tightly woven binding and very thick page stock insures that this one won't be falling apart anytime soon. 'Can't say that about too many titles these days; the paper on most is so thin you can see the other side as you're reading! But not here, friends, this one gets a well-deserved, whole-hearted, 5 star recommendation.All hail the Barbarian and the She-Devil!

"Man did not start the war between Good and Evil. But he WAS the cause..." And so begins another saga revolving around the Watchers, the Fallen, Nephilim, True-Bloods, Half-Breeds and, of course, we humans. I know what you're thinking: great, ANOTHER story regarding Judeo-Christian beliefs about battles between angels, demons et. al. - WRONG. Well, yes, true enough, but this one sits very far apart from any I've read before. It's darker, more vicious, blatantly unholy, disturbing, profane and plays out like a Grindhouse double-bill crossover mash-up of Sin City meets Supernatural.The story starts like you might imagine, but 20 pages in and it starts to ramp up into overdrive; the dialogue is filthy and perverse, the characters are fleshed out or stripped to bone, the intensity quotient burns the meter levels to ash and we're on our way to graphic novel Heaven by way of Hell. No more clichés - we're treated to real characters, horrid evil, sexual deviants, political miscreants and plot devices not in average tales like this. Kudos.Now the even better part - as good as the tale is concerned, the artwork by Simon Bisley (Eisner Award-winning illustrator + artist of 'Batman/Judge Dredd' and 'Lobo', to name a few) is ferocious, feral and fear-invoking. Hyper-real, hyper-violent, hyper-sonic sickness that wouldn't let me put it down until I finished it (much to my wife's chagrin, much to my grin). Immortal sin never felt or looked so good! You NEED this in your collection, so I'm gonna stop writing now so you can hit the 'Buy It Now' button and feel the blistering burn of Brimstone, uber-babes, creepy demons and historical references to our unholy Biblical past.Man, are WE effed-up!5 scorching stars.

A concise, complete filmography chronicling Lugosi's entire career, from his early stage + silent films, his rise to #1 horror actor in the early 30's, his swift decline and typecasting that hounded him throughout the 40's and culminating with the sad tragedy that became his last years. There are some FANTASTIC pictures of Bela in his roles, both known + unknown, that ALONE make this one recommended. It's like looking at a Famous Monsters of Filmland mag devoted to Lugosi - how cool is that?Any fan of horror flicks or B+W cinema would be proud to have this book added to their collection. Definitely worth seeking out.

I gleefully ordered this cd from Amazon, and no detailed info was provided, then someone wrote a wretched review of it a few days later, declaring it unlistenable... there goes my coin on another frivolous whim, I thought. Certainly not the 1st time, probably not the last.However, I'm elated to report that when I did get around to listening to the unlistenable, I was more than impressed. Not solely because I had my expectations lowered to the dregs; no sir, this is one helluva performance by what was arguably the greatest jazz quartet that ever existed. Sure, it's a compromised recording by today's standards (even quality old recordings), and I guess what you listen to it on plays a big role in what you're able to hear, but I've got an old-skool stereo power amp receiver w/ some gigundo speakers, and I had no difficulty hearing ANY of the players, either as a collective OR as soloists, so I was in heaven hearing something I didn't already have in my extensive collection of Miles + Co.The first track, 'Gingerbread Boy', is a bit rough sonically, but Miles plays his ass off on this like I've never heard before. He's on fire, proving to anyone who had doubt that he was still an unstoppable force of nature, both as composer and trumpet sovereign.  Tony drove this band at breakneck pace, but here, Miles is one step ahead of his legendary timekeeper and takes a blistering, vicious solo that floored me. They bob, weave and joust about like sparring partners, so any sonic suffering I have to contend with is ignored by the admiration I have for this band. Next up is the final time this quartet ever performed 'Stella By Starlight' live (according to the liner notes), followed by the only time these giants played 'Dolores' live (ditto). It's powerful and every member takes the tune to greater heights than the vinyl recording (am I dating myself calling it 'vinyl'? Can't say I care...). By the 3rd track, the audio quality has improved considerably.Wayne takes his spot on several tracks, like 'Round Midnight' and 'So What', laying lush comments and piercingly thoughtful remarks as only Wayne can; Herbie actually has space to play by himself during 'Walkin' w/o Tony prodding him and  abstracting rhythmic meters to contradict melodies Herbie is entrenched in. Although Tony does more than his share of subdividing meters, fracturing time, pushing parameters and restlessly shifting rhythmic undercurrents randomly to keep his band mates offguard and instinctually attentive throughout the show. After all, this IS Tony we're talking about. And he never disappoints...One thing about the liner credits I take issue with is that Ron Carter is not listed on bass, but rather Albert Stinson - I've listened to far too many recordings by these guys to know that NO pick-up player could possibly play at this frenzy w/o dropping notes and ultimately embarrass himself (though Stinson is undoubtedly a great player) - this IS Ron Carter for sure; just listen to his playing, it's unmistakable, IMO. There would be a huge vacancy if it was anyone else, and this music is as dense as the Amazon jungle was 100 years ago.This is a historic document of great importance to practitioners of Miles' voodoo and the legendary Quartet that deserves capitalization when referred to, so casual listeners should take note. Pick up the Berlin, Japan or Philharmonic live recordings that have been painstakingly remastered instead. But if you're a voracious fan or collector like me, it really doesn't get much sweeter than this. After all these years, how many more unheard of gems can we possibly hope for? Besides, it would only be a few months until this group dissolved, and we have almost nothing to caress as live documents from this period.The cd comes with a booklet w/ a Melody Maker interview Miles did in 1968 that's hysterical as he trashes his trumpet peers, along w/ some great, rarely seen photos of Miles. Staunch supporters of this man and his bandmates will enjoy this in spite of and because of its aural weaknesses. Who lives in an ideal world? Not me. 5 stars.

I'm not a big reader of Zenescope graphic novels - most appear to be selling T&A (of which I am a big fan, IF used correctly) and seem light on plotlines + development. But I am a huge fan of certain reinventions + reimaginings, like the Bride of Frankenstein, rewritten here. So I gave it a shot + was more than compensated for my suspended beliefs, and heartily recommend this to anyone who enjoys the Frankenstein mythos, X-Files and visceral balls-to-the-wall carnage + hyper-violence.Add a bit of Nazi backstory, severely dysfunctional family dynamics, a dash of Sapphic subplot, a dollop of conspiratorial cover-ups, then heavily pepper the dialogue with cutting edge cursing, wicked sarcasm + cultural references, and you've got yourself one helluva story w/ great artwork that can't be put down.  Read 2 pages and you're 'Screwed'...

A lot has already been said about these on Amazon, so I won't rehash too much, but I have a few points to add. While I love these for what they are - light, almost brushlike but w/ more sound and oomph, an interesting, shimmering  sound on hi-hats + rides, great for not wanting to sound too loud, etc - It's what they're not that irks me.They sound completely dead + have no bounceback on toms, the bamboo isn't top shelf, so that they breakdown, splinter, fray on rims very easily, but the major annoyance is that the rods come out of the PVC almost immediately + constantly have to be pushed back in - a thin strip of gaffers tape where the 2 PVC pieces are helps tremendously, but doesn't eradicate the problem entirely. Because then the inner rods start to come forward and they too have to be pushed back in place. It's a design flaw that you don't need a scientist to solve, just better proactive design. Anyone heard of glue? A dollop at the bottom would work wonders...And if you dig in w/ them at all, the foam core comes out, so these multiple issues make them  great but frustrating at the same time.I play match grip, so I'm hitting the rims more than a traditional grip player would, so the quick deterioration of the bamboo may have something to do w/ that. Maybe not. The Hotrods I've used last considerably longer, but I'm not a huge fan of them either for my own reasons.So as long as you're prepared to deal w/ these issues + plan on keeping several pairs around due to their limited lifespan, these are a sweet alternative to sticks or brushes 'cause they sorta straddle the line between both - it's the best + worst of both worlds.But, as in any relationship, it's the give + take that counts, right?(If you're looking for something a bit beefier that sounds more like sticks but still not too loud and very controllable, and something that takes a beating - pun intended - and lasts longer + thus far hasn't come apart like the Tala Wand - and again, I'm a fan, sorta - try the Vic Firth Rute. It's more steroidal in thickness, sound attack and construction, sounds much better on toms and I've beat them like red-headed stepchildren w/o any issues - yet).

I've been voraciously inhaling the Creepy + Eerie Archives masterfully compiled by Dark Horse, and it's come time to house them in their own bookcase as showpieces in my library. What better way to draw attention to our gory, goulish guardians of said library than to perch these two fiendish friends atop the bookcase? I got the Uncle Creepy last year(very impressive), but for some strange reason thought Ol'Cuz Eerie wasn't going to be all that, and brother was I wrong. I just got him last week, and he's  as impressive, maybe more so, than our uncomely Uncle.First, he's incredibly heavy (solid resin), of enormous stature, same height as Unca Creepy,but his rotund proportions make him look much bigger. (As you fans know, he's always depicted as much smaller in the mags when saddled up to his ugly Unc). He's massively brutish and heebie-jeebie ridden. In a cage fight, my coin's on our Cuz...Secondly, but most importantly, the sculpts executed by Tony Cipriano are amazing on both characters, much better than they've ever been portrayed in print. Facial details are fiendish, costumes are detailed brilliantly, great color choices and bases are perfect. Well-executed paintjobs too, considering they're probably done in 3rd world countries by child labor...but I digress, this review is about our beloved bastions of the macabre, and master T.Cip's hit another home run horror collectible here - how does he DO it? Each statue is limited to 500 hand-numbered pieces and comes in an (un)handsomely collectible box.Long story short (well, for me), you NEED these in your loathesome library and shocker statues. Ask any Cryptkeeper...

As a longtime reader and admirer (for obvious reasons) of Howard's Red Sonja and sword and sorcery in general, I usually pick up all the Dynamite collections of her exploits. Especially when Lucio Parrillo is doing her covers, as I consider him to be the finest artist/painter working in this genre today. One look at the cover and I was in.This edition collects the stand-alone four-issue story arc offspring of the Red Sonja series, and the story is good, though nothing we as fans haven't read before. But, as fans, if you're fond of this character, it's an enjoyable read. As good as some tales, but not as good as most collections, IMO. But my real problem was the vibrant neon colors and just OK artwork, which left me wanting something darker to saddle up properly with the storyline. This cheapened the entire effort for me. You look at Parrillo's artwork and go "Whoa", then view the story art and go "Eh..." Max Dunbar's pencilwork just didn't do it for me - but you may feel differently.Long story short, 'Atlantis Rises', though your personal excitement level may not. 3 1/2 stars.

Having grown up with this album and being especially influenced by these artists as a young musician, I was both eager and skeptical of this release, but decided to pull the trigger and hope that ammo wasn't wasted. It far exceeded my expectations by a longshot, and all true aficionados of music should be required to own this DVD. Not just watch it, but give it repeated listenings - it's the best music DVD I've seen since 'Jeff Beck - Live at Ronnie Scotts' from a few years ago. Yup, it's that good.Both McLaughlin and Carlos are in top form, and instead of each playing a set with their own bands and unifying for an overbloated finale (like a lot of these concert pairings), both bands are blended (I'll refrain from using the word 'Fused') throughout the concert without the potentially disasterous clashing of musical egos and artistic overarching from guys of this caliber. Roles are established and egos kept checked until your space was allotted, at which point you could break loose and raise hell, which happened frequently.What also thrilled me was the selection of tracks - in addition to the classic 'Love, Devotion, Surrender' tracks and reprise, we're treated to compositions by John Coltrane, Bob Dylan, Miles, Led Zep, Pharoah Sanders, Wayne Shorter, Sonny Sharrock and Tony Williams Lifetime, which was the highpoint for me. Here, Cindy Blackman channeled Tony like no one else could (she was his student) and gave McLaughlin the kick in the ass he needed to resurrect some of the blistering, visceral psych-acid-jazzrock fretwork we don't always hear from him anymore. Two astonishing tracks worth the price alone. And don't get me started on Cindy's drum solo, another tribute to her mentor Tony Williams, who Santana calls "probably the greatest drummer who ever lived" - this said in front of his newlywed wife, the best female drummer on the planet (at least the one I live on)! I felt sorry for Dennis Chambers, another monsterous skinbasher, who was relegated to Cindy's shadow most of the night.I could go on, but 'There Comes A Time' when you no longer need to convert the musical mind - if you love great guitarists, virtuoso musicians, near-flawless vocabulary and execution, perfect pacing and performances by egoless giants, and just want to sit mesmerized with the cat-who-just-ate-the-canary look on your face, you need this, as in yesterday. This is your 'Invitation'.

Red Sonja, Volume VI: Death - Dynamite Entertainment} This compelling collection contains issues #30-34 of the ongoing series. Red Sonja sacrificed her life to rid the world of the villainy of age-old demon Kulan Gath and now finds herself travelling with a mysterious Ferryman along the River Styx. When asked by Sonja where their final destination is, the Boatman replies, "To the river's end, where you will be judged". Her reply is curt; "I will be judged by no one - any who died by my hand richly deserved their fate". Not entirely true, as we come to learn, as there was much collateral damage caused by her actions in life, and she now has to confront such events and reflect on her responsibilities as a warrior whose single-mindedness left many fatalities in her wake. Epic battles and past pivotal moments are relived for our entertainment and excitement, whether it be for the incendiary incidents depicted or for the scantily clad she-demon we pine and pant for. 'Doesn't matter either way, our money and time here is as well-spent as her adversaries.The ending has its share of thrilling twists and circular storyboarding ("Same as it ever was, same as it ever was") that's supremely satisfying to aficionados of the series, so don't let this collection slip downstream - you'll be sorry you did when judgment comes round. Even in a savage, eerie underworld, it takes a strong sword arm to survive...The cover is by Alex Ross, the cover gallery includes luminaries like Fabiano Neves (who even illustrates an entire story - rare that is!) and Paul Reynaud (both also do transfixing Vampirella covers regularly), Adriano Batista and Ken Kelly. Impressive lot of talent, and remarkable writers include Ron Marz, Lee Moder, Pablo Marcos, Luke Lieberman and Brian Reed - 'can't go wrong with this one, gents...

{Red Sonja, Volume VIII: Blood Dynasty - Dynamite Entertainment} This astutely compelling and imaginative volume collects issues #41 through 49 of the ongoing series. All lovers of Conan, Sinbad, Kull, Jason and the Argonauts, Ulysses, Hercules, Tarzan, hell, even Vampirella will find much to enjoy here. The eight issue saga begins and ends within this volume, which is true of most of the Red Sonja collections, unlike other character volumes, where there's still no conclusion after 2 or 3 collections, which always leaves me (and you) hanging for closure. Sure, this tale requires some backstory, but it's adequately provided in either dialogue or flashback, so we can all stay up to speed and enjoy the journey forward. And this is quite the journey.While I found a few early compilations not revving at full-throttle (maybe it's me), volumes six, seven and eight are forceful, tightly composed, artistically rewarding and impossible to put down. Brian Reed can give Ron Marz and his ilk a run for their money with the story arc presented while still paying homage to Robert E. Howard properly. Walter Geovani does fine art duty here, especially when it comes to his interpretation of the title character. Powerful, sexual, visceral, she's the ultimate sword and sorcery pedigree of broadsword badassery.The cover gallery is also outstanding - Great covers by Paul Reynaud, Fabiano Neves (who both do excellent Vampirella covers), Mel Rubi, and Adriano Batista all make Red Sonja larger than life as the decisive harbinger heroine of death.Try this on for size; I think you'll find it a nice fit. 5 stars.

I don't really understand folks who claim to love Eurohorror, but won't watch films that are subtitled. Anyone with an 8th grade education can read subs, and seeing these classics dubbed by people who do cartoonish voiceovers is nothing more than insulting - to the viewer, to the director, to the actors involved, to the viewing experience. The entire film's focal point is diverted to the gutter and suffers as a whole. Many casual viewers will disagree, but devotees understand my point completely. The English-dubbed version is wretched to listen to - you will not hear ANY of the actual actors real voices, and the flick suffers as much as the viewer does who wastes his/her time screening it. How do I know this? I've seen it in BOTH languages, and it's like two completely different movies...First off, these are Bava films, so you either love his late-60's work or hate it, period. The same things that we fans of his later 60's output love are usually the very same things that turn others off. So I'm not going to spend a lot of time reviewing the actual movie itself, but rather what's on display in them - the luscious Euro babes with big, teased hair and false eyelashes, the accompanying mini-skirts, go-go boots and chain belts, the futuristic furniture, accessories and decor (the same stuff that's resurgently popular today), the elaborate architecture and European landscapes, the cool cars, the extravagant, permissive lifestyles and hedonistic parties and, of course, Edwige Fenech.I realize that these things have nothing to do with whether these are good movies or not, but I also know I'm not alone in my rabid fascination for all things from this particular time period, and that WILL have an impact on whether you enjoy these films. Derivitive plot? Sure. Annoying soundtrack? Yup. Predictable outcome? Absolutely. It's akin to Agatha Christie on acid. So if the plot steers off course here and there while enjoying the visual feast on display as described above, who cares? Besides, Bava displays a black sense of humor here that's not present in most of his work outside of his few comedies.I'm giving it 4 stars because, although flawed, I don't want folks to think it's a cinematic clunker - it's of of Bava's minor gems that's not often seen or available in the states, but definitely worth your time + attention if you enjoy seeing the master having some fun while delivering the gothic goods with a late 60's psych feel, unbelievable architecture, and a cast that includes the luscious Edwige Fenech in one of her first truly sexy and memorable roles. It's a relentless mod murder mystery and pristine parade of eye-candy and loungy, kitschy atmosphere, peppered with sultry sex and murder as only Bava can pull off effectively. But do yourself a favor and watch it in Italian w/ subs to see, taste, feel and enjoy it as it was meant to be.

[STEED and MRS. PEEL, Volume 1 - A VERY CIVIL ARMEGEDDON - 2013] I must admit, I was leery about this one, being a Cold War kid who grew up watching this iconic TV show as soon as it hit the states on ABC (back when networks mattered, of which there were then only three) and not wanting to see it reimagined or rebooted, let alone being brought into today's techworld. After all, can you imagine Steed on a cell phone texting, tweeting, using an Ipad app, or checking his social media status instead of driving around in vintage autos, wearing his Bowler hat and custom-made suits, and sipping fine brandies and clarets? Heaven forbid.And, thankfully, this did not happen. What we are presented with is a perfectly paced, wonderfully witty, faithful to the extreme episode of the Avengers (screw Disney and Marvel for buying the rights to the name for the superhero franchise, which I also loved as a kid) as we knew it then. Bravo. It starts just like the fittingly formulaic episodes, even down to the campy, colorful titles along with the 'Steed feels his age, Emma turns back time' wordplay and the "Mrs. Peel, We're Needed" prologue before each story begins - it's absolutely classic. The witty, cheeky repartee between Emma and Steed is there in all its barbed glory, the whole 60's Spy thing played for both thrills and laughs, the archetypal villains abound, the finale is exact in its execution leaving a wry smile on one's lips, there's absolutely nothing missing for aficionados of this British dynamic duo. It's faultless to a tee and comes highly recommended.The artwork (for the most part) is close enough to the characters images a majority of the time, but periodically lacks in detailed facial resemblances, yet at other moments is spot-on. The look and color scheme is very 60's, and the cover gallery and sketches at the book's ending is both extensive and beyond fabulous. Joseph Michael Linsner does 4 or 5 astonishing paintings of Mrs. Peel that capture every nuance of her look and character right down to her patented perky, sexy, dimpled smile, and he wardrobes her in the most stylishly mod jumpsuits that left young men back then in puddles of drool. Why did we not have women who dressed like that on this side of the pond? But I digress - just hit the 'buy it now' button and be done with it; you'll thank me later. As soon as I finished this, I pre-ordered the second volume which will be out on November 5th, in hardcover no less.(A word of caution to the young'ins though - if you didn't have exposure to the show and characters and have no reverence for the past, you're not likely to find much here for your Transformers-and-apocalyptic-supervillians-from-galaxies-beyond and CGI laced 3D acid trips that began as comics - this is noteworthy nostalgia for those who prefer more earthly and subtle entertainment. You know - ornery old codgers like moi.)

Absolutely superb likeness, detail and articulation of Spidey's archnemesis, the Green Goblin, that one could hope for. Expertly cast, perfectly painted, astonishing details in his facial features, hands, costuming and pumpkin. Delightfully creepy and larger than most Goblin busts, which usually don't come with full arms, hands or a full back profile. This impressive, expressive  and extremely limited edition likeness is a waist-up replica of one of comics most feared and beloved villians. In the 60's, he was to Spidey what the Joker was to Batman - crazed, comical, fearsome, menacing and hand-wringingly welcome in every issue he appeared in, unlike the movie version which, truth be told, absolutely sucked. The only better bust on the market (at time of this review) is Sideshow's Green Goblin bust, which I also own, but is much more expensive. This is the best pumpkin bang for your buck; a treasured example of what made Marvel magnanamous both then and now. Highly recommended.

Unfortunately, this is the weakest thing I've read by Ron Marz, who has never disappointed me prior to this. It's not bad, mind you, it has its moments, but its over-ambitious storyline is never fully developed to truly come to fruition. This 'kitchen-sink' tale has too many characters and suffers because none of them ever come to the foreground long enough to satisfy those who bought it for their love of a particular character. I'm a huge Vampirella fan, and she has a fair amount of page space, but not enough to satiate me. Red Sonja, Dracula, Sherlock Holmes? They're only peripheral figures as well, just like everyone else. Too many chiefs and not enough Indians, and the tale seems truncated in many areas. Over-arching is its own undoing here - if it went on for more than its seven-issue run, it might have accomplished more, it needed to accomplish more, and promised to. But it fell back on the sword of its promise and died an early death.As a fan of all the characters presented here, I wanted to love it so much more than I did. Maybe my expectations were too high, but my disappointment was equally high. And I am a fan of Ron Marz, I've read almost everything with his name on it, just to be clear. The plot is almost identical to the one he wrote for his 'Artifacts' series, volumes 1-3 in TP, and there he had the luxury to plumb the plot properly, develop his characters and story in a way that's barely fleshed-out in this saga. My thought - if he scaled back a few characters, he would be able to make better use of them and thereby fulfill his audience's dreams and expectancies adequately.At the price it's offered for here, it's still worth a read for the curious, just don't expect the greatness guaranteed in theory by assembling the magnanimous cast in the credits. Which is a shame... 3 stars.

[SO YOUNG, SO LOVELY, SO VICIOUS - (1975) - Directed by Silvio Amadio - Widescreen presentation] Usually listed (and incorrectly so) as a gaillo, this film has more in common with trashy soap operas than the black-gloved, fetishistic serial killings of Bava, Argento, Sergio and Luciano Martino, Freda or their kin. It's actually a coarse retelling of Otto Preminger's excellent 'Bonjour Tristesse', minus any of the estimable aspects of that film, and should be avoided by all except stalwart fans of Gloria Guida and Dagmar Lassander.Angela (Gloria Guida), fresh out of high school, picks up her father from the airport, whom she hasn't seen in a year, and finds out he's planning on remarrying a woman named Irene (Dagmar Lassander) very soon. This doesn't sit well with Angela, and she does everything she can to insure that this union never sees fruition. She has her boyfriend attempt seducing her to no avail and then, after digging into Irene's past and finding mental abuse traumas stemming from a former lesbian relationship, decides she'll seduce Irene herself. This takes up three-quarters of the film, though we do see Gloria naked constantly insuring we never get too bored (truth be told, this doesnt work out nearly as well as you'd think), and Dagmar looks great in several of her costumes/outfits, but never gets undressed (somehow, as demented as this sounds, this makes her sexier as a result).When the Sapphic session between the older woman and the nubile girl finally does take place on a secluded beach setting, it's photographed by Angela's boyfriend to be utilized as a blackmail tool afterwards. As you'd expect, Angela has a sudden change of heart upon realizing Irene isn't the witch she once believed and now wants the negatives destroyed, Irene regrets the tryst and decides she must leave at once for the good of all concerned, but the boyfriend needs cash and still wants to go through with the blackmail. Irene is pushed beyond the breaking point, and the predictable tragedy results.A tawdry, sleazy 70's soap, this flick has precious little going for it apart from the soft-core elements, of which there are more than a fair share, but still somehow left me cold. And I have a high tolerance for the tedious when it comes to exploitation from the 70's. Recommended to hard-core Gloria Guida fans only. So young, so lovely, and oh so boring... 2 1/2 stars.

I got this item as part of Amazon's 4-for-3 sale program and no idea what I was getting into. The story makes for ridiculous reading, but I didn't read the first volume, so that may have something to do with it. But my gut tells me, probably not.It's reminiscent of a 'Heavy Metal' magazine story with the sexual elements cranked up to a Spinal Tap eleven, if you know what I mean. Futuristic, fetishistic women from another dimension feverishly fornicating with humanoid aliens on a meteor presumably (who really cares?) that are massively, monumentally endowed, and this continues for the duration of the entire book, which is its major strength. And then there's some Tarzan-type sexual gymnastics that are tossed our way, again with not much sense attached, but nonsensically entertaining nonetheless. I have little time to care about plotlines when I pick up an item of this sort. If I did, I might scratch my head in wonder; instead I ponder how these women hide the swollen girth and livestock-sized genitalia that they enjoy with shameless abandon. Anatomically impossible and hyper-erotic. And the women are a joy to behold, though in no way realistic either, with insatiable, aroused appetites of biblical proportions, assuming we're talking Sodom and Gomorrah. Ain't life grand?If you enjoy this sort of stuff, it's recommended. You do the math...

[ZETA ONE (AKA THE LOVE FACTOR) - 1969 - directed by Michael Cort - Widescreen] An early (and somewhat embarrassing) example of late 60's British sexploitation comedies, 'Zeta One' (originally titled 'The Love Factor') serves up a decent portion of softcore nudity, trippy psychedelic scenery, some unintentionally hysterical dialogue, some uncomfortable attempts at real comedy and, unfortunately, very little else. Except for a few beloved Hammer film Euro-lovelies like Valerie Leon, Dawn Addams, Anna Gael, Carole Hawkins and Yutte Stensgaard. And therein lies its worth.'Zeta One' was based on a short lived European photo-magazine that obsessed (rightfully so) on beautiful models scantily clad in futuristic clothing. At its liveliest, the film contains recreations of kinky photo-shoot favorites like catfights and fetish-fashioned femmes in torture chamber tableau, as well as colorful scenes of 'alien' women discreetly disguised in identical black wigs and thigh-high Carnaby Street fashions. Sounds fantastic, right? I thought so too, having a genetic weakness for 60's fashions and the bountiful babes who wore them. So shoot me, I was wrong. The original Salvation DVD release gave this as a synopsis - "A race of topless, large-breasted women from the planet Angvia, in another dimension, come to earth to kidnap women to repopulate their planet". Huh? And how might they procreate, if you don't mind my asking? And would you mind terribly if I watched? See, now there's your problem - when you screen flicks like this, these details shouldn't matter, 'cause most men stopped reading right after the "race of large-breasted women" part, and that's how it should be.The film's first quarter of an hour is a mercilessly motionless card game between Robin Hordon (the wooden male lead of 'When Dinosaurs Ruled the Earth'), playing a poor man's James Bond, and office secretary Yutte Stensgaard as they drink, deliver pages of inconsequential dialogue and make furtive eyes at one other. Despite containing the film's first show of flesh, as they're playing strip-poker, this is pedantic padding at its most painful and just goes on forever. Eventually Hordon narrates flashbacks of some "very extraordinary business" concerning the Angvians, an interstellar race of women who kidnap lovely girls then brainwash them with kaleidoscopic optical effects. One such abductee gets hustled into a car by Angvian women in broad daylight then treated to a guided tour of their futuristic lair, which resembles the set of a children's TV program. Angvian headquarters includes such acid-induced deliriums as the 'Contemplation Room', the 'Self-Revelation Room' and let's not forget the unflappable 'Static Time Area' (as if we could). Where's 'Star Trek' era William Shatner when you need him most?  'Still with me? Frankly, I'm shocked...The cinematic 'climax' serves as the film's inglorious highlight with stunning starlets as alien women running naked around the British countryside freezing their backsides off while pretending to fire invisible rays from their hands, and trying (in one instance failing) not to break out laughing. Whilst Eurovixen Brigitte Skay managed to drum up a fair amount of publicity for the film - photos of her in a revealing space-age bikini earned 'Zeta One' the cover of both Continental Film Review and Cinema X magazine - it wasn't until the 1995 video re-release that the film really found an audience, having since gone on to achieve a degree of novelty status due to many of its female cast members (nearly) finding success in Hammer horror and 'Carry On' comedy roles. Not that many of these actresses have fond memories of the production, mind you. Yutte Stensgaard claimed she felt exploited by her then father-in-law/manager who in a surreptitious turn didn't tell her about her nude scenes until she arrived on set, while the late Imogen Hassall was known to joke that a higher force must have been guiding her the day she turned down the role of an Angvian angel. Valerie Leon's sole memory of the production was that one-movie director and screenwriter Michael Cort being a somewhat strange bloke. Then again, if you've seen this film, you've probably guessed that already.It's as simple as this - if you've got a penchant for silly 60's sexploitation films with knock-out babes running rampant topless in pendulum-swinging retro fashions, you'll enjoy it (once). Everybody else needs to avoid this one entirely, or you'll think you got stuck in the 'Static Time Area' indefinitely.

Raven Gregory has constructed a caustic, cautionary yet comical tale here concerning every man's buried fantasy; you know, the one where we wish we were attractive, make that irresistible, to every desirable woman we encounter. And, as a by-product, a few undesirable ones, but hey, ya gotta roll with the punches sometimes, right? Besides, it does a heart good to throw somebody a charity boning just to give something back to the community, yes? It's the stuff of legends, and it's plumbed here with great results.So we have a loser here whose woman dumped him and left him in a world of suck over a year ago and now performs a selfless good deed and is granted one wish by the woman he saved from a mugging in an alleyway one night. He mentions he'd like not to be invisible to the ladies, not have to eat alone in a woman's prison, him being the pathetic piss-ant that he is. Next thing you know, every babe in toyland wants to bang his brains out, but he can't understand why. Suddenly, the world is his oyster (or clam, if you get the drift), and the finest female flesh is lining up for a shagging.Unfortunately, as soon as he screws their lights in (and out), they go all Jodi Arias on him - clinging, possessive, stalking and demanding him all to themselves. So the dream quickly descends into a nightmare before you can say 'restraining order' - it's a  classic take on the "Careful what you wish for" adage, and our newfound hero is still shackled to his hellhole of a world gone awry. And he's still unmercifully stuck on the bitch who dumped him, so he tries to track down the old woman who 'blessed' him with this woebegotten wish and have the spell reversed. Which ain't as easy as all that, trust me on this. Now things get really interesting, but you shouldn't know more than that before picking this one up for yourself.My only minor gripe is that I think Gregory could've expanded and enhanced this storyline, fleshed it out a bit more (what's wrong with a bit more flesh?), it seems a bit short. Another issue in the story arc would have really hit this one out of the park, and a tad more nudity would've aided as well. The dialogue is filthy as hell, and there is some mild exposed flesh (a breast here, a butt there), but nothing that equals the degeneracy of the dialogue, so there's an imbalance present that needn't be. What is here is gold, but a little extra helping of the aforementioned things would make this piece platinum. That's the only thing holding back the fifth star for this reader, but it's still an entertaining and engaging read for all redblooded hetero males everywhere.There's  the usual cover gallery, which is great and welcomed, but some shameless promos for two other Raven Gregory graphic novels pads out the remainder of the book, so the story page count you think you're getting when you sign up for this novella is truncated by the promo bits. Which is a slight drag, but not a detractor that would make you shy away from this otherwise "Irresistible" effort. Imagine this event happened to you, and think how you might have coped differently...

[The Sex Thief AKA Her Family Jewels - 1973 - 88 minutes - directed by Martin Campbell - Widescreen]  The late David Warbeck (who later appeared in three Lucio Fulci horror films in the 80’s and a ton of other films) stars as Grant Henry AKA the Sex Thief in this silly but surprising 1973 British sex comedy. A writer of trashy paperbacks, Henry moonlights as a masked jewel thief who is usually caught in the act but lures his female captors to bed. He is a criminal by choice, not by necessity. Bedroom gyno-gymnast that he is, the women all lie to the authorities about his identity and secretly hope to get burgled again and again.A shameless Hollywood producer and a ditzy blonde wannabe movie star try to drum up publicity by claiming that the notorious thief assaulted her. Enraged and engorged that his name has been tarnished, our beloved Sex Thief purchases a toy gun and stalks the actress. In a forced apartment entry, he catches her in the bath before the pair passionately reenact her made up fantasy scenario. Typically dimwitted and corrupt cops more interested in peddling contraband blue movies (porn in today’s vernacular) than catching the thief also become involved for comedic effect. Despite the softcore stereotype of the British sex-comedy film, this one is fairly well made and occasionally funny, mildly sexy and  a fairly flagrant female fleshfest. Michael Armstrong, who acts in the film as a breast obsessed cop, wrote the screenplay under the demonic alter ego Edward Hyde, is most familiar to exploitation fans for the much maligned and frequently banned ‘Mark of the Devil’ as well as the autobiographical ‘Eskimo Nell’, another Brit sex comedy from that time. The version of this flick known as ‘Her Family Jewels’, had brief notoriety when it resurfaced with some hardcore insertions before being yanked (puns intended) from circulation. Another discovery is actress Gloria Walker AKA Gloria Maley who went from being well-worked over by Warbeck's buzzing stimulator here to providing the blood and guts special effects for 1980’s ‘Inseminoid’ (ugh) - a more diverse career move is hard to imagine. ‘The Sex Thief’ marginally rises above the typical British sexploitation comedy from that era thanks to some pointed raunchiness, a somewhat subversive script and a charismatic leading man. Oh yeah, and a boatload of nudity, which is the only reason to watch flicks like these. No one under 40 will appreciate it, it’s for old codgers (like me) to wax nostalgic over, remember the miniskirts, fashions and marvel at how different times were and how women looked then.The remastered edition is in widescreen, where earlier editions were only available in full screen, and a decent clean-up of picture, color and contrast are noticeable. So if you want to recapture stolen moments from the bygone era of your wayward youth and pilfer a snicker or three in the process, snatch yourself a copy of ‘The Sex Thief’. All else should consider yourself duly warned.

[BARBARIAN CHICKS AND DEMONS, Volume 1 - Erich Hartmann - 2008] Want a deliciously twisted medieval history lesson rife with sexual degeneracy? Who doesn’t? Well, here it is, gents, and it’s brimming with page after page of great graphics and neorealist illustrations depicting some truly perverse ‘Decamerotica’. Each chapter even has a coherent storyline, sarcastic banter and a twist for an ending in most situations (not that it really matters, but it sure helps). It’s clever, concise and delivers exactly what you’re looking for when you get the hankering for filthy, smutty fun.We’re treated to naughty nuns, Inquisitors, barbarians, priapian priests, fertility spells and idols, decadent castle guards, endowed servants, scheming merchants, pagan rituals, demons, succubii, compromised virgins and female sexual predators. It’s perfect. The sexual scenarios are many, varied, graphically portrayed and as life-like as you can get in a graphic novel. And the women aren’t victims for the most part; they frequently turn the tables on the men, knowing we don’t usually think with our larger heads. Great stuff. There’s not much more that can be said without being censored or offending the ‘sensitive’ minds of some readers here, but I can honestly state that this is what you want in a digest of this type. Erich Hartmann has done an incredible job, and as soon as I finished this volume, I threw 2 more of his works in my cart. Highly recommended.

[GIRL IN CAPTIVITY; PSYCHO TORTURE CHAMBER - 2008 - 74 minutes - Japanese w/ English subtitles] This entry from Cinema Epoch's Tokyo Erotique series is better than some of their other releases, as it avoids most of the clichéd story traps we've come to accept as part of our Asian exploitation adventures. Not your typical women in prison, cages, forced factory slaves or nympho killing machines - not that I'm critical of such trash; after all, how do you think I became Dr.NoItAll in various exploitation circles?  (And I'm still not certain this is something I should be proud or shamed of...).A cute Asian teen (possibly very young adult) awakens in a strange boiler room, chained to pipes, realizing she's been kidnapped by possibly the most bizarre captor I've seen (outside of a horror torture porn flick) - what appears to be a Sumo wrestler with a gas mask and voice camouflage who enters the room like he's headed for a WWF cage fight.  Thankfully for the teen, this isn't the case; it's just a bout of fondling and "Getting to know you, getting to know all about you", before he does a few Sumo warm-ups, demanding that she "Cheer for him... with vivacity", then exits, stage left.The hostage is the daughter of a tycoon who's on the verge of a large corporate merger in Beijing and might be being blackmailed for an ongoing affair he's been having with his personal secretary - but the kidnapper's true intentions are kept mysterious. The negotiations boil down to "Cancel the merger and I release your daughter" - it's obvious the kidnapper knows the father, but from where?Not to worry, we're treated to twofold sexcapades - sexual scenarios of the father's infidelities with his secretary as well as those between hostage and captor. The first is fairly straightforward, the second fairly perverse. Nothing heinous or horribly shocking though (then again, I'm numb to a lot of bats*** crazy stuff). Add a bit of Stockholm Syndrome, a surprise identity revealed, some more flesh, a few deaths and an almost touching ending and you have a slightly different take on transgressive cinema. It's worth a gander for those reasons alone. And, thankfully, there's no real torture going on. I was sick of that drivel years ago.This is much better than the 'Girl in Captivity; Hitwoman in Chains 2' IMO. In the final analysis, it's just more Asian exploitation, or `Exploit-Asian' as I call it, but if you've read this far, we're choir mates, so sing for the psycho and the `Girl in Captivity'. 4 stars (for this genre entry).

How many times do you read a graphic novel that actually makes you think while you read? How many make you stop reading to examine the dark, offbeat and unique spin of the artwork page by page as you're doing so? And how few do you pick up again after you've finished reading to re-examine each page several times to marvel and make sure you didn't miss a detail or nuance? This obscure gem is one of those very few that make these things happen, and therein lays just some of its greatness.Part psychological horror, part noir-ish murder mystery, part existential terror tale with hefty helpings of gothic dread, implausible peripheral characters and visceral phantasmagoria all make this a suspenseful read, and I'm not easily impressed nor a huge fan of your typical graphic novels. But I was mesmerized by this one, enough to read it again the next day. The philosophical questions asked alone make you take pause to ponder their implications at several points during the read, but aren't ponderous or off-putting - it's not trying to impress with its intelligence or self-importance, let's be clear about that. This is entertainment that enlightens, assuming you let it. But it's still cool if you don't. Either way, it's a riveting read.It's difficult to describe, but it involves marginalized people with dark secrets who end up in a place called Green Wake, unaware of how they got there and unable to leave. Most are so dysfunctional, disenfranchised and mentally destitute they don't speak to anyone and rarely venture outdoors. Except the two male protagonists, who've taken it upon themselves to act as both detectives determined to discover why they're suddenly residents and act as welcoming committee to the newly arrived, to assist with the shock of this huge void. And suddenly there's a rash of grisly murders all connected to one female inhabitant who apparently snapped and clings to the darkness that envelops all who reside at Green Wake, a place where it's always night and next to nothing makes sense. A purgatory or limbo of squalor that has far too many dark secrets, nightmarish visions and an unusually ever-growing population of frogs. Frogs?To say more would deprive you of the surreal psychosis that waits should you elect to find yourself entrenched in the pages of 'Green Wake'.Highly recommended. So 'Wake' up.

[China and Sex - 1994 - directed by Joe D'Amato (using the name Robert Yip) - 90 minutes - Full Frame] MYA's DVD for China and Sex is a typically mediocre affair from the label whose name is an acronym for 'Mislead Your Audience'. It features a sub-par full frame transfer that looks no better than it might have on VHS. There's plenty of damage to the print and no restoration was even attempted. The film is fuzzy overall, lacks contrast of any kind and the colors are decidedly washed out. The two-channel mono sound isn't much to celebrate, but it's better than the image. Dialogue is clear enough, but any music or background noise is too diminished to really notice. And, typical of MYA, there are no extras. Predictable MYA fodder, abusive to those who purchase their products, which has become more than tedious through time (read my other reviews of MYA'S travesties, as I'm tired of trashing their releases here on Amazon).Content wise, this film echoes many of the themes that D'Amato explored in his similarly-themed and equally awful film 'Chinese Kamasutra', which he also did under the name Robert Yip. The plot revolves around a dancer named Tama, who works at a sleazy brothel, but is unattainable unlike the other girls there (how does this work? You're there to make money and degrade yourself in the process, right? Am I missing something regarding the rules of engagement in such an establishment?). She is not the type of woman that money can buy; in fact the only way in which someone gets to spend the night with her is if they are chosen by her. Enter a wealthy man who sets his sights on her, only to be spurned time and time again. It is only when he is willing to let everything he has go that she finally picks him. Unfortunately what he seeks may not be what he is ultimately looking for. Let's just say that pleasure and pain goes hand in hand when it comes to conquering Tama. The erection-eradicating and shocking ending is the film's only merit, if you could call it that, but most of you will have drifted off long before it arrives. Oh Joe, what have ye done to us now?People who actively seek out the films of Joe D'Amato have no real reason to skip 'China and Sex', but it's weaknesses are apparent from the get go. When Joe has his heart in a flick, the results can be surprising. That isn't the case here; the same can be said of any of his films from the 90's (except his hardcore flicks, which were far better than any of his soft-core sleep-aids from this period). It's worse than most of his work and features some very unintentionally funny, ultra-pretentious dialogue. It's a terrible movie by any employable standard of calibration, even by low-rent exploitation standards, and everybody else should definitely skip it. Save your coin and order Chinese take-out instead.

[Tranceptor: Iron Gauge - Part One] I was unfamiliar with Michael Manning's work until I received this, but after reading reviews of his various works here on Amazon, my expectations were high. Maybe too high, which could be a fault of my own. Then again...The story is weak (not a real problem, as this is not generally why we buy such material), the artwork was adequate but far from mind-blowing (I've seen better, much better), and there was too little of what I signed on for - adult material. It's more of a second rate comic with a bit of explicit sex peppered here and there, instead of a full blown (pun intended) sexual saga. Frankly, I was disappointed, unlike most of the other reviewers here. I wrote my two cents so that potential buyers could acquaint themselves with the other side of the coin before making a purchase they might not be enthralled with, as I was. Mildly erotic and entertaining, but falls short of the brilliance expected after reading so many other reviews. Your call.

[Visions of Giovannna -2003- 46 pages] Italian illustrator and sexual exhibitionist Giovanna Casotto does a nice job of placing herself under our microscopes while engaging in fairly pedestrian sexcapades (meaning there's nothing kinky or transgressive going on here) that are well drawn and realistic. Meaning everyone's endowments are realistically proportioned and not hyper-exaggerated as in most examples of this 'artform'.She takes photos of the scenarios (how does one apply for this job, is what I kept asking myself) and then almost traces them to look as lifelike as possible. It's mostly pencil and ink, with washes of muted color added, so it's not comic-booky but higher caliber embellished illustrations. There are seven scenarios staged within, all male/female or female/female, but all conjured seductively for our hetero-hijinks. Very European, very graphic, as it should be if you're gonna bother with this sort of thing (which seems quaint and archaic in today's world of gonzo cyber-porn and what's available right outside our doors), but also makes me wonder how many do read these anymore for just those exact reasons?Anyway, if you appreciate an almost classy (I know, oxymoronic) European fumetti form of erotica, this isn't half-bad, and for those that obviously do, it's rather enticing and enjoyable. Rest assured, this is no 'Tijuana bible'. (Too)short, sweet and to the point. And the raincoats are optional.

[Vampirella Volume 1: Crown of Worms TP - Eric Trautmann, author - 2011 - Dynamite Publications]For my money, the newer Vampi stories written by Eric Trautmann are among the best and truest to our beloved character, never looking backward, never ignoring what has come before, and always improving on the elements we've come to love and expect from this iconic (and very first) badass supernatural supervixen. Compiled here are the first seven issues of Dynamite Publications ongoing (and still worth reading) series, with fantastic artwork by Fabio Neves (#1-6) and Walter Geovanni (#7). This collection also benefits greatly from the most extensive and gorgeous cover art gallery in any Dynamite collection yet.Trautmann has given Vampi a welcomed character makeover - she's smarter, jaded, cynical, cunning, more visceral and methodically murderous when she has to be than in the past. She's a female version of Joss Whedon's 'Angel' character, only more complex and much easier on the eyes - much, much easier. The story moves briskly, is darker than those that preceded it, the body count elevated, the kills brutal and occasionally humorous (and I wonder why I scare people). On top of all that, Dracula emerges again, though this time in a different form, there's a Lovecraftian element I can't go into here, and Vampi gains a human sidekick by the time the saga concludes. What more could one possibly ask for?Don't be put off by the cover art (which is facially childish, unless you're one of J. Scott Campbell's legion of fans of pin-up 'good girl' art) - there's none of that inside, and that's what made me wait so long to add this one to my collection. Amazon's 'Look Inside' feature finally made me see the light of greatness within the book. If you possess even a mild interest in this character, you owe it to yourself to wear this 'Crown of Worms' proudly.

[Vampirella Masters Series, Volume 5 - 2011 - Dynamite Publications] This, for me, was the weakest edition of the Dynamite collections we'll ever see (thankfully), as they were dredging up some old fodder from 1991-92 with the 'Morning in America' story, which originally appeared in B+W and heralded Harris Comics 're-vamping' of this icon. Adding color makes it look even worse though, more comic-like than later editions. The story was sluggish, the artwork the worst I've seen in any Vampi tale, the page layout like something from an early 60's DC comic. It's dated, uninspired and our luscious heroine never looked worse or more sexless (how is this possible?), and had a bad hair day too. In spite of the reemergence of old Warren key players like Pendragon and Adam, it's pretty much a write-off (no pun intended). It's almost 200 pages of convoluted confusion, and too wordy trying to stretch back in Vampi's mythos while moving forward in a 90's timeline, but ends up like being on a treadmill - when all's said and done, we've gone nowhere. Kurt Busiek is just an acceptable writer who seems to constantly be rehashing old characters and villains (the Cult of Chaos, The Crimson Chronicles) from the golden age of Warren Vampirella sagas without really adding much of his own vision, IMO.Thankfully, this edition's salvaged by the artwork of Jim Balent and Louis Small Jr. in the four-part 'Dracula War' from 1993 and, though it too was penned by Kurt Busiek, the combo of story and art is a vast improvement, and reason enough to bag this if you never read it before. Almost all the Dynamite collections are essential reading for Vampi aficionados, some are downright glorious (read my reviews of all), but this one doesn't offer much bang for your Dynamite buck. 3 stars at best.

I've been collecting the Vampi compilations from Dynamite for a while, but this particular volume (the first) was always too pricey for a trade paperback, at least from my perspective. I also own a few hardcover Harris Publications Vampi comps, and found them wellbound and of high quality.One day while searching, I found a brand new copy of this Harris version at a cheaper price + immediately grabbed it, ultimately being very glad I did. The cover's thicker stock, the binding better and there's a few extras not included in the Dynamite edition (not that I'm knocking them - I own all of their other volumes and pre-ordered the latest edition as well).That said, the Grant Morrison/Mark Millar collaborations were among the finest writen tales of our voluptuous vampire vixen, the three issue story arcs allowing them to stretch out and add additional dimension, dialogue and depth to what was sometimes breezy, silly, lightweight tales in some of Harris' other work in the 90's. Our Vampirella deserved much better, and she got her pedestal elevated in these sanguinary sagas that never disappoint or come up short.Regardless of which publisher you go with, these are essential chronicles in the series and belong in every aficionado's collection. Highly recommended.

A decent read and good B+W illustrations punctuate this collection of EC/Warren inspired terror tales, but when I was finished, I still wanted more. 'Don't really know if it's my gluttony or the shortcomings of the finished product, but something was lacking somewhere.Most of these tales had roots in Eerie and Creepy magazines and appeared little more than rewrites; others had mediocre endings or finales you saw coming as an aficianado of supernatural sagas. I believe the quality of the artwork surpassed the storytelling. And yet the tales, some of which were marginal, weren't bad either. It's just not any kind of improvement over Uncle Creepy or Cousin Eerie's roster of formidable talent back in the early to mid 70's, IMO. Don't get me wrong, I did enjoy the indulged time, but would I prefer it to the classics? Not on your life, or death for that matter. But the purchase was far from a 'grave' mistake...

Demented and delirious, these tales are all interesting + worthy of attention, yet of varying quality, but the artwork is truly exceptional. Even some of the one-page 'Case Studies' of horrific, Lovecraftian (I know, an over-used expression, but it fits here) inmates at the Asylum will raise a sickly snicker.Much like an update of the old Warren publications from the 60's + 70's like Creepy and Eerie, so if those appeal to you in a slightly updated mode, sign yourself into the Asylum.Don't forget there's a shorter second volume available (one of the tales is continued in vol. 2) and a third was promised, a release date given, but no availability as of yet. At these prices, you'd be foolish not to become an inmate...

[SAME TIME EVERY YEAR - 1981 - Directed by Fred J. Lincoln] Though it may not be considered a 'hardcore classic', this film plays to the strengths of Fred Lincoln's talent for near wall-to-wall sex scenes, energetic performances and a bevy of fine female talent. The plot is established in the first five minutes, thankfully, and then we're witness to scene after scene of what we signed on for.With actresses/performers like Tiffany Clark, Loni Sanders (in 2 scenes), China Leigh, Lee Carroll, Holly McCall and Kathy Harcourt, among others, you're bound to find a few babes that appeal to your erotic fantasies. As far as the men are concerned, who cares? Do I care if hedgehog Ron Jeremy is in this? Not on your life; I've never seen someone as repugnant as that clown in a porn film, and my heart bleeds for the women assigned to have sex with him, but I digress. The bawdy babes and brisk sexual escapades are well worth your retro viewing buck, and that's all that matters.

[SERENA - AN ADULT FAIRY TALE - 1980] Director Fred Lincoln (along with his woman/wife and porn actress Tiffany Clark) made quite a few solid porn flicks in the late 70's, but this one's weak all around. I guess it helps if you find Serena attractive, but I've always considered her a third tier tramp with decent oral skills. Nothing more. And none of the other actresses are all that memorable, except China Leigh, as there weren't many Asian porn actresses during the 70's and 80's (unlike today, where they're incredibly abundant).The fairy tale plot wears thin immediately, and remember these folks aren't actors, they're performers, so you're just killing time until the next sex scene, again none all that memorable. You'll probably fast-forward through half the film. It's nice that Synapse is releasing some retro American erotica to go along with their Nikkatsu Asian softcore flicks from the late 70's/ early 80's and the German 'Schoolgirl Report' series from the early to mid 70's, but today's audience that grew up on gonzo porn and plotless filth will find nothing of interest here. Keep that in mind.Synapse is also releasing 'Same Time Every Year' on the same date, and that's a much superior entry and enjoyable flick with finer babes and less down time that I'd heartily recommend over this one. Unless you're a Serena fan, pass on this one + go for the other. Your degeneracy will thank you later.

[Creature From the Black Lagoon Vinyl Bust Bank - 2012 - Diamond Select] For the price asked for this item, there is no better representation of the likeness of the Creature anywhere; it's absolutely uncanny. No Sideshow, CineArt, Aurora, Revill, Moebius or other model kit or collectible for under $300 bucks captures the essence of this legend like this, AND it's under $20 bucks! Don't bother reading the rest of this review, buy this baby NOW!The details in the face are absolutely perfect - not kinda Creature-like, not close, no mere resemblance but perfection personified.
