The level of articulation in the body scales, gills, webbing, plates, claws, points and protrusions in the Creature's body are unparalleled, and the colors magnificent. There are so many gradations of color layering encompassed I couldn't believe it. I sat and marvelled at it over and over again. Then took it down from its nest the next day and marvelled astonished again.More bang for your buck than a lap dance at a car wash or topless baristas at a java joint, your monster collection requires this addition immediately. It's mandatory. THEN go find that cup of joe.

And how the hell did it ever get released? By now, Vincent Price was entrenched in low budget, factory-formulaic yet memorable and mostly enjoyable B flicks for the Corman / Zarkoff stable over at International; how he ended up here is both uncertain and welcomed, as his typically overly-theatrical narrative gave William Shatner something to aspire towards yet provides a coherently campy eccentricity that actually adds much to this surrealistic fever dream. And just what was anyone thinking when they came up with this title? No one in the early 60's was familiar with DeQuincy's 'Confessions of an English Opium Eater' from 1821 (acknowledged as the first serious literary work concerning drug use so prevalent then). It wasn't taught in colleges and didn't enjoy resurgence until ten years later when drug use was in vogue and most professors were themselves experimenting. This film has oddities to the tenth power written all over it. This is probably why I enjoyed it.There's no dialogue for the first eleven minutes, it's more like a graphic novel than film, ripe with pulp novel imagery regarding Chinese slave women abducted for auction at the turn of the century San Francisco, mythic Tong wars running rackets, seaports, opium and slavery, and Asian stereotypes from said time-frame (which is excusable at the time the film was made as well as what little we Americans knew of Asians back in the early 1900's, as they were known for both furtive secrecy and non-assimilation, like most immigrants then). And there's that symbolic, surreal white horse that plays a pivotal role in that first beach scene; later recognized as a well-known metaphor for heroin, derived from opium. Whew. And from here it only gets stranger. Much stranger.Enter Price, a sea-faring roustabout both penniless and on an odyssey, sorta like a turn-of-the-century Charles Bukowski spewing cryptic Charlie Chan-isms to rightfully untrusting Chinese comic book characters each more deceitful than the last. But I don't insinuate for a second that these remarks are unbecoming, rather they add a flavorful flair of the phantasmagoric that lends much to what would otherwise be a dreadful viewing experience. Equal parts film noir, pulp novel, theatrical drivel, racy melodrama, European fumetti and no budget action flick - if it was made a few years later, it would have been a great Jess Franco flick.So as Price, a descendant of Thomas DeQuincy's a hundred years later (and the only thread of continuity to the film's title), attempts to save a young woman from the impending slave auction that takes place later that night where women are bartered for opium, he encounters more trap doors and secret passageways than a hundred spy films while meeting odd characters and savage henchmen brandishing huge swords, bamboo cages with slave girls who must dance provocatively for their potential buyers while a few red herrings are tossed our way, none believable but all enjoyable. Does any of this make sense? `Doesn't much matter, you'll either love it or hate it, the latter group probably ceased reading a while ago.It's a two star film for the Criterion snob, four stars to those who appreciate cinematic oddities, cult, camp and the transgressive taste buds. A poppy for your thoughts...

Classic retro replica of the villianous Dr. Doom is quite impressive at 14"'s in height (including base), looking ominous from his vantage point atop Castle Doom's watchtower. Excellent articulation, fantastic flowing cape, arms crossed defiantly as he plots his next onslaught against his varied enemies, highly detailed watchtower with gargoyle heads sprouting at various points. All Silver Age Marvel + Fantastic Four fans will want this for sure, BUT NOT AT THE PRICES ASKED HERE at the time of this review.You can nab this nefarious monarch on ebay and other sites for anywhere from $150 (a lucky low-end auction) to $275.00 retail, so don't fall prey to the "Sucker's-gotta-have-it-now-so-I'll-rob-him-blind" larceny here and elsewhere. No offense to the sellers, they're just capitalizing on the supply + demand dynamic that oil companies utilize everyday. But robbery is robbery regardless. When there's only one or two sellers offering an item on Amazon, you can bet you'll be paying too much for it. (Another oddity I run across frequently talking to other collectors is that ebay people tend not to be Amazon shoppers, and vice-versa. I buy anywhere I can ge the best price - sometimes/mostly it's Amazon + other ocassions it's elsewhere, but it pays to do your research. Your wallet will concur with me).So scour around until you find this monstrous meanie at a more reasonable price - you'll thank me later.

[WAVES OF LUST - 1975 - Widescreen 1.85:1 - In English or Italian w/ English subtitles - directed by Ruggero Deodato - 88 min.] Although he had a highly respectable career as a television and commercial director, Ruggero Deodato is best remembered for his notorious exploitation classics, 'Jungle Holocaust' (1977), 'Cannibal Holocaust' (1980) and 'The House on the Edge of the Park' (1980). He even directed a notable crime drama 'Live Like a Cop, Die Like a Man' (1976), but this entry from the previous year is unlike his known body of work, for better or worse. BTW, Lamberto Bava was only one of four co-writers here, and had nothing to do with its direction.Two couples bump shoulders at a seaside resort, one wealthy, one not, and get entangled in each others crosshairs with typically wretched results. Highly despicable and wealthy financier Giorgio (John Steiner) and his virtual slave of a lover and part-time subject of abuse, Silvia (Elizabeth Turner), hook up with Irem (Al Cliver) and Barbara (Deodato's wife, Silvia Dionisio) for a weekend cruise aboard Giorgio's massive yacht for a protracted and provocative game of cat and mouse. Not one of the four is under any illusion that this is a simple pleasure trip; Giorgio has had designs on Barbara since he first laid eyes on her ashore, Barbara suspects the levels of physical and mental abuse heaved upon Silvia by her husband and appears to plan retaliation while possibly sleeping with the brutal bastard, Irem knows of the intentions of both Giorgio and his own mate and is apparently indifferent (or is he?), and poor Silvia is desperate for attention and respite from her abuser, secretly plotting a love triangle with the other couple, who conspire against the ruthless misogynist who's also a paranoid alcoholic. Got all that?While complications pile up, so does the clothing as all four spend most of the flick naked or near-nude, whether diving underwater, changing for dinner, tempting and teasing one another, sunbathing, making love or engaged in Sapphic massages. There's an over-abundance of sleazy 70's Euro-grindhouse nudity but, thankfully, both women are easy on the eyes and seeing them prance and preen is pleasurable for voyeurs like me. (Most women believe that there's no such thing as being too rich or too thin; most men believe that there's no such thing as too much female nudity...) Deodato's camera lingers on the flesh lovingly and longingly - it's a pervert's paradise, which is odd when you factor that one of the women flaunted is his own wife. But don't mistake this as a complaint on my part.By the time the proceedings are about to wrap up, we viewers feel as though we've spent too much time with these unlikable, scheming characters too, and can't wait to see the impending debacle unfold but, until then, we sit awash in 'Waves of Lust' as the tides roll in. A 3 star film elevated to 4 due to the pervasive 70's Eurosleaze hurled at us by a true exploitation auteur.Once again, RARO VIDEO has delivered a beautiful remastered print w/ great audio, and has added several bonus features as well as a nice-sized collectible booklet. Considering the market for such product is so small, they truly must be commended for treating their fanbase so affectionately. All hail Raro Video!

[ZOOM UP: The Beaver Book Girl - 1981 - Widescreen - Japanese w/ English subtitles - directed by Takashi Kanno] In an effort to park butts in movie house seats when XXX Porn was prevalent and Betamax video was all the rage in Japan, and consumers could watch subversive sleaze in the comfort of their own homes for the first time in seditious cinema history, Nikkatsu Studios had to push the transgressive boundaries of its releases to new heights (or lows, depending on your perspective) while remaining, if just barely, within the margins of softcore celluloid sex. No easy task, with results varying widely. The new films were rawer, rougher, more visceral and fetishistic than before, and the 'Zoom Up/ Zoom In' series is a perfect example.As an aficionado of Asian exploitation, and exploitation in almost all its incarnations (read more of my reviews as proof), I'm delighted Impulse Pictures is releasing these films for the first time on dvd, although I haven't been totally impressed with any of the three I've currently screened. That won't stop me from watching more of them, as I'm a bona fide sucker for this genre. But this entry has a particular twist I'm not a fastidious fan of, and it dominates the film, so if you don't take pleasure in it either, your overall enjoyment of this flick will be sorely compromised, as mine was. Not that I'm sorry I sat through it, my decadence is deep-rooted and decades old.The film begins with a rape and ends with a tsunami of golden showers, and you need to be informed of this before deciding if it's for you or not. I had no such knowledge, so I was taken aback by the deluge of urinating on others that crops up constantly - the rape thing is entrenched in Japanese cinema and its history, so there's no way around that. These are two elements that are off-putting to me, as I get no arousal from either, and find their inclusion in sexual activity totally alien to my own tastes. Though I make no pretense to criticize those that do, understand? Sex and violence are two entirely separate entities to me, and make for uneasy bedfellows, and scatting is just something nauseating in my head. Again, I'm not preaching to any choir here, I'm a degenerate in my own right, and in a free society, or at least a cheap one, I'm not passing judgment on anybody.The lead female actress is a fairly attractive MILF with an ample rack and come-hither sexuality in her eyes that's unmistakable, and we are treated to many scenes with her. My favorite was the one where she's bound outdoors to a wooden cross with bright red fabric tethers, fully exposed while being photographed and having intercourse (see - I've got issues all my own), but there are a few more as well. The only other female we see naked repeatedly in this flick is plainer than rice (and I mean nothing racial by that), obnoxious and off-putting, and has too much screen time. So variety is lacking too - it's either column A or column B (again, no racial bias intended, sometimes these things just write themselves). Thankfully, the main actress is unique enough to carry the films erotic content, at least for me anyway. Now if the producers would've just dialed back a bit on the golden showers, maybe my enjoyment wouldn't have drowned... 3 stars, but be forewarned, my freaky friends, when it rains, it pours.

[Teenage Hitchhikers - 1974 (not '75) - Widescreen - directed by Gerri Sedley] Look, I'm not here to argue or belittle the other reviewers for this flick, to each his own, right? The film does not disappoint when it comes to abundant female nudity, carefree 70's shenanagins, silly humor and grindhouse ettiquette - but couldn't you come up with a few women someone would actually WANT to see naked? Therein lies my problem; these chicks are skanks, not worth rustling up after last call at your local watering hole back in the day. I lived in bars and topless joints during that time period, and these chicks wouldn't get hired to clean the bathrooms in said temples. Sorry for my bluntness, but someone's gotta call the shot. After a while, I'm sitting there hoping they'd put their clothes back on, or encounter some chick farther down the road who was just a bit higher in the desirability department.No one seemed to notice that that one chick was Claire Wilbur (Radley Metzger's 'Score') who played (what else?) a lesbian and didn't have enough screen time to counterbalance the mediocrity of the two lead actresses, and the third girl they added to the mix was even more unlikable and unbedworthy. Yeesch. During the film's 'climax', the orgy, I noticed both Marc Stevens and Eric Edwards (neither got screen credits), two guys who were porn superstars back then, and they looked too stoned and bored to care, while I was sadly just the latter.BTW, if you bothered to sit through the film, make sure you stick around for the trailers afterwards, it's the real highlight here - there are well over 15 trashy transgressive treats, any of which are better than the main attraction on this disc. DO NOT miss these...I've seen 'em all, and I'm still not certain if it's something I should be proud of or embarrassed to admit. Aww, who am I kiddin' - I loved these flicks!So, if you want to see an indiscriminate bunch of nudity and bad humor, feel free to indulge in this narcoleptic nostalgia; if you're looking for fine women prancing sans garments for arousal and enlightenment, please look elsewhere. Why do you think they didn't use the real actresses on the posters or dvd cover??? Marketing's a cruel mistress...

[NINA - CRAZY SUICIDE GIRL - 2011 - Full screen - 80 minutes - Italian w/ English subtitles - directed by Christian Arioli] First, and most importantly, ignore the hyped details in the synopsis listed here, which are also on the dvd case, so no one's at fault except the rats promoting this swill. Sure, sure, ALL the ingredients for a great exploitation grindhouse paradise are depicted in the narrative, but the immature execution, lifeless acting, lousy direction and complete lack of budget negate any entertainment value entirely. So don't fall prey to the hype as I did, and often have as a lover of transgressive cinema. This clunker needs to remain under everyone's radar, except possibly the MST3K crowd and those seeking a new low in irredeemable films.On the surface, the stratagem appears watertight - a bunch of female models are coerced into doing gonzo porno before being kidnapped by an underworld mob-run video group that has ties to a satanic cult that captures and kills in pursuit of supreme occult power who are being tracked down by a bounty-hunting female assassin who utilizes Japanese swordplay to bring dark justice to the criminals when she's not using a blow-torch to wrangle info out of sleazy smut peddlers, gangsters and druglords - so how can you screw this up, for chrissakes, when it's absolutely golden in concept? Oh, let me count the ways...First, the female lead is wooden (leaden?) and too old for the role (a decent MILF maybe, but), exhibits no fighting skills and only uses a Katana sword once during the film - nothing like the grindhouse mixture of 70's Asian, Italian giallo and Tarantino pulp cinema influences touted here to sell this turkey. There are no highs, just lows, leaving every frame flat and thirsty for more of what we signed on for. There's a sprinkle of brutality and nudity, but not enough ultra-violence, bloodshed, undraped female flesh, satanic sleaze or indecent insanity to make a decent, enjoyable flick as described. You're better off watching a nostalgically bad but bona fide 70's Eurohorror or Italian crime drama by Fernando Di Leo (there'll be superior violence, gratuitous sleaze and better looking women) - this film wants to be those things, but comes off as disingenuous and deceptive, as well as poorly implemented. What a shame...In short, NINA's no GIRL, you'd have to be CRAZY enough for SUICIDE to suffer through after reading this review. Spare yourself.

[VAMPIRELLA MASTERS SERIES, VOLUME SIX]  Dynamite has done it again with this compiled edition of our favorite vampiric seductress's sagas, with solid roots in Greek, Roman and Christian folklore as penned by James Robinson, with bewitching and stunning neorealist artwork paintings by the incomparable Joe Lusko. A compelling rewriting of Vampirella's death, resurrection and backstory on her mother Lilith's true history, what actually transpired on Drakulon and how this all has ties to Hell and the river Styx, this tale's not to be missed by any Vampi fan, either new or old.'Bloodlust' is the main story and the real reason to sink your teeth into this book without hesitation, for the reasons outlined above, as well as others. Vampirella has never been rendered better or more realistically fetching to the eye, bone-fetching in fact. Lord knows there has never been a superior bloodsucking sexually superlative icon since she appeared on the cover of the first issue of her own Warren mag way back in 1969, brought to near-perfect realization by legend Frank Frazetta, and my bets are that there never will be. But here, she embodies all that is the core of her character, her conflicts, and her captivating carnality. Every panel is jaw-dropping, and to see Adam Van Helsing transformed into the Herculean anti-hero is another stroke of brilliance. It's mandatory for aficionados.'Vampi vs. Dracula' is a post-modern retelling of an original tale from 1972 that's well-done, especially for newer fans, though I believe the original was better (and it was in B+W!) and concerns the Cult of Chaos and the Crimson Chronicles, for those who remember such details or collect the also-excellent Vampirella Archive series from Dynamite. I'm not knocking it, I enjoyed it as a blast from the past.Lastly comes 'Two So Different', a thoughtful treatise on alternate or parallel planes, where Bram Stoker and Archie Goodwin (Vampi's original story-teller) sit in a library discussing the two very different tales of vampire characters they are currently penning and how history will remember them both. They are also sharing space with their two progeny, Drac and Vampi, one of whom thinks he can alter his future outcome by doing something unspoken to his creator, but his female counterpart has other ideas. It's a brilliant conception, but the artwork is the weakest offered here. But the novelty more than excuses this shortcoming.Without hesitation, I heartily recommend this edition to all possessing a beating heart, as 'Bloodlust' pumps sanguine and lust unequivocally. It does a heart good...

I grew up with Vampi, Uncle Creepy and Cousin Eerie, as well as a host of other similar publications as a kid and teen, but eventually grew out of them - notice I didn't say "grew up", because the propensity and weakness for such things really never goes away, no matter how old we get. It's always there, lurking in the recesses and quagmire of our inner psyche, and bubbles back up to the surface in later years, usually when a 'memory trigger' has been pulled.Decades later, I stumble upon Dark Horse editions of the beautifully bound Creepy and Eerie Archives and, lo and behold, memory triggers fired off, and soon enough I've got a shelf of them, along with several Vampirella Archives from Dynamite. So now I look into this collection of their Master Series and thanks to Amazon's great 'Look Inside' feature, I've now got three of these as well. I'm not 'into' comics anymore, for whatever reason (probably the comic art), but the neorealist artwork grabbed me immediately and, after reading this one, the stories are surprisingly solid and have substance I initially didn't think they would. One of those rare times when it feels good to be wrong, I guess.'Master Series' Volume Three presents us with the three-part 'Nowheresville' saga along with the two-part 'Fear of Mirrors', both exceptional tales with superb artwork. These stories would appeal to any  TV fans of 'Supernatural', 'Angel' or 'Buffy', as well as Vampi aficionados, new or old.  My favorite is the 'Nowheresville' story, as each part contains a writing style full of depth, twists, sarcasm and contemporary cultural references, along with the sexiest badass good-girl vampire ever committed to paper and pen. You can't go wrong with this edition; the artwork's astonishing and tales are top-tier.So take a trip to 'Nowheresville' - it's someplace special.

Great size, scale, detail and articulation - the robotic 'wing' moves up and down, the artificial leg is posable to get him propped up properly, and the other wing is on a ball joint so it rotates as well as moves up and down, so you can change his posture periodically when you get tired of him in just one position. His head turns too, but the icing is the blue chest button which lights up and provides about a half-dozen random electrical and mechanical sounds when pushed in - a very cool feature.An iconic image brought back to life for all fans of the Adult Swim empire. All hail Robot Chicken!

[THE OUTSIDE MAN - 1974 - Widescreen presentation - Directed by Jacques Deray] Seeing as how most of the other reviews are for the VHS edition of this flick, or penned by fans of Ann Margret (which I am as well, and fault no one for that), I thought I'd add a few remarks about the new MGM  Limited Edition release currently available.No attempt has been made by the studio to remaster, enhance or improve the print utilized here - it's prefaced with the statement, "This film is presented using the best print available", which isn't all that bad, actually, but in the era of blu ray and remastering, it's not all that great either. The audio is more than adequate for a film from this era, but the video colors range from a bit 'hot' in some of the outdoor scenes, of which there are many, to weak and spotty contrast in certain indoor and night sequences, and an overall flatness to the picture as a whole. Again, this shouldn't turn you away from watching, renting or buying this flick if you've got an interest, but there are no superlatives to encourage you to do any of those things either. But, that said, it is a solid yet anomalous movie with a great cast and a European ending as opposed to a Hollywood conclusion, which made it more attractive to me.The strange thing is, in spite of the excellent cast, no actor really makes the film their own - everyone is good, but no one is given enough screen time to dominate, or is ever established as the true central character or powerful enough to chew up the scenery to make it theirs either. 'Not necessarily a bad thing, but a bit peculiar given the talents involved. Jean-Louis Trintignant would appear the central figure, but his English isn't good enough to warrant giving him a ton of dialogue, as his accent is strong. Americans know him for his role in 'The Conformist' as well as 'And God Created Woman', the film that brought Brigitte Bardot international fame, but he's been in many a formidable French flick through the years. Roy Scheider, in a rare role as a bad guy hit man, has almost no dialogue whatsoever, which is a bit of a waste. Angie Dickenson has a scene in the beginning and one or two at the films conclusion, but is severely underutilized. That leaves Ann Margret, who is captivating in the scenes she's in, both sexy and emotive, but I wish she was in more scenes too. So we have a remarkable cast without anyone being unmistakably remarkable, and I think it has to do with the French writers, directors, cinematographers and additional cast members. Umberto Orsini also has a role on par with the rest of the cast; again unremarkable. Alex Rocco plays the same role he's played his entire life, a bodyguard and muscle enforcer for Orsini, whose presence is felt only at the end of the film.The script is solid, the action firm, it's never dull and concludes nicely for a European crime drama (in spite of the American cast), and is a pleasurable unpolished gem from that era - the other reviewers have already mined the plot, so there's no need for a re-hash from me - I'd recommend this movie to those who appreciate this genre and timeframe without hesitation. Just don't expect an impressive print for a limited release that carries a fairly hefty pricetag. 4 stars.

[SHELLEY'S CREATION - Quarantine Studios - 2012 - Limited Edition Statue] OK, it's not Karloff's immortal characterization or any of the second-rate stars who portrayed the creature in various films throughout the decades, but that shouldn't stop you freaks from throwing this in your cart ASAP.Quarantine Studio has constructed a great homage statue as described by Mary Shelley in what has become recognized as the first (and arguably the best) gothic horror novel of all time. The tombstone behind the creature has her name inscribed on it, along with her birth and death dates, and a quote from her novel about the monster. A nice touch.The monster is impressively constructed and rendered; his posture menacing, his body language threatening and chilling, and his facial features not too remote from the image we all see when we think of Frankenstein's Monster. Subtle differences abound, but all you could wish for is present as well. The flat skull and hairline, sloped brow, stapled flesh, dead yet undead eyes, silver metal plates, freshly-sewn stitches and additional knife-scars crowd his face, and his hands are amazingly articulated; he looks like he's prowling for something to strangle. Another original addage is the leg brace that takes over his right leg - metal plates, hinges and leather straps that hold the beast upright are truly unique. His clothing is perfectly aged, and even the brass buttons appear real. It's absolutely killin' for those of us who appreciate such detailed dementia.The only negative I can think of is that there's little contrast in the tomb, shattered cross and ground he stalks upon; a little more paint would've been nice and set up additional contrast and dimension, but I'm incredibly difficult to please when it comes to details.Here's a fact treat that should be notated in the product details - this statue is strictly limited to 100 pieces, which insures it's value at this pricepoint - Sideshow Collectibles products usually fetch $300-$500 for items that run from 250 to 1500 pieces, and I'm not knocking them, so this has an added scarcity attached to it - only 100 people will eventually own one (mine's # 20/100) - period. Now, how many Frankenstein fans are out there? Probably millions worldwide. He comes housed in a nice box and warrants a rightful place in your rec room, labratory, dungeon or crypt. Don't be braindead, give him a home, but by all means, keep him locked up, would'ya?

[Hecto Pascal: Sensual Callgirl - (2009) - directed by Toru Kamei - fullscreen presentation - Japanese w/ English subtitles] Asian exploitation rarely lets me down, that's why I love it; a good deal of it borders on the insane and focuses on wildly deviant sexual behavior, but this clunker was the most torturously tame and insipid waste of 80 minutes I've experienced in ages. Everything about it is misleading, starting with the title - it's never concretely established if there even IS a Hecto Pascal, there's certainly no callgirl, it's definitely not sensual and, oh yeah, there's only one scene with ANY nudity at all. How can you market this as part of the 'Tokyo Erotique' series if there's no naughtiness or nudity? Gentlemen, I ask you in all sincerity, WTF? Before I go on, and for those of you with short attention spans, let's make one thing perfectly clear - you DO NOT want to suffer through this flick as I did, so you can cease reading now. It's devoid of any merit, immorality or indecency, rendering it without value of any kind, and my sainthood in the afterlife of cinematic degenerates is hereby guaranteed for having suffered so heinously so that you, my like-minded brethren, could go unpunished and spared from this tedium. My altar's being constructed as I write this...so is my pillory for being so foolish.For those of you still seeking torture, here are the details - A widow (Honoka) runs a funeral parlor in a poor fishing village, and is locally known as the "Mortician Vulture", and yes, she does indeed provide additional 'services' to the bereaved, but this we find out through dialogue and not depiction. She hires a partially deaf young man as part-time help, and takes an interest in him and his virginity. After a service one day, she instructs him to accompany her in the bathtub (I've seen larger fishbowls), but neither one gets undressed (?) - he's in a suit and tie, she's in a dress, shawl and pantyhose. So fully clothed we're to believe that this is somehow erotic. She washes his hair, then he hers, and I'm cringing in the social awkwardness of the severely dysfunctional characters. It's painful to watch.It's 56 minutes into this sleep aid before the first and only pair of breasts are exposed, and then only for a few seconds as the two have a go outdoors in the approaching typhoon. The pervading melancholy is mind numbing and the boredom relentless for an alleged 'erotic' film, though stating it as such is akin to calling Gov. Romney a liberal and Congress bipartisan. Every opportunity to show flesh (and there were many) was excised like foreskin at a bar mitzvah. Sure, there's a ton of talk about sex throughout the flick, but we see nothing. As a film, it fails all around too; no real plot or development, shallow characters, lousy direction and a weak soundtrack only serve to infuriate rather than entertain or invigorate.Do yourself a huge favor and pick up one of the excellent 'Tokyo Train Girl' flicks instead (read my reviews), or 'Captive Factory Girls' 1 or 2, even 'Girl in Captivity' from the same label (Cinema Epoch) for some enjoyable exploitation that won't disappoint - this one's unbearable. Amen.

I did not find the taste to be that of caramel.  It tastes more like light molasses to me.  It's not unpleasant (if you like molasses) though and would be a good alternative for some people.  I haven't tried it on pancakes, yet, but I think it would be find.  It's a little thicker than "normal" syrup, but overall, I liked it, and the thickness didn't bother me.Note:  I tried it on Eggos and it was pretty good.  I prefer light syrup, but I noticed that I don't get the sugar-buzz-followed-by-needing-a-nap that ordinary syrup gives me.  It's definitely a good alternative choice, and it didn't taste as much like light molasses when I used it on the Eggos.

What a fun little item!  It has lots of little bells and whistles that are cool, though I did find the voice they used to be annoying.  Most kids probably won't though, since it's a sort of "British fashion model" type voice.  I found that the voice recognition on the password lock didn't work very well.  You have to say the word EXACTLY the same way (which I think a lot of kids will have trouble with, but they'll have fun trying) or it won't open.  But there is a reset button so that you can get into it if you need to.  It has a little compartment to hide things in, an "invisible ink" pen and a light to read the writing by, and a notebook to write in.  It's fairly rugged, but you would need to warn your kids about the short lifespan of mistreated electronics.  I really liked the "locking" noise it made, too.  It's for 6 years old and up, but it will depend on the kid.

A very nice little necklace.  It's about 3/4" square and the shape and diamonds make it a delicate and slightly blingy accent.  I don't wear much silver, but this really is something that could go with anything from jeans and a t-shirt to that little black dress.  The chain is fairly short (probably 15"- 16") and the catch is extremely small, making it a little difficult to fasten and unfasten without help, but if you don't have a significant other or a girlfriend to help you, a magnetic catch could be added to it, easily.  This would make a nice little gift for someone, if it fits in your price range.

Although this could be a little pricey, compared to the original coffee mates, and it takes a taller space than the original, this is a really handy, fast way to get your creamer fix.  After opening, you have to use it in 30 days, but for big coffee fans, that won't be a problem.  I found I had to use a little more than they said, but all in all, it was very handy and fast.

This product is really high quality, I think, but my little dog couldn't eat it well because he is old and doesn't have very good teeth anymore.  The strips are fairly thin but they are quite hard and he found them difficult to chew.  But, for a dog who loves to chew, they would be great.

I like this product though I would prefer it to be another flavor.  I'm not fond of chocolate for liquids.  But it's fairly flavorful for a drink with vitamins and minerals.  One of the best things about this, to me, is that it has 12g of protein.  I have difficulty getting enough protein and 12g is quite a bit.  I usually drink half in the morning and half in the evening to spread it out a little, but it wouldn't make a bad breakfast or lunch if you're watching calories.

I bought this because I have trouble with high dosage Vitamin B6, but I do need to take some every day.  Most Vitamin B6 comes in 100 mg or higher, but I have had trouble with what is sometimes referred to as "Vivid Dreams" when I take very much B6.  Some people like that and take high doses in order to experience it, but I found them TOO vivid.  I'd wake up convinced that I heard someone getting in my house, or a spider was on me.  Even after I woke up, I'd believe it was true for a minute or two.  I'd actually HEAR somebody at the door.  I found it terrifying.  When I discovered the B6 was causing it, I started trying to find a lower dose B6 so that I wouldn't have to split the pills into 12 or 16 pieces.  This brand is 10 mg, so I can split it in 4 pieces and do fine.  That still gives me the daily requirement, but I don't have the dreams.  This brand comes out of Great Britain.

I ordered this because it sounded like it was a little different from the usual Febreze (which I don't like) and it is different, but I still didn't like it.  However, this basically an issue of what fragrances you like and don't like.  It aggravated my sinuses and I didn't find it all that pleasant a fragrance, but other people will probably like it very much.  Buying online will difficult, since you can't test the smell.  Your best bet might be to find it in a store, at least the first time you buy it.

Although I am not really fond of black, I ordered these because they looked like they would be a good choice for everyday, average sized totes.  And they are.  One is black, one natural and one is black and white in a chevron pattern (and rather pretty, too).  They are an average size.  I didn't measure, but they're probably average sized.  They're not as pretty as some designer totes, but they make a good choice anyway, for daily use.

I usually refer to my dogs as Little Hog and Picky Eater.  Sadly, Little Hog died in April and I only have Picky Eater now.  Little Hog would probably have liked these pretty well, but PE does not.  He is not fond of things that need a lot of chewing.  He also doesn't like raw meats and, frankly, this stuff does not look cooked to me.  It may be, but it doesn't look like it is and I wonder if that's part of the reason that he doesn't like it.  Also, the curly thing is weird.  I guess they were just trying for interesting textures that a dog would have a way to get his teeth around.  Flat treats are sometimes hard for pets to pick up.  But these treats are difficult for my dog to pick up.  They're just big enough that he can't get his somewhat small mouth around them.  He did eat a little on them but it was only after I pinched them up in smaller pieces.  So, if your dog likes to chew and isn't bothered by raw (or not cooked much) meat, he may like them a lot, so long as he likes chicken.  Otherwise, maybe not.  I gave it an extra star over my first choice of 3 stars, because some dogs would like this a lot better than mine did, and I took off a star from 5 because it just doesn't look cooked to me!  (but I don't know that for sure).

The DII Kitchen Millennium Microfiber Scrub, Scour, and Polish set is a great idea. Unfortunately, even the toughest "Scour" cloth is not strong or coarse enough to replace our trusty scrub sponge (which DII refers to as "bacteria ridden").There are other issues with this set:- the cloths are relatively small (dishcloth-sized) squares- the abrasive cloths (scrub and scour) are only finished on one side (the reverse is standard microfiber)- with only 6 small cloths, they are much more expensive than standard microfiber (non-abrasive) cloths

OWC makes some great products, and this 0.5M Thunderbolt Cable is no exception. I've had no reliability issues, no overheating of the connectors - it just works (as it should). Also nice to have a blue color choice beyond the black and white cables everyone else (including Apple) offers.

Unfortunately there don't seem to be many choices in wireless doorbells. I love the sound from our Heath-Zenith unit (now "Utilitech") but the doorbell button doesn't seem to last more than a year, and they're becoming harder to find.Based on the good reviews, I ordered the Etekcity wireless doorbell. The unit itself is well-made, and the button is a nice modern departure from the standard designs. Etekcity advertises 1000 foot range, but that is only in open air. Silly claim - the point of a wireless doorbell is that the transmitter is outside of a building! Needless to say, the range seemed adequate.There are two major problems with this unit, however. The first led me to return it - the quality of the sound is really poor. There is no question that the standard two-tone doorbell is a cheap set of electronic notes. It just sounds terrible. I went through all of the remaining 51 choices and couldn't find one I liked. The problem is that a doorbell should be just that - a nice set of chimes. The other 51 choices are all tunes - who wants to hear musing playing when someone presses the doorbell button. Maybe I'm just old fashioned.My second concern is about the design of the wireless transmitter button. Although claimed to be designed for outdoor use, the screwdriver slot used to open and replace the battery is on the TOP of the button unit, leaving a gap where rain and moisture can come in.Needless to say, I returned the unit, very disappointed, and still searching for the right wireless doorbell.

This was a tough review for me - there is a lot to like about the Mediasonic USB3 2-bay dock, including its throughput / performance, and cost/value. And while ultimately the performance swayed me to a more positive rating, the build quality leaves me questioning long-term reliability.First, the good news - performance. Tested using the USB3 connection on both a 2013 MacPro and a 2012 retina MacBook Pro, the Mediasonic dock performed faster than my Anker USB3 dock. I didn't have a chance to test a newer SATA6-based SSD, but with my SATA3-based OWC Mercury 480GB SSD I was able to sustain 254MB/s read and 223MB/s write. Both numbers are 10% faster than the same drive in my Anker USB3 dock. For spinning hard drives (both 2.5" and 3.5"), the Mediasonic does not offer a notable improvement in performance over the Anker dock.In all configurations tested, over the course of 3 weeks, I did not experience reliability issues or random disconnects that others have reported. Both of my Macs were initially running OS X Yosemite, and were subsequently upgraded to El Capitan.As a dual-bay unit, the Mediasonic offers some unique capabilities, namely:-  the ability to mount two independent drives on your host computer when in "PC" mode- the ability to copy from one drive to another when in "Clone" modeThe clone mode is interesting, but finicky in my experience. I tried cloning a 500GB 2.5" laptop drive to another 500GB drive, but the clone mode never moved beyond the first LED (25%). Because there are limited LEDs (a status indicator, and then 4 LEDs to indicate progress), there is no real way to check on why the clone failed. Mediasonic's documentation is quite clear that the target drive must be equal or greater in size to the source drive, and there are variations in capacity between drive manufacturers.I was successful in cloning a 3.5" 1TB WD Black drive to a larger 3TB WD Green 3.5" drive, taking about 2 hours and 11 minutes. This is faster than using Carbon Copy Cloner (Mac OS X) to clone between the drives (in PC mode with both drives mounted from the Mediasonic dock).Note that like other hardware "clone" devices, you will get an exact copy of the source drive, partition map and all. So if you're cloning from a smaller (eg. 1TB) to a larger (eg. 3TB) drive, it will mount as a 1TB drive. You will need to use a partitioning utility to increase the drive allocation. Software cloning utilities such as Carbon Copy Cloner (Mac OS X) and Acronis True Image Home (Windows) can adjust the size automatically during their clone process.What concerns me the most about this docking station is its build quality. The dock is flimsy - and the rear power switch didn't always work for me. Eventually, I learned how to press it slightly off-center to make it work all of the time. Not a good indicator of long-term reliability.

This is one of those products you wish you had forever for vacuuming more difficult-to-reach or fine debris. - especially with the long flexible crevice tool that reaches difficult / impossible areas such as the gaps around car seats, tight spaces around heavy furniture, or even the inside lint trap of your clothes dryer.The HomeSource Detail Handy Kit provides 3 different vacuum cleaner attachments: - a LONG, thin, flexible crevice tool that reaches into thin gaps around car seats or even the lint trap of your clothes dryer- a wide scoop nozzle with microfiber strip for picking up fine particles like pet hair or lint- a dusting brush with firm bristles that don't easily wear under heavy useWhat makes this kit neat is that it is designed to fit most major light-duty vacuum cleaner brands (which come in 2 major diameters). The long crevice tool has two different opening sizes to accommodate, while there is an adapter connector for the other two nozzles. It worked fine in both our Eureka and Oreck portable vacuums.Note that these attachments will NOT work in "ShopVac" like heavy-duty vacuums which have a much larger hose opening.

Excellent and clear sound, great value and build quality, but size limits useFirst of all, it is odd that NYNE sent a discontinued product (NYNE Bass Sport) for review. In fact, I couldn't find this particular model for sale anywhere outside of Costco. I called NYNE and spoke directly to a representative who explained that this was a limited "promotional" model that is identical to their NYNE Bass speaker. The only difference is the color (red vs grey endcaps), and the power plug (only includes US not other adapters). So, with that being said, I consider this a review of the current NYNE Bass portable speaker.As many have noticed, this is sold as a "portable" speaker, but it is definitely on the large side. At 13.5" x 6" it is not HUGE (like the B&W Zeppelin), but it is still not a speaker you can throw in your backpack or carry-on.Build quality is excellent and solid. NYNE indicates it is "splash resistant" but this is most definitely not a weatherproof or waterproof speaker system.Setup is easy - although the documentation is a ridiculous, poster-sized page of instructions in many different languages that is folded like a complex work of origami art.To pair, hold down the Bluetooth button on top of the unit, and it will enter discovery mode where it can be paired (without a key) on your Bluetooth-enabled device. If your device supports NFC for pairing, you can do that also. Although the documentation does not state this, NYNE support confirmed that the NYNE Bass will remember a "virtually unlimited" number of different paired Bluetooth devices, automatically pairing with the last connected device if it's available. VERY nice feature.The controls are large black rubber buttons, with embossed indicators, aligned along the top edge for controlling power on/off, volume on/off, bluetooth, and media playback (reverse, stop/play, forward). Without contrast color, even with the emboss, they are not easy to see in dimmer lighting. The power button on the top button illuminates white on power on, and changes color as you near end of battery life.There is a built-in microphone for speakerphone capability, although the range of the microphone isn't quite as far as other devices I've used.Sound quality is absolutely outstanding, and surprisingly well-balanced and accurate for a speaker in this price range. Despite the name, the bass is clear and tight but does not "boom" or color the sound image. There is a bass reflex port in the rear of the unit, and you can literally FEEL the air being pumped through it. I played a variety of music from dance / electronic to pop, vocal, jazz, classical, and never heard distortion even at the highest levels.Midrange is forward, and treble bright - perhaps a bit too bright for some instruments. If you like jazz, classical, vocal you will be thrilled with the sound accuracy. If you like heavy rock or electronic / dance you won't be disappointed with the sound either, but you may be used to more colored bass-heavy sound.There is a stereo mini-jack in the rear for direct aux sound input, but with my iPhone 6s and iPad Air 2, I actually found the sound BETTER quality via Bluetooth. In most systems, you will find Bluetooth noisy and inferior. As a strange side note, I also found the aux input much quieter (lower maximum volume) than the Bluetooth, even without sound limiting on the source device. NYNE support found this unusual but couldn't contradict the behavior.The rear of the case also offers a recessed handle, and a USB plug that can be used to power a device off the speaker's battery. There is also a power switch (different from the top switch) that completely powers off the unit saving battery if you're not going to use it for a period of time.So, why not 5 stars? This is clearly an excellent speaker at a great price. My issue is usability / size. For $50 more you can buy the Bose SoundLink Mini (which I also own), and although the sound in the NYNE Bass is definitely better it is not dramatically so. And the Bose SoundLink Mini is ridiculously small and portable to take with you on a trip, or in your backpack. If it were me, I would opt for the extra $50 and go for the Bose SoundLink Mini which also offers excellent (not quite as good) sound quality in a much more versatile package.

Let's face it - in the electronic document landscape, Adobe's Acrobat format has become the "Kleenex" of document management. And while Adobe created the format, it has at times over the years provided little improvement year-over-year at a heavy cost. Enter Adobe Acrobat Pro DC, and you will find the first truly major upgrade to functionality and quality that Adobe has delivered in many years. And, at the same time, Adobe has confused the delivery model, offering standalone / perpetual licenses (the version reviewed here) as well as ongoing monthly subscriptions. The choices while more confusing also offer more value at a lower yearly cost.So what's new with this release? Quite a bit. Adobe has finally overhauled the core imaging / OCR / font engine to provide some truly breakthrough improvements in quality and accuracy. For scanned images, Acrobat now will recreate the native font outlines in its OCR process (buried in the "Enhance" area), although this does occasionally create some interesting editing artifacts. Flowing, multi-column text is handled much better than in previous releases. Form handling and recognition is much more accurate, especially across platforms. Exports from PDF to native formats (Microsoft Office, etc) are much more accurate and useful. Spell checking is finally included.With this release, Adobe also introduces a cloud platform DC short for Document Cloud for PDF sharing across devices and platforms (Windows, Mac, iOS, Android). If you have an existing Adobe cloud subscription (even a limited use one such as PhotoShop / Lightroom CC) you can access the Document Cloud for free (within your 20GB limit). This applies to both perpetual and monthly license versions of Acrobat / Acrobat Pro. However, today DC is only used by Adobe Acrobat and its associated desktop and mobile platforms. You can't share / save files to other cloud services (Amazon, Box, Dropbox, iCloud, Office365, etc). And even more confusingly, the Adobe Document Cloud is not viewable within the Creative Cloud documents.If you purchase the standalone / perpetual license you have no document signing capabilities. Adobe previously offered EchoSign for a monthly fee. That functionality has now been replaced by the monthly licenses of Acrobat DC or Acrobat Pro DC. If you purchase the standalone version (reviewed here) you have no electronic signature or workflow capability. Compared to Adobe's Photography bundle (Photoshop CC and Lightroom CC at $10/month), Acrobat Pro DC isn't a very good value. Acrobat DC is $13/month (paid annually) or $15/month for Acrobat Pro CC. If you need a lot of electronic signatures, the fee is worth it alone. On the other hand, if you don't need e-signatures, and you don't anticipate upgrading Acrobat every year, you may do better with a traditional perpetual license.What does the "Pro" version give you for an extra $200? (or $2/month subscription):- PDF file optimization (size / compression / version compatibility)- Redaction- Preflighting (checking document prior to professional press printing)- Bates numbering- Document Version ComparisonsFYI - For Windows users, this is the first release of Adobe Acrobat Pro that will NOT support Windows XP.In the "one step back" category, Adobe has attempted to "simplify" the user interface, replacing the traditional 3-panel (Tools, Fil&Sign, Comment) interface and replaced it with more of a touch-oriented set of icons and submenus. On one level, this highlights capabilities that were previously buried within various tabs. Adobe also lets you customize the toolbar from among the many functions. But, on the other hand, some common operations such as "Recognize Text" now become a 4-step process across multiple toolbars / ribbons that used to be 2 user interface clicks.All-in-all, this is a very solid upgrade, and for the first time in many years, one worthy of spending $$ to upgrade. The real / new question is how often you plan to upgrade Acrobat, and if you need electronic signatures. That alone may drive the value in a monthly subscription.

The Plus Guard Your ID Roller has a simple premise - a rolling ink applicator that applies a wide (just over an inch) circulating pattern of dark X's over any (non-glossy) surface. And while it may be better than nothing for things like pill bottles that aren't always easy to remove a label, it is far from the security of a paper shredder.The trick, as others have noted, is that holding the item at an angle clearly reveals the original text underneath on most surfaces. So for medium-security items (you're not going to have your identity stolen from a prescription bottle), this is ok. For higher-security items (financial statements, social security reports, taxes, credit card offers) you still need to use your cross-cut shredder.And, at $13+, with non-refillable ink, this is no bargain either.

Let's face it. Keurig coffee makers are great for their convenience but after a while you get tired of seeing the same limited options for sale.Café Diario offers a nice alternative with its own unique flavor. Rich, balanced, with a hint of cinnamon-like infusion, I enjoyed the regular K-Cups, but am not convinced they beat my favorite Starbucks Veranda (Bold).

The Slice 10513 Pen Cutter ceramic knife sounds like an awesome idea - stronger, safer, and longer-lasting than traditional metal cutters.Unfortunately, for whatever reason, the Slice just doesn't "cut it". The first thing I tried it on was the thin plastic cover on a CD. I had to try 3 times, and it still barely cut the surface. FAIL. Next, I tried it to cut through the packaging tape on a shipped package. And while the first slice seemed to work fine, I found that 2 out of 3 times I had to try again. Even cutting through the cardboard. I just don't know why anyone would allow such a flawed product to be released. I have tried multiple knife positions, angles, and pressures and just can't get this to perform.

Make no mistake, the Lonely Planet 2016 wall calendar is a treat every month with a beautiful photograph and LOTS of great information about a new location. Each calendar includes the photo, location name, top things to see, top things to do, average temperature, random facts, and a big "thing to do" smacked in a big box over the photo.It is this last point that is really irritating a lot of people, especially since the back cover of the calendar only shows the picture, not what you actually see each month (a picture with a big box of text).And, someone went OVERBOARD on the formatting of this calendar, placing a big bold circle around each day of the month. From a distance, the calendar pops from your wall more from the "polka dot" calendar below as much from the stunning photo above.Whoever led the layout of this calendar needs to go back to graphic design school.

There is a LOT to like about the SteamFast SF-295 3-in-1 Steam Mop. Very high-quality construction, easy-to-fill and fairly large (15 oz) tank, super-fast heat-up, strong, adjustable steam. Included are a number of attachments for floor cleaning (with 2 washable microfiber mats), clothes, fabric, even steel/grill cleaning. The adjustable metal handle is great for mopping, and includes storage lugs for the power cord.Steam is strong and even, with 7 adjustable levels. You have to wait for the steamer to heat up before you can change the steam level, however (this is not explained in the manual). Everything from low-level (1) for sealed hardwood floors to level (7). Somewhat annoying - you cannot actually see the level indicator when viewing off-angle.But for some reason, even with different steam strengths, using this for clothes steaming ends up leaving a lot of water drops. For most clothes this is ok, but for some fabrics you may be left with marks. And, the water is HOT and tends to drip on your hands as you steam.Minor annoyances - the cord is long, but not quite long enough for larger rooms. Definitely not as long as most vacuum cleaner cords. And the release mechanism for the metal handle is somewhat finicky, and needs to be twisted to latch.

Avery makes great, quality, jam-free labels, and the Avery 95935 White Shipping Labels, 3-1/2 x 5 Inches (pack of 1000) is no exception. Great, consistent results, works well in both inkjet and laser printers.However, unless you print a LOT of shipping labels on your inkjet printer (and, I would doubt you would at the cost of ink!), I don't see a reason to buy this bulk pack when you can buy the 5168 labels for the same low price per label.AND, unlike these labels, both the 5168 (laser) and 8168 (inkjet) labels offer "Avery TrueBlock" which completely covers anything below. These labels do show any writing or previous marks underneath them.

First of all, let me say that the Tanors Aerator performs just as well, if not just a slight bit better, than the "gold standard" Vinturi aerator, which I also own. Its design has multiple aeration points and cascades the wine.But I can't give it 5 stars because its design is overly complex - and has multiple small parts including a small plastic "header" that easily detach and can get lost during cleaning.The Vinturi on the other hand is made of a higher quality composite material, and is very simple to clean.

Let met start by saying that the Bose QuietComfort 20 in-hear noise canceling headphones are without a doubt the most COMFORTABLE pair of in-ear headphones I have ever owned. Bose includes 3 different ear sizes, and you should try all 3 for BOTH ears for best fit and sound isolation. My ears actually needed two different sizes.Given their overall performance at this price, I highly recommend them - assuming you don't mind the Bose "signature sound" profile, which is pleasing, but not necessarily accurate (aka flat).I am an audiophile - although not to the extreme of an "audio fool". My daily in-ear headphones are $500 Sure e535's which are in a class of their own - three drivers, super accurate (flat) sound profile, replaceable cables. Unlike the Bose, the Shure does not offer active noise cancellation, but with the right tip their noise isolation is excellent. And there is no comparison in sound quality - at more than twice the price of the Bose.Bose is popular for a reason. Just like the RCA "Golden Throat" design of the 1960's, Bose knows that most people prefer a sound profile that is clear, accentuated on the bass, and forward in the mid-range. And these headphones are no exception in that sound profile, although not quite as inaccurate as other Bose offerings. Treble is balanced but not necessarily "bright". On the other hand, there is very little distortion even at maximum listening levels (although you should note that maximum sound volume is lower on these earphones than some others).It's only when you compare in a-to-b tests against a true "reference" earphone like the Shure e535 that you will notice "missing" instruments that are drowned out by the Bose sound curve. Listen to vocals with orchestration such as Lana Del Ray's "Born to Die" or even The Dixie Chicks "The Long Way Around" and you'll discover just how dramatic the sound difference is. On Rene Fleming's "You'll Never Walk Alone" you'll notice the drum rolls are cloudy, bass is "muddy", and instruments like cymbals fade into the background.On the other hand, synthesized pop and electronic music sounds great and although not as clear as the reference headphones, this is a definite "sweet spot" for these Bose earphones.I've also found that battery life is much better than Bose's advertised 12 hours. This is good because the even though you can use them with the active noise isolation turned off, the sound quality is DRAMATICALLY worse, so you will want to have it on at all times. If you need to be aware of outside sounds, there is an "Aware" mode that lets more ambient noise through.In summary:>> Pros- super comfortable, no need to wrap earphone cable around ear- multiple ear size choices - try for both ears (mine differed)- surprisingly good sound, despite "Bose signature" sound profile remarkably clear mid-range, if not a bit too "forward" crisp and controlled, but slightly over-emphasized bass de-emphasized treble- outstanding battery life, way beyond the claimed 12-hoursCons- maximum volume level isn't as loud as other earphones should only be an issue for those already hard of hearing- dramatically worse sound quality when active noise circuit is off- white noise when noise circuit is turned on not noticeable in louder environments (eg. Airplanes)- lack of upper-end (treble) frequency response specs are not trustworthy (they don't indicate cutoff)- noise module is permanently connected near headphone plug- headphone cable is permanently attached (cannot be easily replaced)- Bass can be a bit muddyNotes- be careful changing ear plugs; twist the entire base don't grab the end

Although touted as "the missing manual" series aka "the book that should have been in the box", I would not consider FileMaker Pro 14 The Missing Manual a replacement for the built-in Getting Started Tutorials or Reference documentation. Rather, it falls nicely in the middle, bridging the gap between the excellent and interactive but fairly basic Apple tutorials and the complete reference documentation. As such, this targets an intermediate (not beginner, not advanced) audience, even though there is a lot to learn even for seasoned long-time FileMaker developers like myself.Two tips you won't regret:1) Register your book at O'Reilly, and for $4.99 you can order the PDF / eBook version. This book is 946 pages so it's not easy to carry with you.2) Make sure you download the "Missing CD" tutorial files to follow along with the chapters

I'm a frequent traveler and have become VERY efficient packing, but packing cubes really make a difference to help organize and to keep clothes from shifting / getting further wrinkled. That being said, the packing cube is only as efficient as it matches the size of your suitcase.These Amazon Basics Packing Cubes are lightweight and appear to be durable, although only time will tell. Double-zippered design, open mesh for breathability, if you find the right size combination you will be pleased.That being said, Amazon Basics are known for their quality and value (aka lower price). And yet, there are known "name brands" such as eBags that are equivalent quality, come in many more sizes and colors, for about the same price.

There is no question the Linea Luxury Shower Squeegee is beautiful. But that is the only good thing I can say about this over-priced, brittle squeegee.The fundamental design flaw is that the clear handle is VERY brittle. One drop and it breaks. INSTANTLY. And guess what? Like most shower squeegees, no matter how much you try to get the suction cup holder to stay, it will fail, the squeegee falls, and BAM! the handle breaks.To make matters even more aggravating, the packaging forces you get a scissors to remove the suction holder - it apparently was put together around the packaging.Save your money and avoid this!

Based on past experience, Belkin has had some bumps in the road releasing Apple-certified Lightning cables. Early on, I experienced failures to recognize, but in all cases Belkin customer service replaced the cables, and the new ones have worked without issues since.While the Lightning connectors on early Belkin cables were larger than Apple's compact connector, the newest versions including this MIXIT cable are just as compact as Apple's offering, letting you use your protective cases.I've been using Belkin's 6" black Lightning USB cable to connect to my compact Jackery backup battery without issue. It is one of the few truly Apple-certified cables available in this short length.Belkin's new MIXIT Metallic Lightning to USB cables are a new offering. It offers metal USB / Lightning connectors, with a clear braided cable in colors to match your iPhone. Like other Belkin cables, it works well with no compatibility issues.My only concerns that keep from a 5-star rating are:1) the metal connectors while beautiful can scratch other items that may be in your pocket, purse, or backpack2) this cable is $7-$10 more than the same Belkin plastic cables that are just as compatible and offered in multiple colorsSo the question is whether the extra price is worth it for purely aesthetic reasons.

Let's face it, there's no better way to get that fresh-breath feeling than Orbit gum!Unlike previous multi-flavor packaging, this 12-pack variety pack includes 4 different mint flavors - all of them excellent in taste. Each pack has 14 pieces of gum.Note that the Amazon product listing is incorrect. You receive:4 Spearmint4 Peppermint2 Wintermint2 Sweet mint

Norton Security with Backup is the latest version of Symantec's trusted cross-platform security and utility suite (formerly known as Norton 360 Premier). This new release adds some solid features not present in its prior incarnation known as Norton 360 Premier, including support for 10 devices (Windows, Mac, Android), Identify Safe password management, an updated / simplified user interface, and the Norton Virus Protection Promise (which provides remote support for virus removal at no charge if the automatic engine can't remove an infection).And while I like the new features and the increased flexibility beyond the "1-3 PCs" offered in the prior Norton 360, my initial experience left a bad taste.First of all, even though this is essentially the latest version of Norton360 Premier, the install does NOT retain any prior subscription you may have. So unless you REALLY need the new features in this release or need to support more than 3 devices, wait until your existing Norton 360 subscription is near its end before upgrading to Norton Security.Secondly - and more concerning - is the stability of the installer. The first machine I tried to install this on was running the latest version of Windows 8.1 (with all latest Microsoft updates). The installer recognized a prior installation of Norton 360 Premier and proceeded to uninstall and reboot to continue. But on restart, Windows indicated it was attempting an "Automatic Repair". Ultimately, the Windows repairs FAILED - the error (0xC000021A) is a corruption of the Windows login files that could not be fixed by Automatic Repair, or even attempting to boot into Safe Mode. Lucky for me, I had a recent image backup of this Windows 8.1 install, although I suspect I could have tried to reinstall Windows 8 from the USB media.Speaking of Backups - once again, the Backup capabilities of Norton Security are very basic and file-based, ultimately tied to Norton's online backup services. You get 25GB of free storage but there is no ability to perform a Windows system backup like TrueImage and others offer (Norton used to offer Ghost but this capability has long since been removed from the suite). So while your files are protected, your system is not.Some may be surprised to see there is no CD or physical media - you are pointed to a URL (website) to enter your key and download the Norton setup program (a 1MB file), which you then launch for an additional (125MB) download of the actual product installer. Given that fewer devices are bundled with CD/DVD drives, I think this is a better approach - it always gives you the latest version of the installer and allows Norton to stay up-to-date with platform changes.

This is my third Brother Label Maker and in general I much prefer the Brother models to competing brands (eg. Epson). Brother's tapes are much easier to find and less expensive (often discounted). Even with the extra waste at the edges, the Brother ultimately costs less than the Epson.The Brother PTD400AD is a definite step-up from earlier entry-level models. I owned a PT1750 which has served me well for years. This new model is completely updated although not much larger than the previous generation. It's wider and shorter, allowing larger keys and more dedicated buttons including arrow keys, punctuation, Tab, and dedicated buttons for Font, Label, Frame, Symbol, Sample Labels, and Bar Codes. It prints about 50% faster than my old model and accepts thinner (3.5mm) tape (up to a maximum of 18mm). The display has multiple lines, and indicates format, font, and border. And with a memory, it remembers frequent phrases and labels.So what's not to like? The display is MUCH harder to read, even in good lighting. For all that this is a fantastic label printer, the display alone may be a deal-breaker for some especially if you have to use it on a daily basis.For $20 more, you can buy the PTD450 which has a backlit display, AND it has a USB connection for printing from your computer.Also note that this requires the newer "TZe" tapes. If you have an older "TZ" tape it will not work (and won't even load).

First of all, let me state that the quality and finish of these woven vinyl placemats are outstanding - way above average and easy to clean. Unfortunately, the square shape limits their usefulness in anything more than a casual lunch. You just won't have room for dinner dishes, silverware, and glassware. As you can see from the photo I uploaded, an average dinner plate covers most of this matt.

While the 3M Paint Defender Door Edge Protection Film sounded like a good idea, it failed right from the start even under the conditions outlined in the instructions. Ultimately, the film is not thin and this keeps it from properly following the contours of the average door, buckling and refusing to adhere along the way. Don't waste your time on this.

While there are many good choices for inexpensive Bluetooth Heart Rate monitors, Wahoo Fitness differentiates with the addition of an accelerometer for motion and stride. And the companion Wahoo Fitness app really makes this device shine with stride analytics.The packaging is very minimalist - there is no manual, not even a setup guide, so if you want to get started you must download this (there is a QR code to scan if you want a quick link). I would have preferred at least some simple instructions. That being said, once you actually find the setup / pairing instructions, I found it to be reliable and easy. The chest band is very comfortable, lightweight and good quality. Unlike other HR monitors, the Wahoo includes activity LEDs to let you know it's actually powered on / available for pairing.I'm not a runner - I'm a heavy walker, so the run analytics are limited use for me. But I did like the ability to "calibrate" the device for treadmill use, so I can keep track of my stride and distance without relying on the phone's GPS like most other fitness apps do.All in all, the $30 (or so) premium over heartrate-only devices is worth it for me.

The Epson LabelWorks LW-600P is truly (for now) in a class of its own: a bluetooth-enabled label printer with apps for iOS (iPhone or iPad) and Android. That being said, after using it for a couple weeks, I'm really missing the convenience of a physical keyboard for those times you need to print of a quick label.First of all, the hardware. Epson has really designed a beautiful, compact, easy-to-load printer. Unlike many of Epson's standalone label printers, the tape is very easy to load, and it is easy to access the print head for cleaning if necessary. The unit operates on 6 AA batteries (not included) or AC power.There are some strange limitations, however:- Epson has chosen not to release Bluetooth print drivers for either Mac OS X or Windows. So, if you want to use the printer from your Mac or PC, you will have to use the physical USB cable (included), and manually download the drivers from Epson's website. For Mac OS X, you download "Epson Label Editor Lite" (free) from the OS X App Store. Not sure why it's called "Lite" because there is no "FULL" version by the way.- For Bluetooth, the printer does not support multiple simultaneous connections. So while you can pair it with multiple devices, only one device can be connected at a time. This is problematic in an office or small workgroup if you want to share the printer. Or even if you have an iPhone and an iPad. You must make sure the other device is disconnected, and then connect from the device you want to use.Epson offers many different label options, sizes, and colors, including some unusual ones (iron-on, glow-in-the-dark, even printed ribbon). Unlike the competing Brother TZ tapes, Epson's tape is generally not discounted, so you will pay 2x the price for a tape cartridge of roughly the same length. The extra cost is (mostly) offset by Epson's ability to print with much smaller margins than the Brother printers. My Brother PT-2730 wastes 1.25" combined for every label I print manually. (If you print from a computer, the Brother is much closer to the Epson in margin savings.)The label printing software is quirky, but useful. You can easily add images from many categories (numbers, characters, images) or your own clip art. It is super-easy to create Barcodes or QR codes.- on iOS, the print preview is WYSIWG to size and scale, but it is NOT WYSIWG on Mac OS X (I would assume not on Windows either)- on iOS, Epson's "auto cut" feature really does calculate the end of the label and cut it for you (but it does not closely trim on Mac OS X)- on iOS, the interface is confusing and non-standard (click Left to insert an image?, want to remove an image? choose "image alignment NONE")- on iOS, the label preview function can use the camera to show what the label would like like on a physical item, but it isn't smart enough to preview with the actual label color (you can manually set the R/G/B color of the preview)- BIG PROBLEM on Mac OSX: despite many font choices, BOLD, font sizes, I could NEVER print a bold easy-to-read label (the labels always printed in lightweight fonts that are hard to read)In the end, after really putting this little printer to the test, I found myself wanting a physical keyboard. Unless you're putting together a complicated label, most of the time I find I just need to quickly type some text and print. With the Epson LW-600P, I have to fire up my iPhone or iPad, connect the bluetooth to the printer, fire up the iOS "Epson iLabel" software, type on the phone keyboard, and print.Considering how much more (3x) the LW-600P costs than a regular Epson label printer with a physical keyboard, I can't say I could recommend this unless your needs are different.

Any claims that this is an exact copy of the 1911 Edison Opera are unfounded. I've uploaded a photo of the original Edison model, which plays 4-minute Edison cylinder records.What Brookstone appears to have done with this unit is copied one of the various inexpensive "crapophone" units made in India in the 1950's-1980's.

I've been a big fan of the Sabrent all-metal USB 3 enclosures, so when it was time to house my 12.5mm drive (Seagate FreePlay 1.5TB), I chose this enclosure.Like the other Sabrent enclosures, the USB 3 interface is super-fast (reaching over 80MB/s read and write with the Seagate drive).However, the case design isn't so hot. The upper and lower metal plates are held in place by short metal tabs on one end, and 2 small screws on the other. The tabs aren't very deep, so I found that the plates easily pop off near the tabs.Worse yet - despite being advertised as a 12.5mm case housing, it can't quite fit my 12.mm Seagate drive. The lower plate is fine, but the upper plate is about 3mm too short. If you don't mind wrapping black electrical tape around the enclosure, it will at least house and protect a 12.mm drive. But not elegant or as advertised.

Based on many good reviews, I bought the Areca 8050T2 (Thunderbolt2 version). Unlike the Thunderbolt1 cabinet, the T2 is not being discounted right now, but I felt the investment was worth it for the performance. Boy am I pleased!Outfitted with 8 x 4TB Western Digital enterprise-class drives (7200rpm), formatted for RAID5, I'm actually getting BETTER speeds from the Areca array than the built-in PCIe SSD in my new 8-core MacPro (2013 version) - 1035 MB/s write and 975 MB/s read. For comparison, the built-in PCIe SSD gets 935MB/s write and 925 MB/s read. That's REALLY impressive especially given RAID5.If you're a fan of pretty light shows, the Areca won't disappoint either - especially during its (minute and a half) startup sequence. On the other hand, the LEDs are very bright which may be distracting to some people.My only complaints are with the fan noise. I guess I've been spoiled for too long from the built-in fans in my prior 2009 MacPro. Starting up, the Areca sounds like a wind tunnel, but after its startup is complete, the fan noise drops to acceptable levels. But any workload raises the fan to a noticeable (but not harsh) level. In my quiet office, this was enough for me to splurge on the Corning 10 meter optical Thunderbolt cable to relocate the unit to another room.But this brings up a final point that is critical for any RAID enclosure - power failure. Areca offers an optional battery backup unit for the 8050 (part number ARC-6120BA-T021) that you can order from their website for $150 (sometimes discounted). It doesn't keep the unit powered on, but it does protect the write cache for up to 72 hours. Without this backup, if you lose power during a critical write operation, it is possible to lose all data in certain striped RAID configurations (this is true of ANY RAID controller).Two final tips:1) the Firmware Update does not work with Safari, although every other configuration does. I ended up successfully updating the firmware with Firefox2) you MUST install the Areca Driver/Utility in order to use an Optical Thunderbolt cable

UPDATED: since I posted my review, Anker's amazing customer service reached out to me, offering to replace the unit. We actually went through two more units before finding one with a reliable eSATA connection. What is interesting - and is noted in the product specifications included with the unit - is that the eSATA connection is actually rated *SLOWER* (3gb/s) than the USB3 connection (5gb/s). So, I am now upgrading my review to a 4-star rating, as long as you have a USB3 port to properly leverage this dock's speed.First of all, it's tough to beat the price on this dock. And, I was very pleased with its USB3 performance (148MB/s write, 156MB/s read) with my 4TB Seagate Barracuda 5900rpm drive. That's impressive.  As long as you have a USB3 port to leverage the maximum speed, you can't beat this dock.  The eSATA port (which I had to go through 3 units to find one that worked reliably) is actually rated slower (3gb/s) than the USB3 connection.If there is any slight criticism of this unit, it is the non-hardened finish of the protective plastic door that is scratched the first time you insert a drive. But that is just a minor cosmetic issue.For some reason, it's not easy to find a good, reliable external drive dock these days. For almost 2 years my OWC Newer Technology Voyager Q dock was rock-solid through its eSATA and FireWire 800 connections. Based on reviews of that model and its super-high failure rates, I must have been lucky to have mine fail "only" 18 months into use, and outside the warranty replacement timeframe. Thinking that the issues would have been corrected, I ordered the latest (USB3/eSATA/Firewire800) of the Voyager Q only to find it dead-on-arrival with a completely non-working eSATA port.Enter the Anker USB3/eSATA docking station. For half the price of the Voyager Q you get a super-fast USB3 connection but no FireWire800 port for legacy Macs. But its price and reliability, combined with amazing customer service, are enough for me to rate this a must-buy as long as you have a USB3 port to leverage its speed.

There was so much to expect with Catch.44 - especially with the likes of Bruce Willis and Forest Whitaker as leads. And while Forest especially provides a convincing, if not disturbing portrayal, ultimately the weak script doesn't provide enough leeway for even these seasoned actors to overcome.Throughout the movie, I kept waiting for that breakthrough moment where something deeper, more unusual emerged to bring the story tracks together. And, ultimately I was disappointed by a fairly simple plot, with a focus on high body counts and violence than any sort of depth of character.
