It's as if the filmmaker was trying to reach for a "Pulp Fiction" level of cult delivery, sadly missing in delivery.So, that being said, if you're looking for a high-body-count movie with the guys, some brilliance from Forest Whitaker's disturbing portrayal, and nothing more than go for Catch.44. Otherwise, move on, don't even look, you're going to be left disappointed.

If you're used to using cheap scissors, you will be very surprised using titanium scissors. And, the Westcott Titanium Bonded scissors are very sharp, with a soft-grip handle that is comfortable.But, compared to my favorite (3M Scotch Titanium Non-stick), the Westcott falls short. The cutting blade on these scissors is not particularly long, and for just a bit more, the 3M / Scotch scissors are even sharper, and offer a nonstick finish.

Make no mistake, I *love* my iPhone - but the one thing I missed for work is the high-quality OEM leather belt holster that Blackberry offers. I've looked all around, and there simply isn't much choice for an iPhone belt holster. A few case makers offer bulky, clunky case+holster combinations, but unless you're an aircraft mechanic with a need for industrial-strength protection, these choices are just plain ugly and ungainly.I must say that this leather iPhone holster is a very good value, and surprisingly good quality leather and construction, with even a leather (not microfiber) lining. The oversized cover folds with a solid magnetic closure. It's also a good fit for my older iPhone 3GS with case and my new iPhone 4S. If your case is bulky, though, it probably won't fit this holster.What prevents me from giving this the full 5 stars is the clip design. First of all, it is hard-fastened so you are stuck with horizontal orientation on your belt. That may be more secure / reliable than pivoting designs, but I do like to have the choice.The more serious problem for me is that the clip is EXTREMELY tight. It is literally a fight every time to get it over my average-thickness dress belt. Again, this probably makes it secure, and the included belt loops (which you don't have to use) give the ultimate stability. But the tightness of the clip was a breaker for me. I will keep this holster as a backup, but for now my iPhone holster of choice is the Rocketfish design.

Make no mistake, I *love* my iPhone - but the one thing I missed for work is the high-quality OEM leather belt holster that Blackberry offers. I've looked all around, and there simply isn't much choice for an iPhone belt holster. A few case makers offer bulky, clunky case+holster combinations, but unless you're an aircraft mechanic with a need for industrial-strength protection, these choices are just plain ugly and ungainly.I'd almost given up my search when I found the Rocketfish Mobile Leather holster case. This is one fine iPhone holster! Nice quality leather with a microfiber lining, and a strong belt clip that pivots to allow horizontal or vertical orientation. The oversized cover folds over with a magnetic closure, giving firm closure. And there is a small slip pocket in the front, although sadly not large enough for business cards. Perhaps a few coins to keep out of your pocket at best. Or, maybe an SD memory card.The Rocketfish holster fits both my older iPhone 3GS with its thin Seidio case, as well as my iPhone 4S with the outstanding elago thin-profile case. If you have a bulkier iPhone case, you probably won't be able to fit it in this holster.There is another leather iPhone holster for sale here on Amazon that is *close* but not quite to the quality of the Rocketfish. That holster has a belt clasp that doesn't rotate, and is nearly impossible to get over your belt.In summary, this is to me the near-perfect iPhone holster. Not only does it match what I was used to with the OEM Blackberry holster, it takes it beyond in quality and features. I'm thrilled.

The first thing you notice with the Invicata Men's 1531 Subaqua collection chronograph watch is its storage case. Matte yellow, with an undulating design pattern on the top, it's a hint of the quality timepiece lurking within.And the 1531 Subaqua watch doesn't disappoint. The face is a stunning, 3-dimensional array of watch hands, sweep seconds, date, and count-down chronograph, surrounded by a matte-gold plated stainless surround with shiny numbers, a thick chrome body, and amazingly comfortable black silicone band. The crystal is made of Invicta's "flame-fusion" process, which creates a scratch-resistant and extremely easy-to-view (low reflection) surface. I'm not particularly confident in it's scratch-resistance compared to more premium sapphire crystals, but it makes for a stunning watch face.What you do have to be prepared for with this watch is its size. One word - MASSIVE. On my small wrists it looks plain stupid (it's about 1/2-an-inch thick), and at nearly a 1/2 a pound in weight I just didn't find it comfortable.On the other hand, my friend who has average-sized wrists simply LOVES this watch and the bold statement it makes. And, at Amazon's pricing it's quite the value. On the other hand, I don't think I'd pay the suggested retail pricing when you consider other premium alternatives at that (full-price) range.

As a long-time owner of the Plantronics 975 in-ear headset, I was eager to try the Jabra Extreme2 with its promised noise cancellation features, and modern Bluetooth features (battery level, address book/voice dialing, multiuse).Perhaps I've been spoiled by the feather-light weight of my older Plantronics, but the first thing I noticed with the Jabra Extreme2 is that you can *really* feel the bulk of this on your ear. Jabra includes "Ultimate Comfort Eargels" to support in-ear wearing instead of the over-the-ear hook, but the bulk of the headset means it's not very stable in your ear. If you want to press the answer/end button, for example, you need to hold your fingers on the unit, then press. Not something very natural.The bigger problem for me was audio quality. When I switched between my 3-year-old Plantronics and the new Jabra Extreme2, people on the other side of the line complained that my voice sounded "muffled" like I was talking through a tissue. Their voices sounded fine to me, but even at the highest volume setting, it was still difficult to hear them in all environments. And, despite the promised noise cancellation technology - in wind outside, callers preferred my older Plantronics than this Jabra for background noise cancellation.It's a shame, because there's a lot to like with the Jabra Extreme 2. It supports the latest Bluetooth audio streaming (A2DP), can *simultaneously* connect to two different phones (VERY slick), voice-announces the callerID (if your phone supports it), and even shows the bluetooth battery level on your phone (again, if your phone supports it - my iPhone 4S does). Jabra even provides connectors for charging the unit through USB, 12-volt car, or A/C power. The A/C power cord, however, is ridiculously short (12 inches!) The unit also speaks connection status and battery level with a clear easy-to-understand female voice.On another positive note, I found the battery life to be outstanding (over 3.5 hours of talk time).In the end, the poor sound quality, low volume, and overall fit were deal-breakers for me. It's a shame, because the advanced connectivity, simultaneous 2-phone support, and battery life are outstanding.

I was eager to try the Cyber Clean Shoe RX on my trusty pair of sneakers - which don't have a strong odor, but I figured would be perfect candidates to freshen-up.The product is interesting, as others have said. It's a gel-like blob that you form into the bottom of the shoe, and forward to the toe area, picking up debris along the way.While it did clean out some of the dirt down deep in the toes, I didn't really notice a significant improvement in the overall "freshness" of the shoes, despite the product claims. Hence, 3 stars for actually picking up debris inside your shoes, -2 stars for not really freshening the smell.

This small pack of 5 different "eco-friendly" cleaners is great to have in your car for that quick clean. With the exception of the leather cleaner, which did its job and no more but has a STRANGE smell, I was very pleased with the performance of the other cleaners.The Window cleaner in particular cleans without streaks, and doesn't require a large amount of fluid to do its job right the first pass. And that's good, because this isn't exactly the cheapest set of car cleaners, but you can buy refills in larger sizes.Likewise, the dash cleaner cleans with a matte no-shine finish without needing a lot of product.I only wish that, for this price, cleaning cloths would have been included.

For years, X-ACTO has been the standard for utility and craft alike. Now, with its new Z Series, X-ACTO shows that you really can teach an old dog new tricks, with a super-sharp and VERY durable blade that lasts long after others have dulled.I put this knife through its paces, just as I would my classic X-ACTO. Cutting cardboard, opening boxes, trimming grout in the bathroom, and after 2 weeks the knife is still as sharp as it was when I started. I would have been on my 2nd or 3rd classic blade by now.If there is any complaint, and it is minor, the protective plastic cap doesn't fit very firmly, so I'm careful when taking it out to use.

For anyone who's ever wanted to find an individual outlet switch, you'll know that there aren't many to choose from, and what you generally do find is a clunky and two-pole (ungrounded) design.The Belkin F7C016q Conserve Power Switch is a refreshing design, providing a three-pole (grounded) switch at each outlet. Belkin's switch is small enough, that you can co-locate them, providing individual control for both outlets in a standard wall jack. And, a soft green light near the side switch indicates when it is turned on. This is a great option where you need a switch instead of unplugging all the time. For example, a Christmas tree (if you can reach the plug), or a power-hungry appliance.What is not clear, is the supposed "up to $100 in annual savings" from using this switch. Not every device has a power drain when plugged in (although many electronics do). And, it doesn't always make sense to unplug/turn-off every appliance. If you switch off your coffee maker, for example, you'll need to reset the clock.

I love devotionals, and Christmas devotionals are just special. I also greatly enjoyed Reverend Louie Giglio's other work, Indescribable. which I saw as a film. When I saw this book offered on Booklook (for bloggers) I was quick to request it. WAITING HERE FOR YOU lived up to its expectations. Interesting, engaging, and a great way to start the day.The devotions are short, easily read in less than five minutes. They include a verse, reflection on the verse, a poem or hymn to mediate on, and a prayer for us to pray. It isn't really deep, but isn't intended as a Bible study, but rather a moment with God.This book will be joining the other devotionals I'm keeping for reading during this advent season.  Highly recommended as a devotional for yourself -- and buy one for a gift as well.
My husband got this shirt for his birthday (he has to wear them to work) and he LOVES this brand.
recommended by my dentist.  Makes a differerence

SILENT NIGHT is a totally cute romantic suspense novella, set around Ms. Coble's wildly popular Rock Harbor series.  I enjoyed catching up with Bree, Kade, and Laurie, and the other residents of Rock Harbor. The mystery was short, but this is a novella, so it was just right. If you love romantic suspense, then pick up a copy of SILENT NIGHT today.

EVERY GIRL GETS CONFUSED is laugh out loud funny at times. I greatly enjoyed catching up on Katie Sue's love life and her adorably charming family--both "real time" and "work related."  I got such a kick out of some of the things in this book.Ms. Thompson is truly the queen of romantic comedy--and with her trade-mark bridal series this is sure to be a hit with current fans and new readers alike!I do recommend reading Every Bride Needs a Groom as it truly doesn't stand alone. This is a continuation of the story. And I can't wait for the third book, Every Bride Has Her Day coming in Summer 2016.I highly recommend EVERY GIRL GETS CONFUSED as well the first book in the Brides with Style series. It ended with a happy sigh.

THE OLOGY is a very good book. I like the way it's written. It's simple, but in a complex way. The story about the two children discovering the ancient book in the old stone cathedral is very interesting. I especially like the part of the story where as soon as they pick the book up it turns into a book that even a child can read. I recommend this book to anyone who wants to learn theology at a young age. Very interesting book and story. Beautiful illustrations and many issues are discussed in a way anyone can understand.
my son scored high enough to get into any class he wants in his chosen branch of the military. He said this book really helped refresh his skills.

HIGH-CALIBER HOLIDAY is the third book in this high-suspense series, but it easily stands alone. I enjoyed getting to know Morgan and Brady and getting reacquainted with the other team members who all interact in this close-knit group of friends who work together in one way or another.I thought this was too cut and dried -- at first -- as the book starts with her threatened death but the bad guy is quickly apprehended... But the stalking continues. Roses. Pictures. It is apparent that her stalker knows her well. And has an vendetta against her. Brady and the police as well as his friends work together to profile the stalker--but who is it? And will they figure it out before time runs out?If  you like romantic suspense, you will love Susan Sleeman's books. I couldn't put High-Caliber Holiday down and read it on a Sunday afternoon. My heart went out to Brady, he's been so badly hurt. Morgan was extremely nice and caring--but a bit testy at times.Recommended.

Football is not something I'm drawn to, and if I were to judge a book by the cover, I'd likely choose not to read this book. It would be a mistake. Cassie and Reed are realistic characters with struggles most of us can identify with. Cassie has been badly hurt by a football star, and it is her worse nightmare when she's assigned a job working with them in her work-study assignment. Reed struggles with trying to be good enough to catch his parent's attention. He knows what he wants, but rules seem to work against him.I loved the main characters, but some of the secondary characters won my hearts just as much. Marquis, Hunter... I wanted more about them.  Derek vaguely reminded me of someone I know--thankfully not to the same extent...Candee Fick delivers an impeccable debut in this remarkable tale, filled with vivid storytelling. Catch of a Lifetime invites readers onto a journey of a lifetime as Cassie and Reed discover that even when they fumble the ball, or are getting blindsided in the red zone, the whistle hasn’t blown. The play is still alive, The Coach is on the sidelines, and His playbook is always available. This story is sure to score a touchdown with football fans and romance readers alike.Highly recommended.

This was a charming Christmas story. Kind of slow and depressing at first as Judith is having a hard time coping with the empty nest. She has no life outside her family and now all of them were gone, ,except her husband. Stan and her best friend, Betty, try to cheer her up but nothing seems to help. Judith doesn't even want to decorate for Christmas and it's  her favorite holiday. Stan is at wit's end. He's trying to come up with brilliant ideas and plans to brighten Judith up, even helps her decorate, but no. Nothing. Not even a glimmer.There was so much I could relate to in this book.  The tradition. The time working moms and children don't have together anymore due to jobs and school (unlike those of us raised with stay-at-home moms).  The technology erasing family time. I think we can all point to a recent holiday when no one looked away from their smart phone or tablet.  Conversation? Gone. Kids playing outside? Gone. Everyone is too busy staring at a screen.I love Mr. Walsh's Christmas books (fell in love with him with his first, The Unfinished Gift, and highly recommend KEEPING CHRISTMAS.  So many wonderful Christmas stories out this year, and this is one of them.I absolutely loved Stan. I connected with Judith. This is a not to be missed story. And Mom?  If you're reading this, I'm sorry for the years I couldn't come home. So glad you were able to come to me.
My family loves this TV series.

OUT OF THE ASHES is a good book. I felt sorry for Amelia because she had a very skewed view of marriage. She was afraid that all men were abusive. Nathaniel was really nice and kind. I felt bad for Nathaniel too.  I enjoyed reading it.  My favorite book by this author is Walks Alone, but this was really good. I can't wait to read the next book in this series.If you like historical romances, or "forced marriage" books, you will love OUT OF THE ASHES. And don't forget to check out Ms. Rog's first book, Walks Alone.

Okay, to be honest, I have absolutely no idea how to review this book!  It is very large, like a three-subject school notebook. Each page is lined, wide-ruled. It includes a joke (which my husband greatly enjoyed reading), words of wisdom (either by a well-known person like Ben Franklin or from the Bible), and a section called "This is me" which includes a thought or application or word of encouragement.Will this book cure an alcoholic?  Um, I doubt it. Will it encourage them along the way? I don't know. Will it give people chuckles when they read the jokes? Yes.  Will they enjoy the quotes? They should. What will they write in it?  I don't know.  Whatever they think, I guess.  There is plenty of room for thoughts, and I suppose it will help some to get thoughts down on paper while they are recovering.

I generally love Ms. Wingate's stories and looked forward to this one. Ms. Wingate is a very very talented storyteller, making the story come to life. Her characters walk off the page and into life, becoming the person you see driving down the road, the stranger in the grocery store, the visitor in church.  But then they become more, they turn into friends, since it is written in first person, you know their thoughts, their concerns, their hurts, their plans...Everything.At times this story did seem to drag. It was slow, not a fast-pace edge of your seat book. It's one you can carry in the car and read a few pages at the DMV, a few pages at the dentist, a chapter during your lunch break or lulls at work, but not one that you'd spend the day devouring, burning dinner because you couldn't put it down.If you love Lisa Wingate's books, family sagas, or women's fiction give THE SEAKEEPER'S DAUGHTERS a try. You will want to read this series in order, The Story Keeper, and The Prayer Box, as well as some of the novellas (I absolutely LOVED the novellas)I hurt for Whtney, and cared what happened to her. Wondered where her step-father disappeared to, wondered what she'd do with her grandmother's legacy... Recommended for a great tale.

ANOTHER WAY HOME is the third book in the ongoing Chicory Inn family saga. Readers will want to read this book series in order as the series really doesn't stand alone. I am looking forward to the fourth book in this series coming in 2016.I didn't think at first I cared for Danae. She is whiny, crying all the time, and her husband is almost ready to flee for the hills.  I understand why she is that way, I'm sure any woman who doesn't have a family and so desperately wants one would be the same. (I was blessed with children)  But then she listened to Dallas, found a job to take her mind off it (even if the job wasn't one he exactly approved of, but God was in it.)  A beautiful, heartwarming tale of family, of sisters, of husband and wife relationship, and of God's hand working quietly behind the scenes to answer prayers in a way no one imagined.The first two books are Home to Chicory Inn and Two Roads Home

ANDI UNSTOPPABLE is a great book. I loved it. It was full of mystery and suspense and it kept me on the edge of the seat. I was actually surprised at the outcome, but I'm not going to give any spoilers. I also loved that she became friends with one of her moderate enemies. This book is the third in the series, but it kind of stands alone. There are a few parts where it would help to have read the first two. I highly recommend this book!

This is not a CBA fiction, it is ABA, but DO YOU BELIEVE IN SANTA is clean fiction, sweet, without anything to give Christian readers pause.  It is totally cute, and I fell in love with Mandy and Jake. Belief is a bit suspended as a relationship is decided on belief in Santa or lack thereof, but that aside...Being a secular romance, there is no faith message as in faith in Jesus Christ. But that said, you could read between the lines and substitute Jesus for Santa. You have to approach Jesus with faith as a little child, as they so openly embrace Santa. You have to believe. Believe.  That was the message in this book. Believe.I greatly enjoyed DO YOU BELIEVE IN SANTA and was happy to get a copy on Netgalley for review.  This will be a Christmas classic.  My daughter wants to read it now, and since it's clean, thankfully, I can let her.Highly recommended!

This is an e-short prequel to the Amish Men Of Lancaster County series, showing how the father of our first hero's mother (in The Amish Groom) felt when his daughter left home without warning. A lost dog added insult to injury and the father is left floundering, unable to work, just trying to heal his relationship with God and come to terms with his loss.  I enjoyed getting to know Joel a little better.To those who read the prequel and are judging the series by this, don't. The series is wonderful, full length, and I totally loved all three books in the series.Recommended.

THE CHRISTMAS JOY RIDE is a fun lighthearted story about an elderly widow and her younger, soon-to-be homeless neighbor embarking on a trip across the historic Route 66. Joy had planned to do this with her husband, but this bucket list died with George. Now, she's being forced into assisted living in a strange state, near her sons who both left Chicago for Phoenix. Miranda is iffy about this crazy trip Joy has planned, but it seems to beat sitting around waiting for the end at home, so Miranda packs a bag and goes along for the ride. And the joy that Joy wants to spread. I loved the way Joy spread joy to the winners on  her blog, and I also loved that it ended on such a happy note. I smiled with the ending. Awesome job, Ms. Carlson. I'll be looking forward for your Christmas book next year!

I absolutely loved AN ENDLESS CHRISTMAS. It did start a little slow and draggy, but by the second chapter I was entirely hooked and in love with the host of characters. I absolutely loved some of the Christmas things they did as a family. A play, put on by the grandkids. The Grandfather singing one verse of Amazing Grace every night. Everything. This was an absolutely charming Christmas story that ended with a sigh of contentment (the best kind of book ever) and will go on my keeper shelf.  Love, love, loved it.  5 stars.

Nice cover, and the 8th or 9th Fintie brand I've owned. One very small complaint: There's a tiny, metal logo plate attached to the outside of the front cover, in the lower right corner, that reads "Fintie Original". It is smooth and relatively unobtrusive, but I would prefer none at all -- and this logo plate is not show in any of the web photos.

Absolutely the best there is. They're tough, invisible, and, most important, they're easy to install with professional results. I've given up on the sticky-backed non-water based protectors, because they're too stiff, and impossible to align and install correctly. (Ever wonder why they're sold in packs of 3? Because you'll burn up the first 2 with failed installs.) In addition, ArmorSuit offers a no-nonsense warranty, and it's real: I had a minor imperfection in the installation on one of my gadgets, wrote an email to the vendor, and got a new protector within a week. Amazingly, this quality and care costs no more -- I actually paid less for the ArmorSuit than I did for inferior competitors. I've replaced the protectors on all my gadgets (1 camera, 2 phones, 3 tablets) with ArmorSuit Military Shield, and it's the only brand I'll buy from here on out.

I'm going to return it, because I think it's too soft -- i.e., the scraper end bends too easily, making it ineffective for some tasks (e.g., getting the last bit of peanut butter out of the jar). Another thing I don't like is that the end is completely rounded -- I guess that's OK for icing, but it's a poor design when you're trying to get in the nooks and crannies of a jar. (Most scrapers have one rounded corner, and one right-angle corner.) Overall length is 9.5". You apparently don't get a color choice (mine was orange). Also, note that these ship from China, so delivery will take a couple of weeks to the US.

Simply awful. The bit about a "strong ginger flavor" is nonsense; it has no more bite than Canada Dry ginger ale. In addition, the artificial sweetener leaves a horrible aftertaste. We will be returning or throwing away the 22 cans we did not consume.

Very nice groomer kit. I like that it's simple to use, and the attachments go on and off easily. I use the standard clipper blade for my head, and the body attachment for below-the-neck parts.The rubberized housing is very comfortable. Motor is strong, battery is long-lasting, and blades are sharp (at least at the outset; we'll see how they hold up after a year). I bought this to replace a Wahl with a lithium battery, and that one started to peter out after less than a year's use. Plus, the Remington is easier to use. I'm very pleased.

These didn't work for me. I bought two packages of decals -- a total of eight stickers -- for one patio door that measures 3' x 6', and we're still getting bird hits. I guess the frequency *might* have gone down a tiny bit, but so has the bird traffic and the sunshine (it's now Fall) -- and it was always on the brightest days that the birds had problems seeing our glass. Overall, I consider this a waste of money.

Great headset for all-purpose use. I use it primarily for phone calls, and sometimes for music. It's very comfortable, and I really like the in-line microphone -- there's no hunk of plastic and foam hanging in front of your face. Sound quality is very, very good, without too much emphasis across any particular band; it's natural and smooth. Also, I like the accessories included in the package. Overall, a great value.

I don't know what the filler in this pillow is, but it is definitely not goose feather and down -- these things are very, very heavy.I was skeptical buying them, because the proportion of feather to down is not specified in the web description, and I should have followed my apprehensions rather than chase a low price. Btw, the amount of feather and down is not stated on the label on the pillows, either -- it just says "goose feather and down," and "made in China." Something's fishy, though, because these pillows would not weigh so much if they were truly filled with just feather and down. I'm returning them.

Great ball, great price. OK, so it doesn't come with a pump; why is the reviewer who complained about this surprised? The web description says,"No pump, no DVD: Just one great price!" Btw, I bought the 55cm ball, and found that with extra inflation I can safely get it up to 60cm.

Looks good at first, but, depending on where you live, these will start to rust and the paint will peel off. I live at the coast, so they're good for only about a year. Btw, I have tried these entry guards sold under different brand names, including Rampage and Rugged Ridge and Smittybilt, but they're all exactly the same: Manufactured in Korea, it's simply two light pieces of stamped steel, painted black, with trim adhesive tape on the back. There are plastic guards out there -- e.g., from Bestop -- but they cost 2X as much as these.

Good, soft pillow, but I didn't care for the "crunchy" sound of feathers inside. I mean, it certainly isn't loud, and I never felt any feathers poke through the cover, I just didn't like it. Also, I was a bit surprised at the packaging: The pillow arrived in an open, unsealed plastic bag inside the Amazon bag; I expected a bit more protection during transit. Finally, I didn't like the price; I think there are much better deals out there.
This does not have a fiber tip; the tip is rubber.

It fits the new model (2014) Dell Venue 8, but these are REALLY difficult to install -- plan on using up one protector just getting the hang of it. Much of the problem is the Dell tablet: It has almost no bezel on the sides of the screen. Thus, the screen protector wants to go right up to the edge of the glass, and if you position it just a tiny bit too far -- like 1/2 of a millimeter -- then it won't adhere, because it's running into the bezel. And if you try to lift it up to reposition, you're screwed: You'll get dust specks, fingerprints, smudges, etc. That's why I said, plan to burn one. Mine's on, and it does protect the screen, but it looks ugly. Next time, I'll get one of the water-based protectors.

Love these bags (I have two) because they're sturdy, secure, and pliable. The plastic is a type that's very clear, very flexible, and yet also very thick. I'm not worried about leaks, and the plastic stretches ever so slightly to accommodate odd-shaped bottles and tubes. So much better than sandwich bags!!

I followed the instructions re: dryer fluffing, and these pillows still felt lumpy. After my first night's sleep, I woke up with a monster head-and-neck ache. (And no, I had not been drinking the night before.) I bought the flattest version of MyPillow, and it still isn't flat enough, and definitely not soft enough. If you're accustomed to down pillows, these won't satisfy. I'm returning mine today.

It's a good cable, but the female end is very deeply recessed -- which means that some male plugs *might* not go in far enough to make full contact. E.g., if I plug a normal male USB into the female end of this extender, it's fine; but when I try to plug in my USB-to-audio converter, it doesn't go in all the way due to the design of the converter -- see http://goo.gl/tF2dU3 -- so the contact is intermittent.

These hooks seem sturdy enough, but they do NOT fit the Samsung HM1300. The clip portion is much too small. The listing does not claim that they do fit the HM1300, but one of the Q&A responses does -- that's why I bought them. My fault for believing an anonymous "expert."

These are great cleats -- nearly fabulous at Amazon's add-on price. And for my aluminum boat, they're the best option to avoid corrosion caused when any non-aluminum metal comes in contact with an aluminum hull. I bought two #14 stainless flat-head machine screws for each, put a dab of marine sealant on each 3/16" hole in my boat, and they mounted very tightly and securely. They look good, and they won't corrode. Love these cleats.

Note that this does *not* fit the new version of the Dell Venue 8. It's a decent protector, but I had to return it because I didn't realize that there are two different versions of the Dell Venue 8 Model 3840. (Why in the heck Dell didn't create a new model number for the new version, I don't know.) These protectors fit the older version; the 2014 version of the Venue 8 has a slightly larger screen (by about 4 mm), the buttons are in different locations, etc.

Note that this does not fit the new Dell Venue 8. It's a decent case, but I had to return it because I didn't realize that there are two different versions of the Dell Venue 8 Model 3840. (Why in the heck Dell didn't create a new model number for the new version, I don't know.) This case fits the older version; the 2014 version of the Venue 8 has a slightly larger screen, the buttons are in different locations, etc.

Wow, I really don't understand all the hate re: this tablet. It's my fourth android tablet in two years, and I think it's a great value. It's reasonably fast, and the screen resolution is excellent. Most important -- and this is why I gave up my Asus Memo 8 in order to buy this Dell -- is that it comes almost entirely free of crapware.With Asus, and most android devices nowadays, you get a ton of apps that you'll never use; they take up space, hog resources, and you can't remove them unless you root your device (which voids all warranties and is only for the tech-savvy). The Dell is bloat-free: it comes with Dropbox, an internal browser, and very little else -- and that's exactly what I wanted. I want to choose *my* apps, not have some manufacturer in China decide for me.The only caution about this: Apparently Dell changed dimensions on the Venue 8, so when you're buying after-market accessories like screen protectors and cases, you have to be careful that you're buying for the *2014* model of the Venue 8. Unfortunately, Dell retained the same model number 3840 for both versions, new and old, so I ended up with (and returned) a couple of items that didn't perfectly fit this newer model of the Venue 8.Btw, there is a lot of bad info in these customer reviews, maybe because reviews of the old model are mixed in with the new one; I dunno. Here is a very complete review of this new-model Venue 8:  http://goo.gl/kcYN0qUpdate after 30 days: OK now I understand. The specs on this tablet are great for the price, especially since they updated the screen resolution on the new model. And I still like the fact that there is virtually zero bloatware. HOWEVER, there are serious problems with the browser -- and it doesn't matter if you're using the built-in browser or Chrome or another. The system will simply hang, for a very long time, with no way out. I've had a half-dozen different tablets, always using the same wifi connection, and this is the first one to behave this way. And because the main thing I do with my tablet is surf, it's unusable. I'm returning it today.

For my use -- listening to music (mostly rock) at my desk -- these are great, and sound much better than anything I've tried under $100. However, my setup is simple, with no subwoofer.Yeah, they're a little bass-heavy, but that's easily adjusted in your PC's equalizer. If you have a sub, there may be better options out there. But if you want the approximation of full-range sound and decent volume, these Bose speakers are a great value.

Love these fenders, especially at the price. My boat is unpainted aluminum, so I'm not aware of any issue with scratching such as other reviewers have warned about. I love the fact that these take up so little space, and they don't roll around -- not when deployed, and not when stowed. In my typical day of boating, the fenders are in use for less than 5% of the time, so my primary concern is that they stay out of the way until needed.

For my use, these are not sturdy enough. Note that the warning "NOT FOR HELM USE" is stamped right on the plastic parts -- it seems like they ought to warn you about that in the web page description. I guess if you're using these for secondary (non-driving) seats, or for seats you'll use when your boat isn't moving, they're fine -- but I found them to be way too flimsy. Also the release tab doesn't stay in -- and the seat kit comes with absolutely no instructions or diagrams. Good luck.  :-)
Mine arrived not working. Could be simply dead batteries, but I'm not going to buy some just to test it.
Decent cover, though the material does not *appear* to be highly waterproof. That said, I did not test it, because the 25-50 hp size cover was much too large for my Johnson 25 hp 2-stroke outboard.

This little guy is a great gauge.  It fits perfectly in your hand, the angle is good for nearly all valve stems,  and the readings are very  fast and accurate.  Plus,  for my aged eyes,  it's much easier to read than a small-print dial gauge. I love it -- I bought one for each of my cars.

The spray functions are great, and I really like the pause switch, but I cannot tolerate the NOISE these shower heads make. I can't figure out what causes it, because the loudness is the same on any spray mode. It's so loud that if I'm sleeping and my wife wants to shower, the sound of water pushing through these things will wake me up (and I'm a heavy sleeper). Our showers are fiberglass, and maybe that increases the noise, I don't know -- but three different brands of shower heads we've used in the past never put out the amount of noise that these do. Too bad, because I liked them otherwise. We're going back to our Niagra shower heads ( http://goo.gl/4ebKgv ), which work fine, cost less, and are blissfully quiet.

Great bulbs. They come on instantly, and put out a very pleasing, "warm" light. I tried another brand from Amazon (by Energetic Lighting), and these from LE are much, much better, even though their outward appearance is the same. These are excellent bulbs, for an excellent price.

The light from this is not what I'd call "warm"; it's more on the "cool" side. But the bigger problem is that these bulbs have a slight startup delay -- about a second. I.e., when you flip the switch -- any switch, because I tried several different fixtures -- the light does not come on immediately. There's a very brief delay, of about one second, then they come on full power. I have not experienced this with other LED bulbs, notably the LE brand -- http://goo.gl/5U5va9 -- which I also bought from Amazon. I *greatly* prefer the LE bulbs to these from Energetic Lighting.

The price I paid for this fan makes it hard to complain (I got it thru the warehouse deals at Amazon). It does move a lot of air, but the thermostat is not that great. I.e., it will come on when the room gets hot enough, but it won't turn off soon enough. E.g., we have the thermostat set in the middle, so it comes on at around 90 degrees, but the fan will then keep running even when (in the evening) the room has cooled down to 70. Still, I wasn't expecting (nor do I need) precision, so that failing is livable -- and the value makes it worth 4 stars.

Love this BBQ. I converted it to low-pressure use, because I have a propane tank that serves my whole house, and there's a gas valve on the back deck. I probably voided the Weber warranty by doing so, but that's OK. The heat in this thing is very, very even throughout the grill, and it's very easy to control the temperature range -- I was surprised that it doesn't burn chicken to a crisp, like many small gas BBQs will.The only negative: I wanted the cheapest version without side shelves -- the BBQ is already on a table, so why do I need shelves? -- but this model does not come with a thermometer in the lid. I kinda wish it had that.

No, you wouldn't use this for an all-day framing job, but for a quick rip through a piece of plywood, it's great -- especially when you don't want to drag out the big saw, yet another cord, etc. etc. I already have several Ryobi One tools, so did not need to invest in more batteries -- which makes the cost of this tool very reasonable. Note that this model has the battery on the side, which I think improves balance and makes the saw easier to use single-handed. Ryobi's earlier version had the battery attached on the back.

Such a simple thing, and so difficult to find. I wanted a simple, stylish hook for 30' of garden hose -- not something overly foo-foo, and not something that sticks out too far from the wall -- and this works perfectly.The metal is 2.5" wide, and the hook sticks out 4.5" from the wall. Comes with two pairs of matching white screws: one pair is conventional wood screws, the other is self-tapping sheet metal screws. That's a nice touch.

Good, sturdy cover, fits the back of my GLK350 nicely. Lots of velcro on the underside that doesn't exactly adhere to the car's carpet, but it does keep the cover from sliding around. Also, note that the straps that come with this are removable: You get two adjustable nylon straps with clamp-style clips at each end. At first, I was worried about how well these would hold, but as long as you clip them correctly, I think they're fine. And, this method has the added advantage of being able to position the straps in exactly the right spot for your car's headrests.

Love love love these little lights. Why?Single AA battery, and it seems to last for hours and hours.Handy and sturdy pocket clip.Easy slider focus ring, to make the beam broad or narrow.Really small size -- like, maybe, the size of two AA batteries.Dependable, solid switch.Reasonably weather-resistant. (OK, I haven't tried it underwater, but the seals are solid).Price well under $5 -- I bought five of these to have one in every car and several drawers.Note: I didn't opt for the multi-mode, because I don't see a need for the added complication -- so I can't comment on that.

I ordered (via Amazon Prime) desert boots from Clarks, Nunn Bush, and Bass; these Bass were the clear winners. My shoe size is 9B, and the 9M in the Bass is a perfect fit for me. However, I can tell that they run a bit narrow -- so if you have a wider foot, you may not be happy.The reasons I chose Bass over the others:The overall construction is slightly stiffer in the toe and the sides, so the shoe feels more substantial and gives more ankle support. They aren't stiff, they're very comfortable; they just feel more like a shoe instead of a slipper.I like the styling of these -- the extra stitching along the top, and the contrast stitching along the top of the sole looks really classy, imho. I bought these for nights out in my tiny, funky town, so I didn't want something in the style family of my hiking boots.The arch and sole of the Bass felt (to me) more sturdy, more "there" than the others I tried. I was surprised how much nicer, tougher, and classier the Bass are, considering they're $15-20 cheaper than the others -- but I'm certainly not complaining.  :-)

This is a great cover, especially for the price. The fact that it comes with a center support pole and a carrying bag makes the value even more impressive. My boat is 14' long on the center line, and the beam is 65". I bought the smallest cover, for boats 14' to 16', and it fits great -- I have enough length left over to cover my outboard motor. This cover is rated to handle boats up to 79" wide, and I think that is probably true *if* you don't use the center pole or have a windshield or console. But as you can see from my photos, on my little 65"-wide boat, with the center pole in place, I've got only about 4" of cover coming over each side of the boat at the widest point. I do not intend to trailer my boat with the cover on, so I can't comment about that. But for ease of attachment, construction quality, and ability to repel rain and pine needles, I give it a solid 5 stars.

I previously bought and tried another brand -- Sojitel -- and I like these much better. The Supershieldz fit perfectly and completely, from edge to edge; the Sojitel do not. In addition, these seemed easier to install. Maybe that's just because I had more practice, but it really seemed like they lined up and adhered better, with easier elimination of bubbles. I'll stick with Supershieldz brand from now on.

Good LED, and the motion detector works as described. However, the photocell that is supposed to detect daylight is not sensitive enough. Viz., I have two of these, in bathrooms with windows. But the windows have shades, and I live in a pretty cloudy/rainy climate. I have the Danibos set on "night," which means they're only supposed to come on when the room is dark. But in my situation, they come on most every day, unless we have really bright sunshine. I.e., they come on to provide light when I don't need any light. This isn't a catastrophic problem, obviously; it just means I'll burn through batteries faster than I'd like.The other issue, noted by another reviewer, is this: You should not rely on the foam tape alone if you are mounting this light on a surface that isn't perfect smooth. There are two keyhole slots in the back that you can use for hanging it on a vertical surface, and there are two round holes under the batteries that you can use for mounting on nearly any surface. Danibo supplies the double-sided foam tape, but no screws.

Excellent case. Very very slim profile, solid closure, fits my ASUS MeMO ME181C perfectly. All functions are accessible, and, as a bonus, the power switch is now actually easier to find. At $15 I'd be happy; at $8 (for black), I'm ecstatic.

This thing works, but not particularly easily or well. As another reviewer said, you need to pound it into place; I have a 15hp Mercury 2-stroke, and while this flusher does fit, I have to hammer it on and off with a rubber mallet. Additionally, the seal once in place isn't that great. It does put water into the motor, so that I can run the motor and flush out any saltwater. But it also sprays water out both the front and back sides of the SeaSense flusher, so you'll want to stand clear. I'm keeping it, because I haven't found a better alternative -- but it's far from ideal.
Good match, good quality paint. On props, though, you'll definitely want to use a primer first.
Good price, easy install, seems sturdy, and I like the clear view of the filter.

Our house isn't large, but we had a dead spot in one bedroom. Plugging this extender into a hall outlet fixed that, and had the added benefit of making our wi-fi signal stronger in other parts of the house. Setup is super easy: Just plug it in, press the WPS button on the extender, then press the WPS button on your router. Done. Highly recommended, especially at the refurbished price -- it's a great deal.

Tremendous value, easy setup, good performance. At a new price of $130 (minimum), I'd consider this router to be a very fair deal. But at $80 for the refurbished version, it's a killer deal. Mine looked like brand-new, with protective plastic everywhere. Setup was a snap, and Netgear's Genie software is very well-designed and easy to use. This replaces a D-Link 868L, which I paid $140 for. The Netgear is just as fast, has better range, and is much, much easier to set up and maintain.UPDATE after 60 days:Everything I said above still stands: This router works flawlessly, no drop-offs, great range and speed. HOWEVER, a couple days ago I wanted to ask a tech support question. (My question isn't really critical; I'm just trying to figure out how to hide the Genie Media Server.)Well, it turns out you can't get anywhere with Netgear's customer support unless you have a 13-digit serial number, and the SN printed on the bottom of mine is 12 digits -- I assume this is because it is refurbished. I have sent multiple emails to Netgear, and gotten nothing but "firewall" responses: Where did you buy the product? What is the serial number? Etc. etc. And my email to the Amazon seller has gone unanswered after 2 days.So, I'm reducing the stars from 5 to 3. My router is working fine, and I'm very happy with the performance (and especially the price). But if I had a real, operation-critical support question, I'd be up the proverbial creek. I'm guessing this is *not* an issue with new products -- only the refurbished ones. Anyway, I'm pretty demanding about good customer support -- and Netgear is not delivering.UPDATE to my update:OK, I finally got someone from Netgear to respond, and they won't help me. Turns out their refurbished products come with only 30 days of basic technical support. If I want an answer to my simple question, I'll have to pay for it.

Mediocre quality. I guess this is OK for the money, but I thought the overall fit and finish was not good. None of the pull-out drawers has any dividers, and they don't have side slide guides, which means they kind of flop around. Plus, one the one I received, the mirror was detached from the lid. I could have glued it back in place, but instead I returned this for one from Seya, which I think is much, much better quality: http://www.amazon.com/Seya-Burlwood-Jewelry-Necklace-Earring/dp/B005TKA28G

Mediocre quality, and fittings are not as shown in photo. I guess this is OK for the money, but I thought the overall fit and finish was not good. None of the pull-out drawers has any dividers. And, the hardware is not as depicted: The one I got had plain brass-colored round knobs. I returned this for one from Seya, which I think is much, much better quality: http://www.amazon.com/Seya-Burlwood-Jewelry-Necklace-Earring/dp/B005TKA28G

This stand will hold up your cell phone if you, say, want to use it as a bedside clock. It doesn't work as well for a smartphone with a protective casing such as an Otter Box - the box is too fat to sit securely in the stand's groove - but while I can't set it up vertically I can use it horizontally. The price is certainly right. Shipping from China took weeks, however.

A solid entry in the Deep Black series, "Payback" features the secret NSA team going to Peru to secretly unfix a fixed presidential election. Lia impersonates an elections consultant verifying the accuracy and honesty of the polls, while Charlie Dean and Tommy Karr sleuth around in unseen support of her.The Peruvian VP has the fix in, a deep enough fix that he's managed to have a few of the U.S.-made computer chips meant to control voting booths, altered to swing votes to him. The NSA can't tell the president, who is ill and about to step down, because if the election is delayed, he'll step down anyway, the VP will become president and then cancel the election altogether.Unknown to either the Peruvian presidency or the NSA, a third party plots. A popular general of Inca background is cleverly plotting to put his own man, currently running third, into the presidency. He fakes incidents discrediting both candidates running ahead of him.And he's got an ace in the hole: a nuclear warhead diverted from a shipment meant for terrorists but intercepted by authorities. How he plans to use it, though, differ from the secret plans of the crippled Russian  weapons expert and arms dealer who's been handling it - and building a dummy duplicate for him.What's great about this book is what's usually good about the series: the NSA team's James Bond electronics gadgetry and their ingenious ruses for using it. Lia and the boys get into scrapes and get out of them, all the while maintaining their cover as well as their electronic links to the NSA "Art Room" in Washington, who slice and dice the enormous amount of data at their command to give the field team leads where nothing else exists.I thought the setting refreshing also, a change from the usual plots involving jihadis, Russia or China. The general, descended from Inca royalty, wants to restore Inca culture and raise the status of those of Indian blood in the otherwise mestizo Spanish society. There's interesting background.

This IPod lasted exactly one month past the one-year warranty, then quit. The Apple Store folks diagnosed it as a pressure crack to the display, which wasn't working while the internal electronics were apparently fine. When I pointed out there was no crack visible on the display, they said the crack was internal. Whatever. I didn't use the thing particularly hard. But there was no repair or credit towards a replacement available. One month past warranty. I don't buy extended warranties usually, and particularly wouldn't on a pricey Apple device which you figure should work well and longer for the price you're paying. It worked fine before, but I'll have to think long and hard before getting another one.

I've enjoyed David Downing's John Russell series, but this book is particularly fine. Historical novels set at the fall of Berlin in 1945 are particularly grabbing for me, because of the fatefulness of it all, and also because of its grayness. More on that later.For three books Downing dealt with John Russell's complex intrigues in prewar Nazi Germany. Now he has put together a series plot which allows him to look at Berlin's fall from three different perspectives simultaneously.Russell escapes Germany in the previous book, "Stettin Station", in 1941 after Pearl Harbor and America's entry into the war makes the Anglo-American journalist an enemy alien. A war correspondent since then, now in April 1945 he goes to Moscow on a dangerous long-shot bet - that he can cover the Red Army's entry into Berlin, ostensibly to write about it, but really because he wants to find girlfriend Effi Koenen. Russell doesn't know if she's alive but if so she'll be in danger when the city falls. The NKVD first jails him, then make him an offer he can't refuse - parachuting into Berlin with a spy team charged with bringing back Germany's atomic secrets. Russell's intimate familiarity with Berlin makes him a good guide.His son Paul Gehrts was a 14 year old Hitler Youth when Russell left. He's now in the Wehrmacht, and at 18, after a  year at the Eastern Front, a war-weary artilleryman trying to stay alive as his unit falls back towards Berlin. He's lost all his nave Hitler Youth gung-ho and idealism. He sees Nazism as the lie that it is, and its war effort a lost cause. His mother and stepfather are dead. So is his first love. He's angry at his father for having left.Effi Koenen, a onetime movie actress,  lives under assumed names and continues to do what she's been doing since Russell fled:  Helping Jews and others escape the country. She works  closely with a Swedish diplomat who gets them on ships to neutral Sweden. It's harrowing work: if any of her charges are caught and tortured, they will tell what they know of her to the Gestapo. She uses all her acting ability to disguise who she really is. As the Russians advance, she finds herself with a new charge - an 8-year-old Jewish orphan who has somehow managed to survive this long, and has no one else.So we're looking at this simultaneously from all three perspectives. Russell sees what's happened to the city he left more than three years before, and suspects his NKVD keepers will kill him once the mission is complete to keep their new secrets, secret. (And because, well, that's how the NKVD rolls.) He has no idea if Paul or Effi or any of his other former or almost relatives - his former brother in law Thomas, Effi's sister Zahra, Paul's mother Ilse - are still alive, or how to find them in a huge city now in ruins. Meanwhile the SS still roams its streets executing anyone deemed a deserter or traitor. Every decision he makes about where to go and how to get there - this subway station or that? this person's house or that? streets or rails or through the woods? - will affect whether he survives or not.Effi experiences the fall of Berlin as other civilians do. Most of the people left are women. Food is in increasingly short supply. Her real identity and Rosa's are still too dangerous to disclose to anyone. Every other building has been reduced to rubble by relentless Allied bombing and now Soviet shelling. Goebbels' propaganda machine still spreads propaganda about secret weapons, about a surprise peace deal bringing the US and Britain into the war against the Russians, about German armies poised to relieve Berlin, and a few people actually still believe it. Many people flee to the West towards Allied lines, knowing the Red Army will rape every German woman they can find.Paul, as his own unit is decimated and he finds himself without orders, must steer clear of insane SS types while still seeking to do his duty as a soldier - and wondering what, exactly, his duty now is.The odds for any of them - German soldier, German woman, Anglo-American journalist/spy - surviving this cataclysm are iffy.Downing keeps ratcheting up the tension, and the story moves fast as the net closes on Berlin. The reader knows each day brings the war significantly closer to its finish and its aftermath.  Russell, Paul and Effi and circle around in the dying city, and you wonder when and how they will finally meet one another.What makes this series great is its understanding of the shades of gray created by dual citizenship, by competing ideologies and dictatorships, by marriage, by blood, by familiarity. The beginners course on World War II is about good guys and bad guys. The advanced course gets into all the things blurring that.Like the Jewish informers still, in 1945, working for the Gestapo, walking the streets and fingering other Jews they recognize who are living in hiding.Or the American agreement not to enter Berlin. Is it to let the Red Army have its day after fighting the brunt of the war against the Nazis? Or is it to continuing letting them take most of the casualties, with the postwar lines of occupation already decided?  Are the Communists heroic anti-fascists and partisans, or part of a death machine as formidable as Hitler's? Amidst this all, individuals just try to survive.Russell is mostly English, a Tommy fighting in the trenches in World War I, but has U.S. citizenship through his mother. He was a Communist in the 1920s, but has long since walked away from that. Germany may be the home of the Nazis, but it's also home to those he loves, like Paul and Effi, and more widely to a city, Berlin, whose style, sophistication and sarcasm had always held it a bit apart from the Nazi ethos.And his circle embodies the pros and cons - former brother-in-law Thomas, whose business protects Jewish employees until well into the war; Effi's sister Zarah, her husband a fanatical Nazi to the end; Paul, whose heart is torn as a child by wanting to be as German and patriotic as his friends, while having a father who's a foreigner and quite skeptical of this whole Hitler thing.One vignette has Russell encounter a German Communist railway worker who helps hide him and a scientist on his spy team. Russell realizes what romantic and idealistic views the man holds about Communism - having been isolated from it, and the terror state it's become, for decades - and how disillusioned he'll become once seeing his beloved revolution in action.And while the liberation of some cities is overwhelmingly positive, the fall of Berlin is darkened by our knowledge of what will follow - the violence against helpless civilians, the rape of the women, a new dictatorship succeeding the old one, the gulags and POW camps in the East replacing the Nazi death camp system. Only the choice of victims will change.

James Carroll admirably takes on a most difficult subject in this novel about postwar Rome: the Vatican's involvement with fleeing war criminals of the worst sort.And he touches on an even more explosive issue: the complicity of Roman Catholic clergy in the Holocaust itself.He brings to life a cast of fictional characters representing the many parties plotting and maneuvering in Rome - Americans civilian and military, British diplomats, Vatican Curia, Communist Partisans, escaping Nazis, Croatian fascists hiding out on Church property, the Haganah, fleeing Holocaust survivors, you name it.A high-ranking U.S. relief official has come to Rome to help send one shipload (there will never be another) of Jewish refugees to the States, and to find pathways of escape for Jews in Budapest, whom the Nazis are now sending to Auschwitz in wholesale numbers.  The book suggests how Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg was enabled to save 30,000 Hungarian Jews: the U.S. blackmailed Sweden, which had allowed German troops passage across the country and supplied Hitler with arms and iron ore. This would be officially ignored if it played ball on Wallenberg.Warburg must sort through the Vatican's confusing and conflicting record towards the Jews. It helped some while cozying up to their persecutors, but even its help is called into question once Warburg learns many were made to undergo baptism in order to find refuge. Accept the Cross or die, except that this is 1942, not 1542.Meanwhile, Marguerite D'Erasmo, a young Italian Red Cross official, herself a fugitive from the Nazis, witnesses an atrocity that changes her life irretrievably. She is drawn more closely to Jocko Lionni, an Italian survivor who coordinated the hiding of hundreds of other Jews.Kevin Deane, a deputy to powerful Cardinal Francis Spellman, arrives in Rome as his patron maneuvers to rise in the Curia, with the Americans now holding Europe's pursestrings and U.S. Catholic clergy well-positioned as power brokers. Deane becomes sensitized to the Jews' plight. He slowly begins to understand the anti-Semitism woven into his church's position on them, and even into his own attitudes.But Roberto Lehmann, another influential deputy - half Argentine, half German, serving a German cardinal - assumes a key position as Nazis seek to escape to Argentina with Vatican protection. The Vatican is interested in fighting Communism and reestablishing Catholic influence in Eastern Europe, and not at all interested in how much blood its new friends have on their hands, or the origin of their war loot. Some of the worst war criminals in Europe are believed to be hiding out in or around the Vatican.OSS officer Peter Mates starts plotting America's moves in the postwar - what will become the Cold War. The Communists are becoming enemies and thus their enemies, the Nazis, potential allies.Complicating everyone's game is the wild card of the Jewish underground, itself riven into factions between the left and right, the Haganah and the Irgun, which is variously helping refugess immigrate, legally or illegally, into Palestine; beginning to strike against the British who rule it in the cause of establishing a Jewish state; and hunting down war criminals to kill them, since the world apparently doesn't care much what they did.Carroll sees this from a largely Catholic perspective, making it far more interesting. It takes a Catholic to to understand the cross currents within the church - the many political threads plus the tenets of religious conscience that motivate, or fail to motivate, its leaders.Deane and Sister Thomas, a British nun with access to sensitive Vatican information,  are first stricken with remorse and guilt for what has been done to the Jews, but later recoil from Jewish terrorist strikes against the King David Hotel in Jerusalem - British military HQ there - and the British Embassy in Rome. Killing escaping Nazis is one thing, but attacking one of the principal Allies who fought the war against them?D'Erasmo, herself a Catholic, finds herself increasingly alienated from the church as she entangles herself in the lives of those she helps. She takes a fateful step away from it.Warburg, a secular Jew, can't ignore how little Washington is willing to help people in the direst need. He is effectively an agency of one. His War Refugee Board can't even include the word "Jewish" in its title, although it's clear Jews are by far the primary people in need of its help - countless numbers orphaned, wounded, starving, destitute, homeless, unable to return to hometowns where their neighbors turned them in or seized their property.  Warburg must do what he can - armtwisting, cajoling, dropping names, pulling rank, guilting - to gain even the smallest kinds of support.Carroll deals squarely with something the Church undoubtedly would rather have history forget - church complicity in the Holocaust in Croatia.This was not a question of turning a blind eye, remaining silent or being too cozy with persecutors, but one of priests leading death squads. Carroll focuses on one venue: the death camp for children at Sisak. The Church has never adequately addressed this exceedingly shameful episode in its history. Its obscurity has been sustained by various factors:Yugoslavia's relatively small Jewish population meant crimes there - and not by the SS, but by the less notorious (but equally vicious) Croatian Ustashe - haven't gotten the same attention that the huge concentration camps in Poland or the treatment of enormous Jewish ghettos in Eastern Europe have. The beginning of the Cold War meant U.S. and British intelligence both saw ex-Nazis as potential allies against the Communists, knowledgeable about the new foe, and found Jews' calls for justice to be an annoying distraction.Croatia's fanatically loyal Catholicism meant that the Vatican let it get away with genocide as it maneuvered against the Serb monarchist Chetniks and the Communist Partisans for postwar position.And Communist ascension to Yugoslav power meant true information about atrocities there was tainted by the ultimate Communist goal of smashing Catholic influence throughout Eastern Europe. The Communists aren't who you go to for historical truth. Their own war crimes tribunals were kangaroo courts full of misinformation, in contrast to the Nuremberg tribunal's painstaking efforts to create a factual historical base in a public court of law.Carroll has done his homework, deriving the background for his fictional characters from some of the slowly accumulating major works in a field not yet adequately researched, including John Loftus and Mark Aaron's "Unholy Trinity", Susan Zuccotti's "The Italians and the Holocaust", Ruth Gruber's "Haven", and David Wyman's "The Abandonment of the Jews".His story takes note, via its omissions, of the gaps in the historical record: What Pope Pius XII's position on all this was - we see the maneuvering of key underlings, but he remains invisible - and how complicit the Curia and Croatia's Archbishop Stepinac were in bloodshed involving Franciscan priests under their authority.He sets the scene well in the Eternal City, with a great feeling for its many historical buildings, particularly the religious ones. And I like the interior lives he develops for his Catholic characters - priests and nuns with real feelings, not perfect, subject to human passions - and the difficulty they or any person of conscience must have had in trying to parse the innocence vs. guilt, justice vs. revenge, necessity vs. complicity, in those troubled times.

Flynn takes readers of this successful series back to Mitch Rapp’s roots – how he got started in the intelligence biz.Rapp, a star college athlete, is changed forever when his longtime girlfriend is killed in the midair bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 at Lockerbie, Scotland. And so he is amenable, shortly after college, when carefully approached by CIA recruiter Irene Kennedy to become, not just an agent, but an assassin.In the early 1990s, the CIA is reeling in Beirut, among other places –from the bombings and kidnappings that have claimed many of its agents, including station chief Bill Buckley, and from the burdensome Congressional oversight it now faces.CIA director Thomas Stansfield and Kennedy move to establish the proverbial “off-the-shelf” unit – one totally black, preferably self funded, and aimed squarely to putting fear back into the terrorists who lately have shown they haven’t got any where Americans are concerned.Leading training is legendary, aging and ornery CIA op Stan Hurley, who takes an instant dislike to the young and green Rapp, who has never even served in the military. He makes Rapp’s training a hell, and goes ballistic when on his first mission Rapp deviates from an elaborate and extensive plan to instead take out a target alone.What it’s hard for Hurley to realize is how similar to him in his prime Rapp is, a tremendous fighter with a great capacity for pain and an ability to calculate his every move and expression with the mission in mind.The two must go to Beirut to deal with a growing mess wherein an American businessman is being held hostage and a CIA agent sent to negotiate for him is himself kidnapped. Beirut’s fragile peace is holding but it’s still full of bombed out buildings and dominated by competing warlords beholden to different masters – Iran, Syria, Palestinian terror groups and a corrupt spymaster of the barely post-Soviet Russia.Rapp’s coolness all the way through his training and his first missions, and on into Beirut, makes him compelling. It's also a writing challenge to make an assassin a sympathetic character, but Flynn manages it. Hurley’s character is enjoyable not only in his rollicking non-PC attitude - smoking and drinking and whoring, oh my! - but in the way that fuses with him when he's in action. When he gets tortured in a Beirut basement – well, read it yourself, but I guarantee it’s unlike any torture scene you have previously read.

I like all the Jack Reacher books, and this one is no exception. Early in the series, Child does a good job, among other things, of laying more of the hero’s back story, particularly how and why he has chosen to live the way he lives – rootless, drifting, owning nothing and completely off the grid.Reacher is in Key West digging swimming pools and working as a stripjoint bouncer when a New York private detective looking for him – and Reacher hasn’t found out why – gets murdered.Heading back to New York, Reacher discovers the sleuth’s employer was none other than the daughter of his favorite commanding officer back in his MP days – the daughter he’d had a serious crush on when she was only a teenager.Jodie’s dad has just died, Reacher meets her at his funeral and then someone tries to kill them both, setting the action in gear. He finds his existential outlook challenged once he has someone to protect: Jodie.Behind it is loan shark Hook Hobie, who is both creepy – horribly disfigured – and  scary, and pursuing one of the bigger scores of his business life after getting a piece of a failing family business. We don’t know why he’s after Reacher and Jodie, and meanwhile Hobie worries he himself is being tracked in a mystery dating back decades.Child keeps you turning the pages relentlessly as he pulls slowly draws all these threads together.  Every element of a good thriller – action, back story, suspense, romance, cool and resourceful hero – he does well here. The climax, on the 88th floor of the then-still-standing World Trade Center, is a doozy.

This engaging  mystery brings to life a Florida many of its residents will recognize, particularly those who follow politics or journalism.Janis Pearl Hawk (her mother was a big Joplin fan), a rising and hard-hitting columnist for a Bradenton paper, loses her job, but lands on her feet when wealthy friend Leah St. Clair hires her to be a `backpack journalist' - a blogger - focusing on environmental stories and on a candidate St. Clair thinks is the kind of governor the state needs.Hawk reconnects with a college journalism friend, Mercedes Westerfield, now campaigning for the candidate, Brad MacIntyre. Westerfield puts her on to a big story: that a big pharmaceutical company forced state researchers to bury findings showing their cancer drug more dangerous than a cheap and readily available alternative.Hawk meanwhile also pursues some other big stories: Attempts by a big gambling corporation to muscle its way into managing the state lottery, and a wildlife-destroying dredging project to increase shipping into Port Manatee near the mouth of Tampa Bay.Hawk has a lot on her plate. And then Westerfield is found dead. Hawk wants to stay on her stories, she wants to find out who did it, but then the threats begin.She's trying to figure out if a lobbyist has put a fix in with the statehouse speaker. Her ex-husband wants to get back together with her. Her well-meaning patron and a friendly state police contact try to get her out of Tallahassee to to protect her. And then she finds herself falling for the uncommonly environmentalist candidate, who wants her to work on his campaign. Will she be a campaigner or a journalist? She can't do both.This book is loaded with Florida history and flavor.  We follow Hawk to remarkable places like Wakulla Springs, where "Tarzan" movies were filmed, and the artist's colony at Sopchoppy. We get a helicopter ride over Crystal River's manatees. We go to Tallahassee, where the state legislature is in session, and any manner of skullduggery involving money, power and legislative votes is possible.Brunais' take on the state is a lot like Carl Hiaasen's, minus the latter's goofy humor and outrageously offbeat characters. (No roadkill-eating ex-governors here.)Both depict an explosively-growing state where bulldozers relentlessly clear more and more, with politicians complicit and a population largely unaware - or uncaring - about the long-term cost. The environmentalists are the heroes, trying to save a vanishing wild Florida and its rich biological heritage - and the developers and politicians and lobbyists are the heavies.There are many references to Florida politicians past and present - Charlie Crist, Rick Scott, Bill McBride, T.K. Wetherell, Walkin' Lawton Chiles, Bob Graham, Reuben Askew, Bob Martinez, Alex Sink and many more - lending the book realism and allowing Brunais to show off her deep experience as a Florida journalist. Anyone who has spent time in Florida will find characters and scenes they recognize on almost every page.

The two lead families of the Democratic Party hate each other. Edward Klein documents why and how in this entertaining and fast moving book. It's a good political beach read.It's mostly about three elections: that of 2008, where Barack Obama came from behind to knock off front-runner Hillary Clinton for the nomination, with charges and countercharges of race-card-playing in the South Carolina primary; 2012, where Bill Clinton made a whizbang nominating speech for someone he can't stand and Hillary drank the Kool-Aid in agreeing to lie about Benghazi - `it was a spontaneous riot caused by a video' - to seal Obama's reelection; and the 2016 election, where Obama promised Clinton he'd support Hillary in exchange for their carrying his water, then reneged on it.There are tons of details and fly-on-the-wall accounts of conversations. The Clintons come off much better than the Obamas do. We know most of the Clintons' dirt already and, as a nation, don't seem to care too much, but meanwhile they seem to have a clue about how to run the country, while the Obamas don't. Barack Obama comes off as narcissistic, lazy, and shielded from reality by advisor Valerie Jarrett, effectively the shadow president since 2009.I get the feeling the Clintons shrewdly used this book to get their version of events into play. Klein found leakers near the Obamas who are unhappy with them, but many Clinton sources appear to be lifelong friends seemingly given the green light to talk for this book - people who wouldn't jeopardize their relationship to do so. And for many of the quotations, there would be no question in the Clintons' minds who had given them - people party to conversations where only one or two others were present. So it stands to reason the anonymous sources don't mind the Clintons knowing.The Clintons, heavily covered for over 20 years, may realize there isn't much that can hurt them that hasn't already been printed. We all know about Monica, Clinton's womanizing, the financial scandals dating back to Arkansas days, Hillary's temper and so on. And a lot of the inside poop here is either flattering - Bill Clinton as political mastermind, say - or humanizing. It's remarkable that the Clintons stay together after all they've been through, but they seem politically fascinated with each other. And it's remarkable how many times Hillary initially tells Bill off about something, only to agree later that he's right and go ahead with it. Quite cute, say, is the anecdote about how Bill convinced Hillary to "have some work done" on her face after leaving the State Department, by first doing it himself.The new news is the medical stuff. Hillary's health problems have been more serious than generally noted.  And Bill's heart condition is serious; Klein quotes his doctor, by name, telling him the disease is progressive, i.e. it will continue to get steadily worse. Bill's obsession with sealing his own legacy by putting Hillary in the White House has become single-minded. It's suggested this is the primary thing he wants to get done before he dies.The Obamas seem more on the defensive and more paranoid. You don't get any sense of Klein's sources spinning the narrative back in their direction. Barack comes across as a narcissist stemming from a deepset insecurity about his lack of experience pre-presidency. He's someone who doesn't read much beyond popular novels but thinks he's brilliant. He's visibly bored with the dull business of running the country. He doesn't prepare in advance for big international conferences, who he'll meet and what they'll talk about; he figures he'll just wing it. Detractors (like Hillary) call his administration "rudderless".He's threatened by Bill Clinton, who not only isn't intimidated by him but tries to lecture him. (There's a priceless account of a dinner between the two couples - the strained conversations, Obama ignoring Clinton by reading his Blackberry under the table, Obama sneaking out and coming back a while later smelling of cigarettes.) He's shielded from much by Valerie Jarrett, who surrounds him with sycophants and upon whom he relies too much. She has her own room in the presidential quarters and is the only outsider who eats with the family. He thinks he can move the world with his speeches.You see Obama good at campaigning and manipulating, but not much else. Michelle more or less invites herself and friends to Oprah Winfrey's Hawaii estate for a joint birthday party, in part to draw her back into the Obamas' camp and keep her out of Hillary's. The weeklong stay goes fine, but Oprah resists any political rapprochement, and even starts promoting Hillary not long afterwards.Obama picks Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg (a third Democratic family as powerful as the Obamas or Clintons) as ambassador to Japan, a way-too-late thanks for Kennedy family support in 2008 - and, apparently, just to get her halfway around the world from Hillary's candidacy.It amazes me that the Obamas would work this hard to undermine their own party's frontrunner for the 2016 nomination. The Clintons will have raised a billion dollars for the run.There's lots of dirt about both couples. Bill still womanizes intensively; you wonder if he'll die `in the saddle' like Nelson Rockefeller did. A guy with a bad heart condition?His penthouse over the Clinton Library in Little Rock is his bachelor pad - Hillary avoids Little Rock - and effectively the Playboy Mansion South, the scene of many swinging parties. Klein suggests that the town not only shields its favorite son from scrutiny, but that its women, married and single alike, line up to sleep with him. Klein quotes one person saying Clinton will hit on married women even in front of their own husbands. (You'd think in Arkansas this would get a man shot, but then most other men there don't enjoy lifelong Secret Service protection.) He and Hillary lead separate lives, talking daily on the phone but rarely in each other's presence, and Hillary tells friends he'll have little presence in her White House should she be elected.Klein notes some presidential couples become closer in the White House, where they finally have physical proximity after years of separation on the campaign trail, but this didn't happen with the Obamas, who are effectively estranged. Michelle Obama, of whom White House staffers are terrified, will burst in suddenly on her husband if he's in a room with other women; she's suspicious of him, believing he'd like to emulate Clinton's ways.
