Her post-White House plans, according to this book, don't include him. She and Valerie Jarrett, who plans to follow her, envision a high life of globetrotting funded by wealthy donors where they sit on corporate boards and don't have to do much work.Barack Obama wants to retain control of the party, but Bill Clinton already sees him losing his clout and political capital.The real question mark goes back to Bill Clinton's health. If he dies - a guy with this bad a heart condition? Waitresses and Little Rock matrons, think about it - some think Hillary, relying upon his advice forever, may not go ahead with a presidential run. It often sounds like more his obsession than hers, other than the first-woman-president thing. The family foundation's reins have been handed to Chelsea, in part to take pressure off Bill, and she is being positioned as his replacement as Mom's closest advisor and confidante. Others think Chelsea would encourage her mother to run if Bill dies because it's what he would have wanted. You get the feeling that Hillary, for all her ambition, doesn't have all that much fire in the belly - that it's Bill who's given her the vision, encouraged her, pushed her, made her see a path through obstacles, and been willing to fight battles large and small where she would have been more inclined to go along, get along and acquiesce.Truly surreal is the ending. Bill tells an appalled Hillary, in front of friends, exactly how to stage his funeral if he dies before the election: what to wear (widow's weeds), where to do it (Arlington, he's a former commander in chief.) If properly done, he said, the video footage will be worth a couple of million votes." Not for nothing do they call him the smartest political mind of his time.PS The day before I filed this, I saw a story online at Business Insider quoting an unnamed Clinton confidante attacking this book as lies, all lies, nothing but lies. The story didn't specifically rebut anything or cite any specific error in the book; it reprised a finding of an error in one of Klein's previous books. It suggests to me, though, this book is right, if the attack against it is as unspecific as "lies, lies, nothing but lies." Perhaps the Clinton camp is doing some preventive public fulminating so that  they can deny the unflattering or unfavorable parts of it. I still think they planted a lot of this.The same day, the Wall Street Journal had a front page story about Hillary distancing herself from the Obama administration. This is exactly what the book says she would do - it's half revenge, and half good politics, as seen by Bill Clinton, with the Obama administration in a tailspin on any number of fronts.

Some reviewers contend the main character of this book is the city of Shanghai itself, but I disagree. Aw goes to great lengths to develop five main characters whose paths slowly begin to cross in the present day, some having crossed or skirted each other before.The book takes about a hundred pages to get going. The characters are mostly overseas Chinese from Malaysia, people who have come to Shanghai to make their fortune. Shanghai is seen from these outlanders’ eyes – a cold and fast-moving place where everyone is on the make, where deception and posturing are the norm. An American comparison might be those who come to New York City to succeed or escape.What comes across to me most of all is an overwhelming sense of alienation. Our characters all have failure in their backgrounds, or teeter on its brink today, or both.Phoebe is an illegal immigrant who comes to China for a job that has vanished by the time she arrives. She makes her way to Shanghai determined to build herself up from nothing by reinventing herself, right down to a stolen identity she adopts. She has worked as a bar girl and a factory worker but is determined to do better, and one of her tips on how to do this is a self-help book. She believes in falsifying nearly every aspect of herself to present the images she thinks will lead to success and conceal her hard-scrabble upbringing and lack of education.Justin is the heir to a real estate fortune, the family representative sent to Shanghai to further their enterprise into the next generation. Suddenly, their wealth collapses and he plunges into a funk. Gone are his friends, his family – but also the crushing sense of obligation under which he has labored all his life.Gary is a pop singer from a desperate rural past who wins a TV talent show, launching him into a frenzied pop stardom. He begins to deteriorate as stardom takes its toll, and suddenly a bad incident and negative publicity destroy his career. He, too, becomes mired in depression. The only solace he can find for months are his chats with a girl on the Internet.Yinghui is a self-made business success, a woman who owns fashionable clothing stores. Driven, hard-working, totally obsessed with her business existence, she has no personal life. Lurking behind her is the disappointment of a failed romance during an idealistic and pampered youth, and the scandal which destroyed her family fortunes.Walter is a billionaire who likes, when not swinging some huge deal or another, to lecture on how to find success. And he found it the hard way; we learn just how difficult his own youth was. He yearns for intimacy, but seems incapable of it.All these people are essentially lonely, and Shanghai does little to alleviate that. They must ask themselves – is life better where I came from? Would a return to the provinces be a failure, or are dreams of big-city success themselves a complete illusion?Their world is poised precariously between yesterday’s traditional Asian society,  the one their parents were born into,  and today’s impersonal, ruthless world, one of cellphones and online dating, of fleeting relationships and acquaintances, of fortunes made or lost in huge development deals that create and destroy. China and surrounding nations like Malaysia have been rapidly industrializing, hotbeds of growth and corruption, during our characters’ entire lives.Our characters have little dialogue, in part because they have so few people to talk to that they trust. Their passages mostly remain in their own trains of thought, reflecting upon their joyless existences.Americans will find this book penetrating not only in its plot and characters, but in its insights in what it means to be Asian in the early 21st century.

I thought, when I saw this book's description, that it sounded a lot like Cracked.com, a website my son turned me on to. There's a good reason for that: the author is one of the website's editors.Cracked.com specializes in fact-based (albeit the facts heavily stretched) articles about things retold as one teenage kid might tell it to another. And that's what this book is. If you're a teenage kid, and you're talking about the presidents, it's not at all unlikely that you are concerned with this question: Who, among them, was the biggest bad-ass?The author, and my son, think Teddy Roosevelt was, and his chapter in this book makes a decent case why. This is a guy who punched out a cowboy pointing two guns at him; a guy who proceeded to give a 90 minute speech after an assassin put a bullet in his chest but failed to kill him.The book is a fun read in the way a Ripley's Believe It or Not book is, or was. Things are joyously hyped, tons of stuff is left out, it's not authoritative or balanced or serious nor does it pretend to be, but there is enough of a core of truth to make it a not horrible way to get the teenager in your life to read some history.It's fairly risque. The author is fascinated by LBJ's unique habits of showing people the body part he called "Jumbo"; going to the toilet in front of them to emphasize their subordination to him; and once urinating on the leg of a Secret Service agent who got in his way.Kennedy's sex life gets a good workout, of course - as does his PT-109 exploit, in which he towed an injured shipmate miles through the sea by a strap held in his teeth.Washington leaves the author in awe: he plunged into battle often, getting bullet holes in his clothing while convinced nothing could kill him. The author falsely suggests that Washington, in some nearly mystical way, moved the Continental Congress to war by showing up in uniform at a time when most of them hadn't yet accepted the necessity for it. (Washington badly needed the job and it carried a fair amount of prestige; he wore the uniform to remind them who he was.) He also makes a bit too much of Washington's lack of qualifications to be a commanding general; he's been a mid-level officer in the French and Indian Wars, and it's not like the colonies had a whole lot of British generals at their disposal.But the author also finds admirable traits in presidents who weren't soldiers or fighters. John Adams proved his cojones, in the author's eyes, by not only representing the five British soldiers accused in the Boston Massacre, whom the city was ready to lynch, but by getting them off. Adams was a fierce debater, preferred verbal combat, and didn't care who liked him.Jefferson gets kudos for sending the Navy and Marines overseas to fight the Barbary Pirates - the nation's first overseas war, asserting the nation would no longer pay extortion tribute - and telling Congress about it afterwards.James Madison was a hundred-pound pipsqueak, but was the only president to fight while in office, firing two handguns at the British during the War of 1812 when they sit his house on fire.The book's title premise is pretty silly: that you're getting all this information so that you can decide how to best fight him. Like if you have to fight Jimmy out by the flagpole after school, and consult Ralphy how best to take him. Fortunately, O'Brien doesn't waste too much time on this, and saves most of it for the presidential anecdotes.So who do I think was the all-time bad-ass president? Andrew Jackson, and the book makes, in my opinion, an even better case for him than for Teddy Roosevelt. He fought 13 duels - that we know of, there were probably more - facing death each time and inflicting it most of those times. When nearly 70, he nearly beat to death, with his cane, an assassin whose gun misfired (twice) while pointed at Jackson. (And a little later fired perfectly.) While only 13, he'd fought for the Revolution and escaped English captivity by running barefoot 40 miles. While also suffering from starvation and smallpox. (This is why you want rednecks in the U.S. Army.)It's the stuff of Chuck Norris. 'Nuff said.

There are two kinds of spy novels. There’s the American spy novel, which emphasizes the latest technology and what can be done with it. And there’s the British spy novel, emphasizing the human element – the burned-out agent, the one who no longer trusts his superiors, the double agent, the mole, British class snobbery, and a lot of really good tradecraft.This novel doesn’t manage to be either. It drags, terribly. This is the third installment of Dryden’s series featuring Anna Resnikov, a high-ranking Russian spy who defects to the West as the Russkies kill her MI-6 agent lover. She now works for a large and powerful American private intelligence firm called Cougar.Herein lies the rub. Cougar seems far more powerful than any such firm would ever get. It virtually dictates to the CIA. It has apparently bottomless resources. Fleets of planes, yachts, a mini-sub.Resnikov is beautiful (of course), whip smart, always the one who sees the real deal when others miss it, and a great spy, but I find her strangely unengaging. She is consumed by the desire to work against Russia now, and again and again volunteers for missions where she’ll put herself, alone, in the Russians’ gunsights, on or close to their turf. The author works hard to make this plausible, but I just don’t see it.Resnikov is humanized by her struggle to keep her small son safe. She’s now turned him over to another couple to raise, and the sense of loss she feels at not being able to raise him is poignant. It’s Dryden’s effort to humanize her, to show not even she is Superwoman.But otherwise, she doesn’t grab me. Her tradecraft is OK but not intriguing. She seems rather bloodless – flawless in action, but not exciting or interesting. You don’t sense her working up a sweat or suffering any internal turmoil even when she kills people.The novel doesn’t bring the hardware. Cougar head Burt Miller is all-powerful but not really interesting despite the author’s efforts to show him as rich and a little eccentric, puffing on cigars, wearing flamboyant clothes, telling outrageous tall tales and so on. It comes off like a spy version of Charlie’s Angels – rich guy, beautiful op – although I’m sure this is the last thing Dryden intended. (I think Dryden, as a Brit, may have some trouble writing Americans who are three dimensional. I’m also wondering if the pseudonymous Dryden, if indeed male, may have trouble writing a woman as the central character.)I also had trouble with the plot. Cougar gets wind of revived Russian efforts to destabilize Ukraine in order to ultimately reincorporate it. The French are sucking up to the Russians for trade and oil reasons. The CIA is jealous of Cougar’s power. The Ukraine, undergoing a presidential election, is torn between pro-Russian and pro-independence factions.Meanwhile the Russians are using a very special spy – Balthasar, a Muslim, half-Russian, who is blind but so extraordinarly sensitive as to compensate for his sightlessness. This includes reading minds and being so capable he can work as a field agent. I rolled my eyeballs at this. Balthasar moves around far too easily for a blind person.And the book drags. It took me two or three weeks to read, damning for a spy novel. That’s too bad, because I thought its Ukrainian setting worthwhile and timely – and Anna Resnikov a reasonable stab at a female spy character. Some of the characters’ musings are reasonably subtle or wise.But Dryden spends a little too much time on their interior dialogue, particularly troubled troubled ex-CIA agent Logan. One writing maxim is “show, don’t tell”.  You want to show someone being troubled and what’s eating him in a few deft strokes, rather than spend pages on his thought stream.And even the ending, suitably large scale, fails miserably on the plausibility spectrum. I don’t expect spy novels, of course, to conform to reality, but we see Resnikov perform a series of major actions, improvised in a short period, without any explanation of the preparation, training or inside knowledge that would have been reasonably needed for it. A good spy novel would have the whiz-bang ending, with much more explanation on how they actually pulled it off, and the only unbelievable part the clockwork-like perfection of something so audacious. That only happens in spy novels.Another way you might divide spy novels is between the best ones – well-written, subtle, absorbing, educational – and the mass-market ones, sensational but hokey. I thought this series wants to be seen in the former group, but this installment slips towards the latter one.  The powerful billionaire with his private army who tells presidents what to do, and his gorgeous babe agent? And it still can’t manage to be a page-turner? The first couple of books were better than this one.

Tom Wolfe may never get his historical due for his continuing refusal to get with the program. Today's fiction market is overwhelmingly aimed at women, who make up as much as 80 percent of the market. Tom Wolfe is a man writing often about a taboo subject - manhood. Maybe that's why this book has sold so poorly, and why I didn't even hear about it until more than a year after its publication.Hopefully, one day, people will recognize he is our time's Charles Dickens, whose voluminous works chronicle a certain era like none other. Wolfe has never stopped being a journalist. Novels provide a less controversial medium for him to use his stream of consciousness technique for his characters; used in non-fiction, it left its author open to attack: `How do you know what Gus Grissom was thinking?'  Whether in fiction or non-fiction, though, his technique always has had a certain credibility because of the depth of his research and his insight into human nature - his ability to see people as Everyman, acknowledge how the world looks from Everyman's eyes, and sense how Everyman gets through his day.Wolfe's characters have a certain flatness to them, but it's a graphic-novel flatness, rich in detail, exaggerations intended. While spending an enormous amount of time inside their heads, he devotes little time to their back stories, a rebellion against a Freudian view of the human condition. Wolfe's characters don't dwell on yesterday, their childhoods, or long ago. They're not deeply conflicted. They are hard-working folks making their way up in life, people from small-town or working-class backgrounds confronted with the foibles and pretensions of modern life, executives with big mortgages and kids in private schools who worry about losing it all if they make the wrong move. They don't see psychiatrists.What they think about is the intense experience of Now: What they've got to do today. How it will help them climb the ladder or bolster their position on it. Who they're in love with, or in heat for. What it looks like out in the street or at the chic restaurant or hot soiree or dingy crack house - right now, in riotous detail. If today goes right, they feel good. If not, they feel lousy.There's much here familiar from previous books. Wolfe remains fascinated with art, design and fashion, of course: what status it conveys, what it connotes and to whom. There's his sense that we're preoccupied with the race, class, sex or walk of life we come from - in Miami, the Cubans, the blacks, the Haitians, the Russians, Miami's vanishing tribe of WASPs, and more - and he's determined to set it forth as exactly and convincingly as he can. A racial incident hyped by the media knocks a character for a loop, as in "Bonfire of the Vanities" and "A Man in Full". His over-the-top writing style, with its sound effects and run-on sentences and orgies of gorgeous words, is, if anything, amplified in this book from previous ones. (Some expressions like "buttery jowls" and "loamy loins" seem like old friends now.) He focuses on male strength and manhood, often symbolized by the strength of a man's hands, to do work (Charlotte Simmons' father), protect himself (Conrad Hensley in "A Man in Full") or commit some manly act of courage.That last type of incident kicks off this book. It focuses on two Cuban-American characters in Miami: young police officer Nestor Camacho, and his estranged girlfriend Magdalena Otero. Many names in this book can be mined productively: the macho Camacho; Otero the "other", witness to but not part of the alien and decadent lives of the rich; the egotistical Cuban mayor Dio who thinks he's God.Nestor commits a startling act of heroism and strength, rescuing a panicked refugee from the top of a sailing mast. Televised, he becomes a momentary hero but a pariah in the Cuban community for stymieing a fellow refugee's flight to freedom.Magdalena meanwhile ditches him for unrelated reasons. A nurse, she's taken up with her boss, a wealthy, celebrity psychiatrist whose specialty of porn addiction gets him regularly on TV. Through her eyes Wolfe gives us his take on sexually unhinged modern life with the pervasiveness of pornography, ever more public acts of sex and nudity, and an orgy among the well-connected at a regatta. Only slowly does Magdalena realize her own boss is sex-addicted himself, and also exploiting his richest client's dependence upon him to get entree into his social circles. Wolfe has frequently written about sex in modern life, but here he chronicles ever-darker lows, symbolized by the billionaire porn addict's revolting STD symptoms.To live in luxury with her boss, Magdalena leaves Hialeah's suffocating Cuban embrace. Nestor is expelled from it. His plight deepens when his take-down of an enormous and violent crack dealer turns into a racial incident broadcast on YouTube, leading to his suspension from the police force. He falls in with an ambitious young Miami Herald reporter investigating rumors that a wealthy Russian philanthropist may have committed a monumental fraud. Camacho has been abandoned by everyone around him - the police force, his family, his girlfriend - but never abandons devotion to his duty.The work has some flaws. It ends abruptly. Wolfe's style, particularly the run-on sound effects, can become tedious, and if cut by a third would still get the message across. I have never understood what passages set off by ::::::::::::  connote. Wolfe started using it long ago, but I've never gotten what, exactly, differentiates these passages from the rest of the consciousness flow.And I don't understand the title, unless it suggest Miami is incurably tribal. The ending hints, ever so faintly, otherwise. There might be some rays of hope.But Wolfe's insights into food, language, status, wealth and style are, as ever, dead on, and deeply revealing. And depressing. There is vanishingly little sense that among the upper crust, much style or dignity or human value at all survive amid all that money. A scene of slovenly billionaires stampeding through the Miami Basel art convention in search of deals, seems much like K-Mart shoppers hurrying to a blue light special - but with more vulgarity.

This is not one of my favorite Deep Black books. The story is workmanlike but doesn’t have a lot of life to it. I thought it was predictable and dragged a bit. As other reviewers have observed, the decision to kill off Tommy Karr in an earlier installment was a bad one. He was an interesting character and created an asymmetrical three-person team in the field. Too much weight is thus placed on the relationship between Charlie Dean and Lia DeFrancesca, but it’s not that interesting, and in any case the two are kept apart in the field by superiors aware of their romance.I also don’t like this book, though, because it uses the scenario of nuclear terrorism in the Canary Islands to trigger a tsunami destroying the American East Coast. One of Patrick Robinson’s books had the same plot. To their credit, Coonts and DiFelice note that this particular doomsday scenario gained traction in popular culture stemming from a BBC what-if documentary in the early 2000s, and then the ensuing 2012 Mayan-calendar end-of-the-world craze.I concede that there are only so many contemporary plots for thrillers – the usual bad guys, jihadis, Russian nationalists and Chinese spooks; the usual atomic weapons, the usual illegal obtaining of them from loosely guarded Russian stockpiles or easily bribed officials. But to me it felt hokey, nonetheless. It was more of a Clive Cussler plot than a Stephen Coonts one, and in Cussler’s hands such stories are more clearly fun and escapist.It wasn’t just the plotting. The Chinese business executive who is actually a Chinese intelligence major is a bwa-ha-ha Oriental bad guy straight out of a 1930s B film.  The evil Feng! The mandatory cliffhanger torture session with our damsel in distress (well, OK, DeFrancesca isn’t exactly helpless) also had a hokey feel to it.A couple of new Deep Black members have been brought to the fore. But while serviceable, they’re sidekicks. I don’t see either replacing Karr.I did enjoy the book’s opening sequences in Tajikistan. There’s interesting background on tensions between Tajiks, Russians trying to maintain Soviet-era influence there, and Indians with new bases there.William Rubens keeps fighting the bureaucratic wars. Charlie Dean is always the brave last guy out at the last minute, shooting bad guys and grabbing on to some helicopter lifting off under fire. DeFrancesca is always telling men who are sexist pigs to bleep off.I also think they lean too much on military equipment acronyms. Some of this is OK as it creates verisimilitude, but they do it far too much, including when they don’t follow up by telling you what’s unique or interesting or relevant about it. This series' high-tech edge may be wearing thin; you sense they're trying a little too hard to impress you with the latest greatest guns and scopes that aren't really that new and cool anymore.Anyway, not my favorite book in this series, but I’m a big Coonts fan in general and plan to keep reading Deep Black books.

These are solid, heavy-duty and work well, a good value for the money. They're not particularly attractive - they have that industrial look - so you'll want them in places where they don't show or where it doesn't matter. A lot of household power strips and surge protectors don't have enough space for the many plugs with larger heads or transformers, as a lot of digital equipment have, and you find yourself not being able to plug in everything you need to by your desk or any other location with a lot of gear around. This surge protector solves that problem - 10 sockets, all of them spaced to accept a transformer head.

At the outset of this enjoyable but lengthy installment in the “Presidential Agent” series, Charley Castillo begins to interrogate a fugitive American UN diplomat implicated in the Oil-for-Food scandal, only to be attacked on a Uruguayan ranch by masked gunmen who kill the man and one of Castillo’s men, before being taken out themselves.There’s no sign of who they are or who they work for. An assassination attempt is also made on Castillo’s family friend Eric Kocian, the crusty old publisher of a Hungarian newspaper Castillo’s chain owns. He’s been poking into the scandal, in which Iraqi oil is embargoed in the years before the Iraq invasion, some allowed to be sold for food and medicine, but fortunes made (including by corrupt UN bureaucrats) as the rules are circumvented.Castillo is charged by the president with getting to the bottom of it all, including the murder of a US ambassador and kidnapping of his wife – sister of the suspected corrupt UN diplomat. He doesn’t know who he can trust, even in his own government. He has an uneasy field relationship with Russian gangster and arms trafficker Aleksandr Pevsner, who employs a disgraced and wanted former FBI agent.He must fight a turf war with the director of national intelligence, threatened by Castillo’s direct line to the president, and learn how to infight in Washington. On the other hand, Castillo’s new agency now has a source of funding: oil-for-food scam proceeds, spirited out of secret bank accounts. And he gathers a motley crew of military, espionage and cop operatives around him as his impromptu new team.Some real-world details intrigue if indeed true: Did Vladimir Putin make his personal fortune in the oil-for-food scandal? And did Adolf Hitler, who reputedly had only one testicle, lose the other one in the first World War to a patriotic Belgian dog?Griffin locates much of the story in the cone of South America where he also located his “Honor Bound” series about OSS operations there against Nazis during World War II. There are a lot of echoes of it, beginning with Castillo being strongly reminiscent of that series’ protagonist Cletus Frade. Each is a wealthy Texan. Each is military and a pilot. Each is from a complicated binational background involving two different wealthy families, one of them Hispanic, in essence having multiple identities and nationalities. Each finds out he is an innately skilled improviser of clandestine operations.I was a little disappointed that the oil-for-food scandal itself didn’t get more attention. It’s the McGuffin – the thing everyone wants – but other than a couple of pages devoted to how it worked late in the book, we don’t hear that much about it. I would have enjoyed seeing the UN’s feet put to the fire a little more closely here.

I gave this to my daughter, who is middle school age. It's a great item of jewelry for a girl that age. It's simple and elegant, a classic style she can always wear on a dressy occasion, and a step beyond costume jewelry. But it's low cost and not made from materials so precious that it'll be a problem if it's lost or damaged.Most important, she loved it.

I’m really impressed with the Jack Reacher series. In this one, Child just keeps gently, but inexorably, ratcheting up the tension. He’s an inventive writer and I found the scenario fairly unique. Reacher finds himself working as a government plant in the home of a rug dealer suspected of being a drug dealer, agreeing to it because the latter is close to another criminal Reacher has some long-ago nasty history with. And only slowly and gradually do we learn what history is.That said, the style has deep roots in popular thrillers. Reacher gets into a large, isolated estate on the Maine seacoast. Very Gothic. The dealer’s unhappy family and the huge, high-on-steroids scary thug Paulie are right out of Hammett or Chandler (where the latter would have been described as “hopped up.”)  Child makes a nod to Chandler in some dinnertable conversation between Reacher and the family.I don’t want to say too much about the plot because I don’t want to give anything away, not even the opening scenario which really drew me in. Reacher must himself impersonate a thug to gain the drug dealer’s trust and find his way into his inner circle in a matter of days – to crack his ring, bring him to justice and rescue a missing government agent before his cover is blown.Reacher fascinates in his ingenuity under pressure and his ability to come up with strategems extracting himself from impossible jams. And he’s full of useful tidbits of information. I never knew, for instance, that commercial metal detectors have a dead zone near the floor  to avoid being set off by the metal shanks stiffening the soles of people’s shoes, that 19th century locks can be picked in seconds, or that the odds of surviving Russian roulette played with a well-maintained handgun are vastly in the shooter’s favor. Why? Read the book and find out.

Robert Littell is unique among espionage and intrigue novelists in the extent to which he is willing to experiment stylistically. Some books like "The Company" are straight-ahead style.  Others, like this one, are black-comic in tone. In one, "The Stalin Epigram", each chapter was told from the point of view of a different character. In another he has a story set within a story.This is one of his earlier books. It's set in the Brezhnev era, when the government no longer rules by overwhelming terror but the memory and possibility of it still linger - and the government still wrecks the lives of those who make the faintest peep of dissent.The economy is decayed, Communism has been reduced to empty shibboleths that people mouth but no one believes, and there's a shortage of everything. No one has yet heard of glasnost or perestroika.Our character, with the unlikely name of Robespierre Pravdin, is a fixer, who lives by his wits, obtaining hard-to-get items for those who can pay or trade him something in return. Bolshoi tickets? Beatles albums? Birth control pills? Some new blue jeans? He's your guy.He has a crippled thumb, courtesy of a 12-year stint in the gulags when he was one of many World War II soldiers imprisoned for nothing. As an ex-con and a Jew, he is unemployable, and hence his illegal occupation.  He's an entertaining guy, who crashes conventions and receptions for both the free food and the opportunity to make contacts and glean the information that keeps him ahead of the black-market curve. (And the police.)His Moscow residential building being scheduled for demolition, he finds new lodgings. His new neighbors are a grab-bag of eccentrics - the mortician who cares for Lenin's body, a retired two-star general, some young hippies. And also Mother Russia, a batty but shrewd old woman determined to clear the name of her husband, who was executed during the purges. A government-celebrated author is believed to have actually plagiarized his work, and Mother Russia's late husband was the sole literary judge not to go along with the official story. (This is a thinly disguised version of questions surrounding Mikhail Sholokhov and "Quiet Flows the Don", which won the Nobel Prize in 1965 but whose authorship of it was contested.)Now the original manuscript by the real author has turned up.  Mother Russia wants Pravdin to use his connections and wiles to make sure the truth sees the light of day. Pravdin uses all his skills to do so in the shadows without showing his hand, but inevitably the KGB finds out about it.I was initially put off by the black-comic style, as Littell lays it on pretty heavily and I initially saw it as fiction-writing immaturity. (And my first Littell book, "The Company", was both so good and in the straight-ahead style that I am subconsciously hoping whatever next Littell book I read is going to be like that one.)However, once I got into the rhythm of it, I liked it a lot better. There are overtones of Joseph Heller's "Catch 22" and Ken Kesey's "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" here in its use of absurd humor and in the theme of what it means to be sane in an insane society.I particularly liked the characterization of Pravdin. He writes subversive graffiti. He has certain catchphrases, like introducing himself in gatecrashing situations as "at your beck and call." His whole being is subversive. He's Jewish, for starters, making him a second-class citizen in this supposedly classless society.  His comically elegant manners hearken to those of pre-revolutionary Europe, those, say, of a hand-kissing, heel-clicking Austrian.  (Pravdin clicks together the heels of his high-top sneakers.) He often forms sentences in a flagrantly backwards style - I think it's meant to be a defiant use of Yiddish-influenced speaking style - the better to deliver some mordant commentary or pointed retort.I got the feeling that Littell later on used a lot of the same elements in the more sweeping and developed "The Revolutionist", which traces two revolutionaries who return to Russia from the U.S. in 1917 and then live through the years of turmoil following it. It has some of the same elements, including a large house with a grab-bag of colorful characters, an examination of the hollowness of revolutionary promise, and a defiant protagonist with Jewish roots.This is still an enjoyable book, particularly for those with a taste for black comedy. Although it's not long, it drags occasionally, when the author and characters spend a little too much time pondering the nature of things, or near the end where plot elements are resolved through a lengthy series of letters Mother Russia writes to the Singer Sewing Machine Company. You read that right.

A shocking assault on a U.S. embassy in Switzerland sends the Scorpion on a dangerous series of encounters throughout Europe, before being inserted into Iran to track down the terror attack’s architect. Known only as “The Gardener”, he’s the most feared man in Iran, his identity known to only a few – and the Scorpion has to eliminate him without even knowing who he is. IF he can't, there will be war.It’s a decent page-turner, with the U.S. itching to attack Iran if it can be proven it was behind the attack. But Scorpion can’t understand: why would Iran do such an attack knowing the likely American response? Meanwhile, the Israelis are lurking in the background, concerned about Iran’s nuclear program, knowing an American attack on Iran will put them in jeopardy, and making hints that they’ll attack first.There are a lot of twists and turns as the Scorpion uses his matchless tradecraft to move in and out of countries and cities, to develop and carry out ingenious tactics and to stay one step ahead of all those who’d like to kill him.He’s kind of a bloodless hero, though. Kaplan gives him a love interest here to flesh him out a bit; a French doctor doing charity work in an African refugee camp where Scorpion, wanting out of the business, has gone to lose himself and think about what to do with his life.I found some minor anomalies. There are multiple references to Scorpion’s favorite Glock, worn on his ankle, but he crosses several borders, including airport security searches, without it being detected. That’s not likely. And in Iran, he is given a high-tech sniper rifle, and then makes his long-range shot without ever having zeroed his scope (which requires practice-shooting it, I believe) to ensure its accurate synching with the weapon.Still, Scorpion is a resourceful lone operator (he’s a freelancer) whose adventures make good reading. The scenes of his operating on his own in Iran are particularly good, as is his dramatic extraction. There are a lot of twists and turns that continue right up until the end.

Seems good for the price, so far.  Dry erase markers write well and wipe off cleanly, and the clapper makes a sharp sound when called upon to do so, which pretty much sums up the features and functions of this object.The pivot bolt is begging for a drop of blue Loctite or something, should have had that from the factory so it wouldn't fall apart when handled, but if you do it, it'll quit backing out all the time and you will never have to fiddle with it again.  The stripes are stickers, not paint, fyi.Whatever, it's cheap and cheerful, works.  Just the thing if you're shooting with separate sound and having to sync sound.  Or just if you want to look like a very amateur filmmaker, for whatever reason :)  I'll post back if it falls apart, but so far so good, looks decent, and could probably be re-glued if it ever does come apart.

Nice little saw kit.  Some of the blades were not quite perfect, but I cleaned them up, straightened them a bit, and they cut well on wood, clean and precise.  I'll be getting more saws from these guys in different gauges.

Nice stuff, well machined and very useful.  I'm going over mine with super fine sandpaper, melting the sharp edges and putting a nice finish on it, just because.  Well worth the price, and a very useful basic luthier tool.

Beautiful, heavy wall stainless bottle.  Nice lid and tether, machined nalgene-standard water filter compatible threads.  This is the sexy, skinny 24 oz travel model, and it's great in the side pocket of a day pack, or in your car's cup holder, with its skinny base.  I'm collecting these Guyot bottles in all their varieties, apparently; they're the nicest bottles I've seen if you don't mind the moderate weight, and water's heavy anyway, so for everything but ultralight backpacking, these are awesome, durable bottles, very hard to dent, unlike most thin-wall offerings from others.  They can rust, like all stainless, if you're not careful.  Don't let moisture stay inside with the lid on, or you'll be trying to tape 400-grit sandpaper to the end of a stick and get enough leverage to resurface the inside of your bottle...  pro tip there, don't ask me how I know...  Mine was the last of its kind, arrived battered and in need of some love, but I got a discount so it's cool.  This review may serve no purpose if these have really gone extinct as rumored, but if you can get a good price on one, get it.  At twenty bucks, it's a pretty good deal, but at any less it's a must-buy, IMO.

I love these except the high price, which I think is bordering on the absurd especially for these smaller pieces; the half-round stick-on things made of the same stuff are a pretty good value as bookshelf speaker feet, redneck isolators for your budget mini hifi setup with audiophile pretensions, but these grommet things are really pricey for what you get.  They're small.  These had better last literally forever, or I will be upset.However, they're pretty cool for what they are, aside from the sticker shock for a few bits of plastic, and if you need durable vibration-damping mounts, what else are you going to do?  I'm using some of these to mount a custom subwoofer box into a VW bus in such a way as to not drive the flat sheetmetal into resonance any more than necessary.  These mounts, along with some of the larger flat doughnuts, some FatMat, and a heavy sub box, ought to get a clean sound even in that difficult environment.  And to be fair, you get twelve of them in the package.  I'll mount my sub box and my glassblowing fan with these, and have some left over for a random project.  But you have to buy the matching washers separately, which really begins to look like highway robbery.  I guess I should just shut up about the price, as I bought these things and the washers too, thus proving that despite what I might say, I do feel that they're worth it.  I just feel like they should be cheaper, for some reason.  I guess I'm wrong, though, because they're not.As the other reviewer noted, 70 is pretty soft and rubbery, 50 is gummy bear.  Haven't tried 30, but it must be downright gooey, and I haven't needed that yet.  Watch the weight and don't overload these.  The chemistry is weird, and can attack plastics, finishes, carpet, and who knows what else; beware.I'll post back with durability updates eventually, but if you need a vibration isolating mount, here they are.  You pays your money and you takes your chances.  No idea if these will even work on the frequencies I need, but it's something to try...

This is about as close to perfect as a mouse can get, IMO.  Logitech makes great mice.  I have an ancient optical Mx310 that still works perfectly, and it's okay, but this is amazing, especially for the price.  I wanted a nice mouse, decided I'd try this one and spend more if it didn't work out, but no need.  This is great.  Medium heavy, perfect action, nice barely tacky rubber on the sides.  I think the buttons are perfect.  I reassigned my scroll wheel button to command-w to close windows, and I love it, no problems with hard button push or hitting the side scroll.  If you're super uncoordinated, I guess you might not like the scroll wheel button functions, but you can just ignore them.The loose scroll wheel takes some getting used to, but I like it.  I do wish it was more responsive at super slow speed; slow scrolling does almost nothing, even at full speed and full acceleration in the Logitech control panel app thingy which you must download to get the tricky functions working.  Whatever, you learn to flick the wheel up and down, which is smooth and fun, and gives good control once you get the hang of it.  It could be even better, but it's pretty sweet the way it is.For around twenty five bucks, this is a great deal.  If you want a solid deal on a great corded mouse, here it is.

Just okay.  Microstamped .925, but fairly dull finish, not super nice.  Crudely clipped, non-rounded sharp ends, which I really hate.  Crooked, and rather small.  I'll be making my own from here on out.

Good deal on a titanium spork and carabiner.  I'm neither a ninja nor a prepper, just a titanium fetishist, so I won't mourn the passing of the brand logos and may even hasten their demise, but the bottom line here is a good deal on good gear.  The biner is flat, light, strong, and doing a good job of holding my keys to my belt loop.  Appears to be the same biner that's being sold for ten bucks alone elsewhere.  Recommended!

Fine cut-resistant gloves, but way too small.  I dutifully measured, and ordered the indicated medium size, which seemed reasonable, as I am a medium-sized man.  They fit my wife, who is 5'9 and 125lb...  So mediums are good for a slender woman, not a medium man.  She's keeping them and I am ordering a large, or an extra large.[Edit- the seller contacted me to say they've fixed the size chart problem, plus they sent me out a free pair of XL size.  Awesome service and one extra star just for that; I'll upgrade to five stars when the gloves arrive and fit!]Okay, the XL's fit me perfectly, just a bit snug.  These are women's sizes, or something.  A big guy with man hands might not be able to fit in the XL's, but for most guys, that's what to try first, I'd think.These do what they claim, protect you from accidental slices.  I sharpen knives and tools, and these are just the thing to prevent nicks or worse when you're dealing with large razor-sharp blades.  Nice for the grater and mandoline.  You should still be careful, of course, but these are a lot of protection for the price.
These are not sterling silver.  They are made of steel, and are magnetic.  Do not order these if you want genuine silver.

Horrible, dangerous, useless trap, waiting to break whatever gear you attach it to.I got my new mini ball head, opened the package, and it literally fell apart.  The 1/4" screw and platform are pressed into the ball via a tapered shaft.  The instant some torque gets applied to that shaft, it separates from the ball.  If your camera is attached, goodbye.This piece of garbage will break your gear the first time it gets bumped, or maybe the second or third, but eventually it will fail, guaranteed.  Avoid.  It's not to be trusted for anything, period.  Obviously, the shaft needs to screw in to the ball and not be radically prone to falling out.  Obviously, you don't press a tapered shaft lightly into a ball and call it good.  Horrible, criminally negligent design.  Appears deliberately constructed to break something for you.  The maker should be sued into oblivion, but good luck with that now that our trade deals have given corporations not only personhood but effective sovereignty.  Now we can enjoy fine products of Chinese capitalism like this, which make China lots of money by breaking your gear, thus forcing you to replace it.  Does this look inexpensive to you?  This could easily be the most expensive piece of gear you ever buy, seriously.  Whatever you do, don't actually attach a camera to this thing.Buy American, from trusted sellers.  I've bought and had to return so much junk off of Amazon lately that I'm about done.  Low prices are not attractive when the quality is even lower.This thing is junk.  The ball is super rough.  It doesn't lay over 90 degrees in the notch, more like 83...  There is nothing right with this and it should not be purchased by anyone, ever.  The maker ought to be publicly beaten and humiliated.  And Amazon ought to screen out garbage like this, or it will become Ali Express, which really sucks because everything is misrepresented junk.CAVEAT EMPTOR!!!![Got a replacement.  It works and has not fallen apart even with a bit of twisting.  I'd never trust it with anything more than a super cheap light fixture, but for something like that it might do.  I'd pass and save up for something better, won't buy again, not recommended.]

Well, this is interesting.  The old unit, the EQS746, claimed 100db (or 105db according to some sources) S/N ratio, and .005% THD.  The new one, the 755, claims in the official specs portion of the owner's manual 83db S/N and .01% THD, a rather profound drop in spec.  Is this real, or a typo, or what?  Inquiring minds want to know.  I have a call in to Clarion; it'll be interesting to see if they ever get back, and what they say.  It would also be interesting to open up a 746 and a 755 and see what's inside...  I need to buy one or the other, so maybe I should buy both and do some testing and inspection.  It would be tragic if they really downgraded the new model in terms of audio performance, but anything's possible these days of late-stage corporate capitalism, so caveat emptor!

So much better than the old crusty kinked one.  The ends on this are tough plastic blocks, and the cable is brightly reflective, which is nice at night.  Nice solid chrome hardware, basic and good, clasps work and feel good.  Looks good so far, now let's see how long it lasts.

I had high expectations, but this is even better.  Tons of info and great stories, perspectives, and wisdom.  Great book for pretty much any guitar or bass player or luthier.  I guess I'm intermediate level, and I'm learning a ton; I'd think most anyone would find this book worth it, even if you already know what you're doing.  He's got everything from basics to advanced tricky stuff.  Buy it!

No idea what anyone might actually want this for IRL, but for the money, you really can't beat it; this thing costs less than the sheath alone for a big-name high-end tomahawk.  Do be aware of potential quality issues; I got one from Midway that was pretty wonky, main blade off center and badly ground, a Monday lemon or something.  I got with Cold Steel and after some calls, I sent some photos, called again, and eventually they sent out a new one, and let me keep the old one for a beater, which was nice of them.  The new one is straight and proper, sharp, too.  The differential heat treat is nice, as I found when I started filing and melting edges.  I'll throw and abuse that beater and see if I can break or bend something...The non-sharpened edges and finish in general aren't anything amazing, about what you'd expect for the price, kinda rough.  I'm going to round and polish everything, just because.  If I ever have to break this thing out, the S has definitely hit the F, and if you've got a bit of bling in a situation like that, all the better.  Come the zombie apocalypse, it's great to have any tomahawk at all, sure, but having one of these with a nice custom finish?  Points for style for sure.  Yep, I've been watching too much Walking Dead.The sheath is interesting and almost actually useful.  It does protect you from the pointy bits, but that's it, and that's not really enough.  I can see several ways to make it a useful way of carrying your 'hawk on belt, rig, or pack, but at present, without some work, it really isn't.  You can't actually attach it to anything, which is an issue.  The way it is now, it's pretty secure, but very slow to open.  It needs to be really secure, but also accessible, and instant to access.  At present the snap strap is fumbly and awkward, and how can you attach it to anything?  If you use the grommets at front or back, the thing will hang all wrong, and if you use both, you can't open the sheath because it needs to hinge.  Hmm.  Somebody thought this thing brilliantly about halfway through.  I'm going to work on some mods.Oh, well.  This is pretty much a toy or a man cave decoration anyway, not really a serious tactical accessory, if we're honest.  I mean, sure, it'll split a head, but when or where would you actually carry it and use it before something else, like ferinstance an AR or a Glock or just a big knife?  Now, if some magic were to cause all firearms to stop working, a 'hawk would attain a whole new level of relevance, but until then...  It's a big chunk of steel and black plastic to lug around.  I suspect most of these don't get carried much, but I'd still like to work out a really slick battle-ready sheath, just because.I've decided it's a vehicular accessory.  My plan is to bolt the sheath inside one of my vehicles, and have the thing within reach.  The way the sheath works, about the only way is to have the 'hawk blade down, with the front part of the sheath attached to the car, and then raise the end of the handle up in an arc to free the spike; it has to kind of rotate out.  I can justify it to my wife by explaining its many life-saving uses in an accident, like breaking glass, prying open (or hacking through) stuck doors, cutting seat belts, and of course dispatching any rogue zombies or smallish dragons present at the accident scene.  Be prepared!

Horrible junk, not stainless steel.  Stamped from the softest super thin plate steel I've ever seen, dead soft, zero spring, strongly magnetic.  Definitely not stainless steel.  Burrs all over and slot cut wonky.  Not worth the free postage.

I had high expectations of a $50 "super" pliers.  The rough draggy action didn't really live up.  They've smoothed out a bit with use and lube, but I sure wish they were better.  They should have made the rotating pin and the surface it contacts more precise, at least; it bumps and chunks along, and there's no way to get to it to polish it because it's a rivet, pressed in.  Fit and finish is generally underwhelming, plenty of burrs and sharp edges where they ought not be, plus the front edges don't mate up smooth, looks imprecise and isn't good for holding things evenly with the tip.I bought the best I could find, just wish it was a bit better value.  One vinyl handle cover thing fell off on day one just playing around with them, lame.  Glue them on if you want them to stay, I guess.  The pliers aren't very ergonomic; the best seems to be to rest your thumb on the back curve of the wire cutter piece.  The teflon finish is highly imperfect largely because the steel underneath wasn't finished particularly well, seems like a waste.  How about melting the sharp edges and doing a real Tenifer coating or something?  Thought a $50 English-made pliers would be really well finished, but not so much.  I'm going to buy a pair of the $15 China parallel pliers to compare.My grandpa had a pair of similar looking parallel pliers that were so much better, it's not even funny.  Silky smooth, perfect.  Wish I had those, but they somehow disappeared...  As I get older, I realize the old guys were right along: they don't make 'em like they used to.  I'm going to start buying old hand tools whenever I can.  They're just better, generally, and I bet I could pick up an old set of better-made parallel pliers for a lot less than $50.  Whatever, I now have "Manley Super Pliers" and that's probably worth $50 just to get to say.  I hear these will cut a treble hook wen nothing else will, but in the desert, that's the least of my concerns.

Three thick bone picks.  Might work well for bass players and/or ogres.  These picks come with a squared off blunt edge, definitely need some bevel work to be nice, IMO.  And the sides are slick and smooth; I'll maybe sand for some grit and grip.  The other reviewer who said they're more like blanks is right on.  And when you file or sand or whatever, watch out, these are the stinkiest bone I've had the displeasure of smelling, pure death, could seriously turn you vegan.  I might boil mine or something to get rid of the reeking dead cow smell; it's a serious issue, leaves my fingers smelling really foul.  Not sure if I like these at all, for anything.  But the price is right, and if you think you might enjoy playing with a beastly bone pick, here you go.

These are a bad deal.  Mine arrived with balls of what appear to be welding spall and spatter stuck on them, plus two of them were a bit rusty.  Not something you'd be proud to use, or show a customer.  When stewmac has stainless gauges, way nicer and thinner where it counts, for just a couple bucks more, why buy these junky non-stainless ones?  I'd have to spend time with a grinder and a file to make these just okay, and that's not even okay.  These would be acceptable at five bucks, but not at twenty plus five shipping.  Come on.  Somebody is trying to sell these for more than they are worth.  Make your own or buy good ones, but don't buy these if you have another option, which you do if you're online...

This is more of a dangerous toy or an inferior weapon, not so much a useful trainer.  It's way light.  And quite hard.I just naively assumed that of course it would be the same weight as the real thing, and have a dense but soft, flexible blade and spike, but nope, it's hard and light.  I think that's pretty lame and potentially quite dangerous.  This thing is pretty useless as is.  What can you actually do with it?How hard would it have been to mold the blade in soft rubber and/or mold in a weight or something?  They just did it one-piece, the cheapest possible way.  How are you going to practice with something that feels and balances different from the real thing?  If you flip this thing around or throw it, or just hold it, it's balanced totally different from a real 'hawk, so how is that a trainer?  I guess you can drill into it and add some weight, if you care enough.  It's so hard that you can't do any impact with it or you'll hurt your partner; it's basically an oddly shaped plastic club.  I guess depending on what you want it for, you could add weight, or padding, as appropriate.  I'd rather it was soft on the striking edges and came with a removable weight for when you want to use padding, along with some extra soft padding to add for combat training...  Now, _that_ would be a nice trainer.  And it wouldn't have to cost much more to produce.  And Cold Steel could design a good sheath someday...  Okay, I'll wake up now.  Buy this one and mod it to suit, I guess.  It's super cheap at least.  Be careful playing around sparring with this as is; it's light (fast) and hard, begging to knock somebody's tooth out, break a nose, crack a rib, or just put a big nasty bruise on your training partner, and who wants that?  If you're using it solo, for katas or strength or whatever, I'd think you'd want it heavier than actual, if anything.  YMMV.

Hot little rock at a reasonable price.  My PRM-8000 immediately said 700+ CPM at almost point blank range when out of the packaging, which is more than I want to hang out with for very long, so I didn't spend any time trying the other side for a higher reading.  The sheet that came with the material listed some 50,000 CPM activity, which I'm guessing is calculated total activity, or just a reading from a much more sensitive detector than mine.  People sometimes don't understand that CPM numbers are dependent on the size and type of detector used, among other things.  CPM on its own doesn't really mean that much; it's more about knowing how your detector behaves, what's normal, and what's not.  For my detector, 18 CPM is normal background; 700 is really something.After having the new counter read a rock-steady 18 CPM average for months, I almost wondered if it was actually working as a detector, so I got this rock rather than making a trip to the mineralogy museum to visit their uranium sample...  Oh, yeah, it works!  Pretty dramatic, flashing light almost constantly lit, alarm going off...  Works great, scared my wife... :)Were I a Geiger counter maker, I'd include a check source like this with each and every one.  It's great to see exactly how the counter responds at different distances, how long it takes to average and react, etc.  Also instills the desire for a more sensitive detector... :)Anybody with a Geiger counter should probably have a radioactive source with which to test it.  That ends up being ironic, because if you want a Geiger counter to help you avoid exposure to radiation, you end up getting extra exposure from your test source, if nowhere else.  I'm not all that worried about it, but I am keeping this little piece of subatomic weaponry rather far from my fragile human body, as a rule.  This is like a miniature machine gun, and when you hold it close, it's spewing little energetic bullets that tear through your DNA, breaking it, causing replication errors, mutations...  Seven hundred microscopic wounds per minute, or maybe fifty thousand; either way, I'll pass if I can, thanks...I may make a little lead-lined wormwood box to hold this.  The lead is probably more tightly regulated than this stuff, which is funny, because lead can't mutate your great grandchildren by your simply being next to it.  Some might say that being near this stuff for a while won't harm you, and some will even say that low level exposure can be therapeutic; the hormesis theory.  For my part, I'll limit my exposure to the degree possible, thanks.  If you want to wear this as jewelry or play with it and then suck on your fingers, or make it into a lollipop or sprinkle it on toast, I guess you can do so freely, thanks to Amazon, America, and freedom!  Me, I'll be cautious and prudent :)  I am glad that we have the freedom to do foolish things, but I wish we didn't exercise it so often...  Ahem.The listing could have been a bit clearer about exactly what was being sold; the description was a little vague, and I thought the sample pic was the actual sample I'd be getting.  Whatever, I'm happy and got what I wanted for a reasonable price, but if you want a specific size or CPM, maybe contact the seller first or something.  I just wanted a sort of go/no go tester, not anything calibrated or powerful, so this little chunk fit my needs perfectly, and I'm glad it's not hotter, actually.  Came well packed, in a nice little tin.  Bueno!

Nice.  Handy size, neutral color, good texture for most any fine or delicate work.  I'm using it for guitar maintenance, but I may get another one for greasy/oily stuff, cars, bikes, guns; this is a handy product at a reasonable price.  Beats using a yoga mat...

It's okay.  Why the back is open, I don't get.  It's a sun hat; it shouldn't give you a sunburn on the back of your head.  I'll sew the seam in back, and sew in a panel to cover the hole over the closure in back, as I don't have a pony tail that needs a way out, nor do I anticipate having one any time soon...  This thing is not "milk" colored, that's for sure.  Light peach, or crayon-caucasian color, perhaps.  Not a great color.  Not a great hat.  Cheap, though.  And it has a facemask.  Come the UV apocalypse, I'm set.  Until then, it'll probably sit in the closet.  The adjustment thingy in back doesn't hold; fabric too thin.  Surprisingly hot to wear in the sun.

These are not right.  They only make contact right at the tip; at the joint end of the jaw, there's a large gap, so you really can't use these with thin wire at all.  They work okay with fat copper wire, but not with anything thin.  There's no reason they should be like this; they should mate without a gap, of course.  Junk, sloppy, awful.

Sweet, precise, proper.  Because I'm a perfectionist, I'm going over it and melting all the edges and corners, and I may mirror polish it, just because.  Mine came a little beat-up looking, not what I'd really call a "nice brushed finish"- lots of little scratches and dings from manufacturing or whatever, which is normal, but it'll look amazing polished, and I wish it was a bit smoother to start...  If you're going to work on your bass, or somebody else's, you probably need one of these.  Fair price for a quality tool, machined in the USA.  Beefy, looks like it'll last forever with reasonable care.  Four stars instead of five because I'm a finish and polish guy, and this was a bit rougher than nice, but that's a minor quibble.

Just awful.  Really weak glue, falls apart instantly.  There doesn't seem to be a functional striker for singing bowls on Amazon, unfortunately.  This thing has inspired me to make my own from a dowel and some suede; mine will be cheaper and better :)
These are the real deal, high quality gel caps.  What with testing showing that many supplements are bogus or tainted, the best way is to source pure ingredients and make your own caps.  Here you go!

What a wonderful invention.  We keep these on a few windows, and when the bugs go there as they always do, they remain indefinitely.  It's a bit sadistic, but it's so much nicer to hear a fly stuck and buzzing than flying around in your face...I have one of these on my bedside window, and if a bug gets in at night, I aim the bedside reading light at the fly sticker.  Five minutes, and the bug is stuck, works like a charm, much easier than hunting with a fly swatter.Easy to apply and peel off once you get the hang of it, although my wife still sometimes gets herself hoist on her own petard and stuck to the things, somehow, which is kind of a messy bummer.  Do try not to touch them, as they are super sticky, of course.  This pack seems to be the best value, and they work well.  Recommended to anyone with windows and unwelcome flying insects.

The butane seems good, burns well in my Xikar, but the metal fill nozzle on these doesn't seal super well, vents a lot of gas while filling.  None of the adapters is a better fit, so I just try to line it up straight, but it always leaks more than cans with a plastic tip, it seems.  No big deal, especially as you can afford to vent a little bit if you've gotten a good deal on a case...

This is what it says on Uncle Bill's website: "Uncle Bill's Sliver Gripper is all about an American success story. We follow Uncle Bill's model of an American made quality tool that is still hand polished and hand sharpened just as Uncle Bill did 30 years ago."However, when I saw that my new tweezers were nothing like my old ones, I called to get the straight scoop.  The guy I talked to told me that twenty years ago, they completely changed how they were made.  They guy I spoke with told me that the tweezers would cost "forty bucks each" if they were still made the old way.The old ones had really sweet precise points.  These don't.  These are cheaply stamped, poorly finished where it counts, at the tip.  They don't work anything like the old ones, unless and until you put a bevel and a point on them.They can't simultaneously claim that these are made the old way, and also say that they'd cost $40 each if they were. I don't appreciate the cheapening of a beloved survival tool, nor being lied to about it.I am keeping these under protest, and putting a point and an edge on them myself, which will certainly take me a couple of hours, thus raising the cost of these tweezers to forty bucks a piece, in terms of my time...So buy these if you must.  The guy claimed they hadn't made the metal thinner over the years, but I would almost swear that my old pair was stiffer and less susceptible to sideways deflection.  Whatever.  Like so many things, these just ain't what they used to be.  I would have much preferred that they maintain quality and raise prices as necessary, instead of cheaping out.

Used to be awesome.  Not anymore.  They barely resemble the great product they were, as God is in the details, and Elvis has left the building...I called, and talked to some goomba with a bad attitude who first told me that they couldn't make them like they used to or it would cost "forty bucks each".  Then, when I said they'd cheaped out with mass production and lost all quality control, Rocky said I had it all wrong, lots of meticulous time and labor went into each and every pair...  Can't have it both ways, genius.I call BS.  These used to be great, they are not anymore.  Buy them if you must but be prepared to spend some time with files, stones, etc, if you want a pair anything like the days of old.I'd prefer they raise prices rather than destroy quality.  The old ones worked like magic.  These didn't work until I worked on them a LOT to get something like a "pin point" tip.  My old lost pair was awesome out of the box; these need major work, to work.Also, the little lines on the inside have vanished.  The clown I talked to on the phone insisted they are still there.  They ain't.These will be my last purchase, unless I can somehow find a vintage set.  Sad.  These are more like blanks than a finished product now.Ah, capitalism.  You are the death of quality, and you'll be the death of us all.  You killed Uncle Bill's quality.Cue Taps....

No, no, no.  They didn't just cheapen and ruin a perfect tool.  No, they didn't ruin these tweezers.Yes, they did.  These new ones are worthless, nothing like the quality tweezers they used to be.  Of all the horrible things capitalism has done lately, this one in particular really angers me.These suck.  Stamped, not ground, and thinner, weak.  Horrible, tragic.

XLNT.  I'm really impressed with the PII Pro.  It's the brightest light of this size I've tried, and it throws a nice beam, hot in the center but with some spread, amazing and very useful output for such a tiny thing.I just gave up on another brand with a switch that just wouldn't stay off, and was thus too annoying to carry.  This one is perfect for the key 'biner.  This has a quality look and feel, easily worth the extra bucks over cheap generic versions for carry.  Nothing sucks like needing light and lacking it; carry at least one quality light at all times.  I got a bunch of the little cheapies to scatter around in cars and toolbags and such, but it makes sense to carry a good one.I'll post an update if it ever fails or does anything wrong, but so far the PII Pro seems pretty ideal.As others have said, it ships in demo mode, which turns off automatically after a few seconds to save battery.  You have to hold down the button for twenty seconds, till the light turns off, to get it out of demo mode, if you want to be able to actually use it.  It's just tragic that some reviewers here couldn't figure that out without so much needless suffering.  RTFM, kids.There's absolutely no function to this light but off/on; no strobe, dimmer, and no ability to do Morse code, because of the electronic switch.  The instructions are: Press button for On/Off.  That's it.  That's fine with me; I don't know any Morse code apart from SOS anyway...  I sort of assumed that because this light has a microprocessor, it would know some tricks or dim or something, but nope.  It's a small, bright white light, with a demo mode.  Period.It also comes with a little plastic holder "docking station" strung on a garrotte, I mean a thin cord.  Not something I'd wear around my neck, but whatever, it's an option.  You can store the light clipped to it one way for access, the other way to prevent the switch from being hit.Good gear, get at least one!
The case does actually seem to be stainless.  The blades, unfortunately, are not.  Stainless feeler gauge for $6?  Nope.  I'm going to Eastern Gage for a real one...

Description says it's for granite, so I bought it.  On the blade label, it says it's only for softer stone and you need a better blade for harder material like granite.  Maybe I'll try it anyway, but it's irritating that they aren't more clear about what it's for.  I guess this is the cheapest diamond blade QEP makes, and it may work fine, they just want you to buy a more expensive one...  I'll post back if I keep it, and try it out...Edit- Kept it, cuts pretty well even in thick granite.  I'm trying to cut thick countertop material, which isn't what this blade or my HF tile saw are really for, but it does okay on straight cuts.  Bevels, not so much, but I think that's the saw's fault, not the blade.  For the price, give it a shot, should work fine on most stone.

These are cheap.  I got three pieces of pretty hard white bone, that look okay for a saddle.  Two pieces of translucent and much softer material, that don't look good.  All the pieces are right at 75mm, but all are undersized a millimeter or two otherwise; more like 75 x 11 x 5mm, fyi.  Cheap, yes.  Worth it?  Buffalo?  Who knows?

Perhaps quality has dropped lately, as it sounds like others got useful material.  Me, not so much.  I received a one-pound bag of bone chips numbering forty, not sixty plus- just noticed that the listing descriptions don't agree on whether this is supposed to be 40 or 60.  Seeing as only six of the pieces were long enough to possibly get a 2-7/8" saddle out of, and they're all thin, I don't think sixty real bone saddle blanks would weigh just one pound...  Anyway, nothing in here that could be a nut, all too thin.  Bunch of awkward shapes, and all super stinky, coated with something waxy; these would need to be boiled and prepped and cleaned before use.  I should take a pic of what I got; bears little resemblance to the product photo.Not impressive as guitar components, and too expensive for scrap bone chips, which is what these are.I am going to spend some quality time with a bison femur and a bandsaw and make my own blanks.  I am also going to return this silly bag-o-bones, or exchange it for actual saddle blanks, if MyGANN has some stashed away in the back room...Update:  I contacted MyGANN and explained that these wouldn't work for my purposes, the advertised purposes of making saddles and nuts for guitars.  Since the item was not at all as described, I asked the seller to pay return shipping.  Here is the response:"We don't give return pre-paid label since there is nothing wrong with your order. It is natural bone material. Anyway, it look like you're happy with it. Just keep these and we will give you full refund back." -MaryDelightful.  I did obtain a refund, thanks to Amazon.  I am out the shipping cost, which in this case is more than the value of the material.  Lesson learned.  I won't buy from this seller again, and I'll look into making my own bone blanks...  If you want it done right, DIY!

Cheap compared to the $200 tungsten pliers, which I may have to buy after all, because these aren't working for me.  The jaws on these were a bit laterally misaligned, and when I tried to clip a small safety pin, the "tungsten" edge promptly dented, which I have never seen tungsten do...Maybe I'll try another pair, hope they're better...The seller wants to stick me with return shipping, and Amazon doesn't want to print my review.  Don't buy these.  Hope I can get a good pair, but I am not optimistic.

Nice, attractive, simple, modern, pretty cool itty bitty trash can.  I'm not sure what it's best suited for, because once you put a napkin or two in it, the lid gets stuck, can't really move, as is illustrated nicely by the product photo.  It's pretty small, and the lid could be finished a bit nicer; it's sharp edged and rather roughly stamped, could have been thicker and nicer metal.  A modder could stick some Sculpey or something inside the lid to give it heft and inertia/momentum, and deaden the ping, if one wanted to obsess and take the mini trashcan to the next level, which would be ridiculous, but I may just do it...  Being as this thing is stainless, it's a good value if you need a little tabletop, bedside, desktop, or elsewhere trash can, especially if you make small and frequent bits of trash for whatever reason, as I so often do for so many reasons.  Remember:  Cleanliness is next to Godliness, but OCD is just a disease...  :)  My mini can has a big vertical scratch on the top part, unfortunately.  If I cared, I'd return it, but I'm going to beat this thing up anyway, scratch it, dent it, so I don't mind.  I'm in it for the long haul, hence the stainless.

A stout little whisk broom, sturdy and built for business.  Nice metal fittings, thick stitching, looks like it'll do the job and last a while.  What more could you want in a classic whisk broom?  I will post back in a year, or a decade, with a durability report.Four stars because nothing is perfect- my example has a few crooked brown strands, is a bit less photogenic than the one shown- plus I'm having relationship problems, which I am taking out on this innocent whisk broom by unfairly deducting a star.  Life is hard for me, you, all of us.  Why should it be any different for a broom?  I didn't get any breaks.  Let somebody else give this thing five stars, I'm not doing charity work here...

Got two, the first one was open, dirty, used, and cracked.  The second one was brand new, in a sealed box, and still cracked.  There's a hairline crack at every single hole, and a couple elsewhere, too, all over the black base piece.  How or why this is acceptable to Dremel, I have no idea.  I guess I'll keep the thing, because I need it immediately, and it does work, but I do believe I'll make my own mounting table with metal hardware and a non-plastic chassis, maybe corian or laminate or tough plastic or something.I'll update on the progress of these cracks and when/if this thing fails.  Plus, I'll look into a good glue for cracks in ABS.  ABS plumbing cement or something...  Seems like I always have to work on my tools before I can do work with them, and it seems like things in general are getting exponentially cheaper but ever more expensive...  Meh.  If I had it to do over, I might just save the $30 and make my own, but I am lazier than I am thrifty, so it stays.  One last complaint, though- it's allegedly made so that you can inset it into the underside of your work surface, and they show a cutout shape you could use, but it neglects the "Dremel" badge at the front.  That should have been vertical or horizontal, but not set at the pointless 45* it is, which gets in the way if you want to inset the thing.  I guess you could always Dremel off the Dremel badge...  I think I'll make up a handmade high-quality version of this in metal and sell it on Etsy.  Wonder if Amazon allows such talk?  If you read this, they do!Contacted Dremel.  At first, I was completely blown off.  Then I was insulted and lied to.  Then I was sent yet another one.  Will it be any better than the first two?  I'll update when it gets here.  For now, I am shocked and appalled at the blatant lies the rep told me.  Between the "quality" of this piece and the rep, I am having serious doubts about the Dremel organization.  Perhaps I'll move up to Foredom before I spend any more money on Dremel.  Hmm.Third one got here.  It's cracked, too.  I give up.  Saving my pennies for better gear.  New stuff that's cracked just doesn't cut it for me.

Nice, pretty thick, well finished, well formed, straight, even and proper.  It's hard to tell with pics how burly or well made something is, but these look and feel nice in person, no issues.  I haven't installed them yet, so I don't know about durability, but the finish looks and feels tough and solid, nice powdercoat.  I'm sure it will scratch off if you scrape them on concrete, but c'est la vie...  I guess I'll rout my cabinet edges to match this (.50") radius, and it should be slicker 'n snake snot on a brass doorknob.  If you want sharp edges, they make another style for that, but I'm more of a rounded-off edges guy, so I like these.
We didn't care for it.  Too thick and fat, not soft enough.  If you're looking for a beefy pillow, this might suit.

Like everyone else, I think the switch blows.  I tried keeping this thing on my key 'biner, which hangs on my belt loop.  The light is always on, always flashing and sending unintelligible Morse code...  When you sit or recline, it always manages to turn on.  I'm always jamming the switch back to "off" where it won't stay.  I often find the light stuck on, of its own accord.  Lame, frustrating, no good for wearing on your person.It's a decent light, adequately bright, and it's good for stashing various places, but not for carry, IMO.  I'm ordering an LRI PII Pro to carry; hopefully the smart switch will eliminate this sort of thing.

We shall see how useful this thing actually is...  So far, I noticed it doesn't fit on some of my bass tuning keys, so I'll take a Dremel to it and relieve it a bit.  It's also a bit fat to fit in between tightly spaced tuners without bumping the adjacent ones.  But for rapidly restringing a guitar with slow tuners, this speeds things up nicely.  Just be sure you don't go the wrong way and snap your string; I'm sure it's been done...

Garbage; suede came unglued and fell off after one minute of use.  Disappointing.  Replacement was no better.  If you actually intend to use this much, or at all, I'd look at a different one.  In the picture it looks substantial, but is pretty dinky IRL.  Claims to be Tibetan, has large "Made in India" sticker...

Works great, looks fine.  Just the thing for turning the speaker jack on the laptop so the cable doesn't poke straight out the side, awkwardly, when using headphones or external speakers.  My adapter thingy's metal bits are goldtone instead of silver as pictured, which is fine with me because it matches my cable.  I got this thing sent to me from halfway around the world for less than it would cost me to send a small package to the next state.
