Mostly set in the modern day, predominately New York City, the little touches and details the author integrates in the story are likely to resonate with fans of the art world and opera, yet I'm neither and still found much to enjoy.Beyond being an excellent story with some hot sex scenes, for those who like that, a clever and entertaining take on the vampire myth, and a love story, for those who look beyond the surface there is more. What does it mean to be human? Are some of the Earth's creatures more important than others? (Put another way, if it is okay for us humans to kill "lower" animals for nourishment, would the same logic justify "higher" creatures killing us for the same reason?) If you could live forever, would that be a good thing and what would you be willing to give up to do so? Marie grappled with all of these questions. After you read Blood Diva, maybe your answers will be the same. Or maybe not.**Originally written for "Books and Pals" book blog. May have received a free review copy. **

The world Melody Curtiss imagined for the setting of this book is unique. The story is post-apocalyptic, yet unlike many books with that premise, the world isn’t lacking in technology or modern conveniences. At least not completely. Instead the area where the story takes place (what was formerly the North Western US) has areas that are settled, with all the things we have today and then some, and unsettled areas that don’t. The problem is, those more appealing areas also have laws that limit freedom, especially for women. It is essentially a dystopian world. Fighting against this system can have severe repercussions.The author describes the book as “feminist science fiction,” which is also an applicable label, as most of the significant characters are females, fighting to increase their rights in various ways. The protagonist is Sarah Rosen, a young feisty rebel. Will she be able to make a difference? I enjoyed finding the answer to that question, never sure how it was going to work out, but eager to see.**Originally written for "Books and Pals" book blog. May have received a free review copy. **

The travel memoir or narrative has long been one of my favorite non-fiction genres. Part of that is the obvious. I love to travel and since being on the road all the time isn’t feasible, experiencing new places and things vicariously is an alternative. But it’s more than that. A good guidebook or the right internet site can take you to the same places. Besides that, the way you experience a place will be different than how anyone else does. (In fact, in some instances I’ll have been to some of the places myself and the vicarious experience is replaced by comparing notes, which was true for much of this book for me.)Books like this, what I describe as a travel adventure or quest, with a specific, usually difficult goal involved (in this case, riding a bike on roads and trails that roughly follow the Continental Divide of North America from well into Canada to the Mexican border) are also entertaining and interesting to me for other reasons. Getting a feel for the logistics of such an undertaking satisfies the curiosity of my more analytical side as does the problem solving involved when unanticipated problems come up.However, there is a third item that I find essential for a travel memoir if it is to hit the highest mark for me, putting the journey chronicled in the story into a bigger perspective. What did this experience teach the author about life, the world, and his or her place in it? It’s this area where The Divide excelled. In between the day to day adventure and problem solving, Doneen considers his life thus far and where he wants it to go from there, not unlike a coming-of-age adventure novel. But even better, it’s true.**Originally written for "Books and Pals" book blog. May have received a free review copy. **

Xavier, the brother of the protagonist David, is the stereotypical computer nerd. He’s socially awkward and sometimes too logical by normal standards. I’m afraid I saw a bit of myself in Xavier at times. :) I even thought uCupid, his phone app to match people with their “soul mate,” wherever they might be, sounded like a great idea. The right data, analyzed the right way, can solve any problem, right? I’d sure like to think so.Of course, where Xavier (and I) fall short in our theory is that the typical human isn’t as logical as Mr Spock would like us to be. Human emotions and, yes, love is largely about emotions, aren’t always so logical. Love isn’t free … is funny, dark and thought provoking, with explorations of themes involving family, our obsession with (and sometimes over reliance on) technology, and yes, even love.**Originally written for "Books and Pals" book blog. May have received a free review copy. **

Little Mouse is an interesting, thought-provoking read. The perspective of a Jewish family experiencing the horror of the rise of Nazi Germany, trying to make sense of what was happening and how to react, drew me in quickly. What they did and the sacrifices they made to survive by fleeing the country make up the first part of the book and setup the overall premise.However, once they escape and have begun to rebuild their life in Scotland, the war ends, and something happens that once again puts all they have built at risk. What they decide to do and how they accomplish it is the meat of the story. The decision of what to do was predictable, if not clichéd. However, I did find the moral dilemmas they faced in coming to their decision thought provoking and was pulling for them to succeed.**Originally written for "Books and Pals" book blog. May have received a free review copy. **

I drafted The Princess, my eleven year-old granddaughter, to read this book and give me a kid’s perspective to add to my own in writing this review. The Princess gave it high marks (a letter grade of A+) with the comment that she really liked it. She described it as having “a lot of fantasy” and a “moral about luck.”I concur. It’s a fun read that should hit the sweet spot for its target audience (ages 7-10) with a lesson to be learned (I’d describe it as “be careful what you wish for”), that comes through clearly, yet doesn’t overshadow the fun of the story.**Originally written for "Books and Pals" book blog. May have received a free review copy. **

I will give Grace Burrowes credit for creating a male character who is very unusual in Regency Era literature and I will also give her credit for improving my vocabulary as there is some terminology used in this novel with which I was wholly unfamiliar.Unfortunately, I had some issues with choices that the author made in developing the characters.  I couldn't help but feel that Darius' choices didn't have to be as foregone as he made them.  I also struggled with the situation that brought Darius and Vivian together.  While the author is given credit for originality, the plotting just didn't come off as believable as I would have liked.Bottom line: I read Book 9:David first in this series.  It was quite good and was the catalyst for my purchase of the first book in the series.  I'm sorry to say that this book could not equal it.

I came late to this series and read book 9: David first.  I won't repeat my review of that book here, but I found it to be well written and plotted with characters interacting in believable situations and facing realistic problems.  I wish I could say the same about book 2: Nicholas.Unfortunately, Nick was just weak and rather ridiculous when considering the resolution to the BIG PROBLEM that kept him from consummating his marriage to the heroine, Leah.  Her character was much more sympathetic and believable.  Leah's treatment by her father was horrendous and made me really feel for her.  Nicholas' character was just annoying.The writing didn't flow as well, the plot just seemed padded and Nick's real relationship to the secondary character of Leonie could be seen a mile away.  Overall the Lonely Lords series has been very good.  Unfortunately, Book 2 was a huge disappointment.

Regency era romances, most romances in fact, follow a formula which goes something like this: handsome hero meets beautiful heroine, attraction occurs, but one or both of them is haunted by events in their past. Problems, exacerbated by often dubious misunderstandings, drive a wedge between them, one or the other of them is hurt/endangered, the H/h comes to the rescue, problems are solved, declarations are made and all's well that ends well for a final, romantic HEA.  Those elements, with the exception of the aforementioned dubious misunderstandings, are present in 'David: Lord of Honor.'So, what sets 'David' apart and earns it five stars from me?The short answer is the quality of the writing. The longer answer is the complexity of characterization.  The writing is very good in that it flows smoothly, balances engaging character dialog with the characters' internal musings that actually move the story along without being a rehash of what's already been said out loud.  The language used feels correct to the period and the plot, while not complex, is engaging.  For at least 60% of the novel, the reader is left to wonder if the H/h will actually be able to work out their problems.As to characterization, the reader comes to know Letty and David  at a fairly deep level.  Both are believably human, both have experienced believable sorrow and regret in their past lives that has shaped who they are when they meet  and both struggle believably, with their relationship.  Do you notice a theme here?Ms. Burrowes has done what so many authors can't or are unwilling to take the time to do: she has made the manners, mores and social strictures of the Regency Era an important CHARACTER in this story, but has done it in a very unusual way by putting the characters in a setting that is the antithesis of Regency Era propriety.  As a result, the social/moral conflict in this story feels real to the era and because of that the angst it produces also feels real and made this reader's heart hurt more than just a little throughout.Given her circumstances, Letty is understandably hard, but not calculating.  Given his upbringing and past experiences, David is understandably weary and heart sore, but not weak.  The secondary characters rise above window dressing to serve real purpose in enhancing reader knowledge of the main characters and help move the story along.Because I came to care deeply about these characters, I found the sex scenes to be some of the best I've read in this genre.  The first are achingly tender and beautifully described without being anatomically graphic.  As later intimate scenes occur, they become infused with a sense of near desperation as the obstacles between these two, especially those on Letty's side, rise to the near insurmountable.  The sex scenes do as much as the dialog to set feeling of growing despair and inevitable separation between these two.Is this novel perfect?  No.  David comes off just a shade too understanding and Letty just a bit too self-sacrificing but neither excess is so great that it will get in the way of rooting for them to be together. Also, I would have also preferred that the 'villain' of this piece have been more present through dialogue than being mostly just talked about. Finally, the act of violence that threatened Letty felt a bit contrived.  These are things I noticed as I read, but they didn't interfere greatly with my pleasure in the reading.Bottom line: There is a fair amount of angst in this story, but I found it believable and very, very satisfying.  I'll be reading more of Ms. Burrowes' writing.

What I believe this author intended was something along the lines of the old Claudette Colbert/Clark Gable 'screwball' comedy, It Happened One Night.  Unfortunately, what should have been sprightly dialogue and humorous misunderstandings was little more than annoying prattling and plodding, repetitive action.  The heroine, Felicia, acts closer to 15 than nearly 21, the hero, Glen, Duke of Somerset, comes off as a Sir Galahad, solving all the heroine's problems while being simultaneously dim when finally being told the truth of Felicia's present circumstances.  The secondary characters are okay, but mainly function as window dressing.  A very contrived plot element involving kidnapping was included for no apparent reason than to introduce a new character into the story as it certainly didn't add any tension.If you are a fan of a Regency Era romances and have some care that the manners and mores' of the period be represented accurately, then you will likely be disappointed in Madcap Miss.  Forms of address are too casual the attention to the era's proprieties is very uneven.  To her credit, the author is fairly consistent with language, both of the upper classes/aristocracy as well as the patois of the working class. As far as the writing is concerned, the author struggles with continuity and phrasing (e.g. "He noted an odd look in her tone.).Bottom line: "Madcap Miss" is a bit of a monstrous mess.  I did finish it, but can't recommend it when there are much better written and plotted Regency romances out there.

Fictional characters are woven into well-researched historical events to provide a story with good characterization, excellent setting and period description and gripping action.  Notorious Angel kept me interested from first to last even though I though the pacing bogged down from time to time.So why didn't I give it five stars?As another reviewer mentioned in her very well written reaction to the book, the heroine, Eleanora is held captive and raped by the hero, Grant, very early in the novel and that this kind of event was a familiar trope of 70s-80s romantic literature.  However, this sexual encounter isn't the highly romanticized  "shy, reluctant-woman-resists-strong-domineering-male-when-she-really-loves-him"encounter.  They are virtually strangers, she's a virgin and it's just plain rape, ladies and gentlemen...rape.  He justifies his actions because she'd been traveling alone and keeping casual company with a prostitute.  Permission to rape by association,if you will.Yes, I know that women were considered little more than intelligent cattle during the period of this novel (1850s) and that women of that era, conditioned to the dominant preeminence of men, may not have had quite the same reaction as a woman today might.  That said, Eleanora's reaction to the rape still troubled me.  She seemed to 'get over it' too quickly on her way to falling in love with Grant.  It never seemed to be an issue between them and was never mentioned again until later in the novel when a Grant asks her if she betrayed him because of "what he did." Honestly there were many occasions of ill treatment on his part that it's hard to know if he was referring to the rape in that circumstance.Bottom line: the book is well written, the history is fascinating, and the plotting is gripping.  I just couldn't connect with either Eleanora or a Grant and I just wish the whole rape sequence had been left out or treated differently.

The heroine, Penelope, spent too much time wringing her hands about how she didn't 'fit in' to the ton and how much she wanted to go back to the country and her botanical studies.  I found her unbearably whiney. She never did find her spine with her aunt, who treated her abominably, or Drake, the so-called hero of this piece.Drake was basically a twat.  He would acknowledge his 'twat-ness,' straighten up for about 3 or 4 pages, then go back to being a twat.  If I read one more time how he needed the 'perfect duchess,' I thought I would scream, especially considering the reason he wanted said duchess.  A secondary character in the form of Lady Daphne started out as a good rival to Penelope for Drake's attentions, but then she just fades away.Bottom line: The characterization is shallow, the main conflict is shallower, the 'chemistry' between Penelope and Drake is shallower still.  The author phoned this one in.

There are many things to like about this book.  The dialog is often funny, both main characters, Abby and Kipp are likable, the secondary characters, especially Brady, Kipp's best friend and Abby's co-conspirator are fun and funny, and the plot is reasonably believable.  The ending was satisfying once you got past one relatively inane complication on Abby's part.  That is sufficient good news to allow me to give a measured recommendation.The bad news is that the editing is poor and the author has continuity issues.  There were enough poor and unintended word choices, suddenly appearing characters and misplaced dialog to distract from the reading.  Kasey MIchaels, according to her own end notes is the author of 110 books.  I don't know where this novel falls in her writing career but there really is no excuse for the kind of errors littering this book.  I suppose that some of it might be attributed to the conversion of the print version, originally published in 2001, to the digital version published in 2014.  Either way, be warned that you may find the errors and omissions distracting.

A pleasant, sweet-to-the-point-of-being-saccharine story of an arranged marriage between a baker and a chef in the Old West.  There is no emotional depth, no tension and no real challenge in the reading.  It's a bit like literary cotton candy: fun to read, but devoid of anything that will make you remember it an hour after you've finished it.

Shallow character development, slow pacing, and poor editing are all wrapped up in a prosaic 'the prince and a commoner' storyline with liberal doses of not-very-hot sex.That's my one line review of this novel.  I stopped at the 60% mark because I got tired of reading essentially the same basic dialog over and over again.  Both the writing and the plot are amateurish with characters who range from juvenile (Clara) to unlikable (most every other character).The hero is deeply troubled and wears a t-shirt to bed (sound familiar?).  He makes frequent references to 'control,' BDSM and how 'dangerous' he is.  The danger comes in the form of violent nightmares and The mention of BDSM were mostly silly references to spanking.  I think the author meant this to be a way to build tension but for me, it just became annoying.Probably the most aggravating aspect of this novel is that the story's  Prince is a son of the British Royal Family.  There's a danger in that because this reader's natural tendency is to think of the real Royal Family.  That being the case, much of the action and dialog (what there is of it) comes off as unbelievable.Bottom line: this novel aspires to be a 50 Shades with its hints st BDSM.  It isn't.

The first 60%: Bitchy, spinsterish woman writes a pamphlet critical of the profligate ways of the local rake.  He shows up to see who she is and  verbal sparing ensues.  Bear in mind that this is the same rake who won her family home in a card game and who she wants to loan her money to return it to profitability.The next 20%: Allusions to a BIG SECRET in the woman's past stand between the developing relationship between the spinster and the rake.  She wants him, he wants her, but she's afraid he will hate her once he learns the BIG SECRET.The last 20%: The BIG SECRET is revealed and you must be prepared to totally suspend belief to make it work.  There were so many illogical elements to this entire story that I just couldn't suspend belief enough to care how it ultimately ended.Bottom line: This was too much like a soap opera story line for me because of the often illogical actions and vacillations of the heroine.  The hero wasn't much better as he would often get fed up with the heroine, tell her off, storm off in a huff and then would come trouping back for more.  The pacing in the first part of the novel was incredibly slow and the BIG SECRET wasn't worth the effort and time it took to find out.  I just didn't find the characters or the conflicts very believable.

While reasonably well written, there is nothing original or very interesting about this book. Is's been a while since I read a vampire novel, but I remember all of the stock elements and they are all here: the devastatingly handsome alpha male vampire leader, the beautiful, strong, spunky, often poor decision-making human female, powerful sexual attraction between the two of them leading to copious amounts of sex, and the various elements of vampire lore that are stock-in-trade for novels in this genre.As for the supposed attraction between Raphael and Cyn (Cynthia), I didn't buy it.  It starts with her having vampire induced wet dreams and continues with what appears to be Raphael's mind control along with significant infusions of his blood.  This was a theme addressed in Charlaine Harris's Southern Vampire Mystery series and was an understandable source of doubt and distraction for that series' main character, Sookie Stackhouse.  Cyn is considerably more sophisticated and accomplished than Sookie, but for some reason, this doesn't appear to concern Cyn and don't think it's because she's any smarter than Sookie.Bottom line: Nothing new here. To the author's credit, the central conflict of the story is resolved in this book, but the relationship between Raphael and Cyn is left to the sequel.  I'm not interested enough to find out what that might turn out to be.

About fifty percent of this book is slow-moving and tedious especially since it is told from two perspectives, that of Olivia and True.  While the author does a better job than some with this double perspective, I still found it repetitive.  The best written parts were True's flashbacks to his abandonment and tumultuous fight for survival as a feral child essentially raised by animals.I never understood Olivia's passivity with regard to the members of her family who seemed to go out of their way to criticize and demean her. I know that women weren't as likely to speak up for themselves during this era, but her meekness seems extreme to me.  I really didn't understand the motivations for two of her three marriages and I didn't completely understand why she held herself apart from True quite as long as she did.  In short, Olivia's character didn't make a lot of sense to me.The pace last half of the book picks up with a couple of revelations and a little mystery.  I suppose what put me off was what felt like an abrupt ending.  As long as it took to develop the relationship between True and Olivia it was almost as if the author got tired of writing and wanted the book to just end.  I have to say that the suddenness of the ending and the unemotional nature of it left me flatly disappointed.Bottom line:  I liked the character of True, found Olivia fairly uninteresting and was left with a strong feeling of dissatisfaction when the story ended.

While still a good read, The Orphan Pearl did not reach of the same level of 'wonderfulness' as the two previous books in the series.  While the conflicts plaguing Caro and Adam in 'The Secret Heart,' and Sophie and Julian in 'The Lover's Knot' were believable, I struggled with the conflict at the center of this book.  I found that there wasn't much to attract me to the female protagonist, Lady Lily Spark. Lady Lily's disappearance and presumed death is at the heart of Adam's angst in The Secret Heart,  but she reappears to become the focus of this book along with the male protagonist, John Tacitus Ware.  Frankly, I found her spoiled with self-serving attitudes that were both annoying and dangerous.  I also felt that John Ware's character was not quite as well developed as were Adam and Julian in the previous two books.As wonderful as the first two were, this book just didn't have the same level of cohesivness as the first two and I found myself more conscious of the effort it took to read it than I did with the first two.  With those, the time flew by, with this one I was more willing to put it down.  The author does provide much more historical background in this book in the form of the beginnings of the ultimate collapse of the Ottoman Empire, but I didn't find that particularly instructive or interesting.Bottom line:  If you've read the first two books in this series, you need this one to round out some of the stories of the other characters, but you may find it is not quite as good as the previous two.  There is a fourth book coming that will tell the story of Lord Kingston, probably the most angst-ridden and, to this point, despicable of the continuing characters.  He has intrigued me and I look forward to reading more about him.

The first book in this series, The Secret Heart was excellent and met nearly every requirement I have for a fully realized, deeply engaging book.  It has a place on my keeper shelf.  So does the second book in the series, The Lover's Knot, the story of Julian and Sophie.Ms. Satie is a remarkable author who writes period romances with themes that resonate in the today's world.  There was more of a mystery in this book and the internal struggles of the heroine, Sophie, with regard to her relationship with Julian, would be instantly recognizable to many modern women today.  The hero, Julian is not above manipulating people to get what he wants, but I couldn't help liking him.  I also liked that the Earl of Kingston, an important secondary character in Secret Heart, showed up in this book, albeit briefly.I did feel that the plot meandered a bit more than necessary and the secondary characters weren't as fully fleshed out as in the first book.  However, they still served to add interest and texture to the plot.  There also wasn't quite the surprise twist to the mystery as there was in the first book.Bottom line: The few criticisms aside, this is a very good book.  The main characters are fully fleshed out, the plot conflicts are heartbreaking, the road that Julian and Sophie travel to find one another is long, arduous and very satisfying once the destination is reached.  Be advised that this author does not shy away from sex in her novels, but this is the first novel I've read in quite a while where the sex is integral to the H/h's relationship and not just something to titillate and sell novels.Final note: Even though each of the first two novels can stand alone, I recommend that you read the series in order.

When you belong to BookBub, free selections are often among the offerings.  I've certainly taken advantage of those 'freebies' often enough and have frequently been disappointed.  You get what you pay for, right?  I am so happy to say that this is not the case with "The Secret Heart," the first offering in the No Better Angels series by Erin Satie.Set in late Regency/pre-Victorian England, the story of Caro (Caroline) and Adam, Lord Bexley is one of the very best of this genre.  Too often, stories set in this period are fixated on the relationship between beautiful people who face some problem or obstacle that is too easily resolved in an unsurprising HEA.  In other words, most books in this genre follow a formula that grows old with repetition.  'Secret Heart' has many elements of that formula, but the deviations are noteworthy and create a story that is engaging, believable and thoroughly entertaining.More than anything else, this is a story of rebellion for both characters.  For Caro, the story highlights just how few choices most women had during this era had and just how much they were at the mercy of the men in their lives: fathers, brothers, husbands.  Because Caro is determined to not be a victim of her dissolute father and brothers, she often manipulates those around her. As a consequence, she is a substantial departure from the typical Regency era heroine.  You may not like her at times, but you  will likely understand why she acts the way she does.  She is one very focused and determined lady which makes her relationship with Adam one that was intended to solve the problems of her future, but instead becomes one that endangers her sense of self.  One of the most heartbreaking scenes I have ever read is when Caro realizes that in loving Adam, by allowing him to love her, she is giving up some of the control of her life that she has fought so hard to attain. She fears being 'owned and powerless.'  Without giving up too much of the story, the way that the author chooses to show her realization, in a moment that should have been euphoric, is at once chilling and heartbreaking.For Adam, his chains come in the form of his title and the expectations and disdain of his cold, controlling and autocratic father.  Adam would appear to have all of the advantages of title and position but because of past events he labors to break free of the strictures imposed by his position and his guilt.  I have to say that there were times that I did not care for him and found him weak.  It was because I felt that way about him but still found myself wanting him to find happiness that I knew that Ms. Satie is an author to watch.  The only criticism that I have of this novel is the major event that figures large into Adam's angst which is the disappearance and presumed death of his sister.  I never quite understood the assumption that she is dead but, given the time period,  I guess that would have been the conclusion that most would have drawn given that she was never found.The most original aspect of this novel is the direction of Caro's and Adam's respective rebellion.  As a gentlewoman, Caro's choice of ballet and Adam's choice of boxing as the tangible expressions of their rebellion stands out as notable exceptions to the traditional formulaic historical romance.  Because both characters see themselves at the mercy of their circumstances, their avocations become the one thing that they can control.  The author's descriptions of Caro's seeming automatic lapse into the essential ballet positions when stressed and Adam's immersion into the violence of boxing as a release for his considerable frustrations are, at once, beautiful and compelling.Secondary characters are well developed and interesting.  Daphne, Adam's cousin and Caro's friend is a quiet, but strong voice of reason for these two and would make and interesting character for a book of her own.  The Duke of Hastings, Adam's father, doesn't make an appearance until late i the novel, but he is frightening in the depth of his efforts to manipulate the course of his son's life.  The depths to which he goes to bring his son to heel have tragic consequences.  Lord Kingsley and Adam have a complicated past that is only partially revealed near the end of the novel, but I think I'll probably see more of him in subsequent novels.  Giselle, a professional ballerina who became mistress to Caro's father and served as governess to Caro was one of the architects of Caro's attitudes toward life.  Each of the secondary characters is interesting in their own right and make for richly textured story.Bottom line: There is nothing 'fluffy' about this book; there is very little flirtatious banter and no extensive description of clothing, balls or homes.  What you get instead, is a beautifully told story of two people who seek to be in charge of their own lives.  In order for me to become really immersed in a book, I have to believe in the characters and the situations in which they find themselves. These characters felt believably human to me and I rooted for their HEA.

It just moved too slow for my taste and felt that the plot was unnecessarily padded.  The heroine is beautiful, the hero is manly, the villain is villainous.  I felt that Fiona was unnecessarily bullheaded from time to time.  Even though Alec explained the error of her thinking with regard to the identify of her mother's killer, she persisted in thinking it was someone else.  She was wrong.The writing is fair but, even though I finished it, I just couldn't get engaged with the story.

I thoroughly dislike stupid heroines and Cele, the female protagonist is just that.  I get that she was hurt by a man in the past but when she continually makes critical decisions based upon that I can help but dislike her.  It makes me want to shout, "open your eyes, grow up, move on." Why the hero, Dahleven continued to stick with her and make excuses for her,  I'll never understand.  It's one thing to be stupid for a time but to persist in it the way Cele did tried my patience.  There are few books the get the dreaded DNF, but this one did at the 90% mark because I simply didn't care how the author wrapped it up.As for the writing, it's adequate, at best.  Since this is a work of fantasy, it's incumbent on the author to do some world building.  She does that but I didn't feel especially drawn to this world.  The pacing was plodding and there were too many mental 'asides' by the characters.  I give the author credit for effort in originality.  Unfortunately that was over shadowed by a dull plot.  There was only one character that I liked and that was Sorn, but he died fairly early in the story.  Lucky guy.Bottom line: At best, the book is boring, at worst, it's annoying.  I cannot recommend it.

Though 'His Wicked Reputation' starts a bit slow it builds to a decent, if abrupt ending.  I suppose that since this is the first book in the Wicked Trilogy, the author did not feel compelled to tie up certain loose ends like who killed the oldest brother, whether or not all the missing art work was found and whether or not Eva, the heroine, will face legal consequences for art forgery.  All that said, the H/h of this story do have enough of a HEA that you may find yourself on the fence about buying the next book in the series.Be advised that the sensuality rating on this book would run about a seven on a scale of ten.  While I don't mind sex in the books I read, I prefer it to be a bit more 'organic' as they say these days...a natural consequence of building sexual tension.  There was one time in particular that the sex felt more crude than romantic which is a substantial turn off for me.Bottom line: this book is not bad, but neither is it great.  The jury is out as to my decision on buying the next in the series.

Trite dialog, alternating POVs between first person to third person, use of present tense In 3rd person...all of these are things I can overlook or adapt to if the characterization is good and the story interesting.  Unfortunately that was not the case in 'Geoducks.'The two main protagonists are uninteresting, the female secondary character does nothing but try to push her best friend in to having sex with the neighbor, the old boyfriend...whoever she can think of.  I found myself very easily distracted while trying to plow through this book and putting it down often.  I finally threw in the towel at the 25% mark.Honestly, I couldn't find anything to like about this book.  It was boring, trivial and entirely forgettable. Thank goodness it was free.

It was free and described as funny, so I 'one-clicked' it as the author describes e-book purchases.  That's the good news.While the author's premise offered promise and was the primary inducement for selecting this book, I found that I didn't care for the writing.  Both the dialogue and the main character's internal musings are meant to be breezy and witty but I found them juvenile and dull. What humor is to be found is cloaked in liberal use of the 'F' word.  Understand that it is not the word that I have issues with, it's that its too frequent use points to a general lack of sophistication in the writing.Bottom line: The negative reviews are right about this one: promising premise, poor execution.  For me, this isn't even a very entertaining beach read.

Like Ms. Long's first book in the Pennyroyal Green series, 'Like No Other Lover' is a solid, absorbing, well-written entry.  The two main characters are well developed and their complicating situations are believable.  I did feel that the HEA was a little too neat and it felt a bit rushed.Bottom line: Ms. Long's series is worth the money to acquire it and the time to read.

And that is because Ms. Bennet's  basic storyline doesn't seem to vary.  In the two books of hers that I've read, the male protagonist is emotionally damaged but is ultimately saved and redeemed by the love of a strong woman.  If the surrounding details of the plot were more interesting it might be bearable but, alas, that is not the case.  They are entirely predictable.As far as her writing style is concerned, I'll levy the same complaint that I levied in my VERY critical review of the first book of hers that I read which was 'Alex: A Cold Fury HockeyNovel.'  As in that book, each chapter is an alternating POV between the male and female protagonist.  I really dislike this device because I find it amateurish and distracting.  Many fan fiction authors who write for free can do better than that.You may be wondering why I would choose to purchase and read the work of an author whose work I so roundly criticized.  Since I read a great deal I sometimes forget authors I've read before.  I was sucked into 'Make it a Double' by the synopsis and the number of 4-5 star reviews.  While I'll say I liked the characters in 'Double' better than 'Alex,' this will be the last of her books that I read.  Even if there is a new Bennet book published tomorrow I'm pretty sure I will have already read it.

So many Regency Era romances follow a tried and true, if hackneyed, formula.  The Perils of Pleasure is anything but typical or formulaic.  It is a deep breath of fresh air in a genre burdened with over sexualized tripe.The male protagonist, Colin is a young London rake making his march  to the gallows for a crime he didn't commit.  Fortunately he is saved quite dramatically by Madeleine, a woman hired to choreograph his rescue.  The successful rescue sets off a series of adventures, discoveries and resolutions that are surprising, intriguing, inventive and original.Apart from a few formatting errors, this is one of the best stories in this genre I've read in a long, long time.  There is humor, intrigue and great poignancy.  The main characters are likable and sympathetic as they grow and develop throughout the story. The intrigue is well developed and unpredictable and the plot twist at the end was truly surprising.  The ultimate resolution for our two main characters was by no means assured but was ultimately, deeply satisfying.Be advised: there are two fairly graphic sex scenes between the two main characters, but rather than being gratuitous sexual interludes, I felt them to be a natural element in their developing relationship.  In my opinion, the scenes were not included to heighten prurient interest but to show character and relationship development and as such are some of the best I've read.Bottom line:  If this is a sample of Ms. Long's prowess as a writer, I will happily read more of her work.  Well done, Ms. Long, very well done.

Honestly, I can't say that 'When Lightening Strikes' is terrible, but neither can I say it's great.  I've really have thought hard about why I had such a 'meh' response to this story.  The only conclusion that I have some to is that I felt like I was being 'told' about this couple and their trials and tribulations rather than being engaged with them as the story went along.  It was kind of like being introduced to someone who is perfectly likable, but who does not inspire you to seek further acquaintance.  I guess I'm just not terribly interested in reading more in the Whiskey Creek series.

The Madness of Viscount Atherbourne contains all the necessary ingredients for a satisfying romance: a dashing, devastatingly handsome but tortured male protagonist, a beautiful, kind and loving female protagonist, a revenge plot, a not too surprising plot twist, good character development, and a hard fought for HEA.  Some authors take these elements and create a really good story that clips along and others, with all those same elements create drudgery.  I am happy to report that Ms. Braden's efforts fall into the former rather than the later.For me, the characters' actions need to have some logic behind them, the plot complications need to feel believable, the characters need to develop and grow over the course of the story and the ending needs to make sense.  Happily, this story and its characters make sense, is well written and absorbing and the ending made me cry.  One of the highlights of this book is the character development, especially that of the the hero, Lord Lucien Atherbourne.  The cause of his tortured angst is completely justified even if his method of revenge seemed a little far fetched. However, I felt that the characterization of the heroine, Victoria, was a bit weaker.  It took her a little too long to to find her spine, but not so long that I lost patience with her as I so often do in romance novels.  There are some interesting secondary characters who make significant contributions to the story.  I especially liked the Greek chorus like comments of  Lady Wallingham found in the chapter headings.  They were pithy, humorous and set a slightly more sophisticated tone than what is often found in Regency Era romance novels.Bottom line:  You may find that this story drags a bit through the first half, that Victoria shouldn't have been surprised as she was at the depth of Lucien's commitment to revenge, and that she gives in a shade too often to sexual attraction when she shouldn't, but you will also find that this is a very well written book.  I'm pretty sure that you'll care about the characters and you'll be invested in their achieving a happy ending.  In short, it's worth your time and your money.  Now I'm off to get the second book in the series.

Misunderstandings and deception, well meaning or otherwise, are the stock and trade of romance novels.  Used effectively they create delicious tension that ultimately ends in a satisfying HEA.  Used gratuitously as they were in Christian's and Jessie's story and you get a boring, repetitive story that is a test of this reader's will to finish.The premise that was used to set up the meeting of Christian and Jessie was far-fetched and unbelievable.  Their constant on-again/off-again relationship was trying and went on entirely too long before the inevitable HEA.  Both characters are hypersensitive and very quick to misinterpret each other's actions which leads them to cycle through attraction/lust/loathing/despair and tears so often that I became impatient with the characters and the story.Bottom line: there is no depth to this story and I didn't feel compelled to wade through Cutter's story which is also contained in this edition.

My Lady of Deception: a weak 3 stars.  The story began well with an interesting premise and good pacing.  Unfortunately, about 40% of the way in, with the first major conflict resolution, the story devolved into an overblown melodrama of guiltily kept secrets and handwringing angst.  There is mild tension in the Irish Revolt plot.  With regard to characterization, it took Georgina too long to find her spine and Adam's highly developed sense of betrayal turned him into an unnecessarily nasty piece of work.  The inevitable HEA was a little to saccharine for my tastes.Bottom line: with a little better editing and a lot less melodrama, this could have been a heck of a good story.Netherworld: a solid 3 stars.  With a plot and main characters that are very similar to those found in Dark Deceptions, Netherworld moves us backwards from the English Regency Era to 12th century Wales complete with damsels in distress, knights in shining armor and wet, gloomy castles.Instead of a single heroine, we have a pair of young women being brutalized by a family member who find love in the arms of their rescuers.  The good news is that Chrystobel and Islyn have somewhat better self esteem and are generally spunkier than poor downtrodden Georgina in Dark Deceptions.  The male protagonist Keller is also more forthright, focused and goal oriented in spite of some understandable previous heartbreak.  As a consequence, I liked him a good deal better than whiney, suspicious Adam in DD.Bottom line: Netherworld is an big improvement over a Dark Deceptions with much less angst, much more action, and more appealing characters.Final word: Be advised that the last 10% of this book billed as 'bonus material' is actually single chapter teasers for other books written by the authors.

You'll have to decide for yourself whether or not it's fair to review a book before the reviewer finished it but, try as I might, I could not make myself read to the end of this one.  Just over a third of the way into this I found myself skimming...never a good sign.  While I can't complain about the cost (it was free), I do value my reading time.The title tells you this is a Scottish time travel romance.  Unfortunately, the author tried way to hard to pull off the time travel aspect of it to the point that it felt unnecessarily contrived and silly.  Where Diana Galbadon's time travel method was surprising and smoothly integrated into the story, this one was clunky and overdone.  It required entirely too much buildup.Once our heroine makes the big time jump, her actions, even with her belief that 'it's all a coma-induced dream' make little sense and are not believable: readily adopting a Scottish accent, happily marrying her hunky 'Coma Husband,' kinda' having sex with him then making out with his brother, etc.  Needless to say, she acquiesces to her surroundings very quickly.  As for our hero, even though I read fully 1/3 of the novel, he is so little known that it's hard to feel much for him.  Absolutely nothing about either character 'grabs' me.Bottom line: All romance novels follow the same basic formula leading to the required HEA.  The only thing that sets one apart from the others is the quality of the plot, including the conflict, and character development.  One third of the way into Love Beyond a Time there is no believable, sustainable tension and the characters haven't interested me.  Time to travel on.

The female protagonist, Shannon, is one of the most hapless characters I've ever read and that haplessness plays out in a wasteland of frenetic slapstick that was only occasionally funny.  The sheer volume of falls, social blunders, embarrassing objects that fall out of her purse or pocket is ridiculous and conversations about her personal hygiene and parents' sex lives is frenetic and overwhelming.  The author does have a good sense of the female psyche especially as it relates to how we see ourselves reflected in the eyes of the men in our lives, but the few insightful nuggets related to that is lost amidst frequently unfunny nonsense.What dialog there was was subsumed in a sea of the heroine's internal dialogue.  I realize that dialogue is much harder to write than just straight prose, but it certainly makes for a much better pacing and a much better read.The repeated use of 'overwhelm' as a noun rather than a verb or adjective, to whit: 'I’m shaking with overwhelm, adrenaline, embarrassment, and excitement.'  It can be used that bit is is awkward and distracting.Bottom line: This author's simply tried too hard to make Shannon's misadventures funny which is unfortunate because the author does seem to have a handle on some aspects of the female psyche that are at once funny and sad, painful and uplifting.  I wish she'd tapped more into that.

Ms. Day provides what so many others lack in a period romance novel: good characterization, wonderful pacing, an intriguing plot, realistic complications and a believable conclusion.  To be sure, the red herrings did little to throw me off, but the mystery element was still good.Her characterization of Eliza who has ordered her life to be the antithesis of her willful, flighty mother, is a study in how the influence of our parents, for good or for ill, is always with us.  She is one of the few female protagonists whose 'hangups' felt believable and integral to the story.  As the protagonist, Jasper Bond's parental motivations and influences were not quite as well developed until the very end of the novel but, in the end,  no less compelling.  The only criticism I have of his characterization is Eliza's oft repeated musing as to his physical beauty.  I got it after the first several mentions.Be advised, as with all of Ms. Day's novels, the sensuality rating is very high.  From the middle of the novel until the end, the sex is frequent and graphic.  That said, there is a tone to this story that is more deeply romantic than I have perceived in her some of other novels.  It's not just about the sex.  Eliza's and Jasper's growing and deeply emotional connection fills a void that neither of them understood or were aware of until the other filled it.  That's what makes Pride and Pleasure a cut above most other period romances.

I read a great deal and I often choose period romances, most of which have a predictable plot arc:  boy meets girl, boy and/or girl have issues of one kind or another, boy and/or girl feel attraction but some misunderstanding drives them apart, dramatic circumstances throw them back together, misunderstandings are overcome, happily every after is achieved. I am thrilled to say that while most of those plot elements are present in Courtney Milan's "The Heiress Effect," there is such originality in characterization, real tension in the development of the plot and no guarantee that a HEA will be achieved which makes this a book in which very little is predictable or typical.  In fact, I would describe this book as being one of the BEST I've read in the period romance genre.Characterization:  Attractive, but bespectacled, serious and ambitious young man, Oliver Marshall meets abrasive, plump, over loud in both speech and dress, Jane Fairfield.  From the jump, these two are non-typical.  Both are the by-blow of aristocratic parents and both have had their adulthood informed by the fact that they are 'outsiders' and the emotional baggage that they carry is both realistic, relatable and heartbreaking.  The difference is that Oliver has worked diligently to suppress his natural tendencies in order to 'belong' so that he might make a difference to many (the politically and economically disenfranchised) and Jane has worked frantically and forwardly to alienate many so that she might make a difference for one (her half sister).  To say that Oliver and Jane are initially oil and water is an understatement but somehow they recognize something in the other that they need.Plot tension: This novel is really three stories beautifully woven together with plot elements that are also very non-typical for the genre: Jane's story which shows her to be loud, badly dressed, ill-mannered and abrasive;  Oliver's story where he is principled, but frequently wavers in his ability to stay true to his principles and finally the story of Jane's half sister, Emily Fairfield a sheltered young woman who suffers from what is likely temporal lobe epilepsy.  Poor Emily's condition is worsened by the guardianship of an uncle who is incredibly cruel in his well-intentioned and earnest, if ill advised efforts to protect and 'cure' Emily's affliction.  Interestingly, there is also a member of Oliver's family who suffers from agoraphobia and it is this family member who provides the catalyst for the HEA which was by no means assured throughout much of this novel.The 'happily ever after:'  Authors often try to write strong women but few succeed.  You may have a different idea of what a strong woman is, but for me a strong woman is one who knows who she is, what she wants for herself and those she cares about and who follows both her heart and her instincts with truth and dignity.  Jane Fairfield is all of those things and more often at great cost to herself.  One of the best scenes I've read in recent memory is the one in which Jane tries to talk herself into becoming the bland, unassuming, aristocratic help-mate that Oliver believes he needs to have the kind of political career that he wants.  Fortunately that self-talk is short as she realizes that she is  finished with playing a role.  She tells Oliver, "It's just as well that you don't want an 'awful' wife," she told him, "because I had hoped for a husband with a little courage."  Given what the reader has learned about Jane and Oliver to this point, that is a devastating thing for her to say and an even more devastating thing for him to hear, but it is a dead-on accurate testament to Jane's strength and courage.  After this, Jane walks away and proceeds to begin the process of building a life for herself without Oliver.  Jane is no shrinking violet.Bottom line: This is a terrific book that looks not only at the developing relationship between Oliver and Jane, but also at the way people with medical difficulties were treated, often being used as medical guinea pigs.  It also touches on the growing pressure for political enfranchisement for all English citizens including women, the beginnings of influence by the growing numbers of England's ethnic and cultural minorities and very briefly. at the beginnings of understanding with regard to modern genetics.  Thus, "The Heiress Effect" borders on historical romance instead of just period romance.  All that said, it is at its heart, a sensitive, compelling, heart-tugging look at two people who are at once opposite and the same and who  are the embodiment of the aphorism  'the whole being greater that the sum of the parts.'  Well done, Ms. Milan, VERY well done.

If I make it to the 65% mark in a book I usually finish it.  The Ruby Brooch will be the exception.My very first time travel romance was Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series.  I won't say that ruined me for all others but it did set a bit of a standard for setting up the time travel premise and having the time traveler cope with and adapt to the time to which he or she has traveled.  DG does it quite well by having her heroine Claire Randall flung backward to the mid-18th century and having to rely on her wits and common sense to navigate and make a life in the alien and often hostile environment of the Scottish Highlands at a time of great upheaval.  DG does a creditable job of taking a fantastic premise and making it believable and absorbing.Unfortunately, Ms. Logan and the Ruby Brooch cannot claim the same.  Instead of her wits, our heroine relies on the trappings of the 21st century: flashlights, multi clip repeating rifles and handguns, modern medicines including IVs and Tylenol, her iPhone, iPod and the straw that broke this readers back: a modern pregnancy test.  Her efforts to hide her "other worldliness" was perfunctory at best.As far a characterization is concerned, I found it to be uneven and often contradictory.  Both Kitherina and Cullen, our main protagonists cycle through emotions with alarming unpredictability and often without real explanation or provocation.  Some of the secondary characterizations are quite good especially that of Sarah Barrett.  I really like her more than Kitherina.  As far as Cullen is concerned, he is supposed to be a Highlander (seems to be requisite in time travel novels), but speaks English with very little Scottish influence showing in his speech except when he is engaged sexually with Kitherina.  It was infrequent enough to feel affected rather than illustrative of his character.The great western migration was a fascinating period in American history but very little of the history of that time is incorporated into the story.  While DG may occasionally be criticized for her massive research and how it shows up in her book as very detailed description, Ms. Logan might be criticized for not enough.  This reader got only the barest sense of what life on the trail was like.  My knowledge of U.S. History reminds me that it was a grueling, monotonous, dangerous journey and not enough of that figures into the story.Bottom line:  Given the setting this could have been a terrifically engaging read but is instead, shallow and silly.  Give this one a pass.

I've read many of Victoria Holt's books over the years and have enjoyed them to varying degrees.  Unfortunately I could not find much to like aboutThe Secret Woman.  I threw in the towel at the 25% mark rather continuing to wade through plodding dullness.

I had a hard time getting into this book.  With so many characters and confusing relationships, authentic Georgian Era dialogue that challenged my patience and a female protagonist whose personality I found annoying, I almost gave up on it.  That said, I'm glad I stuck with it.  The pacing could have been a bit better in the beginning, but Noble Satyr ends up being mildly tension-filled and intriguing.  The love story had a real stop and start quality to it, but for the most part I saw the logic of Roxton's actions.  From a historical standpoint, It is an excellent look at the differences in French and English culture during the waning days of Louis XIV and George II.Bottom line: I wouldn't call it a fun read, but it is an interesting and well told tale that establishes a well written series.

Beautiful, strong woman + rich, conflicted, impossibly handsome man x lots of hot sex divided by complicating situations = a classic Sylvia Day contemporary romance.  It's not a compelling read, but it is easy escapism for a boring Saturday afternoon.

I think this author wanted to write a grand love story where the flawed, damaged hero overcomes his past to woo and win the strong, independent female protagonist.  The HEA delivers that ending, but the journey to that point is painfully annoying.The hero (H) has serious mommy issues resulting in his frequently stated disrespect for women of his own exalted social class, seeing them as weak, scheming and vacuous.  At the same time, however, he REPEATEDLY tells our heroine (h) that he cannot marry her because she is not his social equal even though she is the opposite of what he disdains most about women of his class.  This, however, does not keep him from several attempts, with varying degrees of success to get her into his bed, suggesting more than once, that she become his mistress.  Bottom line, the guy is a right bastard through 80% of this book.What about our heroine?  Motherless from an early age, she is raised by her doting, country doctor father and a maiden aunt.  She has a consuming interest in veterinary medicine and wishes to become a country vet at a time when women were barred from universities, let alone all professions except the 'oldest' one.  My main problem with her is that she is a tease.  She allows our H have his way with her, often topping just short of intercourse then pulls back insisting that to go further  would ruin her reputation.  Having that happen once in a novel is one thing, but it happens repeatedly in this one to the point where she looks more like a sexual tease than the spunky heroine she's intended to be.Bottom line:  this book is one giant eye-roll after another and I didn't care for either of the main characters.  The writing was flat, the pacing was sluggish and the only thing that mitigated the eye-rolling was the Hero's twin sister calling him out on his weak BS.  She was the only believable and interesting character in the entire book.

There's something missing in this novel.  Hmmm...let me think...  I have it: a plot!I am 25% of the way into this book and nearly the entire focus has been the main character's attempt to get the hunky Scotsman into bed so that she can hand in her V card.  She's mid to late 20s, previously engaged, has been dumped, beaten up and nearly raped and all that seems to have had less impact than the fact that he doesn't want to have sex with her.  They've done everything up to the point of actual intercourse including things that would have popped her cherry, but not the actual deed.  It would be nice if the author had a better understanding of female anatomy.  That way she could have let her female protagonist off the metaphorical "hook."Bottom line:  It sucks.

This was bought as a gift for my daughter who is into owls.  The colors are attractive and, while not quite as bright as they appear in the photograph, are close enough to work well with her decor.  Overall she seemed very happy with it.

He needs an heir, she needs a protector.  Same old, same old.  It is elevated beyond 2 stars because the little bit of murder and mystery in the plot provide a mildly entertaining read.  It's likely that you'll have the mystery figured out by chapter 7 and the culprit figured out a few chapters later, certainly before the denouement, but it will likely keep you interested.Bottom line: Loving the Marquess is a long way from the worst Regency romance I've read, but it's certainly far from the best.  It's easy reading for a winter afternoon.

Part gothic, part historical, part mystery, part romance...overall a nice blend of several genres that make a satisfying read.  A deception such as the one portrayed in this book could only have happened in a time before instantaneous communication and rapid travel across great distances.  Of course, the author was still obliged to pull out a number of 'convenient' plot devices to make it work, but even with that it managed to keep me engaged.Bottom line: This is a enjoyable, mildly suspenseful snowy afternoon read.

The first two thirds of this book was some of the smartest, cleverly imagined and presented historical romance I've written in a good long while.  Why?  Because the central conflict was realistic and convincing.  So many books in this genre rely on hackneyed situations that push the H/h together.  Typically it goes like this: one or the other needs to marry in order to save the family estate.  Some 'dark secret' or scandal and a series of often trivial misunderstandings serve to create tension until the inevitable HEA.  The reason that Adriana and Tynan get together follows that formula, but that's where the similarities between this book and so many others in this genre part company.  The scandal surrounding Adriana is realistic to the period and has created real problems for her family.  Tynan's entry into her life is due to the machinations of her now deceased father but the reasons for it are not quite clear in the beginning.The character development is good, the romance develops slowly, the dialog is quite good and the little bit of history included in this book involves England's oppression of Ireland in the late 18th century.  Both the characters and their obstacles and complications felt believable.  That's the good news.What I've described above occupies the first 2/3 of the book.  Adriana has suffered social ostracism for her transgression committed when she was a young girl just entering society.  Five years later, Tynan marries her as a means of furthering his own political interests and in so doing helps her make her reentry into society.  Unfortunately, the author chose a plot element to illustrate Adriana's reemerging personal strength and self reliance that I thought was silly and melodramatic.  I just can't see it happening and because of that, my estimation took a nosedive from a 5 star read to a 3 star read.  Pity.

Standing Stones is well written, but very grim.  Yes, I understand that Scotland was under the heel of the British for a very long time and the people endured the hardships of British rule, a harsh landscape, bouts of starvation and the vagaries of a struggling economy.  However, I think I need to be in the mood to read something like this and unfortunately, I just was not.

I had to think about it a while before I wrote this review.  At it's core, Lucien's Fall is the typical 'troubled-man-saved-by-a-good-woman' scenario found in many romance novels, but it is saved from the standard cliches of this familiar plot by the depth of characterization, a truly engaging story line and a minimum of  annoying and credulity stretching misunderstandings and plot twists.The opening of the novel grabbed me right away and I loved  how music was used as a barometer of Lucien's inner struggles and a device to attract Madeline, the female protagonist.  He is a truly flawed anti-hero who is at once detestable, pitiable and tragic.  Most importantly, for me at least, is the fact that Madeline is not stupidly blinded by Lucien's physical beauty.  She is a strong, smart woman who is caught between her duty to marry as means of preserving her family home and her growing  attraction to a man who is at once frightening and exciting, but most importantly, free.  It is his seeming freedom from convention that attracts her the most, but that attraction is a point of real and believable conflict for her.An important secondary character, Madeline's mother Juliette, was not as well drawn in my opinion and I really didn't understand her.  She seemed unduly bitter and manipulative and I couldn't find sufficient reason in her backstory to warrant it.  She does love her daughter, but she is not above overlooking Madeline's interests and desires to pursue her own objectives.  As a result, much of the tension created by  Juliette's actions felt contrived, less believable and annoying.  Another character, Charles Devon, Madeline's suitor, handpicked by her mother was a bit too forgiving to be believable especially given all the waffling Madeline did with him over whether or not she could marry him. She perpetrated a fairly significant betrayal and he took it far too well in my opinion.  I would have liked a little more tension from him.In may ways this is an atypical period romance.  It lacks the interminable gushing and highly descriptive emoting over the physical appearance of the H/h, the ultimate physical union of Lucien and Madeline is well written and not rushed, and it avoids most of the often annoying and illogical actions that mar many of the books in this genre.  Lucien is often detestable and Madeline's struggles to avoid being attracted to him felt very realistic. It did drag a bit in the middle, but the expected HEA was satisfying, believable and really, really romantic.Bottom line:  It is a good read and I recommend it.  I'll be reading more of this author's work.

Windsong started off slow and struggled from time to time with uneven, often contradictory, characterization.  Some of the characters, especially Rory and his mother. Judith seemed to turn on a dime--cold, critical or aloof at one juncture and then with little explanation or provocation, loving and complimentary in the next moment.  While the book has a reasonably interesting plot, I just had a hard time engaging with the characters.

I knew what I was getting into when I purchased this book: it's chick-lit, pure and simple.  Chick lit can be entertaining by allowing the reader immerse him or herself into high romance, usually spiced with a little sex before the inevitable HEA. I often think of chick lit as adult fairy tales: fairly unrealistic but fun to read.  With regard to most of these basic expectations of the chick lit formula, Ms. Bennett succeeds.  Her characters are those that you expect to find in most romance novels: a flawed and emotionally stunted, but devastatingly handsome male protagonist coupled with a 'strong,' nurturing, emotionally mature female protagonist who will ultimately 'save' him.  Clearly Sutton, the female protagonist, likes projects because Alex certainly promises to be one.So what problems did I have with this book that rated a two star assessment?  Several.  I've listed them in ASCENDING order of annoyance/disappointment: 1) The male characters most often acted like 12 year olds or at least they talked like it.  I do understand that men talk differently with each other than they do with women (usually) or in mixed company, but there was a level of juvenile immaturity that I had a hard time with. 2) The author chose to alternate points of view from chapter to chapter.  Chapter 1 is Alex's POV, Chapter 2 is Sutton's POV and so forth.  To me this smacks of amateur, fan fiction style writing when the author is not sufficiently skilled to create a distinctive voice for each of the major characters.  There were times that the alternating POVs were nothing but a rehash of a particular event in the story.  3) Once the seal was broken so to speak, the book morphed from chick lit to 'dick lit' with one sex scene after another to the point that it felt like filler rather than a device to move the story along or develop the characters.  Sex scenes dominated the last 60% of the book. 4) The author inflames one of my pet peeves in her choice to TELL you pretty much everything rather than SHOW you through dialog, action and setting.  The bulk of the story is told through internal dialog, again, in my mind, the hallmark of an inexperienced or lazy writer.  Some internal dialog is okay/necessary but the predominance in this book is grating.  5) My chief complaint is the plot.  It's about a half an inch deep and uses every--single--cliche known to literature before the couple's major stumbling blocks become magically and too easily resolved.  To wit: the clingy, bimbo ex-girlfriend heeds Alex's warning and goes away; the old boyfriend bows out without a whimper, both Alex's and Sutton's fathers enter rehab and they all join hands and sing Kumbaya as reconciliation and forgiveness rule the day.  Forgive my skepticism, but Alex's father's transgressions toward him are so egregious that I really had a hard time swallowing the big 'forgiveness scene. The H/h's culminating 'commitment scene' which is crucial to all HEAs in chick lit, is formulaic, overplayed and silly.Bottom line:  This can be read in an afternoon with absolutely no strain to your brain power, but when you finish it you may only get the same kinds of marginal satisfaction that you get from lite beer.  Personally, I prefer my romances to have a little more substance.

I'm writing this at the 52% complete mark on my Kindle.  I'm slightly more than halfway through and NOTHING has happened in this story beyond the female protagonist, Jayne, mooning over how beautiful Luke/Lucifer is, eating dinner in H.E., LLc. corporate headquarters (Hell, get it?  Yuck, yuck, yuck), an aborted night out and taking a walk through San Francisco's Chinatown.  There is no action, there is no tension and as a consequence there is no continued interest on my part.There is, however, entirely too much silly, convoluted description of Hell's corporate structure, references to the poker games of the Archangels, the bowling league of the Guardian Angels, and the 'betting pools' of H.E., LLc.'s employees.  There is nothing in either Jayne's or Luke/Lucifer's characterization that makes me want to keep reading.  Ms. Bernard's attempt to create a tortured, sympathetic Satan who will be saved by the love of a good woman is just--plain--boring.Bottom line: I bought this book on the strength of Ms. Bernard's work in The Black Rose trilogy.  While I may have criticized her choice to break that story up into three parts, I praised her story telling.  Unfortunately, her talents at writing humor don't match her skills at writing romance and drama.  Devil to Pay is not worth your money or your time.
My review for this book is included with the the review for the last book in the series "The Lady Triumphs."  I liked this book, but feel strongly that did not need to be a series.

What follows is a review of the iHomeSet Touchless Countertop Soap Dispenser - Automatic Sensor Pump - Stainless Steel - For Kitchen and Bathroom (8 oz, Silver) that was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.Packaging: The unit came packaged in a medium weight cardboard box with the unit wrapped in plastic to protect the stainless steel colored coating on the plastic unit.  Instructions and a footed unit base were also included.Assembly: The directions included a schematic drawing illustrating the various parts of the unit as well as instructions for battery insertion, filling the unit and attaching the plastic footed base.  Directions for assembly and operation were fairly simple but I had difficulty getting the 4th battery to fit flush with the other three.  As a result the plastic door to the battery housing could not be firmly closed as I would have liked.Construction:  While the main body of the unit may be stainless steel, but remainder of the unit is plastic with a stainless steel/chrome appearance.  The battery housing is on the bottom of the unit and wires that run the pump and the electric eye were visible within the battery housing.  Since the soap dispenser is used near water it worries me about water getting to the wires and affecting the operation of the unit.  Once it was filled with dish soap, I turned it upside down and noticed that the lid to the soap chamber leaks.  I had to wipe a considerable amount of soap off the top of the unit after righting it.As another consideration, while the stainless steel look is popular in kitchens these days it does have its drawbacks.  As with stainless steel refrigerators, ovens, microwaves, etc, the soap dispenser is prone to showing fingerprints and water marks, especially when sitting so near the kitchen sink.  What’s more, when I went to wipe the unit off, if I would forget to hold it from the back of the unit a dollop of soap would come out.  I am constantly wiping fingerprints and streaks off my stainless steel appliances and I found myself doing that with the soap dispenser and sometimes having to wipe up soap from the counter-top as well.  So my advice is to turn the unit off before cleaning.Unit operation:  Since this is a touchless unit, all it requires is a pass of the sponge or your hand under the nozzle to readily dispense a dime-sized dollop of soap.  The instructions say that a single push on the on/off button will change the amount of soap dispensed.Day-to-day use:• Day 1: I filled the soap chamber with Dawn liquid dish soap.  The unit operated as expected after I put in the batteries and held down the on/off button located on the top for 3 seconds as instructed.  A red light near the electric eye blinks to let you know that the unit is operating and it took three passes of my hand to prime the pump and get the first dollop soap. Several other passes under the spout resulted in soap being deposited on my sponge.• Day 2: I picked up the unit to wipe underneath it and the battery compartment door fell off.  The battery that I had difficulty fitting flush with the others was loose, but with a fair amount of effort I managed to get it back in and the battery door back on.  Unfortunately, at that point the unit no longer worked.  I tried turning it off and then back on which produced no results.  I also tried replacing all of the batteries which also produced no results, so the unit is now sitting, non-operational on my kitchen counter.• Day 3: The unit is now working. I did not do anything different to make the unit work, but it was working this morning when I tried it.  I was able to test the three different dispensing levels that were described in the directions and that feature does work.  The largest amount dispensed is slightly larger than a dime.• Day 4:  Still working, but the amount being dispensed is smaller than the setting I selected on the previous day.• Day 5: Still working, however it takes two passes under the electric eye to get enough soap on the sponge to wash a dish.  The first pass results in just a bare drop of soap, but the second pass is a normal amount based upon my dispenser selection.  I don’t know what is causing this except that it might be that the soap dries a bit in the nozzle if the unit isn't used for a while.BOTTOM LINE: This is a GOOD LOOKING product, but is a POOR FUNCTIONING product.  Given the problems noted above, I CANNOT RECOMMEND it.

I was offered this book in exchange for an honest review.To be perfectly honest,  I thought I might not be able to finish this book.  First, the epub copy  I received was so poorly formatted that reading was often a frustrating physical labor.  I certainly hope that the published Kindle edition does not suffer from this problem.  Second, and more important is that the first part of the book is largely the female protagonist's internal dialog.  I understand that internal dialog is a legitimate literary device, but I find too much of it to be wearisome.  The internal dialog does lessen but there is still a good deal of it throughout the book.  All of that said, I am very, very glad that I persevered.Both Marin Strang and Lawrence Fyre are truly products of their upbringing.  Marin is the daughter of  strict Jehova's Witness parents but who never knew her mother because she died at Marin's birth.  She is so bereft that as a child she frequently picked out a woman that 'might' be her mother to watch from afar and devise stories justifying her mother's absence in the hopeful belief that she might not actually be dead.  As an adult, she ultimately rejects the strictures of the Jehovah's Witness faith and strikes out on her own leaving her often remote father behind.  Marin has become a school teacher,  is struggling to get past a failed relationship and lives very 'lightly,' in fear of accumulating too much 'stuff' that would keep her from being able to move on at a moment's notice.Lawrence is the product of an alcoholic mother and who, from a very early age, was the primary protector of his little sister. As an adult,  Lawrence is just endearingly odd.  He's an owner of a book shop in Brighton, lives in what amounts to a storage facility and has a eclectic selection of friends.  He is estranged from his father, his mother is dead and his sister, to whom he is very close, is perilously ill with a chronic, congenital condition.The magic happens when these two find one another.  There is a strong poignancy to their relationship that is often awkward, fraught with emotional undercurrents and burdened by the weight of their considerable 'baggage.'  Some of the most affecting reading I have done lately are the passages dealing with a substantial, heart rending loss experienced by Marin and Lawrence.  I cried through much of it but I have to feel it is a fairly realistic portrayal of the feelings of those who experience a loss of this kind.Bottom line:  This is a well written, and moving look at the journey of discovery of two people who didn't know they were lost until they found each other.  There are some rather cliched elements to this story, but even those are handled better than I've read in many books.  My initial concerns  were overcome by the depth of characterization, good pacing and emotive story development.  I'm glad I read it and believe Ms. Potts to be an author to watch.

I feel like such a curmudgeon as I write this, but I can't help how I feel.  Make no mistake.  I think Ms. Bernard is a talented writer who created a story in three parts unnecessarily, but that was original, interesting and reasonably well plotted.  My complaint lay in what I believe to be unnecessary serialization.The total length of the three books combined is 542 pages.  I figure that title pages, author's notes and previews for the next book down to around 500 pages.  That is a very decent length book.  So, why break it up into three books?  Of course my immediate supposition is to simply sell more books.  I understand that this my be Ms. Bernard's sole occupation, but I feel is a bush league, amateurish move that didn't enhance the story and certainly didn't sit well with me.As for the ending of the Black Rose Trilogy, I didn't feel that it lived up to the build up and, as a consequence, I'm left with a sense of having been let down.
