This isn't uncommon for the current vein of literature that disdains plot, but it's disappointing for a writer of her caliber and it's curious that the editorial process didn't clean up much of the frippery.The result of all this for many readers will be an effect that is oddly similar to watching True Detective's second season: recognition that it is technically inspiring, appreciation for a deep understanding of California's background and underside, and guffaws at a plot and characters that only the writer and a few fans can take seriously.  Watkins will undoubtedly get some literary plaudits for this, but on the whole this is best reserved for those looking to learn a little bit about technical writing.  Otherwise, it should be avoided by those interested in reading a coherent novel.  3 stars.

This is gum, so there's not too much profound wisdom to be shared about it.Spearmint and peppermint have three packs; sweet mint and wintermint two.  Sweet mint is perhaps the best of the bunch but its flavor will expire within a few minutes.  Peppermint is quite strong and can last in the range of ten.  This does contain xylitol, which kills bacteria in the mouth and means the various flavors are not a bad choice for after snacking, as many dentists recommend xylitol gum for periodontal purposes.  (Keep it away from dogs and cats, however, as small doses can kill them.)  The sticks are somewhat larger than those found in Trident boxes, although they do go bad fairly quickly.Why 3 stars?  Simple reason.  This is a variety pack available in big box stores, and it generally has been sold for about 30% less than current pricing reflects here.  You're better off buying it elsewhere for now.

Adam Makos' "Devotion: An Epic Story of Heroism, Friendship, and Sacrifice" tells two tales: a heroic effort by a couple of pilots, and a longer tale of how the pilots got there.  While the main incident is well told, Makos has some difficulty with the background and B-stories required to stretch it to book length.  The result is a book that is still very much worth reading but not at the level of his previous work.  4 stars.Makos gained well deserved notoriety with his previous book A Higher Call, one of the better untold tales of World War II that came to light in the twilight years of the men who fought it.  That book worked on many levels; while the escort of the damaged bomber by a Luftwaffe pilot was itself remarkable, the biography of that pilot, Franz Stigler, was even better.Devotion follows the model of the previous book, where hundreds of pages of background take place before the incident involving Jesse Brown and Tom Hudner - where one pilot gets shot down and the other makes a heroic choice.  The incident and the followup to it take up about 75 pages and 4 chapters, and is well done.  The problem becomes the other 325 pages, where Makos' back story doesn't work as well.There are a few reasons for this; among the first is that Makos makes a number of  curious editorial decisions, not the least of which is hiding the results of the incident until late in the book.  This is also Makos' first exposure to the Korean War, and while the bibliography and interviews show a good deal of research, it's also pretty clear that he's not on the same firm ground as he was in Higher Call with years of study.In turn, that shows up in how he sets up the background here.  While the childhood history of the pilots makes sense, especially for Brown, the first African American to serve as a Naval aviator, the two years before in between their naval service and the advent of the Korean War aren't particularly compelling.  Brown's encounters with racism are quite interesting (the casual hatred he received from other African Americans in the Navy, along with a notable scene where he's refused service in a bar not in the South but in San Diego), but otherwise the backstory is more or less a Med cruise with the highlight being a bunch of sailors and Marines from the Leyte hanging out with a young Liz Taylor.  That Makos chooses to focus on this rather than things like the move by the Navy to jets and the resulting politics along with the events that led up to the Korean War is a problem.In turn, this means that when Makos does get to Korea the story doesn't have the heft it deserves.  The battle at the Chosin Reservoir was described by S.L.A. Marshall as "the most violent small unit fighting in the history of American warfare", yet Makos recounts only a few incidents with Marines that were attached to it, and of those he doesn't weave them compellingly.  A incident he describes that was heroic enough so that a Medal of Honor was later rewarded receives little coverage, Army units receive short shrift, and foreign units receive no attention at all.While this certainly focuses attention on Brown and Hudner, there are a lot of incredible stories from Chosin, and the workmanlike telling of the battle (and backstories prior to their involvement) means the book feels like it's missing a couple of cylinders.  It's not a bad book by any means, and the story of Brown and Hudner is worth retelling.  However, other books have told the individual stories better - a number of books have been published on Chosin, and there's been one by the Naval Institute on Brown and Hudner - and Makos could have weaved a better tale here.In sum, worth a read and it's great to see this story getting wider coverage after 60 years, but Makos doesn't cover much new ground here.  4 stars.

Been a bunch written on this already, so not a ton to add.  Highlights include:- Relatively easy to install.  Having done plumbing work before, this ranks about a 2 or 3 on the difficulty scale.  Yes, you need silicon to secure the base, and yes, it has plastic water feeds which you'll need to cut.  Other than that, it's generally beginner level, and Delta has extensive documentation.- Easy to clean.  Used Windex.  Worked perfectly, which doesn't happen on some metals.- Relatively cheap.  At current prices, about $20-30 less than you'll find something comparable at a box store.4 stars.  Nothing extraordinary here, but a good faucet.

Nisid Hajari's "Midnight Furies" is a frightening look at the ethnic cleansings and boneheaded politics that helped create modern day India and Pakistan.  While most modern writers on both sides concentrate solely on the Kashmir, Hajari goes further into the conflict by including the bloodbaths that occurred in the Punjab and bringing the political background that made this possible.  A star off for bringing in minor players that overtly complicate the book and for not providing a bit more background on historic Muslim-Hindu-Sikh relationships before World War I, but overall a disturbing but important book.  4 stars.As Hajari notes, save for the uplifting story of Gandhi most Westerners know little about India's evolution from vassal to independent state.  Unfortunately, there is good reason for this: the story of the birth of Pakistan and India is not one that most of its participants would like told, as it involved ethnic cleansing and mass murder that can only be compared to Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, or any number of countries following World War I.How did this happen?  The political leadership on both sides initially presented fairly firm positions but by all accounts were capable and interested in compromise, but after several incidents, those positions hardened from political posturing to outright hatred.  That gave cover for tolerance and, at times, direct encouragement for lower class proxies in the battle to encourage those who weren't coreligionists to flee, by fire, brutal violence, or simply outright murder.What started in the Punjab (Delhi was once an strongly integrated city, for instance) spread throughout the border regions, and the result was horrific.  Muslims attacked Hindus, Hindus attacked Muslims, Muslims attacked Sikhs, Sikhs attacked Muslims, and essentially, no governmental or religious organization made an effort to stop them, and it's questionable that once the genie got out the bottle if any had the power to do so.  Gandhi, for instance, was assassinated by a radical Hindu organization that felt he betrayed all Hindus by going on a hunger strike to force India to live up to its agreement to release part of its reserves to a starving post-partition Pakistan.  The sad irony is that following Gandhi's murder, Pakistan promptly used those newly released reserves for arms purchases instead of food.Besides the failure of Nehru and Jinnah, the political leadership of Britain bears particular blame as well.  While some of Britain's mistakes came from severe budgetary pressures - it's worth remembering that Britain's simultaneous withdrawal from Palestine was as much financial as much as it was the realization it couldn't govern the region any more - others were not.  Churchill's hatred for Indian independence leaders knew no bounds; while out of power, he met with Jinnah and offered his promise of unwavering support for the new Pakistan as long as they would offer their army to support the Commonwealth and continue to swear allegiance to King and Crown.  In turn, Attlee's government wasn't any better in their full voiced support for Nehru.There was more than just support, however.  Most notable was the incredibly stupid decision by Mountbatten to massively accelerate the removal of British control without any corresponding governmental plans - quite literally, borders were being drawn up by a Brit in the last week before independence - meaning governmental organization on independence was non-existent.  Moving from unbelievable to outright stupid is that in the case of Kashmir, the British-run Pakistan army had its British commander in chief planning to go to war against India's army, run by, of course, another British general.  Both armies were intended as bulwarks against the Soviet Union; instead, they promptly began killing each other instead.There are two major drawbacks to the book.  First, Hajari brings up such detailed political analysis that readers will often simply get lost in names that show up once or twice and then disappear into the woodwork without much understanding of how they related to the greater story.  Second, what would have helped significantly is a chapter or two on the historic fights over the Indian subcontinent, as while the author hints at some of the conflicts over princely states, it would have been very useful to go back a few centuries into the historical conflict between Muslims, Hindus, and Sikhs.Still, an important if disturbing book.  4 stars.

Peter Longerich's "Goebbels: A Biography" breaks new ground.  Using the recently published complete set of the Goebbels diaries, Longerich reveals a narcissistic and fawning academic who vastly overestimated his own talents and contributions, had no deepset political beliefs, and was often completely out of his depth.  While this will be a reference for years to come, 1.5 stars off as it is also a distinctly ponderous German academic work that often unnecessarily veers into psychobiography.  3.5 stars rounded up to 4 to represent the importance of this work.With the 1992 discovery of the microfilmed Goebbels diaries in an archive in Russia and the resultant publishing of a massive, 29 volume German language edition finally concluding in 2009, Goebbels is the one Nazi figure well overdue for reevaluation thanks to the introduction of this significant new material.  Longerich, a German history professor at the University of London known for his work on the Holocaust and a superb biography of Heinrich Himmler, is the first academic to fully utilize Goebbels' writings to analyze the man in a way not available to past historians.This has both benefits and drawbacks. While the diaries are often a conscious attempt by Goebbels to inflate his role for the future historians of the thousand year Reich (at least until he became convinced defeat was inevitable by late 1944), when combined with Longerich's thorough review of the scattered alternative sources, they also inadvertently reveal the conflict between Goebbels' opinion of himself against that of his peers, superiors, and the historical record.That, more than anything else, is the focus of the book.  Goebbels and many of his prior biographers cultivated an image of an icy political and public relations genius who was intricately involved in Reich policy.  Longerich destroys this myth.  While Goebbels was free to experiment with public opinion, he was was largely ineffective as a politician, often marginalized by Hitler with opinions that were ignored by the leadership, and in general his greatest value to the party was that he was the best of the Nazi public speakers and could routinely draw and captivate a crowd.While the early years present some problems as the diaries do not commence in full until 1926, enough nuggets survive to reveal an interesting sketch.  Goebbels was a essentially a failed PhD with a club foot that held him back socially, got a marginal job at a newspaper, editorialized for the party, and then through luck and circumstance was introduced to party figures early on and slavishly promoted his master's ideology as his own.  Goebbels came from the left side of the NSDAP and advocated a far closer relationship with Russia until realizing Hitler was not in agreement, and without much in the way of second thoughts did a complete 180 to align himself with whatever Hitler wanted, something he continued for the rest of his life.Longerich uses these discrepancies and anecdotes to argue that the main driving force behind Goebbels' career was a desperate narcissistic craving for recognition.  While he is probably right, compared to other outright psychobiographies like The Immortal Ataturk: A Psychobiography, the analysis here often feels a bit armchair as it's not Longerich's specialty.  On the other hand, it does reveal many of the negative traits that crippled the man; it's hard to argue that Goebbels' own insecurities didn't help lead him into philandering (which Goebbels did aplenty, although perhaps the most interesting tidbit is the speculation about Hitler's interest in Magda Goebbels corresponding with the timing of his half-niece's suicide) and seeking security and patronage wherever he could find it.  Overall, though, Longerich is often better off when he narrates events than psychoanalyzing his subject.The other weakness of the book is that despite what is likely a masterful and thorough translation and editing job (apparently 3 separate translators worked on this over 5 years - the book was published in a German edition all the way back in 2010), this is very much a ponderous academic tomb in the German tradition.  This isn't unexpected given the writer and source material, but readers used to more accessible English language, non-academic biographies will find this ponderous at best.While this is not nearly as accessible as other biographies on inner circle Nazi leaders and may turn off lay readers with its depth, it is a groundbreaking academic work that should be on the shelf of anyone concerned with Nazi leadership.  3.5 stars rounded up to 4.Disclosure: This impartial review was made possible by the publisher providing a copy of the ARC of this book.

The Black & Decker HF100WD is a decent enough specialized convection oven.  It does a good job on frozen fried food, an ok job on fresh food when oiled, and a so-so job on fresh food when not oiled.  4 stars despite the labeling.It's not apparent from many of the reviews, but B&D is late into the 'air fryer' game.  Philips created the concept in the UK five or so years ago - a convection oven that has a pull out drawer in the form of a fry basket.  This got Philips into a whole lot of trouble with the UK agency that deals with advertising claims, as Philips went on and on about the health benefits of 'air frying' when all they were doing was selling a convection oven with the fans slightly different.  This may have been why it took several years more to get the same models into the US.B&D's entry operates largely the same as Philips with a few less electronic controls; indeed, the timer on this is manual, so that if you unplug the HF100WD early, it'll still tick off until you hit the bell signifying that time is up.  Given that it is about half the price, this is well worth the tradeoff.These are actually quite good at preparing store bought frozen junk food, which generally contains a decent amount of oil in the package.  The only downside is that things that can drip - think mozzarella sticks, or burgers - you're likely to end up with a bit of a mess to clean up, although the non stick basket and barrel are actually quite easy to clean.  A general rule of thumb is that cooking time on a convection oven is about 75% that of a conventional oven which seems to apply here to things like onion rings (which turned out well), but seems a bit longer for things that require baking all the way through like egg rolls (which also turned out far better than in a microwave or conventional oven.)  Other items that turned out well included chicken wings and tater tots.This isn't quite as good with home made french fries coated in olive oil, mostly because the basket is too small to line more than half a portion up evenly.  (In fact, B&D points out that you need to shake the basket with any French Fries.)  It worked well on turkey and chicken burgers with a little oil, but you're likely better off using other methods to cook salmon and baked potatoes.4 stars.  Most of what you'll cook in here you probably shouldn't be eating anyway, but it's marginally better than going to a fast food place, and if you're creative you can come up with healthier fare.

Hershey's Kisses don't need much of a product review besides, perhaps, "burp."  (That, and that this bag has 9200 calories in it.)Writing a review extolling Hershey's versus Cadbury versus Ghiradelli is kind of irrelevant as you already know which chocolate you like.  You're not going to be buying 4 lbs of chocolate if you've made it to the point where you've a. got a credit card and b. have somehow navigated your life to that level of financial responsibility without having sampled Hershey's before.The only notable comparison here, then, is the pricing.  That's more interesting since it works out to $0.073 per Kiss for each of the 464 Kisses in the bag.  About 10 seconds of work online will show you that you can get a 40 ounce bag that works out to $0.03 per Kiss, or a 12 ounce bag that works out to about $0.048 per Kiss, both available from large box stores without membership requirements.Both of those are far better deals than this, so a 3 star rating is appropriate.

The Maytex Thermal Shield Kaylee Panel sells at a premium for its effectiveness.  In general, you'll be better off buying sew-on light blocking fabric.Based on previous reviews, it's not clear that many reviewers are familiar with light blocking fabric, which is routinely available at most craft stores.  It's a fairly heavy blend with two or three layers in white, and it blocks heat and light extremely effectively.In contrast, the Maytex panel is quite lightweight with a single greyish - not white - layer that covers about 90% of the back of the burgundy fabric, excepting the top.  This means that there is significant light seepage from the top of the panel regardless of how it's mounted.  There are velcro attachments at the side of the panel, but they are spaced about 2 feet apart so there will likely be both heat and light seepage from that as well.As other reviewers have noted, a 50" x 84" panel is not enough to provide coverage for most windows, so you'll need two panels that have something like 3-4" of overlap.3 stars.  Works ok, but there are better and cheaper solutions out there.

Bissell's SpotClean ProHeat Cleaner is really more of a cleaning solution applicator than a true spot cleaner.  While it's appropriately priced for the functionality, you're probably better off either spending significantly more on a true steam cleaner or renting one if you need to deep clean surfaces more frequently.  3 stars.There's been a lot written on this so far, so just a few points.  The most important one is that despite the ProHeat name, this basically just takes the warm (but not hot) temperature water you've put in the unit and uses it to dilute and wash the cleaner you've added.  It also doesn't have any attachments that loosen dirt or stains by beating the surface.  Basically, you're just shampooing with rather expensive Bissell cleaning solutions; unsurprisingly, Bissell isn't going to market this as a shampoo applicator.Compared to an older freestanding Bissell vacuum/cleaning model, this isn't bad, since it does about 80% of the same cleaning in about 1/4 the package.  Compared to a true steam cleaner like the wildly expensive but incredibly powerful Ladybug line, though, the difference is night and day.  As such, it's not the worst thing to have in your arsenal, but there are probably better values out there.  3 stars.

The Miele C2 is a decent canister vacuum, but compared to a top tier model like the S658i Blue Moon it's definitely entry level.  While the unit has plenty of power at 1200 watts, a star off as the included STB 205-3 isn't one of Miele's better attachments and suffers in comparison to the high end versions.  4 stars, however, as the parquet cleaner is good and as nearly the least expensive of the compact canisters, it's a very good base if you'd like to upgrade.If you're reading this review, you are likely familiar with Miele's well deserved reputation for great vacuums.  Within the Miele lines, though, there are definite differences.  Among them is that the C2 is the compact version of the canister models and is about 2 lbs lighter than the latest version of the traditional canisters like the C1 or the higher end C3.  (It also uses a smaller dust bag, the FJM series.)This isn't to say that this isn't a decent enough vacuum as is.  The 1200 watts here is equivalent to what Miele had on its highest end vacuums a decade ago, and compared to a Hoover or Electrolux or such it does a better job.  However, when compared head-to-head against one of those highest end models, the legendary Blue Moon, carpeting just didn't quite feel as clean.The blame here probably lies in the compact STB 205-3 Turbo Plus rotating roller brush attachment.  It just doesn't seem like it gets deep into the carpet the way the Blue Moon's venerable SEB 217-B does.  Nor does this include a HEPA filter, which those with dust mite allergies will find is essential.  On the other hand, the Miele Parquett Twister SBB 300-3 is a good bare floor accessory, and the VarioClip attachment holder is a nice upgrade over leaving small brushes sitting around.Where this has true potential is to use it as a base to get a true high end Miele.  You can buy your own HEPA filter, the SF-HA 50 HEPA 13, replace the STB 205-3 with the higher end SEB 236 Powerbrush found on the top end C3s, and swap out the SBB 300-3 with the larger Miele SBB 400-3 Parquet Twister XL.  Sell off the original parts for a reasonable amount, and for about $100-150 more than the list here you end up with a vacuum which has almost all the capabilities of the highest end C3, the C3 Brilliant at about half the price and 3/4 of the weight.Experienced Miele owners know that if you're looking for a relative bargain in a wildly expensive brand you're generally better off buying a lower end unit and upgrading it.  In a nutshell, that's exactly why the Miele C2 is an interesting vacuum.  4 stars.

The Philips Norelco NT3155/60 3100 Nose Trimmer is one of those devices that you'd think should show up on a late night paid TV spot to theoretically solve a problem that you didn't know you had before you bought it, gave up after 5 minutes and threw it out, and several months later discovered it cost a lot more than $14.99 as your credit card number been stolen.  Instead, it unexpectedly does an effective job in efficiently trimming hair inside the nose.  Doesn't do the other marketed tricks, though, so 4 stars.There's a classic scene in About Last Night where Demi Moore is sleeplessly rummaging around in Rob Lowe's stuff, finds a weird device that she can't figure out, and Lowe wakes up to explain to her that it's a nose hair clipper.  Things have progressed in 30 years from the days of brass clippers, with a number of manufacturers producing battery operated trimmers.  Most of them don't work terribly well, since if you end up being off at all, they pull and pinch.  And hurt.  A lot.The NT3155/60 has a big blurb on the box about how its trimmer doesn't do that.  Surprisingly, you can press it up into the nasal cavity, it'll slice off hair, and it doesn't pull it at all.  It can take a little while to do it with the single AA battery powering it, but that's fine.  Easy to clean as well, since you just toss it under some warm water.The eyebrow attachment is marginally useless; the trimmer just doesn't have enough power if you've got any sort of length, and a traditional blade trimmer plus comb is far more efficient even if you don't.  You can theoretically stick this into your ear canal and trim hair there too, but any physician worth their while would advise against putting stuff in your ears.4 stars.  Had expected to toss this, but it'll have a place in my grooming drawer.

Richard Rhodes' "Hell and Good Company" offers a different take on the Spanish Civil War.  Rather than delving into the political, social, or military aspects of the war, Rhodes provides an overview and then layers in some of the technological and medical advances along with a few cultural tales.  While many of these anecdotes are fascinating, the narrative would have been served by going into a bit more depth.  Even those quite familiar with the war will learn something, though, so 4 stars.Best known for the groundbreaking The Making of the Atomic Bomb and its sequels, Rhodes is one of the premier nonfiction and technical writers of his generation.  Among his gifts are the ability to make complex and densely layered subjects understandable to the lay reader while still satisfying the professional.  That type of writing requires significant primary source research, and in the case of the Spanish Civil War meant Rhodes turned to some of the writings by English speaking doctors, nurses, and writers.From that research, Rhodes can make an effective argument that the war shaped the world, or at least the next war, in a few areas.  Blood transfusion, storage, and several surgery techniques were largely refined during this period, and it is somewhat startling to see how far behind Spanish medicine was in comparison, particularly areas like disinfection and nursing.  The same goes for several military advances, and the author does make a good point on how the war introduced widespread civilian terror bombing to the Western world, along with the brutal practice of targeting medical providers.The rest of the military overview is a bit more spartan.  There are some interesting insights - most notably that the later truth that the republicans were badly outgunned was actually the opposite during the early part of the war thanks to Stalin's more modern weaponry - but in general this is an area in which additional depth would have helped significantly.  The numerous battles and fronts along with the oft-ignored Italian contribution are capably described albeit with great brevity, but the puzzling omission of maps in a book that at its base is about multiple military campaigns means readers will likely be lost more often than not.The political and social observations aren't quite as striking.  Hitler's motivations for aiding the nationalists are explored well (obtaining a base of supply of pyrites and distracting France and England while he rearmed Germany among them), but Stalin's goals are essentially absent, and the rancorous political debate outside Spain receives minimal coverage.  It's also a little disappointing to not see an author of Rhodes' talents at least attempt to untangle some of the confusing internecine struggles of left and right that drove large parts of the war, as those conflicts are still very much relevant even in 21st century Spain.  Rhodes does some exploration of how the war affected the work of Picasso and Miŕo, but much like the military overview readers familiar with the subject will likely be left wanting more.Like Rhodes' other works, this is extremely accessible and insightful where the author has interest, but unlike the rest of his writing it leaves the reader wanting more.  Still, it's worth a read.  4 stars.Disclosure: This impartial review was made possible by the publisher providing a copy of the ARC of this book.

Bad experience with this one, unfortunately.  Short review of the negatives:1. Never got -ac speeds with this; maxxed out around 180 MB/s, and did check to make sure adapter and router were properly set up.  Considering other USB adapter worked fine with -ac, unlikely it was on router or PC end.2. The clip that can potentially hold the adapter on the back of a laptop screen only works with an extremely narrow screen; a 1/4" one proved too large, so you'd need an extremely thin bezel to attach it.  This is a shame, because the adapter is close to 2" long and does stick out significantly if you attach it to the back of a laptop.3. After about a month of use, stopped working entirely and was returned.Second star is that it was a decent value for the money and it installed easily enough.  Others might have better luck as it's entirely possible this was defective from the get go, but I'd suggest spending $20-30 more for one of the higher rated adapters.

A few minutes ago, a blog post from the Wall Street Journal announced:"Amid a continuing uproar, the maker of TurboTax tax-preparation software said Thursday it would reverse changes in its products that forced some customers to pay more to prepare 2014 tax returns.Intuit plans to reverse the changes next year, and also said it would shield some customers from or compensate them for additional costs incurred this year."As a very long time user of Turbotax, it's about time.Will this permanently impair the product?  Hard to tell.  I can guarantee this, though: the series of disastrous decisions that led up to the reversal will likely be studied in B-School for decades to come, along with Intuit's attempts to regain their customer base.  We'll see, but their track record isn't exactly promising.

"American Sniper" has created a firestorm among viewers on both ends of the political spectrum.  Some will rank it 5 stars based on their views of the implied politics; others may rank it 1 for the stories it does not tell and the lack of subtlety in what it does.  My rank of 5 stars is based off of neither ideology nor its Oscar worthiness.  Instead, it is based off of how it addresses topics that will be very familiar to veterans - and deserves watching as a worthy entry point to those who aren't.A recent Washington Post wonkblog piece on successful war movies pulled up 36 since the late 1950s.  Many of those, however, have found lackluster support among active and retired service members and their families.  Fury, Inglorious Bastards, Hart's War, Behind Enemy Lines, Pearl Harbor and even Hurt Locker were movies that proved hits but rang hollow to those familiar with how the military actually works.In fact, of the 36 films listed, only 5 received generally good reviews from both veterans and critics:  Blackhawk Down, Bridge on the River Kwai, Full Metal Jacket, Das Boot, and Saving Private Ryan.  Of war movies that weren't part of the original 36, I would add We Were Soldiers and the the oft-ignored but successful Courage Under Fire.Include three great recent miniseries (Band of Brothers, Generation Kill, and the Pacific), save space for a few more movies that are a bit less universally praised (Platoon and Lone Survivor could fall in this group among several others), throw in some top down narratives (Patton, The Longest Day), and finally consider a couple great but limited release films like the tiny independent Fort Bliss and Taking Chance, the latter of which has received new life on Amazon Prime instant video.The math would suggest that even if this omits a few films and series, only 20 or perhaps 25 well reviewed and realistic military movies have been produced over the last 40-50 years.  I'd argue that this is a huge reason why American Sniper has been such a success, because it is a worthy addition to this list despite its numerous flaws in plot and character.What are those?  Some haven't been discussed much - at least one scene with the Marine Corps will likely irritate members of that service - but the ones that have been cited the most are that the Chris Kyle and the story he tells from the bestselling book are toned down, simplified, and cleaned up significantly.That brings up an an interesting point, as it's likely many of us wouldn't have much liked the real life Chief Kyle of the book and stories had we served with him.  Pretty much everyone who has been in invariably ran across his type at some point during their career.  They'd often described as just a bit too Hooah: cocky, a braggadocio, and someone who saw the world in black and white and could never be convinced that it might be otherwise - but who was also supremely talented in their skill set, and even if you couldn't stand their personality you'd respect them for it.The more complex Kyle isn't presented here, but part of the reason the movie works with even the stripped down version is that it brings home a truth of how the military has always been structured.  It wasn't that important to like or agree with someone and hang out with them or their teams.  What did matter is that you relied on them to do their job with the same competence that you did yours.  As long as you both respected that, the mission got done, and you could go home at the end of the day.  That was what mattered, and for most, always will.Beneath everything else here is that story of survival and its costs.  Much like the lead character, the plot doesn't explore subtleties, nor does the world it presents show up in shades of grey.  That part of the narrative ends up a fairly simple tale of us-versus-them, and in the hands of many directors and screenwriters could have been reduced to something awful like Red Dawn.Where Eastwood is to be commended is his enrichment of the story by bringing a complexity of a different sort to the film.  American Sniper presents viewers three critical aspects of military service which very few movies get right: that the generally accurate military culture in it is quite different than that in civilian life, that the effects of deployment in that culture means that life for spouses and dependents are dramatically affected in a way that most civilians aren't exposed to until they've seen a movie like this, and that the gap between the civilian and military world over the last three or four decades has grown tremendously and is extraordinarily concerning to anyone who has put on a uniform or lived with those who have.In other words, it succeeds in bringing up the big issues that service members deeply care about and that the rest of society outside of veterans doesn't usually want to discuss.  Despite its flaws, getting that part right during a very watchable film makes this at least a good movie, if not a great one.  As such, it's one that should be seen by as many Americans who want to begin to gain some understanding of the issues that concern every member of the military today, regardless of their political affiliation or their view on the Iraq and Afghanistan wars.Finally, what's been lost here is there's some irony in the debate over whether or not this is high art and if it deserves Oscars.  In the end, where it ranks among the best films of the year isn't as relevant as that it qualifies as one of the most important.  That's why it's worth a watch or purchase.  5 stars.

Bruce Hoffman's "Anonymous Soldiers" is an worthwhile analysis of the terror operations undertaken by Jewish partisans and the corresponding countermeasures by the British prior to their withdrawal in 1948.  In short, Hoffman concludes that terrorism worked to effectively undermine British control and effectively spread their targeted message well beyond the confines of Palestine.  The book bogs down as it gets into the minutiae of the 1944-1947 period, though, and and probably will turn off readers looking for a more general history on the region.  However, this will still likely serve as a reference for those looking to understand what was the most politically effective terror campaign in history and will be a staple on academic reading lists for some time to come.  4 stars.There's been a lot of history written on Israel's birth, but the British role in administering the Mandate has not received as much attention, partially because documentation of that side of the struggle was locked away for 50 years.  Having finally received access to the British archives, "Anonymous Soldiers" - the title comes from a partisan poem - recounts a more balanced view of the struggles than in the past.The first 150 pages tell the story of the Mandate from 1917 to 1944, and there are some startling revelations thanks to the newly uncovered British records.  Besides immigration quotas being unfilled in the early years before they were lowered in an attempt to appease the Arab population, a remarkable statistic is that between 1927 and 1929 Jewish emigration from Palestine actually exceeded immigration.  The story of the Arab revolts starting with the incident at the Western Wall in 1929 is well known, but the narrative would have been helped by some explanation of the history of just how the British ended up with the mess of the Mandate in the first place.  A more generally oriented book like Lawrence in Arabia is almost essential reading to understand how the situation evolved, and important topics like the initial attempts to partition Palestine by the British (not to mention the complex internecine politics of the era) are barely addressed.Once he gets to 1944, though, Hoffman slows down and spends the remaining 350 or pages of the book going through the intricate details of Jewish partisan operations - mainly Irgun, which generally targeted property and the smaller Lehi, which conducted assassinations, with the Haganah largely being left out of the narrative - and the inept British response.  Hoffman deconstructs many of the myths of the terror campaign, and one in particular, the bombing of the King David hotel by Irgun, is done in such a way that advocates for the traditional narrative will find themselves squirming.On the British side, what jumps out is just how underfunded and understaffed the police force and the military were for most of the Mandate until the very end when it did little good.  10% of the entire British army and 3% of the budget (a remarkable 1 solider for every 18 residents and 20 for every one of the estimated terrorists) proved remarkably ineffective by the time Britain finally attempted a more robust but ultimately futile response.  Just as interesting is the role of international pressure on the British, especially from Americans.  Most discussion of America and Israel starts in 1948 with Truman's decision to recognize the nascent state, but Hoffman provides some valuable context in the immense financial and political pressure brought to bear prior to that; among other things, examining the 1944-1947 period explains Marshall's position far more thoroughly than has been done by other historians.Despite the flaws, this will be the reference guide on the subject for years, and it's no coincidence that a copy of Begin's history of Irgun, The Revolt was found on the shelf of an Al-Qaeda training facility in Afghanistan in 2001.  4 stars.

Richard Price's "The Whites" is an engaging, deep, and complex tale of seriously flawed characters careening from one tragedy to another in a New York far more reminiscent of the 1990s than today.  While it takes a while to figure out where the author is taking the main plot, it's offset by a marvelous job of slowly dribbling out the secrets that drive the characters.  The one weakness here is the mess of too many supporting characters driving subplots that ultimately do nothing for the conclusion, but this is still largely worthy of the buzz.  4 stars.After his previous novels and writing for The Wire, Richard Price doesn't really need to prove that he could write an intricate procedural, let alone under a sort-of-but-not pen name.  (In a recent interview, the author provided a more practical reason: he had contractual obligations to Farrar Straus under his real name.)  The blurbs for this book are from some of the top writers around, largely because Price has created many professional fans by showing he knows how to write deep characters and how they interact with the gritty world around them.That's what he does here.  The main plot takes a while to get going as he builds up one supporting character after another, but a good hint is the title.  "Whites" refers to the most egregious murder suspect a cop could never bust, and the members of the old Wild Geese anti-crime unit each have one.  Now disbanded with most members off the force, the unit's history (and the history of other characters) begin to encroach on their current lives.This is a bit of a hard book to characterize.  It's not a cop thriller, nor a psychological study, nor a tragedy.  It's probably best described as a book about how damaged people - some with badges, some without - deal with an imperfect world.  What makes the book a challenge at times is these aren't characters for whom you'll wholeheartedly root; they've all done some pretty sketchy things, and there's no moral compass besides survival and, for some, trying not to do worse than they already have.  One note is that thanks to the focus on past events, this feels much more like the gritty New York of the early 1990s than today.  Most of the characters from Girls would run screaming to Long Island or New Jersey after encountering a chapter or two of the world here, but drop in someone from Homicide and they'd feel right at home despite being a few hundred miles up the coast and 20 years out of date.The one drawback is that Price's love of secondary characters is at times a drag.  He can't be content to draw brief outlines, which slows pacing.  In one longer arc, this results in a subplot that really doesn't have much purpose besides stalling out things while the main plot meanders to catch up.  Better editing could have eliminated this and probably made this a 5 star read, but it's still a cut above most procedurals.  4 stars.

The Linksys WRT1900AC Dual Band router is a high end router that lives up to much of the potential of the 802.11ac standard.  It's got great speed at very good range, which is the entire reason to purchase it.  It does miss on a few fronts - some of the options in the software are problematic - but it's really one of the first routers that shows what 802.11ac can do.  4 stars.For those unfamiliar with it, 802.11ac is a fairly new standard - keep in mind that you will likely have to buy a $50+ USB adapter for most pre-2014 devices - that offers substantially better range and somewhat better throughput in the 5 GHz range, where dual band routers really are worth the money.  The problem with previous generation 5 GHz routers is that they offer fantastic speed within 25-30 feet of the router and drop off massively the farther out you get.That's not the case with the WRT1900AC.  As expected, within 10 feet of the router this was good, topping 250 MB/s.  But a good 50' away from the router, through two walls, this did far better than expected, coming in over 100 MB/s, well ahead of the two other -ac routers I have tested.  There are some other neat features, like being able to name your own guest networks, but the best of them is that the USB 3.0 and combo ESATA/USB 2.0 adapters are genuinely fast - 65 MB/s write, 80 MB/s read - which means this actually is worth considering as an inexpensive NAS server with a couple of cheap hard drives attached.What's not as helpful is the firmware.  The biggest issue is that there are too few options for a high end device; you can't, for instance, play with the channel widths, which matter a lot if you're in an area that has a whole bunch of other routers.  More annoying is that you can't configure this for OpenVPN, and most aggravating of all is that the main workaround for dealing with locked down firmware - flashing this with OpenWRT - seems to be made rather difficult by Linksys.Still, it's a worthy high end router, if a bit expensive.  4 stars.

The HP 8 1401 is an 8" budget tablet that shows the penny pinching with a feature set that's straight out of 2010.  At this price point, you're better off buying any number of other tablets that are more capable.  2 stars.Leave it to HP to enter the 8" tablet market while other manufacturers - Lenovo for one - are exiting it because demand just isn't there, but the 1401 is HP's budget entry that isn't much of a bargain even compared to HP's other products.  The $10 more expensive 7" HP S7-4200US has a better Tegra 3.0 processor, a 1280x800 screen, and a 5 MP rear camera versus the 1401's dated 2 MP.  At 8", the $60 more expensive Slate 8 Pro has a very crisp 1600x1200 screen, a much better Tegra 4.0 processor, an 8 MP rear camera, and a battery that holds nearly a 50% higher charge.That's not to say this isn't somewhat capable.  In use, apps ran relatively well thanks to the quad core processor, although by using the older Jelly Bean instead of Kit Kat there was one that crashed repeatedly.  Battery life under light use was 8 hours, but with normal use ran only about 6, unsurprising with the smaller battery here.  The biggest drawback is the 1024x768 screen, which is relatively crisp but is just too low resolution for this size. The similarly sized IPad Mini has precisely double the resolution of this, and while bright and responsive, apps and video just don't look right when you're accustomed to more modern screens.Besides the HP products mentioned, the identically priced Asus MeMo Pad 7 has a 1280x800 screen and a faster Intel Atom processor, and for $50 more you can get the 8" version.  If you don't mind hacking a bit and still being largely locked down, as of this writing the Kindle Fire 7" is $20 cheaper but with a far more capable processor, much better 1280x800 screen, and significant content.  Finally, the refurbished 9" Nook HD+ is now actually cheaper but has one of the best 1920x1080 screens on the market even almost 2 years after release.  Try all those instead of this model.2 stars.  If this were 2010 this would be a bargain, but it's about 4 years too late.

Mr. Clean Liquid Muscle all purpose cleaner is a run of the mill concentrated cleaner.  It works well in concentrated form on areas that are heavily soiled, and otherwise works ok when diluted as intended.Why 3 stars?First, some people may find the Gain scent can be a little bit much.  It's not that strong, but it's definitely noticeable.Second, however, is the pricing.  For 30 ounces of this, you pay more than for 128 ounces of Simple Green.  That's not a particularly good value, even if you like the scent.3 stars.  It does the job fine, just expensively.

ANSI/ISEA Z308.1-2009 sets a minimum standard for first aid kits, and PhysiciansCare has made a marketing campaign out of products that nominally meet those standards.  Unfortunately, while this kit may comply with the bare minimum of those standards, it misses the "optional" material that anyone trained in emergency response would deem a necessity.  2 stars.Essentially, ANSI's standard requires a first aid kit to contain a number of bandages, an antiseptic, a burn treatment, a first aid guide, and exam gloves.  That's more or less what's in here."Optional" items include:Analgesic (should contain no ingredients that are known to cause drowsiness)Bandage compress(es) in sizes 2 in. x 2 in. (5 cm. x 5 cm.), 3 in. x 3 in. (7.5 cm. x 7.5 cm.) or 4 in. x 4 in. (10 cm. x 10 cm.)Breathing barrier for cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)Burn dressing(s) at least 12 sq. in. (77.4 cm.2)Cold pack(s) at least 4 in. x 5 in. (10 x 12.5 cm.)Eye covering(s)5Eye/skin wash, 4 fl. oz. (15 ml)6,7Hand sanitizer with a minimum of 61 percent ethyl alcoholRoller bandage(s) at least 2 in. (5 cm.) wide and at least 4 yd. (365 cm.) long, unstretched and individually packagedWhat's included from this optional list are 1 ounce of eyewash instead of the 4 ounces recommended - if you're flushing eyes, you definitely will need more than an ounce - a cold pack, and scissors.  That's it.Not including a $0.25 breathing barrier for CPR is something that is simply unbelievable in a kit like this.  Almost everyone who has ever taken EMT training carries one around with them.  It's small, cheap, and simple to use - and something that should have been included, despite the newer recommendations on untrained individuals doing chest compressions first.2 stars.  You can add some items to this to make it a worthwhile first aid kit, but you shouldn't have to.

Hampton Sides' "In the Kingdom of Ice" tells three tales.  First is a portrait of the two men behind the journey, and the second is the confluence of both events and the Gilded Age that made such a folly not just possible but inevitable.  While worthwhile, Sides meanders a bit with those two, but moves from interesting to gripping when coming to the long-forgotten and disastrous journey by the Jeanette to find the mythical North Pole of legend.  The combination of all three stories is a solid read.  4 stars.The late 19th century and early 20th century's obsession with getting to the Poles is one of those cultural phenomenons that seems both archaic and even for the time, rather strange.  Most modern readers will know about it tangentially from the setup to Lansing's story of Shackleton, Endurance, but starting in the 1870s, there was a 40 year period where an astounding amount of treasure and lives were lost in pursuit of it.  More than anything else, "In the Kingdom of the Ice" details exactly how the beginnings of this folly started.The thinking behind why one needed to go to the Poles were outright bizarre, with some roots in mythology.  The Greeks proposed the eternal spring of Hyperborea, the Vikings a drainage pool called Ultima Thule, Jules Verne popularized the myth of a hollow earth with a warm vent in the Arctic in Journey to the Center of the Earth, and a number of psuedo- and real scientists somehow thought there might be a warm water sea at each Pole.With eight countries either proposing or running expeditions, the post-Civil War United States was ripe to join them, and the confluence of events that prompted this is the focus of two parts of the tale here.  The new technology and culture of the Gilded Age meant the United States had to make the trip or be left behind.  One driving force behind this was a young naval officer, George Washington De Long, looking to get back to the Arctic after an unsuccessful journey, make a name for himself in history, and almost as importantly, beat the Army before they could mount an expedition.  The second was the incredibly and eccentric wealthy New York Herald owner James Gordon, who both liked boats and simply wanted to sell more papers with stories either real or fabricated.  The third was the world's leading cartographer, August Petermann, who despite all evidence to the contrary from his armchair was convinced a trip to the North Pole would be not just worthwhile but easy - and in a variety of ways, more than anyone else contributed to the disaster.The result of all this was command by De Long of the USS Jeannette, a converted yacht that was well equipped for the disaster of the journey north.  The Jeanette ran into some simply astounding bad luck - had certain events transpired only a few weeks earlier, for instance, the crew would have been far better informed as to what they were about to run into - but to discuss the journey in detail would be to ruin the story here.  About the only reveal that isn't a spoiler is that a major naval award is named after a prominent crewmember, and that naming is well deserved.Suffice it to say, though, that Shackleton at least had an idea of what awaited him.  De Long and the rest of the crew of the Jeanette didn't until far too late on their voyage, and their journey marked the end of the Open Polar Sea myth.4 stars.  A worthwhile remembrance of a forgotten folly.

Epson's VS330 isn't a bad projector for business use and is really aimed at  slideshow presentations.  It's lacking a couple of things that imply some cheapness in the manufacturing process, though, and there are both better resolution models that don't omit those features and ultraportable models from other manufacturers available at its price point.  3 stars.The "VS" denotes Epson's "Value Series", and there are definite design decisions here that reflect that.  The lack of 3D, some connectivity options and no carrying case aren't terrifically important but do imply some corners being cut.  What is more significant is the sound issues here, with a 1W speaker, a 37 db fan that sounds louder and can overwhelm the speaker, and the baffling lack of an audio output line.  All of these would have been extremely cheap to correct, and in practice almost entirely eliminates this for watching video except for short stints.Thus, this is basically a slideshow projector for business use, and it's fine for it.  The image quality is ok but not spectacular, with colors being bright but with a slight bit of tinting.  It's not awful by any means, but is more or less what you should expect from a lower cost projector.  2700 lumens does mean this will work in less than fully dark rooms, but the nominal rating of 25' from screen is a bit much; this is best used somewhere around 8-10'.While it's a decent enough business projector, the real issue is what else is available at this price point.  If you're looking for a portable business projector, the ViewSonic PJD5533W is a better value.  Video quality is roughly similar (not awful, not spectacular) but offers 1280x720 resolution versus the VS330's 1024x768, which tends to help perceived video quality significantly if your source is originally in 16:9 or 10 format versus 4:3.  The speaker is only slightly better (2W), but it does have an audio output, is a full pound lighter, and even includes 3D capability.If you're looking for a truly portable business projector, there have been a number of pricey ultraportables that have come out over the last year or two.  However, Infocus has just released two new LED projectors, the Infocus IN1142 and InFocus IN1146, that are priced almost identically to the VS line.  Like most LED projectors, they're significantly dimmer at 700 and 1000 lumens respectively.  However, at under 2 lbs, if you're traveling a lot they make a lot more sense than the VS330.All that said, this isn't a bad projector.  It's just that the competition has surpassed it, and while it's inexpensive the value isn't compelling at this point. 3 stars.

"The Zhivago Affair" is an unusual book, combining a literary biography with elements of a political thriller.  Using extensive archival research, Washington Post national security editor Peter Finn and writer/translator Petra Couvee have produced what is best described as a robust biography of Doctor Zhivago author Boris Pasternak along with a vivid description of the intrigue unintentionally launched by the book.  While much of the buzz on the book focuses on new revelations on the CIA's involvement, the far meatier part is an examination of the intense pressure put on Pasternak by the Soviet government.  A star off for not following a couple of trails that would have made this a truly gripping book leave this at 4 stars.There had been rumors for years regarding whether or not the political storm raised by Doctor Zhivago had been fueled for political purposes.  In 1999, Petra Couvee received the first semi-official acknowledgment that there had been some tricks played, namely that the Dutch intelligence service had been involved in printing the book.  In 2007, Peter Finn wrote an article on the first major attempt to tie in the CIA to the book.  Ivan Tolstoy's "The Laundered Novel", a Russian language monograph, apparently claimed the CIA was behind the Nobel Prize campaign and speculated on a number of other Cold War contributions.  Becoming fascinated, Finn went to work on getting relevant material declassified and working his intelligence sources, and with an introduction to Couvee began the book.The result ends up really being more of a story about Pasternak and his incredible naivety than it is about the CIA.  Pasternak was one of the very few intellectuals that had been spared in Stalin's purges - Stalin apparently liked his poetry and told the KGB to lay off him as his "head was in the clouds" - and as a result, somehow didn't foresee any problem writing a book that could easily be taken as a direct challenge to the 1917 Revolution.  Unable to get the book published in the Soviet Union, Pasternak began trying to get it published in the West with varying success.Meanwhile, in 1956 the CIA had started a program (quite literally, a publishing house) to get Western books into the hands of Soviet citizens.  In 1957 a British MI6 officer purloined a copy of the manuscript, and a year later the CIA decided it wanted to publish the book for Russian consumption.  Having been warned against showing any sort of direct involvement, the Agency went through a series of elaborate maneuvers to publish a Russian edition for the 1958's World's Fair in Belgium.  After one disastrous attempt involving an American who tried to steal the book and print it in the United States for his own profit, with the help of the Dutch intelligence service the CIA eventually settled on an anti-communist Dutch group to publish around 1000 copies.The timing was propitious.  Without the CIA's involvement, Pasternak had won the Nobel Prize for literature.  The resulting storm is the focus of the rest of the book, where the full weight of the Soviet state fell on Pasternak for a book that almost none of them had read.  (Indeed, when Khrushchev eventually did so, he wondered why it had raised such a fuss.)  One of the great mysteries not really answered by the book is why Pasternak didn't pursue the opportunity he was given to leave Russia; had he done so, he would have been a very wealthy man and his family would have been away from the harassment that continued after his early death from cancer in 1960.All this is worth a read, but what's a bit unsatisfying about the book is that it doesn't pursue two of the most interesting aspects of the story: what else did the CIA do in the cultural Cold War if it published a million books in fifteen years, and what happened to the money?  Zhivago apparently made a number of people a fortune, but the author wasn't among them and about the only reference made to this is a brief comment about long standing litigation by the author's heirs.  Perhaps it is a dry tale full of lawyers, but one suspects that the untold story of how Zhivago's publishers got away with it might have been a compelling tale and certainly was worth a chapter to end the book.4 stars.  Not quite a Cold War thriller, but worth a read.

"Cyador's Heirs" consists of a young protagonist tale that L.E. Modesitt has told many times before in his Saga of Recluce.  It's neither original nor awful; mostly, it's like welcoming back an old friend who regales you with a good yarn for the umpteenth and perhaps once-too-many time. It's probably best enjoyed by those who already have a significant investment in the series.  3.5 stars rounded up to 4 for sentimentality."Cyador's Heirs" marks Modesitt's 17th entry in the Saga of Recluce.  It is his first since 2010's Arms-Commander and as the first of two planned volumes marks the first time since 2007's Natural Ordermage and 2008's Mage-Guard of Hamor that he has written extensively in this world.While Modesitt had largely exhausted the "young ethical mage from a well placed family grows into his powers and becomes the most powerful wielder of magic and a competent military commander while crushing enemies foreign and domestic despite a peaceful outlook on life while paying a price for their actions" template years back, what made the last three books palatable were their departures from this formula.  A mature feminist protagonist fighting a brutally patriarchal society provided a significant twist to Arms-Commander, and a less well birthed and strongly flawed hero attempting to overcome his mistakes and survive in a brutal environment made Natural Ordermage one of the top books in the series.Cyador's Heirs doesn't have that.  What it does have is a second-in-line to a throne who learns about his powers, gets some guidance from a tutor in magic and a tutor in military affairs, learns about politics, gets thrown into a big military conflict, and learns how to command troops and grow his powers without killing himself.The nominal twist here is minor: watching exiles from an advanced civilization try to cling on to some of the remaining remnants of it.  This makes for at least a few interesting moments, as thanks to previous entries in the series the reader will know more about that civilization than do the characters.  It's also been long enough since Modesitt has used the original template so that it's not as numbingly repetitive as it was when he wrote one of these every year, and it's not the worst of the series by any means.That said, Recluce fans will probably enjoy this rewrite of a story that Modesitt has told many times before, but the Imager series provides a more creative take on this motif than do most of the later Recluce books. Those not deeply invested in this series will likely enjoy the first few Imager books more.3.5 stars rounded up to 4, mostly because it's good to see more of the interesting world that Modesitt created 25 years ago even if his most recent entry is of middling quality.  It's nice to be back in Recluce, but given Modesitt has previously demonstrated he's capable of breathing new life into an old series, it's probably fair to have hoped for something more original here.

The Seagate Backup Plus series really is an improvement over Seagate's previous models, with the most helpful aspect being casing that ventilates a bit better.  The software is nothing special, but the drives have been reliable and fast.  4 stars.Having used previous Backup Plus models in 1, 2, and 3 TB sizing, the 4 TB version is more or less identical, with the internal drive being slightly faster - 145MB read/write on average, versus the mid to high 130s for the 3 TB model.  This also has a 64 MB cache, which on sustained transfers doesn't help but on smaller read/writes should.The major differences between this and the previous Backup Plus model is slightly better ventilation and a solid case rather than a removable and swappable interface.  This latter change isn't entirely welcome, since one of the nice benefits of the removable interface was to be able to hook up bare drives to a USB 3.0 port along with the option of hooking up a drive to a Firewire connector if required.As is the norm for Seagate, the software is nothing special; you're better off just backing up things wholesale.The only difference between the PC and Mac versions is the packaging and drive formatting; the PC comes in black, the Mac in grey.  Unsurprisingly, the Mac version sells at a premium that has nothing to do with the costs of the product ($10-15 as of this writing) so with even minimal computer knowledge you're better off spending 15 minutes of your time buying the cheaper model and reformatting.4 stars.  It's a solid backup drive.

The Presonus Eris E4.5 monitors are remarkable little speakers with great imaging and outstanding response for their size.  About the only drawback to them is that if used as intended - which is to be attached to a computer - they are actually too good for much of the source material that you'll be using.  5 stars.Presonus is known within the electronic music industry for pretty much everything you'd attach to a computer to make music - recording systems, mixers, software, and controllers.  The Eris, Sceptre and Temblor series marks their first foray into studio monitors.  It's a bit of a misnomer to call the Eris 4.5 their lowest end monitor, with a more proper description being that it's designed to be used with a variety of equipment.  One example: the 4.5 is the only one of their monitors that has a 1/8" jack for easy connection to a standalone MP3 player.Having used Magneplanar and Dahlquists, these are not quite in their imaging range but rather remarkable for a small set of computer speakers and far above what you'll find with other brands.  The 25 W goes a long way here.  Rated to 70 Hz, these are probably best paired with a subwoofer as they do have a low cut option below 80 or 100 Hz, and even a generic powered one helps; the PreSonus Temblor T10 is probably overkill.The only downside here is that these are good enough so that they will reveal source material limitations.  You're not going to want to listen to MP3s through them unless they're at least 320 kbps, and you will become very aware of the audio encoding on streaming material.  That's more a function of finally putting good speakers on a computer rather than a hit against the speakers themselves.  5 stars.

The Acer C720 is really one of the first fully functional Chromebooks, where it achieves about 90% of what users need out of a laptop.  With significant hardware upgrades over previous models, it's probably not going to be your primary PC, but it does a better job than its major competition - tablets - at a far superior price.  A star off for a bit of hardware lockdown leaves this at 4 stars.There's been a lot written about the Acer C720 and Chromebooks.  The best advice that doesn't seem to be commonplace but is common sense is that you can and should try Google's applications first via another platform.  If you can stand them, they will be your primary software on the Chromebook.  For instance, Google Drive's word processor and spreadsheet are very impressive for a free cloud based app, but those with more complicated work will soon recognize they're still a bit raw in places - especially if you're used to Word or Excel.  The biggest drawback is actually printing, as USB printing is basically a no-go on Chrome with virtually no drivers; you're stuck with cloud based printing instead.If you can get past this, then the Chromebook is priced competitively for what it offers: Haswell architecture for really nifty battery life (stated 8 hours, but I've seen it run up to 10), a 16 GB SSD for offline storage, and a 1366x768 screen that isn't spectacular - especially in the days of 1920x1080 tablets - but isn't mediocre either.  Best uses of this include streaming videos from the web to a TV (it handles 1080p quite well, and has an HDMI port) along with plenty of web browsing.  Battery life and lightness here - it's really not much heavier than a tablet at under 3 lbs - makes this more or less a perfect laptop to bring along to a coffee shop for light work or play.  Fortunately, Chrome does have VPN support built in for insecure Wifi connections, although it doesn't support SSL VPN.Being priced like a smartphone or locked down tablet like the Kindle or Nook, the true value here may be to hack this and install Linux - specifically the Crouton distribution - for far superior functionality, with easy dual boot capability.  A few caveats, though.  First, you'll probably want to upgrade the hardware as while Linux will run on a 16 GB drive and 2 GB RAM, you'll feel massively limited especially with storage.  Unfortunately, it's not that easy to get into the machine, and doing so will void your warranty.Second, even if you do get into the machine, the RAM is soldered in and can't be replaced.  Moreover, the SSD can be replaced but uses the new NGFF form factor, which means that it's smaller than even an mSATA card and largely unavailable.  The good news is that there is one NGFF SSD available on Amazon - the My Digital SSD - and people have had success putting it in the C720 and dual booting.  You can also add an external hard drive, but a mechanical drive will definitely limit your battery life.Just keep in mind, thought, that once you spend to upgrade this, you're looking at a $300+ laptop - in which case, you're probably better off buying a used laptop of your choice for more juice.  However, if you've got a 128 GB drive and Linux installed on the C720, it's quite functional.Hence, for $199 or even $299 with an upgraded SSD, not the worst deal in the world, especially compared to tablets around this price.  Basically, you're trading the screen of a tablet for significantly better hardware and a keyboard.  4 stars.

Jack Cheevers' "Act of War" is an important entry in naval and intelligence history: a careful examination of the leadup to, capture of, and aftermath of the USS Pueblo incident in 1968.  A star off for a couple of aspects that could have used a bit more coverage leaves this at 4 stars, but still a highly recommended read.While it has been nearly forgotten now outside of North (and, to a lesser extent South) Korea, the seizure of the USS Pueblo was one of the more traumatic incidents in one of the worst years of American history, 1968.  Sailing in international waters, the Pueblo was captured by North Korea in a brazen violation of international law that essentially was an act of war.  The resulting imprisonment and torture of her crew was horrific; the intelligence loss devastating, and the blow to the projection of American power essentially equivalent to the effects of the similarly timed and far better remembered Tet offensive.Cheevers deserves significant praise for his reconstruction of the causes of the incident, beginning with the horribly planned mission and marginal equipment, continuing with the lack of promised support, and finishing with the ineptness of any coordination by the Navy with the Pueblo, including failing to tell the Pueblo of the (even more) forgotten and massively dangerous situation on the ground, where the North had sent in a hit squad to assassinate South Korea's president.Cheevers' detailing of the torture the crew of the Pueblo is difficult reading along with the American efforts (or lack thereof) to get the crew rescued, although in fairness, the North Koreans were not at all interested in releasing the crew until they got what they wanted, which was a perceived humiliation of the United States.  The followup to the crew's release is also interesting, with only a politically savvy Secretary of the Navy saving his service from further damage to itself after much of the utterly stupid command decisions were revealed while the brass attempted to put full blame on Commander Bucher.Why 4 stars rather than 5?  It's mostly because Cheevers gets close to writing the definitive account of the incident but misses on a few fronts, notwithstanding his attempt to get a North Korean commentary that wouldn't have provided much value.First, while his linking of the Tet offensive and the Pueblo is valuable, Cheevers essentially drops the Vietnam side of the equation in the American response; there is very little exploration of military recommendations and strengths at the time as it related to the chaotic situation in Vietnam.  Second, while it is eyeopening to see just how worried the United States was about South Korea looking for an excuse to go to war with the North in 1968, Cheevers doesn't seem to have incorporated much of the South Korean perspective.Finally, Cheevers could use a professional military perspective in his analysis, particularly when it comes to Bucher.  It is hard not to admire the man for his outstanding conduct as a POW, and in fairness, much, if not most, of criticism of Bucher seems wrong.  Bucher was handed a ship that really wasn't ready to undertake a mission that was disastrously planned, when he was attacked he couldn't have put up much of a fight, and his treatment by many of his fellow Naval officers and command following his release was rather awful.That said, though, Bucher made a number of serious command mistakes prior to the capture that Cheevers given his non-military background doesn't follow up on, most notably in not preparing for a worst case scenario of having to scuttle his ship.  Even with the Navy's negligence in preparing and supporting the Pueblo, Bucher could have likely mitigated the disastrous intelligence damage with a little preparation, creativity, and drills.  That perspective - along with an explanation of the career suicide Cheevers would have faced for refusing to get the Pueblo underway until it was prepared - would have been valuable, and it is very difficult to believe that there's not been at least some helpful professional military literature written on the subject.Still, this is an important book on something that hasn't received nearly enough attention. 4 stars, and worth a read.

Brian Staveley's "The Emperor's Blades" is a solid debut fantasy.  It's action filled, has an interesting world, and enough plot twists to be worth a read.  It does seem to tick off every standard requirement to write a fantasy novel, though, and between that and a bit of uneven plot distribution one star off.  4 stars total, and it's promising enough that the inevitable sequels should improve as Staveley hones his craft.It's refreshing to have many newcomers in fantasy using George R. R. Martin's template for a world; people trying for power in a screwed up world makes far more interesting reading than princesses, knights, and wizards.  "The Emperor's Blades" follows that path, with a dead king, conspiracies galore, an ancient and modern danger, and three heirs discovering that the rich world in which they live in is not quite what they had anticipated.Other reviewers have focused on the plot and the characters; in summary, it's not bad.  The problem is that it feels a bit like Staveley had a list of boxes to check for Martinesque fantasy plot inclusion, which makes things a bit more formulaic.  Ancient evil?  Check.  Eastern-style monks who know about this evil and all sorts of lore?  Check.  Generic megalomaniac jerk characters as antagonists?  Check.  Brutal training that doesn't exactly fit well in the world's structure?  Check.  Ambiguous gender roles in a semi medieval world?  Check.  Likeable sidekicks?  Check.This isn't to say "The Emperor's Blades" is bad fantasy at all; it's just that it's less original than something like The Name of the Wind, which used most of the above checkboxes but in a much more creative fashion.  As far as plot, the only major weakness in the writing is the third point of view character, Princess Adele, who receives far less stage time than her brother - although despite her limited participation, she's still responsible for a major revelation that provides more to plot advancement than several hundred pages from her brothers.With more experience, there's promise that Staveley will up his game a bit in the inevitable sequels.  Worth a read, and 4 stars.

Con Coughlin's "Churchill's First War" brings a little covered area of the vastly mined life of Churchill to light: his brief sojourn in British India as a junior Army officer, and a nasty campaign in today's Afghanistan to introduce him to war being less glorious than he'd thought.  4 stars.Churchill has probably received more biography (including his own!) than any leader save Lincoln, and as such most of his life is well covered.  Coughlin takes an interesting approach, however, in focusing distinctly on his very first posting and engagement, which both Churchill and his biographers tend to skip.  Essentially, needing money to pay for his cavalry ambitions, Churchill began his writing career as a foreign war correspondent in Cuba.  Through mining an awful lot of family connections, he managed to be posted to British India.  Through more connections, ended up as a colorful war correspondent and volunteer junior officer dispatched to Malakand for what turned out to be a brutal six week campaign against the forebears of the Taliban.Given the short length of the posting, the focus is partially on a couple very specific battles - Churchill could have easily been killed - but mostly on the parallels of the problems Western forces have faced over the last decade in the exact same region.  Nothing much has changed there in over 100 years, and Coughlin makes a compelling point about the careless demarcation of Indian and Afghani territory slicing directly through tribal lines (largely for static defense purposes that were never needed) as a direct source of the conflict.As such, this is more a book about the region than it is about Churchill, but still worth a read.  4 stars.

Jane Ridley's "The Heir Apparent" is the definitive work on Edward VII.  Meticulously researched with vast access to primary materials that have never before seen the light of day, this does two things that every biographer wishes.  First, it redefines the subject and will likely serve as the stand alone book on him for decades to come, and second, it is academic writing that is equally gripping as a novel.  5 stars.Edward VII's place in British history is controversial.  He was certainly a product of the peak of the wanton Gilded Age: a womanizer who serially seduced other men's wives, a spendthrift who cared nothing about bankrupting his friends through his demands on them when he would visit (his hunting forays were simply extraordinary), and for the first 50 years of his life, someone who contributed very little to the world besides being at the peak of society as a playboy.  This view wasn't helped by his numerous political enemies following his death; his contributions were dramatically rewritten, and his playboy tendencies offset his reign.Ridley began the book aligned with the general consensus on "Bertie" as she calls him, but through lengthy and often incredibly difficult research - the work of finding letters back and forth between the various players in foreign, uncatalogued sources is jawdropping, along with decoding his appointment book - she reaches a different and compelling conclusion.  Edward wasn't much as a heir to the throne, but once on it, he was a surprisingly effective and popular monarch.Other reviewers have covered many of the topics raised by Ridley in the book, but there are a few that remain that are noteworthy.  First, Victoria comes across as simply insane: marrying a domineering man, venerating his memory as a saint, becoming involved with other men who surpassed Albert's model of abusiveness, and generally having what could be only called as a disastrous effect on the throne when she interfered with her ministers.
