Second, Edward VII was the last British monarch to exercise real political power (of which he gave up plenty during his reign to ministers who often fought him tooth and nail), but the source of that power is fascinating given Ridley's portrait of Victoria.Bertie's power in foreign relations - the Entente Cordiale prime among them - came from continental Europe's misunderstanding of his power at home, where monarchs there actually did have real political power and where Bertie, in turn, simply acted like he did when he'd go overseas and then ministers at home would have to figure out how to merge his actions with their own goals.  Ultimately, Victoria's pet project of marrying off relations to improve foreign relations failed miserably, but the 10 years of Edward VII's reign were as close as she ever got.The only caveat is that it's recommended to read something like MacMillan's The War That Ended Peace to provide appropriate background to the complex world of European relations; given Ridley's focus on Edward, many of the other players make far more sense with a bit more detail.5 stars.  A truly definitive book.

Howard Blum's "Dark Invasion" brings to light a long lost series of attacks by Imperial Germany on the US during World War I, most notably a series of bombings and an anthrax poisoning.  A half star off for slightly breezy writing and another half star off for skipping a proper conclusion leaves this at 4 stars.While there's a plethora of books coming out to mark the 100th anniversary of World War I, "Dark Invasion" covers a niche that has largely been lost to history's dustbin: the covert operations of Germany against the United States prior to 1917.  Remarkably, despite having the largest spy network in the world, in 1914 Germany had all of one agent in the United States.  Through a crash course of recruiting, Germany's patched-together network proved remarkably able to create havoc well beyond their weight over the next two years.Blum's focus is on the men who conducted these operations along with Tom Tunney, the head of the NYPD bomb squad, whose agency was responsible for the vast majority of captures.  Of note are a Harvard professor who murdered his wife, escaped to find a new identity, and then bombed the US Capitol and nearly killed JP Morgan (whose financiering saved the Allies), a devilishly clever chemical cigar fire bomb that, thanks to non German allies, sunk innumerable transport ships, and a largely unknown anthrax attack designed to kill horses that appears to have killed quite a few people.  Tunney's work is remarkable, especially given the jurisdictional limitations that faced him through working for the NYPD versus the federal government; an interesting point is that Wilson was made well aware of the intelligence on the German spy network but that it did not appear to factor into his decisions.Three quibbles.  First, Blum uses on a breezy writing style that seems more appropriate for the movie to come.  Second, there is almost no original research here as Blum is reliant on the numerous literature about covert German activities that appeared at the end of World War I and were promptly forgotten.  (One of the greatest financial disasters in movie history at the time, for instance, was the 10 hour "The Eagle's Eye" which covers much of the material in Dark Invasion.)  Finally, and most frustrating of all, Blum concludes the book without a chapter on the fates of the various players here.Still, a decent read on the first terrorist attacks on the United States.  4 stars.

The Oral-B Precision 7000 is a great toothbrush.  Unfortunately, there is almost nothing to justify a $60 price differential between this and the previous generation Oral-B Professional Precision 5000 and current generation Triaction 5000 besides being priced 50% above those models.  3 stars.Oral-B makes very good toothbrushes, and it's worth getting one.  Unfortunately, their marketing leaves something to be desired; usually, you end up having some neater features on the higher end models.  That's not the case here.  About the only real advantage this may have over the lower end models is (supposedly) a slightly stronger battery.  The batteries on the Oral B brushes tend to really take a hit after a couple years of use, so how helpful this is remains to be seen.  (The travel case is certainly pretty and somewhat sturdy, but it's so bulky that it's hard to call it an advantage.)Unfortunately, Oral B has done this before, introducing the Triaction 5000 with a different brush and initially charging 25% more than the previous generation Precision 5000.  This is now priced at a 50% premium to the Triaction 5000 with essentially identical features, and the same open charger that tends to collect nasty crud.Unless you really want a black toothbrush in your bathroom as a fashion statement, this isn't worth the premium over the lower priced models.  Buy them instead.

Margaret MacMillan's "The War That Ended Peace" is a worthwhile followup to her masterpiece Paris 1919, offering the same intricate reexamination of history.  In this case, however, the book is slightly less effective as it reads more densely; indeed, it could (and will probably) be used as required reading for upper level international relations courses.  Still, it's tremendously insightful, worth 4 stars, and will stand out as among the best of the 100th anniversary literature.In a sentence, one of MacMillan's conclusions is that Europe's La Belle Epoque was was not quite as good as it seemed.  There was peace, wealth, culture - but there was also tremendous nationalism, utterly incompetent governance, and without the work of a few able statesmen Europe would have flared into conflict long before 1914.  (One particularly interesting observation was of every French cadet being brought to see what hill they'd have to charge down once war was finally declared on Germany - starting the better part of 40 years before the Great War.)MacMillan takes a very in-depth look at the complicated pre-war relations between the great powers, and one other conclusion that's worth noting is her comment in the introduction that there were a long series of actions that slowly led to less and less choices for all involved.  Those actions are the meat of the 600 pages of the book, and at times it gets a bit dense and hard to keep track of the many players involved.  This isn't a popular history; it's a intricately detailed, dense analysis of the decisions and, at times, random bad luck that precipitated the war.  MacMillan lays much of the impetus of the war at the foot of bizarre foreign policy and naval buildup propagated by the Kaiser along with the economic backing of Russia that drew them into the French orbit (with France's own interests well ahead of Russia's), but there's certainly more than enough blame to go around.The other minor weakness of the book is MacMillan's occasional editorial comment on how countries then translate into countries today.  These tend to be very short blurbs, and don't fit with the rest of the massively researched analysis.  The author may in fact be right on her commentary, but a better fit would have been to dedicate a final, more detailed chapter to her conclusions.4 stars.  Very much worth a read, just not quite the masterpiece that Paris 1919 was.

The Braun CoolTec razor is likely to be under the Christmas tree in many households that have a gadget-loving partner that needs to shave, as the CoolTec bar really is pretty neat.  Unfortunately, the bottom line is that it's not a particularly good razor.  3 stars.Basically, CoolTec throws in a bar - likely a Peltier cooler - that is supposed to make shaving with an electric razor less irritable to skin.  It does certainly provide a chill when shaving, and it's a neat innovation.  However, veterans of electric shaving are unlikely to notice much difference, and there have always been a few alcohol based pre-shave products which work just as well to make shaving more comfortable.The problem is that the CoolTec bar is wide enough so that the two blades on the razor turn into  essentially single blade models, and this presents a major problem when going over the chin, jawbone, and mustache areas.  The third blade, the long hair clipper, is especially ineffective; I'd find long hairs I'd missed a day later.It's a neat toy and may get those who've avoided shaving with electric razors into that camp, but there are far better razors at this price point.  3 stars.

The Jabra Motion Bluetooth headset has monster features galore, with one glaring exception - the sound quality isn't up to other Jabra models.  An amazing tool, but the sound quality leaves this at 4 stars.If you've ever wanted a Bluetooth headset that can do everything, this is pretty much it.  Want longer range versus other BT headsets?  It's got it natively, and if you want truly long range with a PC, it's got a USB adapter that can leave you Skyping clear across the house.  Want to intuitively answer calls without buttons and use voice commands?  Check.  Want noise cancelling ability and intelligently long battery life?  Check.  About the only thing that's not spectacular about the features is the 6" USB cable, but presumably people want short cables for the cigarette lighter adapter (conveniently included with the headset).What it doesn't do well, though, is to provide good sound quality on outdoor calls.  It's unclear if this is a function of the microphone or noise cancellation just not working quite right, but I've had better sound quality on cheaper models.4 stars.  Even with the sound quality being a bit off, still a nifty toy.

NOTE: As sometimes happens, Amazon and third party sellers seem to have combined several different products under one listing.  The product reviewed is part of the STBD1000x series and is 5400 rpm.  The newer Momentus XT is 7200 rpm.  See comments for details.Seagate's hybrid STBD1000400 drive is both priced and positioned rather oddly for the drive market.  It is about $40 more expensive than comparable 1 TB laptop drives, only slightly less expensive than far faster 256 GB SSD drives, and doesn't really have enough cache to really take advantage of its nominal hybrid functionality.  If you're really looking for a single hard drive for a laptop and are on a strict budget, this isn't a great choice, but it's not awful either.Intel hit upon the hybrid concept a couple years back for desktops with their Smart Response Technology, where you could combine a small SSD drive with a mechanical drive and reap the benefits of both size and speed for frequently accessed data.  (Back in those days, a small SSD made far more sense economically; even a 256 GB SSD was price prohibitive.)  With less space for drives, laptops are a bit different; you're frequently stuck with a single drive, and so it makes sense for a drive manufacturer to create a hybrid drive.Unfortunately, with 8 GB of SSD cache, this does one thing and only one thing well, which is to access and write smaller amounts of data - as in, starting up programs.  Realistically, you'd need somewhere between 32-64 GB of SSD capacity to really notice sustained transfer speed improvement along with fairly sophisticated disk management software to keep frequently accessed programs in the SSD cache.What's particularly strange about this drive is that SSD storage has gotten cheap yet Seagate has placed a $40 price premium on the drive over comparable 5400 rpm drives for what's probably $5-10 at most of cache memory.  The result is a relatively quick 5400 rpm drive, but one that doesn't make a ton of sense from a value perspective.  Most users would be better off buying a 256 GB drive (often found on sale for around $150) as a main drive and using an $80 USB 3.0 enabled 1 TB external drive for larger files like video.It's not that this is an awful drive; Crystal Mark shows 105 MB/s read and 115 MB/s write, which is quite good for a 5400 rpm drive.  It's just that the value proposition here doesn't make much sense, nor does the performance jump out at you either.3 stars.  Seagate either needs to price this more appropriately or come out with a model that is a truer hybrid.

About the only real quibble with Scott Anderson's "Lawrence in Arabia" is that it is slightly mistitled.  Its subtitle of "Imperial Folly and the Making of the Modern Middle East" more accurately reflects the book's focus, as it brilliantly describes exactly how the British - and to a lesser degree, the French, Germans, and Ottoman Empire - bungled the birth of nations in the Middle East to such a degree that their mistakes still haunt the world 90 years later.  Using primary source research, much of which seems to have been skipped by other authors, this account surpasses Fromkin's A Peace to End All Peace as the single best reference on the subject and stands alongside MacMillan's Paris 1919 as a must read on how the modern world was created.  5 stars.Much of the story of the arrogance and blunders that created the modern Middle East is well known.  Sykes-Picot, the disaster of the negotiations at Versailles in 1919, and the British campaigns in Palestine and Iraq have all received substantial attention by scholars.  Anderson frames the conflict with a focus on 4 players that neatly represent their countries' interests.  T. E. Lawrence is well-known, of course, but the three other players are not: William Yale, a Standard Oil employee assigned to buy petroleum leases in Palestine who by 1918 ended up becoming the United States' "expert" on the region, Aaron Aaronsohn, a Jewish agronomist who founded an anti-Ottoman spy ring and viciously battled with Chaim Weizmann and other Zionists, and Curt Prüfer, a brilliant German spy who was among the first to see the potential of using Arab liberation as a weapon against current rulers and who, incredibly, recruited Weizmann's sister as his lover and one of his spies.  By interweaving their stories and other players like Sykes, French Colonel Edouard Bremond, Sharif Hussein and his sons, Dejmal Pasha, and the British military and intelligence establishment, Anderson constructs an extremely accessible history.At the center of this tale is Lawrence, and Anderson provides enough valuable insights on his character and actions to make this book be worth a read for that alone.  What is well-known about Lawrence is that his rise to prominence came almost as an accident and that his autobiography - which was originally intended as a very limited release for his friends - exaggerates much and muddles up more.  What is not is that Lawrence's leadership in the Arab revolt was quite personal and risky - Lawrence seemed to be outright seeking death on a number of occasions - yet arguably didn't have as much impact as his two great strategic observations.  Despite lacking any military training, Lawrence deduced the vulnerability of Alexandretta and the impact of isolating Ottoman troops in Medina long before anyone on the British staff did.  The second played a central role in British strategy, and if his advice on the first had been taken the Ottoman Empire might have collapsed as early as 1915 with the arrogant disaster of Gallipoli avoided.By the end of the book, Lawrence is more pitiful than heroic.  A five minute conversation between Lloyd George and Clemenceau at Versailles superseded 4 years of fighting and hundreds of thousands of deaths in the Middle East, and directly contributed to the mess that has existed there for the last 90 years.  Lawrence's observation on ibn-Saud and Wahabism proved remarkably prescient, and the rivalry between British Egypt and British India military and political staffs that helped create the mess is almost unbelievable.  About the only thing missing here is the postwar chaos and look at the Cairo Conference and the work in 1921 by Lawrence and Winston Churchill to provide a temporary fix to the mess made of the region, which Fromkin covers effectively.There's a lot more that can be said for the topics covered in this book, but the strongest recommendation is simply that even readers quite familiar with the region and history will learn something new here.  5 stars, and a must read.

The Braun Cruzer 5 Hair Clipper is a good, rechargeable hair clipper with a cleverly designed removable guard for different lengths.  4 stars.Most reviews of this product along with the manufacturer's description seem to miss that this is basically just a solid 1 1/2" trimmer with a removable guard.  As such, it's perfectly fine for trimming sideburns or such with the guard off.  It's just about the right weight for a clipper - lighter clippers are a bit hard to go through thick hair - with the only real drawback being that as a rechargeable it's definitely not as powerful as comparable Oster or Wahl corded models.  If you're going to be doing a lot of hair cutting, it's worth spending the extra $20 or so for a plug in model.The one really neat feature of this is the removable guard.  It offers 8 settings of 3 mm increments between 3 mm and 24 mm with a single attachment, which is certainly unique.  It's a little disappointing that standard barber shop clipper blade guard sizes aren't marked off as well - there certainly is room for them on one side of the guard - but since they both vary by clipper brand and are measured in inches rather than millimeters it's understandable why Braun didn't do so.The lack of a charging stand and a travel case are the primary seasons why this is 4 stars rather than 5.  Something lightweight like this begs for being put in a travel bag as a slightly less powerful but still very effective clipper when you're on the road, but sadly Braun didn't include one.  Still, an effective rechargeable clipper.  4 stars.

Peter Berg's "Wilson" is a immensely readable and captivating biography of Woodrow Wilson.  Perhaps because of his access to two new archival sources - letters to Wilson's second daughter and the records of Admiral Grayson, Wilson's physician and close aide - "Wilson" does a superb job of revealing the man behind the many myths.  It falls a little short, though, when it comes to his administration.  4 stars.As Berg rightly points out, everything about Woodrow Wilson is arguable.  This is likely one reason why most modern biographers have generally skipped him as a subject; John Milton Cooper's Woodrow Wilson is the only recent attempt to try to interpret Wilson for the modern age, and that biography concentrates far more on Wilson's political achievements and failures than it does trying to illuminate the complexities of one of the most brilliant yet fallible men to ever occupy the Presidency.Berg's addition is welcome precisely because he shows Wilson's gifts and weaknesses.  Wilson has probably been subjected to more psychological assessment than any President besides Lincoln or Jefferson - Freud's tar and feathering of him in Psychological Analysis comes to mind, a book which Berg deftly discredits - but no one has really examined the details of Wilson's early life in the way that Berg does.  Berg's portrait is of a man who was equal parts brilliant and arrogant; Wilson was almost always the smartest person in the room but required continuous acknowledgment of his brilliance.Where Berg provides a unique biography is that Wilson's contributions outside the White House receive significant and detailed exploration in a way that few if any biographies have ever covered.  It's hard to overestimate the effect that Wilson had on undergraduate education as many of his reforms at Princeton were adopted by virtually every school in the country soon thereafter.  Berg does one better than most biographers, though, as he reveals just how much of the genesis of these reforms came from Wilson's total impatience with his own education, how he basically decided to invent his own course of study of political theory, and how he effectively became one of the first academics to publish or perish.While Berg does an admirable job exploring Wilson's administration and reveals some startling new insights - most noticeably, that Wilson likely was suffering from mental incapacity during part of his time at Versailles, and just how much the death of his first wife and courting of his second distracted him from the Presidency - the book falls slightly short here.  There are a couple reasons.  First, Berg doesn't incorporate much of the plentiful political analysis by other scholars about Wilson.  Wilson's great accomplishments as a Progressive were done with a largely friendly Congress, but Berg largely skips exactly how Wilson got much of his legislation through besides frequent visits to Capitol Hill and the President's Room, uplifting but not condescending oratory, and trading away the rights of African Americans in exchange for other legislative goals.  Bringing in some of the other scholarship here would have helped; there were a lot of political crosswinds blowing at the time, and Berg doesn't really mention them except in passing.Second, Berg's decision to provide extremely limited editorial commentary does the author a disservice.  Berg doesn't shy away from what he describes as Wilson's "genteel racism" but unlike a biographer like Jean Edward Smith doesn't call out his subject for his failings either.  There has been a lot written on Wilson's problems over the years, and Berg's exploration of Wilson's personality would have been a masterful way to incorporate them; a good summary of Berg's conclusions is that Wilson often took advice from no one but himself.  In doing so it made him perhaps both the best political theorist since Madison to occupy the White House - and also among the worst practical politicians to ever do so.Definitely worth a read, though, as it provides insight on one of the most consequential administrations in American history.  4 stars.

This Scotch tape is a very thin tape that is fairly adhesive but doesn't have a whole lot of tensile strength - it's akin to some of the really flimsy packing tape you'll find for $1 a roll.As such, it's not really something you should be using to tape up a box.  It's best used on top of an already existing seal, or as a replacement for a label that just says "fragile."  If you're using this to replace multiple labels, this might actually be fairly cost-efficient as you could likely get several hundred 'fragile' pieces from the tape.  As tape itself, it's rather expensive for what you get.4 stars.  It does a job, although it's a bit expensive for its purpose.

The thinkThin bars are decent if not perfect protein bar meal substitutes.  There are definitely worse bars out there - some of the MetRX bars come to mind - and probably some that are better.  What's been really striking to me about other reviews, though, is that they don't acknowledge that different flavors may find different takers.For instance, I find the chunky peanut butter one of the best bars out there.  It's got enough texture so that it offsets the slight mush flavor of the large amount of protein found in any protein bar.  On the other hand, the creamy peanut butter bar doesn't have this, and is generally pretty nasty to eat.For a those not interested in a full serving of protein, the thinkThin snack bars like the Mixed Nuts are really quite good and deserve a try if you're looking for a quick and relatively healthy meal substitute.  Granted, a can of garbanzo beans has more fiber, more protein, and with a little seasoning more taste than any of these bars, but if you're in a rush, thinkThin bars are worth a look.

"Abaddon's Gate" by the writing team of James S. A. Corey continues the Expanse series in page turning fashion with action galore.  The book isn't quite as sharp as the first two as the expansion on-the-fly of the series weighs a bit on the plot and structure.  Still, a fun summer read.  4 stars.It's hard to find good modern space opera - likely since most people who are capable of writing it probably end up doing screenplays instead as the payoff is far more lucrative - but Daniel Abraham and Ty Franck really brought a breath of fresh air to the genre with Leviathan Wakes and Caliban's War.  Their mix of modern characters, reasonable science along with the fiction, plentiful action, and multiple plot twists resulted in two very good books and the expansion by the publisher of what was supposed to be a trilogy into a six book saga.As "Abbadon's Gate" starts, all three major powers are at a standoff as to how to deal with the events of the cliffhanger ending of Caliban's War, where the original threat of the protomolecule has evolved into something larger - the gate of the book's title.  Meanwhile, James Holden is still haunted by another cliffhanger, who turns out to be not just non-corporeal but nonsensical, and is generally enjoying life.  However, the political events of the first two books inspire a conspiracy to jolt both the powers and Holden out of their complacency and deal with all the Gate represents, and the book takes off from there.It's hard to provide commentary on a page turner like this without ruining things, but there are a few points.  A bunch of major characters in the first two books don't appear in this one, and the vast majority of the action has the main protagonists of the Rocinante involved but off to the side.  Most of the newer characters are generally well written and their stories interesting, but a couple of the supporting cast arcs aren't as well done.  One major plot twist that sets up the last third of the book seems slightly forced as well, and overall the book doesn't feel as tight as the first two in the series.All this fits with the series being expanded on-the-fly by the publisher, where what was originally supposed to be a conclusion ends up being a middle book.  It's not badly done by any means and this is a still a fun read, but it just feels like the two authors bolted on a bunch of material onto what would have been the previous ending to the series in a way that would allow more books.Still, it's a great summer read, and the best news is that the new characters and expansion of the storyline here means that the sequels should be fun too.  Definitely should read the first two books before this, though.  4 stars.

The Energizer 180W Cup inverter is a useful little gadget for powering a whole bunch of electronic devices on the go.  It's important to be aware of its limitations, but 5 stars for the price and functionality.There have been a bunch of reviews about how this works day-to-day, but since no one has yet discussed the technical aspects of the inverter it's worthwhile reviewing them instead.First, while there's nothing in the documentation regarding how many amps this puts out, as this is rated 180W it presumably can supply up to 15A between the USB ports and the AC adapter.  That's an important number, as most cigarette lighter fuses aren't rated above 15A.  This means that this a. won't blow out your car fusebox and b. does have reasonable limits as to what devices can draw from it.  However, the AC outlet has enough juice to successfully run most electronics short of something like a laser printer.  This also includes a second adapter with direct-to-battery alligator clips if you're so inclined to bypass the cigarette lighter.Second, the 2.1A draw for the USB ports is shared between all four ports.  A 2.1A output on a single port will charge nearly anything quite quickly.  However, if you have 4 devices plugged in, you're going to be running at 525 mA per device, which is actually not awful and more or less what USB 2.0 is rated at - there are a bunch of nominal 'quick charger' adapters that provide this output.  (Keep in mind that some older devices may require trickle charging at 200 mA, which this can't do.)  Bottom line is that this will keep most modern devices at fairly stable charge levels while they're plugged in, but if you've drained the battery on 4 separate devices and plug them all in to recharge, it may take a while.Third, this is a modified sine wave inverter, which at this price point is expected.  (Pure sine inverters start at $200 and up.)  For almost everything you'll likely plug into this device modified sine wave power is ok; you can't use something like an alarm clock or a drill, and you definitely wouldn't want to plug in very sensitive electronic equipment or an expensive stereo.Finally, what's important to note about any DC-to-AC inverter with most 12V car batteries is that this is not something that you'll want to run with the engine off if you're going to use it for more than an hour or so.  A standard 12V car battery isn't designed to repeatedly discharge to low levels, and doing so will dramatically shorten its life.  If you really want to run an inverter off a 12V battery for extended periods of time, you're much better off replacing your lead acid battery with a deep cycle model that's designed to fully discharge.  Otherwise, this is best either used for brief periods of time or when your engine is running.

The Canon Carrying Case for the P-208 Scanner is pretty much about what you would expect for a basic case for electronics.  It is made from thick fabric that will prevent scratches and damage from light bumps, but without any sort of padding for drops.  There is a small bag at the bottom of the case to house a USB cable, and there's a handle that seems somewhat gratuitous.The only knock on this case is that there's utterly no reason for its existence besides making Canon an extra $25; the mesh case included with the P-208 is really insufficient, and this should have been part of the package.

L. E. Modesitt's "Antiagon Fire" is a solid entry in the prequel series of the Imager Portfolio.  Modesitt hews to his standard narrative of a superpowered protagonist who is struggling to be ethical, which means the plot unfolds in Modesitt's typical progression: lots of politics, some action, and some philosophy.  While this is a step up from the military march of Imager's Battalion, it falls slightly flat in an area that is usually one of Modesitt's strengths - forcing characters to confront the moral consequences of their decisions.  Still, a good read.  4 stars."Antiagon Fire" picks up immediately from the end of the previous book, and protagonist Quaeryt faces most of the same problems he did before; he has an army to lead but he's not overtly in command, he has people equal or senior to him looking to undermine him, and he's tasked with both diplomatic and military responsibilities.  In this case, those responsibilities are less clear cut than before; instead of being expected to defeat large armies through his growing powers, Quaeryt has a more subtle task, to complete Lord Bhayar's consolidation wars with less direct methods.  However, Quaeryt quickly discovers that he has a loophole to do more than he thought, and the book proceeds to follow his missions to finish the consolidation of the continent.Why is this a slightly weaker book than it should be?  A few reasons.  First, the loophole almost feels like an out for Modesitt to let his character not have to deal with the machinations that many of Modesitt's previous characters have faced when their preferred path gets blocked by bureaucratic enemies; Quaeryt largely has free reign over his actions without consequence (at least in this book; Rex Regis has the potential of being very interesting should Modesitt choose to follow up this thread.)  On a related note, Modesitt also continues to have problems with writing Quaeryt's superior Lord Bhayar; this may be the first competent boss Modesitt has ever come up with in his many books who isn't one of the main protagonists and doesn't die immediately.  Modesitt seems so used to writing scheming, incompetent leaders that presenting one that is merely self-interested presents some difficulty.Second, what's a bit more disappointing is that several of Quaeryt's actions bring up some serious questions regarding ethical leadership and politics, and for once Modesitt doesn't explore them deeply.  It's hard to explain this without providing spoilers, but one example is that Modesitt often negotiates around potentially controversial decisions by Quaeryt with the plot device of having Pharsi foresight guide his path.  Despite this, the Pharsi legends are still not fully explored; perhaps Modesitt will do so in the final book in the series.All this said, this isn't a bad book by any means, and it's better than "Imager's Battalion."  It's just that had Modesitt done his normal philosophical pondering, this would probably have been far more difficult to write but also have had the potential to be one of his better novels in a long time.  Perhaps that's nitpicking a bit as it's still worth a read.  4 stars.

Canon's P-208 document scanner is a nice piece of hardware for those who need to scan while on the road.  It includes duplex scanning, a TWAIN driver, and has a functional Automatic Document Feeder (ADF).  However, the bundled software doesn't use the full functionality of the scanner, and as such it's nowhere near to a desktop replacement.  A star off for this leaves it at 4 stars, but if you've already got the software or don't mind spending a bunch of money to buy some it's worth looking at.The last few years have seen the arrival of a plethora of travel-oriented scanners.  Wand scanners like the VuPoint Magic Wand are great if you're scanning books in a library but for document scanning are slow and tedious.  For USB-powered scanners, Fujitsu's ScanSnap 1100 is a fantastic ultraportable scanner at under 1 lb but lacks an ADF and is simplex only, HP's Scanjet 1000 is duplex but also is missing an ADF, and Brother's DS700D is duplex but also doesn't have an ADF and is quite a bit heavier at almost 3 lbs.  About the only two portable scanners that are true desktop replacements are the Scansnap 1300i and Canon's own P-215, but they're both also heavier at 3 and 2 lbs, respectively.Enter the P-208, which uses a single USB-to-mini B cable, has a size point that is small (1 1/2"x12 1/4"x2 1/4") and light (1 1/4 lbs), has a unique but functional 10 page ADF that works for documents up to 8.5"x14" and as small as a business card, color duplexes at around 8 ppm, and has a TWAIN driver so that you can use it with most scanning software and amend existing PDF files.  While the included case is mesh and doesn't really provide much protection, you can buy a more robust one, and if you buy the WU10 battery and wireless adapter, you can even use this with an Android device and skip the PC or Mac entirely.Canon has also done something unique in figuring out a way to make this almost completely plug-and-play.  By putting a "Lite" version of CaptureOn Touch onboard the scanner's internal memory, it can be run simply by plugging it into a USB port on most anything running Windows 7.  That version does a yeoman job scanning.What's the catch?  The rest of the bundled software.Unfortunately, the nominally more comprehensive full version of CaptureOn Touch included on the install CD doesn't take full advantage of the P-208's capabilities as it doesn't allow access to the TWAIN driver.  (Evernote and BizCard 6 OCR contact management software are also included, but they're not the main scanning programs.)  CaptureOn Touch saves in a variety of file formats, but none above 300x300 dpi despite the scanner being rated at up to 600x600 at 24 bit depth.  It allows only very minor editing of any captured images, not even allowing for skew correction - important if you use the ADF, which can easily do so if you've got more than a handful of pages - and is otherwise a generally mediocre program.  Finally, it ran into problems distinguishing dark text on dark background at 300 dpi, which meant that image wasn't even included in the capture.The good news is that because this has a TWAIN driver it can be used with more robust scanning software, and once you access device settings through the driver far more features become available.  The bad news is that you'll have to buy new software outright or use leftover software from another scanner to do so, and overall this still isn't a one-stop solution for a scanner.  You're far better off with something like the ScanSnap ix500 for routine use.For travel, though, this really hits a size and price point that's unique - it's actually smaller than a dedicated card scanner like the CardScan Executive with a whole lot more functionality, and might be an ideal scanner for the road.  It's easy to imagine scanning receipts, business cards, and miscellaneous documents on an airplane or hotel room with this; combine this with NeatReceipts and ABBYY Finereader and you've got a true portable scanner for the road.  The only problem is finding software that can take full advantage of the hardware here, and that's why this is 4 stars and not 5.

The Frigidaire FAD704DWD is a good, solid humidifier that restarts automatically when it loses power and allows a hose to be connected for continuous drainage.  By and large, it doesn't seem much different than its predecessor, the Frigidaire FAD704DUD, and in operation it seems essentially indistinguishable.  4 stars, as Frigidaire humidifiers are still basically hit and miss when it comes to reliability.Those who've purchased humidifiers tend to understand that humidifier reliability is often a random walk even for the nominally 'good' brands, and Frigidaire isn't any different.  I've had two good Frigidaires and a good Comfort Aire and two bad ones of both brands.By and large, the -DWD doesn't appear any different than the -DUD.  There are a couple minor differences in the specs, but the power consumption as measured by a Kill A Watt appears roughly the same, the case appears identical, the sensor reads the same humidity, and the noise level is indistinguishable.  About the only major design flaw with the -DUD that wasn't catastrophic (like the coils failing) but did plague some users was that the continuous drain port would often have problems directing water out.  According to customer service, about half the units required an adapter to function properly; to get one you simply had to call them and they'd send it for free.In limited usage, the continuous drain here works fine.  It's entirely possible that might be the difference between the two models.  Finally, for the record, you don't need a pump if this is placed within a foot or two of a drain, but do if there's any length of hose required.  If that's the case, the Little Giant VCMX-20ULST works well up to about 25 feet.4 stars.  Good humidifier, although that's always a crapshoot.

The Oral-B Triaction 5000 is a good, top-of-the-line toothbrush.  However, the many features that make it so are also largely unchanged from the previous top-of-the-line Oral-B Professional Precision 5000, save for a $20 price increase and a fancy new brush that many people won't use.  3 stars; it's a good brush but most people will find the older model to be a better value proposition.Oral-B makes very good toothbrushes, but their marketing leaves a bit to be desired; this is far from a breakthrough.  You'll get a very good cleaning from this one, but is it any better than what you'd have gotten from their previous top-of-the-line model?  Iffy.  The main differences between the two are that the newer model has a more clearly marked button to switch between the 5 cleaning modes, stops and chimes every thirty seconds instead of simply vibrating, has a green plastic backing instead of a blue one, has a green LED instead of an LCD to show battery charge, and uses the older version of the charging stand with a dimple in the middle instead of the newer ring one.  The last is probably not a good thing, as the older version was a gunk magnet and required near-constant cleaning.Other than that, they're pretty much identical: 40000 pulsations/minute, 8800 oscillations/minute, a sensor that presumably warns you if you're pressing too hard, nominal 10 day battery life (which is a little bit lower under field conditions, and there's a noticeable difference between a new battery and an older one for both life and strength of brushing) , and a wireless SmartGuide that you'll probably throw in a drawer and ignore.That leaves the new brush head, which twists and turns as well as rotating, as the only real difference between the two.  Of course, you can simply go out and buy a pack of the new brush heads and put them on the older model if you'd like; both use the exact same stem.  It's probably not advisable to do so, though, as most dentists recommend gentle bristles for electric toothbrushes and the new brush head definitely doesn't qualify.It's a good toothbrush, but it's not worth $20 more than the previous year's version unless for some reason you either really like the older base stand or have fallen in love with the new brush head.  If the price differential vanishes, I'll raise the rating as it's a very good toothbrush.  For now, though, 3 stars.

Microsoft's Office Home & Business 2013 isn't a particularly noticeable upgrade over 2010 unless you're either a Windows 8 or cloud computing fan.  After a customer revolt, they fortunately fixed most of the draconian licensing issues that would have made this a complete fiasco.  4 stars; it's a good product with a few useful new features, although probably not worth an upgrade if you've already got 2010 unless your needs are very specific.There's not a lot to be said about Office that hasn't already been written; you either need it or you don't, and while they've come a long way, there are still going to be things that most of the cloud based solutions can't offer that various Office programs do.  Home and Student doesn't include Outlook (a big deal a decade ago, but for most not terribly important nowadays), Professional and Professional Plus include Publisher and Access, and all three versions include Word, Excel, Powerpoint, and OneNote.Unless you spend a substantial amount of time working on multiple devices at multiple locations, Office 2010's value proposition is better for most users compared to Office 365's $10 a month, which includes 20 GB extra of Skydrive space, some Skype time, and installation on up to 5 devices.  Initially, Microsoft made an utterly boneheaded attempt to differentiate Office 2013 and 365 by offering 2013 as a once-ever install for almost all versions, much as they did with some of the digital versions of Office 2010.  The customer revolt was meaningful and swift, as something as innocuous as upgrading your hard drive would have cost users the entire retail price.  Fortunately, Microsoft backed down and a reinstall is now permitted once every 90 days.As far as new features, the PDF editing in Word is a small plus.  It matches fonts nicely, is better than several other third party solutions, and is definitely superior to the freeware PDF editors currently available.  Unfortunately, it also requires conversion from and reconversion to PDF format, and in doing so for more complex PDFs it often will ruin formatting.  Given ABBYY Finereader's plugin currently crashes Office 2013, this is particularly annoying.  Outlook now syncs with web-based email far better than its predecessors, Powerpoint is a little more intuitive, and Excel seems largely unchanged for most power users.  The biggest change is that Microsoft is definitely pushing cloud based solutions; saving locally is a bit of a pain without having to go through hoops or changing defaults.  On the bright side, should you wish to use Dropbox or Google Drive, those apps integrate far easier with Office 2013 than with any other version.4 stars.  Microsoft nearly shot itself in the foot with the licensing policy here, the relative value of upgrading from 2010 is iffy, but overall Office 2013 is as solid as ever if you really need it.

There have been a lot of reviews already, so not a ton more needs to be said about the OXO Good Grips Measuring cups.  They're fairly sturdy, the grips are nice (especially with the hook grip versus a punchhole), and accurate.Regarding the metal strength, I've found that the 1/4 and 1/3 cups are small enough so that they don't bend when scooping flour or sugar.  The 1/2 and the 1 cup versions still do.  A slightly thicker handle for the larger cups would have helped, but on the whole these are still superior measuring cups.

Mitchell Zuckoff's "Frozen In Time" is a remarkable story of search and rescue gone wrong and survival in the one harshest environments on the planet during World War II.  It is also a story of negotiating government bureaucracy to put a fitting end to this saga.  While it's a compelling tale, there are a few weaknesses that should normally leave this at 4 stars, but it's worth rounding up to 5 given both the subject matter and the author's willingness to put himself on the line to try to write a proper conclusion.Greenland's geographical importance to the Allies during World War II for both weather prediction and as a waystation for transporting aircraft came at a significant human cost; the weather conditions there often made flying incredibly hazardous, and the glaciers and ice on Greenland made rescuing survivors even more so.  In late 1942, disaster hit as a plane went down, and every search-and-rescue (SAR) command's worst nightmare came to pass: not just one but two of the rescuers went down as well."Frozen In Time" tells the story of all three planes, the story of the survivors during the winter of 1942-1943, and the incredible effort the United States military - and especially the United States Coast Guard - made to get these people out and back.  The story here is one of the great survival tales of the Second World War and the eventual resolution of it reached the highest levels of the military and government and headlined national news.  Having been largely forgotten outside the Coast Guard aviation community it's well past time someone of Zuckoff's caliber brings it back to life.The second story here is the 2012 search put on for one of the planes, which is mostly about the persistence of a few people in and out of government fighting against bureaucracy, budgets, and impassivity to do the right thing, along with some semi-hairy times during the actual search.As a book, there are a few weaknesses.  The editorial decision to interweave the 2012 story with the 1942 one ruins much of the suspense and is largely unnecessary from a narrative standpoint; the stories could easily have been told chronologically.  There's a weak spot in the telling of the behind the scenes story of the amazing persistence of the 50+ sorties run by a single pilot on a single plane, but there's no examination of the logistics and support for it.  Finally, it's a bit disappointing there is no analysis of how a series of bad decisions abetted bad luck here; it would be very surprising if there's not been a decent amount written about the lessons the SAR community learned from this incident.All that said, considering Zuckoff put his credit card, house, and reputation on the line to get this book written, it's a bit unfair to give this the 4 stars that would otherwise be appropriate.  5 stars, and well worth a read.

Raymond Feist's "Magician's End" wraps up the Riftwar saga with a surprisingly decent read.  It's not Feist's best book, but it's far from his worst.  4 stars.With the Riftwar series, the prolific Feist accomplished a feat that very few others have achieved: on average, he managed to crank out a sequel once a year for pretty much thirty years running.  As long time readers know - about the only people who might remotely consider buying "Magician's End" by now - the quality has varied dramatically.  Especially considering Feist expanded the framework on the fly to fit everything in, some entries were quite good.  Others weren't.The good news is that "Magician's End" ranks towards the upper end of the later books, even if it's nowhere close to the earlier books in the series.  That's largely because Feist figures out a way to bring back a bunch of series favorites in a way that isn't totally unreasonable.  The plot isn't anything to write home about - the B-story here isn't all that compelling, for instance, which is somewhat disappointing given the work he put in on some of the characters over the last few books - but Feist recovers by pulling back the curtains to reveal more of the secrets of the universe in a way that is somewhat reminiscent of A Darkness at Sethanon, and that along with the old friends coming back make this one of the better entries in a while.The standard disclaimers towards Feist apply, of course; if you don't like his books, this isn't going to change your mind.  However, as a presumed long-overdue series wrap-up - arguably, Feist might have left himself an out if he wants to write more in this realm - it works well enough.  4 stars, and not a bad way to go out.

Richard Rubin's "The Last of the Doughboys" achieves something uncommon for a history book written by someone who doesn't specialize in the era: it truly transports readers back to the world of the Great War.  More impressively, it does so without requiring expertise in the relevant military history or sociology.  5 stars, as it is a remarkable book especially considering what Rubin had for source material.While there are a plethora of oral histories of American World War II veterans, the same cannot be said for their Great War counterparts.  This is particularly disappointing considering that other countries didn't follow America's disinterest; for instance, the Imperial War Museum has thousands of hours of interviews of World War I veterans, resulting in books like Forgotten Voices of the Great War and many of Peter Hart's books that break down various fronts of the war.Enter Richard Rubin, who in 2003 decided to see if he could track down the few living American survivors of World War I - all centenarians by then - and interview them about their service.  His method was ingenious; unable to find them through the Veterans Administration, he used the French government's awarding of Legion d'Honneurs to those few veterans still alive in 1998 guide him to the even fewer left 5 years later.  By what was often sheer force of will, Rubin conducted a noble, often quixotic effort to track down and interview the last survivors.The result is not precisely military history.  One reason for this is that the lives and lifestyles of anyone who has won the genetic lottery and become a centenarian is almost worthy of a book itself, and Rubin spends some time exploring those ramifications.  The other reason that isn't mentioned, though, is that there were no officers or NCOs left for him to interview because they were five or ten years older during the war and had passed away before he began his research.  Rubin's source material is thus entirely composed of junior enlisted types, and as such their experiences aren't necessarily central to the combat experience of the Great War.  With the exception of George Briant and Frank Buckles, most of the interviews he conducted provide only the beginnings of a story than anything else.Instead, Rubin wisely writes a book that is just as much about the America of the Great War period as it is about the experiences of the veterans in France and elsewhere.  Eugene V. Debs, Jim Crow, and the vagaries of the Wilson, Harding, and Coolidge administrations make appearances, and the wider focus lets readers unfamiliar with the social and political history of the time comprehend the America that embraced the Espionage and Sedition Acts of 1918.  Rubin then weaves in the wartime experiences of the veterans to introduce other firsthand accounts on the Great War, many lost in dusty obscurity since they achieved popular success 80 years ago and then subsequently vanished.  By tying together his interviews, the first hand accounts, and other literature, Rubin creates an accessible ground level history of the American experience on the ground in France.  Remarkably, Rubin incorporates not just well known battles like Belleau Wood, but tracks down the very last survivors of the AEF Siberia detachment and colored regiments.  This allows him to tell stories that readers simply weren't interested in back in the 1920s, and Rubin should be commended for bringing this to the forefront of the American experience.It's not a great oral history book, nor a great military history, nor a great social and political history of the 1910s and 1920s.  Readers wanting more depth and detail in each of these fields can find plentiful books on the subject elsewhere.  That doesn't detract from "The Last of the Doughboys" at all, though.  It combines all of the above and is a remarkable achievement in how it uses the final living threads of history to reconstruct a world long gone.5 stars, and very much worth a read for those at all interested in America's role in the conflict that shaped the modern world.

Peter Nolan's "Is China Buying The World?" is a useful collection of facts and assertions that point out that much of the fear of Chinese business dominance is overdone.  A star off for his almost-near omission of some of the most salient points of the discussion of Chinese domestic and international markets, however, makes this brief book a little less convincing than it should be, and a half-star off for producing what at times feels like a data dump leaves this 3.5 stars rounded down to 3.Nolan, a professor of Chinese development at Cambridge, has been a one of the more insightful and productive academic writers on the complicated relationship between China and the West.  His basic argument here isn't particularly complex and should be familiar to anyone generally aware of the Chinese market.  For reasons of history and government, China has lagged badly in international development since the days prior to Western interference, when it possessed 33% of world industrial capacity versus 18% in the West.  Much of the resulting attempts at growth over the last decade are an attempt to catch up on a per capita basis; China remains brutally poor in many areas (although he does not discuss the particularly dramatic rural-urban split), lags in R&D, lags in overseas opportunities, lags in strategic resources, has massive foreign reserves partially because of the dramatic Asian crisis in 1997-1998, and overall has accepted far more foreign direct investment than it has returned.Many of these are fair points, and this is a somewhat effective response to many of the Chinese-taking-over-the-world arguments which are made for local political consumption.However, where the book falls short is in what he leaves out.  The biggest omission is on foreign investment in China, where he paints a much rosier picture of the climate than what most Western executives report.  China has certainly welcomed foreign investment, but extracts a price that no other country on the planet requires: not only Chinese majority ownership of forced joint ventures, but also technology transfer to Chinese companies as a basis to be allowed to sell to the Chinese domestic market.  It is true that Western firms have a massive R&D advantage on China, but the lack of respect for intellectual property has narrowed this gap tremendously.  Furthermore, there isn't a discussion of Chinese fiscal policy, which while it has received some unfair political pandering does possess some genuinely disturbing tendencies and also creates issues for companies selling to the Chinese internal market.The book also suffers from what can best be described a tendency towards data dumping of largely irrelevant factoids.  Some of this comes from the source material of the book being an expansion of a white paper Nolan gave to the US-China Business Council in 2011, with a target audience likely expecting reams of data whether or not it's relevant to the overall thesis.  However, the value of including such tidbits of information like "In 2003-2004 GE engines powered more than 80% of coalition aircraft during Operation Iraqi Freedom" is dubious and often gives the impression that Nolan is looking to outright overwhelm readers with data instead of convince them with arguments.Still, it's a useful primer for those who aren't that familiar with Chinese development over the last few decades.  3 stars.

The main point of Donna Freitas' "The End of Sex" is entirely reasonable: that the hookup culture on some campuses isn't particularly healthy for college students.  In the process of trying to support this, though, Freitas runs into some major problems, butchering the methodology of her survey and providing an overall analysis that is both flawed and and impractical.  2 stars, as credit needs to be given to the author for at least doing some serious thinking and passionate writing about this phenomenon.Freitas' conclusion about the hookup culture - that it "silences, shames, isolates, and disempowers students, quashing their ethics, desires, and differences, their need for respect and connection, and their need to be treated with bodily dignity, to express emotion, and the experience of pleasure" - is going to alienate some readers even before they crack open her book.  Even if readers don't agree, though, there is an objective argument to be made about the consequences for this generation once they begin attempting to settle down and form long term relationships without the benefit of learning from the dating mistakes everyone makes in their teens and twenties.  Not surprisingly, the most compelling portion of the book comes when Freitas discusses Kerry Cronin's work on the challenges and benefits of actually getting students to try dating rather than hooking up, since Ms. Cronin is one of the few people who've taken practical steps to address this gap.Unfortunately, that is one of the few highlights.First, the methodology for many of her arguments is simply atrocious.  "The End of Sex" is largely composed of a quantitative analysis of the data set of Freitas' earlier book, Sex and the Soul, which received high praise from someone as distinguished as Harvey Mansfield for her qualitative approach as a "welcome change from the neutral questions and narrow statistics" of quantitative social science.  While the in-depth interviews in "Sex and the Soul" certainly provided some interesting insights, Freitas - a professor of religion who is familiar with the classics but not qualitative methods - outsourced the data analysis after she completed her survey.  Unfortunately, her decision to not seek the same assistance in setting up the survey proves fatal here.While Freitas has gathered a sample of 2500 students in 7 undergraduate settings to discuss their habits, many of the answers received from this data set don't correspond to other research that's available, probably because there are some fairly obvious holes in how she collected and sorted the data.  Among them is her bewildering decision to frequently categorize her results by the respondents' choice of college; about the only meaningful correlation suggested by this is the unsurprising revelation that evangelical college students have somewhat different values than their peers elsewhere.In addition, much of her application of this data is equally questionable.  One of the more eye-popping arguments she tries to form is that since 75% of her respondents disagreed with the question "sex is primarily the taking of pleasure from another person" it follows that that the same 75% therefore disagree with "the notion of hookup sex as a purely physical experience."  A full dissection of the problems here would take several pages, but suffice it to say that Freitas is on far more solid ground reviewing philosophy than reviewing data.A major concern in both books is that Freitas is largely silent on what might be a happy medium for young adults between the extremes of abstinence projects like Anscombe at Princeton (which she admires save for their problems with LGBT students) and the hookup raunch she condemns.  The role of and health of sex as a part of a committed relationship is entirely omitted besides a suggestion that "(for) committed student couples...press(ing) pause on (their) sex life can be empowering."  It's possible this might work for a small group of students, but overall this is not substantially more helpful than her belief that reading Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics, St. Augustine's Confessions, and Plato's Symposium can serve a significant role in helping students not succumb to the temptation of hookups.  Freitas is probably on to something when she suggests that colleges should consider spending resources to help students think about dating and relationships, and there is certainly a valued place within academia for the use of classics to help students grow into ethical and moral adulthood.  However, it's not clear that her reading list would discourage hookup culture outside of the occasional philosophy department.Finally, despite including panel discussions with with sociologist Mark Regnerus and incorporating his earlier comments on the same subject, it is particularly odd that Freitas does not address his more recent work on premarital sex among young adults.  Consistent with other sociologists who have done work on this area, Regnerus' analysis suggests that the prevalence of the hookup culture is exaggerated, that it occurs far more at elite universities than the vast majority of other colleges, and that college student behavior in aggregate shows a lot more diversity than is claimed by media reports.  Ironically, during her lecture tour for "Sex and the Soul" Freitas admitted that in interviewing students on a larger campus she found them participating in more traditional relationships and believed that the size of campuses might make a difference, but unfortunately that observation doesn't make it into this book.2 stars; Freitas' heart is in the right place and she's done a lot of thinking, but this isn't an effective book.  For a more balanced and statistically robust look at this issue, try Regnerus and Uecker's Premarital Sex in America: How Young Americans Meet, Mate, and Think about Marrying instead.

The foam on the product is extremely low quality. Unless you are getting this for a kid that won't actually use it then don't even bother. The foam chips off with normal hits and dents with soft hits. This is nothing like Nerf's Strike swords which are even cheaper than this. It's quite amazing that Hasbro/Nerf actually mass produced this product and decided to sell it at such a steep price.
